GERMAN 1B03.name: Intermediate German I
GERMAN 1B03.description: A course designed to expand German linguistic skills through practice in reading, writing, listening and speaking, promoting intercultural learning and international awareness. Three hours; one term.

GERMAN 1BB3.name: Intermediate German II
GERMAN 1BB3.description: Through integrated and interactive practice in reading, writing, listening and speaking, this course is intended to serve as a foundation for the advanced study of German language and culture. The sequels to this course are GERMAN 3Z03 and 3ZZ3 . Three hours; one term.

GERMAN 2CC3.name: Germany Through the Ages: Culture and Society (Taught in English)
GERMAN 2CC3.description: An interdisciplinary look at the historical events, cultural phenomena, and personalities which have shaped German culture and society until World War II. Topics include: Medieval and Romantic Heritage, the Golden Twenties, Nationalism and National Socialism, the Holocaust. Three hours; one term.
GERMAN 2CC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

GERMAN 2FT3.name: The Fairy Tale (Taught in English)
GERMAN 2FT3.description: An examination of fairy tales from a variety of cultures and historical periods with particular emphasis on German tradition and the work of the Grimm Brothers. Students will also explore theories of the folktale and their implications for our understanding of other literary genres. Three hours; one term.
GERMAN 2FT3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

GERMAN 2G03.name: Berlin/Vienna: The Cultural Life of these Cities (Taught in English)
GERMAN 2G03.description: Through literature, film, and music we will trace the history and culture of Berlin and Vienna, from the end of the 19th century to the present. We will discuss Freud and psychoanalysis in Vienna, the Golden Twenties in Berlin, the Third Reich, the post War period, and contemporary multiculturalism. Three hours; one term.
GERMAN 2G03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program.

GERMAN 2KK3.name: Postmodern Alienation and Anxieties - Kafka for the Twenty-First Century (Taught in English)
GERMAN 2KK3.description: This course is forward-looking to disasters of the 20th and 21st centuries, to Kafkaesque, postmodern anxieties and alienation, links between terror and technology, arbitrary legal systems and abuses of power in literature, film, and popular culture. Three hours; one term.
GERMAN 2KK3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Offered on rotation.

GERMAN 2N03.name: The Holocaust in Film and Fiction (Taught in English)
GERMAN 2N03.description: Focusing on the moral, philosophical, and cultural legacy of the Holocaust through the artistic imagination, we will explore the roots of European antisemitism, the Final Solution, politicization, universalization, trivialization, aestheticization, commercialization, Holokitsch. Two hour lecture, two hour tutorial; one term.
GERMAN 2N03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Offered on rotation.

GERMAN 2P03.name: Modern Germany Through Film: Golden 20s - Avant Garde - Transnational Cinema (Taught in English)
GERMAN 2P03.description: This course explores German culture through films which reflect and shape different German national identities before, during, and after WWII, including the Cold War, East & West Germany, unification, racism, Islamophobia, and the recent refugee crisis. Two hour lecture, two hours for film screening; one term.

GERMAN 2Q03.name: Horror Film: Vampires, Monsters, and Mad Scientists (Taught in English)
GERMAN 2Q03.description: This course will explore the aesthetics of gore and violence in both classic gothic & expressionist film noir and contemporary horror films from around the world, using methods drawn from film theory and cultural studies. Four hours (Two hours for screening, two hours for lecture); one term.
GERMAN 2Q03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

GERMAN 2Z03.name: Intermediate German I
GERMAN 2Z03.description: The course is designed to further expand German linguistic skills through integrated and interactive practice in reading, writing, listening and speaking. The sequel to this course is GERMAN 2ZZ3 . Three hours; one term.

GERMAN 2ZZ3.name: Intermediate German II
GERMAN 2ZZ3.description: Through integrated and interactive practice in reading, writing, listening and speaking, this course is intended to serve as a foundation for the advanced study of German language, literature and culture. The course is enhanced by the use of WebCT and multimedia technology. The sequels to this course are GERMAN 3Z03 and GERMAN 3ZZ3 . Three hours; one term.
GERMAN 2ZZ3.antirequisites: GERMAN 1BB3 The Department reserves the right to place students in the course most appropriate to their abilities.

GERMAN 3H03.name: The New Europe: A New Germany (Taught in English)
GERMAN 3H03.description: In the heart of the ‘New Europe’ lies a ‘New Germany,’ united after almost a half-century of division. German literature and film provide an insight into this fascinating multicultural world. Three hours; one term.
GERMAN 3H03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

GERMAN 3Z03.name: Advanced German I
GERMAN 3Z03.description: The course is suitable for intermediate-advanced learners of German and helps develop receptive and productive skills. Students will acquire and use more complex vocabulary and grammatical structures, and will become more familiar with cultural, historical, and linguistic aspects of the German-speaking countries. The sequel to this course is GERMAN 3ZZ3 . Three hours; one term.
GERMAN 3Z03.antirequisites: GERMAN 3E03 The Department reserves the right to place students in the course most appropriate to their abilities.

GERMAN 3ZZ3.name: Advanced German II
GERMAN 3ZZ3.description: This course offers a communicative approach to language, culture and literature through integrated and interactive practice in reading, writing, listening and speaking. Three hours; one term.
GERMAN 3ZZ3.antirequisites: GERMAN 3G03 The Department reserves the right to place students in the course most appropriate to their abilities.

GERMAN 4CC3.name: Translation: Techniques and Practice
GERMAN 4CC3.description: This course offers practice in the translation of literary and non-literary texts. (English to German and German to English.) The practical component will be complemented by an overview of electronic and on-line translation aids, as well as different theories and techniques of translation in Western Culture. Three hours; one term.

HISTORY 1CC3.name: Ten Empires that Shaped our World, 500 BCE to Present
HISTORY 1CC3.description: A thematic survey of the interactions among peoples, cultures, and the environment as structured by evolving political and economic systems in the pre-modern era. Three hours (lectures and tutorials); one term Antirequisite(s): HISTORY 1B03.

HISTORY 1DD3.name: The Making of the Modern World, 1750-1945
HISTORY 1DD3.description: An introduction to themes of global oppression and resistance, trade and consumption, the movement of peoples and ideas, and environmental change across the 19th and 20th centuries. Three hours (lectures and tutorials); one term May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 1EE3.name: The Historical Roots of Contemporary Issues
HISTORY 1EE3.description: An investigation of the complex historical roots of contemporary social, political, and economic issues. Lectures and tutorials (three hours); one term.

HISTORY 1FF3.name: Exploring History in a Small Group Setting
HISTORY 1FF3.description: This small seminar is intended for Level I students with a strong interest in history. The discussion-based format will mirror the experience of studying history at a more senior level. Topics will vary, representative of the interests of the department’s teaching staff. Seminar (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 1FF3.prerequisites: Registration in Humanities 1 or Social Sciences 1; and Grade 12 History, 3 units of level I History, or permission of the department.

HISTORY 1M03.name: History of Greece and Rome
HISTORY 1M03.description: The history of Greece and Rome from the bronze age to the fall of Rome based on literary, documentary and archaeological evidence. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Cross-list(s): GKROMST 1M03 Antirequisite(s): CLASSICS 1M03 This course is administered by the Department of Greek and Roman Studies. May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 1P03.name: A History of Magic
HISTORY 1P03.description: This course probes the meaning and influence of magic in human societies from ancient societies through to the present. Topics include magic and religion, the social and political practices of astrology and charms, medicine and healing, the European Witchcraze and persecution, magic and political protest, and contemporary pop culture (i.e. Harry Potter). Two lectures, one tutorial; one term May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 1PP3.name: Pop Goes the Past!
HISTORY 1PP3.description: History has a valued place in pop culture that impacts the public understanding of the past. This course interrogates these representations, from films to fashion to video games, as cultural artifacts that shape understandings of the past. Three hours (lecture and tutorial); one term.

HISTORY 1Q03.name: History of Medicine
HISTORY 1Q03.description: This course explores developments in the history of health and medicine from a global perspective between 1500-present. Topics include religion and healing; global medical theories; medicine and colonialism; the impact of pandemics and epidemic diseases, the development of modern medicine. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 2A03.name: Modern Middle Eastern Societies
HISTORY 2A03.description: A survey of the political and cultural history of the Middle East from 1800 to the present, with emphasis on contemporary social problems emerging from post-WWI colonialism, nationalism, Islamism and Arab-Israeli relations. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
HISTORY 2A03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
HISTORY 2A03.antirequisites: PEACEST 2F03 May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 2CC3.name: The Medieval World 400-1050
HISTORY 2CC3.description: The Early Middle Ages: The barbarian kingdoms to the feudal monarchies. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2CC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2CH3.name: Introduction to Critical Heritage Studies
HISTORY 2CH3.description: What is “Heritage”? How does it differ from History? Using Canadian and international examples the course examines the multiple ways in which the concept of heritage is understood and used, in relation to preservation, to museums and material culture, and to collective and individual identity. Lectures (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2CH3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2CS3.name: The History of Slavery in the Americas
HISTORY 2CS3.description: This course explores the system of slavery in the Caribbean from the sixteenth to the nineteenth centuries within the context of the Atlantic World. It addresses such topics as slave resistance, the social, economic, and cultural consequences of slavery, and its abolition in the nineteenth century. Three hours (two lectures, one tutorial); one term.
HISTORY 2CS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 2DD3.name: The Medieval World 1050-1400
HISTORY 2DD3.description: The High and Late Middle Ages: Themes in European history, society and culture. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2DD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2DF3.name: Art and Revolutions in France, 1789-1914
HISTORY 2DF3.description: This course examines the intersections of visual culture and the political revolutions of 1789, 1830, 1848 and 1870, as well as stylistic innovations in art including Romanticism, Realism, Impressionism, Pointillism, Fauvism, and Cubism. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2DF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): ARTHIST 2DF3

HISTORY 2EN3.name: The Post-Slavery Caribbean
HISTORY 2EN3.description: This course considers the transition to freedom in the Caribbean from the late nineteenth century and the social, political, and cultural transformation of the region following the end of slavery. Three hours (two lectures, one tutorial); one term.
HISTORY 2EN3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2G03.name: Modern Latin America Since 1820
HISTORY 2G03.description: Liberalism, nationalism, militarism and the various revolutions will be covered, as well as the U.S. role in Latin America and the Caribbean. Three hours; one term.
HISTORY 2G03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2GR3.name: A History of Monsters
HISTORY 2GR3.description: From Beowulf to the day after tomorrow, this course examines the cultural evolution of monsters, from the unknown to the forsaken to the darker corners of the self. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2GR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2GW3.name: A History of Global War
HISTORY 2GW3.description: A survey of the course and development of the two global wars of the twentieth century covering the period from 1914 to 1945. The emphasis is on the military, economic, and political events that characterised the conflicts. Lectures (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2GW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2H03.name: Tudor and Stuart Britain, 1485-1714
HISTORY 2H03.description: This survey course examines a period of profound political, religious, economic and social change in Britain during the reigns of the Tudor and Stuart Dynasties. Three hours; lectures and tutorial.
HISTORY 2H03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2HH3.name: Pirates, Pilgrims and the Enslaved in the Mediterranean, 1450-1750
HISTORY 2HH3.description: This course examines the Mediterranean region as a zone of intense cultural interaction. Particular emphasis will be given to the interaction between Christian, Jewish and Islamic societies. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
HISTORY 2HH3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): SCAR 2FF3 Anti-requisite(s): RELIGST 2FF3

HISTORY 2II3.name: Modern Germany
HISTORY 2II3.description: This course examines the complexities of German social and political history since 1890, including World War One, Third Reich, cold war division, questions of national identity and the peaceful revolution of 1989. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2II3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2IS3.name: Historical Roots of Current Social and Political Crises in the United States
HISTORY 2IS3.description: This course explores the historical roots of current social and political challenges in the United States with emphasis on histories of race, gender, class, citizenship status, and other hierarchies. Sample topics include movements for racial justice, voting and voting rights misinformation and conspiracy theories, pandemics, and health care. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2IS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2J03.name: Africa up to 1800
HISTORY 2J03.description: Survey of the political, social and economic history of Africa including the evolution of early human cultures, the rise and fall of civilizations and the contact between Africans and Europeans. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2J03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2JJ3.name: Africa since 1800
HISTORY 2JJ3.description: Survey of the political, social and economic history of Africa including the partitioning of the continent, the practices of European imperialism, independence and the process of national building. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2JJ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2KK3.name: History of Capitalism
HISTORY 2KK3.description: A History of Capitalism from 1500 to the present. This team-taught course introduces students to characteristics of capitalism, core institutions, and explanations for periodic crises. There are opportunities to read selections from leading proponents, agents, critics, and reformers. Essay topics will be negotiated with students, so that there will be an alignment with their programme/faculty. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
HISTORY 2KK3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II and above Cross-list(s): IBH 2BF3

HISTORY 2MC3.name: Modern China
HISTORY 2MC3.description: A survey of China from 1840 to the present, with emphasis on political developments, revolutionary movements, social change, and China’s relations with East Asia and the West. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2MC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2PP3.name: Making History
HISTORY 2PP3.description: This course provides students with field experience working in the archives under the direction of a trained archivist. Students will think critically about knowledge production and public history through hands-on work with archival materials. Seminar (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2PP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2PQ3.name: Histories of the Written Word
HISTORY 2PQ3.description: How do we know what we know about the past? Working with rare books and maps from McMaster’s collections, students will explore the history of writing & recording information around the world. This course is taught by McMaster’s rare books librarian. Three hours; one term.
HISTORY 2PQ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2Q03.name: Imperial Russia
HISTORY 2Q03.description: A survey of Russian history from Peter the Great to the Revolutions of 1917. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term Prerequisite(s) : Registration in Level II or above.

HISTORY 2QQ3.name: The Soviet Union
HISTORY 2QQ3.description: A history of the Soviet Union from 1917 to the present with an emphasis on social history, culture and identity. Lectures and discussion (Three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2QQ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2R03.name: U.S. History to the Civil War
HISTORY 2R03.description: A survey of the political, cultural, social and economic development of the United States to 1877, from the colonial and revolutionary eras to the Civil War and Reconstruction. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2R03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2RR3.name: U.S. History Since the Civil War
HISTORY 2RR3.description: A survey of the political, cultural, social and economic development of the United States from Reconstruction to the present. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2RR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2SH3.name: Canadian Sport History
HISTORY 2SH3.description: An exploration of selected topics and themes in the history of sport in Canada. Three hours (two lectures, one tutorial); one term.
HISTORY 2SH3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 2SS3.name: Liberty, Empire and Industry: Britain, 1688-1867
HISTORY 2SS3.description: A wide-ranging survey of the British experience from the Glorious Revolution of 1688 to the widening of the Parliamentary franchise that included working-class men for the first time in 1867. Three hours (two lectures, one tutorial); one term.
HISTORY 2SS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2ST3.name: Empire, War, Welfare State: Britain, 1867-2020
HISTORY 2ST3.description: This course covers: the height of British global power, imperial and anti-colonial politics; the two world wars; the establishment and meaning of the welfare state; and the fraught relationship between Britain and the rest of Europe between 1945 and 2020. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2ST3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
HISTORY 2ST3.antirequisites: HISTORY 2MM3 May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 2T03.name: Survey of Canadian History, Beginnings to 1885
HISTORY 2T03.description: A survey of the political, cultural, social and economic development of Canada to 1885, from first nations and colonial origins to Confederation and the North West Rebellion. Two lectures, one tutorial (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2T03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2TT3.name: Survey of Canadian History, 1885 to the Present
HISTORY 2TT3.description: A survey of the political, cultural, social and economic development of modern Canada, from the North West Rebellion and nation-building era to the present. Two lectures, one tutorial (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2TT3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2UV3.name: American Foreign Relations since 1898
HISTORY 2UV3.description: Survey of major events and turning points of U.S. diplomatic history since the late 19th century. Emphasis on cultural dimensions of the American empire and selected historiographical controversies. Two lectures, one tutorial (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2UV3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2V03.name: Re-Making History
HISTORY 2V03.description: This course invites students to participate in the remaking of a moment in history-in the emotions, debates and conflicts that made that event important for our twenty-first-century world. See the department website for this year’s topic. The course will consist of lectures and experiential learning, individual and group assignments, and a weekend conference.
HISTORY 2V03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 2XX3.name: Age of Terror: History of Terrorism in the Modern World
HISTORY 2XX3.description: From the French Revolution to the day after tomorrow, examining lone wolves and dictators, secret societies and secret police, and zealots, mercenaries, and militias, this global survey interrogates violence as a critically important characteristic of the modern condition. Two lectures, one tutorial (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 2XX3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 3AR3.name: Atlantic Revolutions, 1750-1804
HISTORY 3AR3.description: An intensive exploration of the great eighteenth-century Atlantic Revolutions in comparative perspective. The course will examine the differing cultural and social rationales for revolution, the nature of the new revolutionary regimes in America, France, and Haiti, and an exploration of the phenomenon of counter-revolution in all three societies. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3AR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3CG3.name: Canadians in a Global Age, 1914 to the Present
HISTORY 3CG3.description: This course considers ways in which global developments influenced and were influenced by Canadian peoples, with a thematic emphasis on selected developments such as wars and revolutions, the development of international alliances and organizations, and the spread of mass communication and consumer culture. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3CG3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3CH3.name: Catastrophic History: Natural & Technological Disasters
HISTORY 3CH3.description: An examination of how natural and technological disasters have shaped past societies and how catastrophe features as an important method of understanding the human condition. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3CH3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3DD3.name: Jews and Jesus
HISTORY 3DD3.description: A study of Judaism in the Greco-Roman World. The course will explore selected questions in political history, the development of sects and parties, the role of the temple, apocalypticism and the Dead Sea Scrolls. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
HISTORY 3DD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): SCAR 3DD3
HISTORY 3DD3.antirequisites: RELIGST 3DD3 This course is administered by the Department of Religious Studies.

HISTORY 3DF3.name: Art and Politics in Second Empire France
HISTORY 3DF3.description: This course examines the intersections of politics and visual culture in France 1852-1870 and critical issues related to photography, painting, sculpture, printmaking, architecture and the Universal Expositions of 1855 and 1867. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3DF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3DS3.name: Diasporas, Trade and Conflict: The Sea in History, 1000 BCE to Present
HISTORY 3DS3.description: A study of the global socio-economic, cultural and political impact of maritime communities, from the Polynesians and Chinese to the Ottomans and Europeans. Topics: ships and technology, navigation history, trade and plunder, enclaves/colonies, Atlantic slave trade, and naval warfare. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3DS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

HISTORY 3EC3.name: Chinese Intellectual Traditions
HISTORY 3EC3.description: A survey of philosophical traditions and political thought in pre-modern Chinese history. Three lectures; one term.
HISTORY 3EC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3FF3.name: Nazi Germany
HISTORY 3FF3.description: This course examines the origins and growth of National Socialism, its twelve years in power and the war that led to its demise. Themes under consideration will also include daily life in Germany in the 1930s and the Holocaust. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3FF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3GN3.name: Moments in Twentieth Century History Through the Graphic Novel
HISTORY 3GN3.description: This course will consider the graphic novel as an historical source. It will pair, in chronological order, graphic novels, which address a moment in twentieth-century history, with related scholarly studies of the same moment. Three lectures; one term.
HISTORY 3GN3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3H03.name: Italian Renaissance, 1300-1600
HISTORY 3H03.description: An examination of the nature and influence of one of the most important cultural episodes in European history. Topics will include the Italian merchant and urban life, political culture, humanism, art and architecture. Three lectures; one term.
HISTORY 3H03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 3HI3.name: Advanced Historical Inquiry
HISTORY 3HI3.description: In-depth investigation of historical issues and problems in a small class setting. Topics will vary, representative of the interests of the department’s teaching staff. Seminar (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3HI3.prerequisites: One of HISTORY 1FF3 , 2HI3; and registration in Level III of an Honours program in History; or permission of the department

HISTORY 3HQ3.name: History of Quebec
HISTORY 3HQ3.description: This course is a lecture-seminar survey of Quebec history from the British Conquest of 1760 to the present. Topics to be covered include Quebec’s place in a new empire, colonial society and economy, the rise of political protest, rebellion, and nationalism, the role of key institutions such as the Catholic Church, the industrialization of Quebec, and the postwar modernization of state and society. Students will engage in seminar discussions and be expected to complete a number of written assignments stressing critical and analytical skills. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
HISTORY 3HQ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 3I03.name: The International Relations of the European Powers, 1870-1945
HISTORY 3I03.description: An examination of the origins and course of the First World War; the failure of post-war stabilization; and the origins and course of the Second World War. Three lectures; one term.
HISTORY 3I03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3J03.name: The United States in the 1960s
HISTORY 3J03.description: An examination of the political, social and cultural changes that occurred in the United States during the 1960s. Topics include the civil rights struggle, Black Power movement, New Left, opposition to the Vietnam War, counterculture, feminism and the conservative backlash. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3J03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3JJ3.name: Crime, Constables, and Courts: Modern Criminal Justice, 1700 to Present
HISTORY 3JJ3.description: A study of the changing face of the institutions of criminal justice and of criminal behaviour, as revealed in statistical and conventional historical works. The focus will be on North America, Great Britain and France. Three lectures; one term.
HISTORY 3JJ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above, with a minimum of six units of History

HISTORY 3JR3.name: Justice and Reparations in the Post-slavery World
HISTORY 3JR3.description: This comparative course examines struggles for justice and freedom in post-slavery societies in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Focusing on the post-slavery Americas, the course will explore social, legal and political struggles to create free societies and reparations for slavery. Lecture and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3JR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3KK3.name: The Vietnam War
HISTORY 3KK3.description: The history of the First and Second Indochina Wars (1945-1973) is examined from multiple perspectives. Explores how and why the war was fought, as well as its global legacy.
HISTORY 3KK3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3N03.name: Poverty, Privilege and Protest in Canadian History
HISTORY 3N03.description: An examination of the political, economic, and social factors shaping the persistence of poverty in Canada in the 1800s and 1900s, together with an analysis of reactions to such inequality. This includes investigation of ideological divisions, ethnic relations, and gender dynamics within the working class and within the labour movement. Three lectures; one term.
HISTORY 3N03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): IBH 3BC3

HISTORY 3RU3.name: Early Modern Russia
HISTORY 3RU3.description: This course explores the changing character of Russia in the pre-modern period. It provides an important foundation for later courses on Imperial and Soviet history. Lecture and discussion (three hours).
HISTORY 3RU3.prerequisites: Registration at Level II or above

HISTORY 3ST3.name: Street Life in Canada
HISTORY 3ST3.description: This course explores the role the street has played in Canada since the mid-19th century in shaping lives and identities. We will examine the different users of the street, and the changing representation of the street as urban spaces developed. Lecture and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3ST3.prerequisites: Registration at Level II or above

HISTORY 3TC3.name: Science, Technology in World History
HISTORY 3TC3.description: An introduction to the manner in which science and technology influence society and how society influences science and technology, paying particular attention to the transfer of knowledge and machines over time and between cultures. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
HISTORY 3TC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
HISTORY 3TC3.antirequisites: HISTORY 2EE3 May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 3TR3.name: Trees and their Histories
HISTORY 3TR3.description: Inspired by the trees on McMaster’s campus, this course examines trees and their significance in history and the present through multiple lenses including: biology; colonial and economic histories; visual, material and performing arts practices; indigenous and environmental studies; poetry, prose and psychology. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term Cross-list(s): ARTSSCI 3TR3 Prerequisite (s): Registration in Level II and above.

HISTORY 3UA3.name: The History of the Future
HISTORY 3UA3.description: This course examines how technology has historically shaped social ideas about the future and how these social ideas about the future shaped subsequent technology. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3UA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3W03.name: Women in Canada and the U.S. to 1920
HISTORY 3W03.description: This course examines key areas of women’s history, such as indigenous cultures, slavery, immigration, religion, witchcraft, the family, sexuality, paid and unpaid labour and the first wave of the women’s movement. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3W03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3WW3.name: Women in Canada and the U.S. from 1920
HISTORY 3WW3.description: This course examines key areas of women’s history, such as the impact of the Great Depression and the Second World War, the civil rights movement, the sexual revolution and the second wave of the women’s movement. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
HISTORY 3WW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
HISTORY 3WW3.antirequisites: WOMENST 3GG3 May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 3XX3.name: Human Rights in History
HISTORY 3XX3.description: A thematic examination of the global historical evolution of the notion of human rights from antiquity up to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in the 20th century. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
HISTORY 3XX3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
HISTORY 3XX3.antirequisites: PEACEST 3XX3 Cross-list(s): PEACJUST 3XX3 May be offered in person or online.

HISTORY 3YB3.name: Youth Subcultures in Britain: From the Teds to the Acid Ravers
HISTORY 3YB3.description: Post-World War II youth formed distinctive sub-cultures based on music, fashion and visual culture. This course explores the transnational origins and legacy of (among others) the Teddy Boys, Mods and Rockers, Skinheads, Hippies, Punks, Glam and Goths, 2-Tone, Hip-Hop and Acid Rave cultures. Lectures(three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3YB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3YY3.name: Britain and the First World War
HISTORY 3YY3.description: This course is designed to be an in-depth thematic exploration of the British experience of the First World War. Military, political, social, economic, technological and cultural issues and concerns will be considered. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 3YY3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HISTORY 3ZZ3.name: Judaism in the Modern World
HISTORY 3ZZ3.description: Jews and Judaism in a century of catastrophe and renewal. The progress of Emancipation; Jews in Canada and the U.S.; the Jewish catastrophe in Europe; the Jewish identities in literature and the arts. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
HISTORY 3ZZ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
HISTORY 3ZZ3.antirequisites: RELIGST 2XX3, 3ZZ3 Cross-list(s): SCAR 3ZZ3 This course is administered by the Department of Religious Studies.

HISTORY 4AW3.name: North Atlantic Crossings, 1750-1940
HISTORY 4AW3.description: This course focuses on the cultural and intellectual interplay between Britain, Canada, and the United States, focusing on the contexts of Enlightenment; the effect of transatlantic revolution; the rise of evangelicalism; the Darwinian revolution; and the differing origins and outcomes of the ‘progressive’ impulse. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4AW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4CE3.name: Early Canadian History
HISTORY 4CE3.description: Selected them in early Canadian history. Information on the precise focus of the seminar may be obtained in the Department each February. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4CE3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4CM3.name: Modern Canadian History
HISTORY 4CM3.description: A selected theme in the history of modern Canada. Information on the precise focus of the seminar may be obtained in the Department each February. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4CM3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4DW3.name: Indigenous History in a Decolonizing World
HISTORY 4DW3.description: This course is designed to be an in-depth seminar examining Indigenous history centered around the theories and methodologies of ‘decolonization’. Informed by a selection of readings from Indigenous authors, primary sources, and oral histories, topics include Indigenous/non-Indigenous relations, decolonization, resurgence and traditionalism, Indigenous feminism, land-based knowledge, and Indigenous nationhood. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4DW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4E03.name: Medieval People
HISTORY 4E03.description: An examination of some representative medieval lives. Figures discussed may include the abbess Hildegard of Bingen, the scholars and lovers Heloise and Abelard, the knight William Marshall, and the ‘Good Wife’ of the Magier de Paris. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4E03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4FF3.name: History of Health and Medicine in the Colonial World
HISTORY 4FF3.description: Themes will vary, and may include health and medicine from a comparative perspective, the relationship between imperialism and medicine, public health and urban environment, exercise and health. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4FF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4G03.name: Nation and Genocide in the Modern World
HISTORY 4G03.description: A thematic study of genocide and mass murder in the twentieth century from a human rights and humanitarian law perspective. The first part of the course covers the theoretical and legal aspects of genocide studies. The second part explores specific case studies of colonial massacres, the Holocaust, and the Cambodian and Rwanda genocides. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4G03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History, Global Peace and Social Justice, or Peace Studies
HISTORY 4G03.antirequisites: PEACEST 4GG3 Cross-list(s): PEACJUST 4GG3 Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4HH3.name: China’s Great Cultural Revolution
HISTORY 4HH3.description: A critical assessment of the origins, development, and consequences of the darkest political campaign in 1960s-70s China. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4HH3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4HP3.name: The History Practicum
HISTORY 4HP3.description: The history practicum offers a capstone experience for upper-level students. It is an opportunity for experiential learning in the field of history. Selected students will work closely with a supervisor on an ongoing historical project at one of Hamilton’s many heritage sites. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4HP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV or above of any Honours program in History

HISTORY 4I03.name: Women and Social Movements in the 19th- and 20th- Century United States
HISTORY 4I03.description: Women’s involvement in social movements such as anti-lynching, unionization, feminism and civil rights is used to discuss power, social change, race, femininity, masculinity and class in U.S. history. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4I03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4JJ3.name: U.S. Foreign Relations
HISTORY 4JJ3.description: Topics in the history of the United States Foreign relations in the modern era. Seminar (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 4JJ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4K03.name: Environment and Environmentalism in Modern North America
HISTORY 4K03.description: Explores how different social groups in the United States and Canada confronted the sometimes adverse impact of urban and industrial growth on the physical environment of their communities. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4K03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4KK3.name: Research on the British Atlantic, 1750-1850
HISTORY 4KK3.description: This seminar course will generate research projects on topics ranging from the political, cultural, and social impacts of the American Revolution on Atlantic societies, the nature of Atlantic slavery in an age of emancipation, the nature of counter-revolutionary impulses, and the creation of new settler societies after the American Revolution. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4KK3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4LP3.name: The Cultural History of Paris, 1789-1914
HISTORY 4LP3.description: Topics to be examined include: developments in architecture and city planning; the conservation of historic buildings and monuments; cultural institutions such as museums and art exhibitions; and the impact of gender, race and economics on experiences and concepts of identity in France’s capital. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4LP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Cross-list(s): ARTHIST 4LP3 Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4MM3.name: White Supremacists and Human Rights Activists in Modern Canadian History
HISTORY 4MM3.description: This course examines the prejudice and discrimination targeting racialized groups such as Indigenous Peoples, African Canadians, Asian immigrants, Jews, and immigrants from Southern and Eastern Europe. The course also examines human rights activism. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4MM3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History

HISTORY 4P03.name: Contemporary Europe
HISTORY 4P03.description: Topics in the history of Europe during the 20th Century. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4P03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4PP3.name: Divided Germany
HISTORY 4PP3.description: This seminar will examine the social, political, and cultural development of East and West Germany from Allied occupation to the fall of the Berlin Wall. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4PP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4QQ3.name: The Soviet Experience
HISTORY 4QQ3.description: Focuses on themes and issues of historical and historiographical importance in Russia from 1917. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4QQ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4QR3.name: Quantitative Research on Major Topics in History
HISTORY 4QR3.description: A study of selected major topics where statistics have been prominent (for example, the emergence of modern economies, the slave trade, class and wealth, local and regional studies, crime); assessment of statistical evidence; collecting and analyzing data for a research paper. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4QR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History. Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4RP3.name: Independent Research Project
HISTORY 4RP3.description: A reading and/or research program under the supervision of one member of the Department. A major paper is required, as well as a formal oral examination. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4RP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History with a Grade Point Average of at least 9.0

HISTORY 4RR3.name: Truth and Reconciliation After Atrocity
HISTORY 4RR3.description: This course explores truth commissions and other truth-seeking mechanisms established globally to address historical atrocities and contemporary human rights abuses. Seminar (two hours): one term.
HISTORY 4RR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History, Global Peace and Social Justice, or Peace Studies
HISTORY 4RR3.antirequisites: PEACEST 4RR3 Cross-list(s): PEACJUST 4RR3 Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4S03.name: The German Reformation
HISTORY 4S03.description: This course examines the Reformation as a critical religious, political and cultural event. Topics include Lutheran and Calvinist theology, gender, confessionalization and the role of printing. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4S03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4SS3.name: Early Modern France, 1450-1789
HISTORY 4SS3.description: France was without question one of the most powerful polities in early modern Europe and serves as a useful focal point for understanding the emergence of absolutism, colonization, imperialism, urbanization and changing gender and social roles. Seminar (two hours); one term.
HISTORY 4SS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

HISTORY 4TT3.name: Interwar Europe, 1918-1939
HISTORY 4TT3.description: A seminar devoted to the examination of selected themes - cultural, diplomatic, economic, military, political, and social - in the history of interwar Europe. Seminar (three hours); one term.
HISTORY 4TT3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History Departmental permission required.

MUSIC 1A03.name: Introduction to the History of Western Music I
MUSIC 1A03.description: An introductory survey of Western music, from Gregorian chant to the time of Bach and Handel. Emphasis is on important composers and their works in relation to their society and culture. Previous knowledge of music is helpful but not required. Three lectures; one term Antirequisite(s): MUSIC 1MH3, 2B03.

MUSIC 1AA3.name: Introduction to the History of Western Music II
MUSIC 1AA3.description: An introductory survey of Western music, from the time of Mozart to the present. Composers studied include Beethoven, Schubert, Chopin, Verdi, Wagner, Debussy, and Stravinsky. Previous knowledge of music is helpful but not required. Three lectures; one term Antirequisite(s): MUSIC 2MH3.

MUSIC 1CB3.name: Theory and Analysis I
MUSIC 1CB3.description: The analysis and writing of functional harmony. Includes study of music by J.S. Bach and others. This course is intended for students with significant music theory background, such as Level 8 RCM Theory, or equivalent. Three lectures; one term.
MUSIC 1CB3.prerequisites: Music 1CA3 or MUSIC 1CR3 , or permission of the program

MUSIC 1CR3.name: Rudiments of Music
MUSIC 1CR3.description: Introduction to rudiments of music through to study of functional harmony. This course is not intended for students with significant theory background. Three lectures; one term Antirequisite(s): MUSIC 1CA3.

MUSIC 1DA3.name: Practical Musicianship I
MUSIC 1DA3.description: Sight-singing, dictation, and keyboard harmony. Students taking this course should be able to read music and will be required to sing and play keyboard exercises for the instructor. Two lectures, one lab; one term Antirequisite(s): MUSIC 1D03 A/B.

MUSIC 1DB3.name: Practical Musicianship II
MUSIC 1DB3.description: Continuation of MUSIC 1DA3. Sight-singing, dictation, and keyboard harmony. Two lectures, one lab; one term.
MUSIC 1DB3.prerequisites: MUSIC 1D03 or 1DA3; or permission of the instructor if space permits

MUSIC 2A03.name: Music of the World’s Cultures
MUSIC 2A03.description: A survey of music traditions of non-European cultures, e.g., far Eastern, Indian, African. Three lectures; one term.
MUSIC 2A03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

MUSIC 2CA3.name: Theory and Analysis II
MUSIC 2CA3.description: Continuation of Music 1CB3. Chromatic Harmony and the completed major minor system. Three lectures; one term.
MUSIC 2CA3.prerequisites: Music 1CC3 or 1CB3 or permission of the instructor if space permits.

MUSIC 2CB3.name: Theory and Analysis III
MUSIC 2CB3.description: Continuation of Music 2CA3. Chromatic Harmony and the completed major minor system. Three lectures; one term.
MUSIC 2CB3.prerequisites: Music 2CA3 or permission of the instructor if space permits.

MUSIC 2CU3.name: Music and Culture
MUSIC 2CU3.description: An introduction to thinking, researching and writing about music as a product of the culture in which it is practiced. Both Western and non-Western examples will be considered. Three lectures; one term.
MUSIC 2CU3.prerequisites: 6 units of Music courses; or permission of the program

MUSIC 2DA3.name: Practical Musicianship III
MUSIC 2DA3.description: Continuation of MUSIC 1DB3. Sight-singing, dictation, and keyboard harmony. Two lectures, one lab; one term.
MUSIC 2DA3.prerequisites: MUSIC 1DB3 or permission of the instructor if space permits.

MUSIC 2F03.name: Music for Film and Television
MUSIC 2F03.description: An examination of how music functions to help create meanings in film and television programs. Examples will be drawn from throughout the history of film and television. Three lectures; one term.
MUSIC 2F03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

MUSIC 2II3.name: Popular Music in North America and the United Kingdom: Post-World War II
MUSIC 2II3.description: Popular music, its social meanings, and media and technology interactions, from rock-and-roll to now. Topics include rhythm and blues (Chuck Berry), pop (Madonna), metal (Led Zeppelin.) Three lectures; one term.
MUSIC 2II3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

MUSIC 2MC3.name: Psychology of Music
MUSIC 2MC3.description: Overview of the psychological roots of the musical experience. Sample topics to include the perception of pitch, timbre, meter, and tonality as well as the communication of emotion. There will be a particular emphasis on the practical implications of basic principles of perception and cognition, with a focus on improving the quality and efficiency of music performance, learning, and education. Three lectures, one term.
MUSIC 2MC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of a Music program; or MUSIC 1CR3 or 1CB3
MUSIC 2MC3.antirequisites: MUSICCOG 2MA3, 2MP3 , PSYCH 2MA3, 2MP3 A thorough knowledge of music theory is advised.

MUSIC 2MT3.name: Introduction to the Practice of Music Therapy
MUSIC 2MT3.description: An introduction to the practice of music therapy, with an emphasis on the diversity of music therapy applications such as: bio-medical, psychoanalytical, behavioural and rehabilitation. Three hours (lecture, web module); one term.
MUSIC 2MT3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

MUSIC 2MU3.name: Introduction to Music Therapy Research
MUSIC 2MU3.description: Current research papers will be explored in the fields of education, rehabilitation, neurology and mental health. Three hours (lecture, web module); one term.
MUSIC 2MU3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above. Completion of MUSIC 2MT3 is strongly recommended, but not required.

MUSIC 2SI3.name: Singing
MUSIC 2SI3.description: Introduction to singing; not intended for those with prior vocal training. This course meets concurrently with MUSIC 3SI3. Three hours; one term.
MUSIC 2SI3.prerequisites: Registration in level II or above of any program and one of MUSIC 1E06 A/B , 1EE6 A/B , 1GB3 A/B , 1GF3 A/B , 1GJ3 A/B , 1GP3 A/B , 1GR3 A/B ; or permission of the program

MUSIC 2TT3.name: Broadway and the Popular Song
MUSIC 2TT3.description: An historical examination of the development of English-language musical theatre in the twentieth century. Attention will be paid to the history of American popular song and its impact on the genre. Three lectures; one term.
MUSIC 2TT3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

MUSIC 2U03.name: Jazz
MUSIC 2U03.description: An historical survey of jazz, focusing on selected performers and arrangers. Three hours; one term.
MUSIC 2U03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

MUSIC 2WW3.name: Woodwinds
MUSIC 2WW3.description: Introduction to the playing of woodwind instruments; not intended for woodwind specialists. This course meets concurrently with MUSIC 3WW3. Three hours; one term.
MUSIC 2WW3.prerequisites: Registration in level II or above of any program and one of MUSIC 1E06 A/B , 1EE6 A/B , 1GB3 A/B , 1GC3 A/B , 1GF3 A/B , 1GJ3 A/B , 1GP3 A/B , 1GR3 A/B , 1GW3 A/B ; or permission of the program.

MUSIC 3CP3.name: Constructing Counterpoint
MUSIC 3CP3.description: Topics in Counterpoint. Possible topics include species counterpoint, inventions, fugue. Seminar (two hours); one term.
MUSIC 3CP3.prerequisites: MUSIC 2CB3 or permission of the program

MUSIC 3E03.name: Solo Performance
MUSIC 3E03.description: The technique and repertoire of any orchestral instrument, piano, organ, harpsichord, voice, recorder, saxophone or guitar. 12 one-hour meetings; one term.
MUSIC 3E03.prerequisites: MUSIC 2E06 A/B on the same instrument and registration in a program in Music

MUSIC 3EE3.name: Solo Performance
MUSIC 3EE3.description: The technique and repertoire of any orchestral instrument, piano, organ, harpsichord, voice, recorder, saxophone or guitar. 12 one-hour meetings; one term.
MUSIC 3EE3.antirequisites: MUSIC 3E03 , 3EE6 A/B Lesson fees are charged to students taking MUSIC 3EE3. Lesson fees must be paid by September 1 for Term 1 and by January 1 for Term 2.

MUSIC 3J03.name: Orchestration and Arranging
MUSIC 3J03.description: A study of the orchestral/band instruments; scoring of music for various ensembles. Three lectures; one term.
MUSIC 3J03.prerequisites: MUSIC 2CB3 or permission of the program Offered in alternate years.

MUSIC 3JJ3.name: Topics in Music History: Music Before c. 1750
MUSIC 3JJ3.description: Advanced study of selected music prior to c. 1750 in its historical, socio-political and artistic contexts. Possible topics include: medieval music, Renaissance music, the music of J.S. Bach etc. Three hours; one term.
MUSIC 3JJ3.prerequisites: MUSIC 1CB3 ; and one of MUSIC 1MH3 or MUSIC 2CU3 ; and 6 additional units of Music; or permission of the program.
MUSIC 3JJ3.antirequisites: MUSIC 3Y03 Music 3JJ3 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units. Alternates with MUSIC 3KK3 .

MUSIC 3K03.name: Brass Methods
MUSIC 3K03.description: Basic techniques of playing brass instruments. Brass literature for various educational levels. The instruments studied differ from those studied in MUSIC 4K03. Two lectures, one lab; one term.
MUSIC 3K03.prerequisites: Registration in level II or above of any program. Students will be expected to read music. Non-music students will be required to bring their own instruments. Offered on rotational basis.

MUSIC 3KK3.name: Topics in Music History: Music from c. 1750-c. 1900
MUSIC 3KK3.description: Advanced study of selected music in its historical, socio-political and artistic contexts. Possible topics include: Mozart’s operas, nineteenth-century piano music, Viennese Classicism, Lieder, etc. Three hours; one term.
MUSIC 3KK3.prerequisites: MUSIC 1CB3 ; and one of MUSIC 1MH3 or MUSIC 2CU3 ; and 6 additional units of Music; or permission of the program.
MUSIC 3KK3.antirequisites: MUSIC 3YY3 Music 3KK3 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units. Alternates with MUSIC 3JJ3 .

MUSIC 3O03.name: Conducting
MUSIC 3O03.description: Fundamental conducting techniques applied to works selected from the standard repertoire. Three lectures; one term.
MUSIC 3O03.prerequisites: Music 2CB3 and one of Music 1E06 A/B, 1EE6 A/B, 1GC3 A/B, 1GB3 A/B, 1GF3 A/B, 1GJ3 A/B, 1GP3 A/B, 1GR3 A/B, 1GW3 A/B; or permission of the program.

MUSIC 3P03.name: Percussion Methods
MUSIC 3P03.description: Basic techniques of playing percussion instruments. Percussion literature for various educational levels. Two lectures, one lab; one term.
MUSIC 3P03.prerequisites: Registration in level II or above of any program and one of MUSIC 1E06 A/B, 1EE6 A/B, 1GB3 A/B, 1GC3 A/B, 1GF3 A/B, 1GJ3 A/B, 1GP3 A/B, 1GR3 A/B, 1GW3 A/B; or permission of the program. Offered on rotational basis.

MUSIC 3SI3.name: Vocal Pedagogy
MUSIC 3SI3.description: Introductory study of vocal methods for teaching, intended for vocal specialists. This course meets concurrently with MUSIC 2SI3. Three hours; one term.
MUSIC 3SI3.prerequisites: Registration in level II or above and permission of the program

MUSIC 3SS3.name: Special Studies in Chamber Music or Accompanying I
MUSIC 3SS3.description: Advanced supervised studies in chamber music performance or vocal or instrumental accompanying. Times to be arranged between the students and instructor; one term.
MUSIC 3SS3.prerequisites: A grade of at least A- in MUSIC 2E06 A/B or MUSIC 2EE6 A/B ; and registration in Level III or IV of a Music program; and permission of the School of the Arts. Students requesting this course must submit a written proposal to the School of the Arts by April 15. This course is primarily for students pursuing the Diploma in Music Performance.
MUSIC 3SS3.antirequisites: MUSIC 3S03 This course cannot be repeated. Students taking MUSIC 3SS3 must pay additional lesson fees to the School of the Arts by September 1 for Term 1 and by January 1 for Term 2.

MUSIC 3V03.name: Foundations of Music Education
MUSIC 3V03.description: A study of the philosophical, psychological and sociological foundations of music education, leading to the formation of a personal philosophy of music education. Seminar (two hours); one term.
MUSIC 3V03.prerequisites: MUSIC 1CB3 and 9 additional units of Music; or permission of the program. Offered in alternate years.

MUSIC 3WW3.name: Woodwind Pedagogy
MUSIC 3WW3.description: Review of woodwind technique and woodwind pedagogy; intended for woodwind specialists. This course meets concurrently with MUSIC 2WW3. Three hours; one term.
MUSIC 3WW3.prerequisites: Registration in level II or above and permission of the program

MUSIC 3X03.name: Independent Study
MUSIC 3X03.description: Supervised study in any area offered and approved by the School of the Arts . Times to be arranged between the student and instructor; one term.
MUSIC 3X03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of an Honours Music program and permission of the School of the Arts . Students requesting this course must submit a written proposal to the School of the Arts by April 15th.

MUSIC 4C03.name: Advanced Studies in Harmony and Counterpoint
MUSIC 4C03.description: Advanced harmonic and/or contrapuntal study focusing on a post-Baroque style or genre selected by the instructor. Possible topics include: sonatas, songs, jazz arranging and scoring. Seminar (two hours); one term.
MUSIC 4C03.prerequisites: MUSIC 2CB3 and registration in level III or above; or permission of the program Offered in alternate years.

MUSIC 4E03.name: Solo Performance
MUSIC 4E03.description: A continuation of MUSIC 3E03 or MUSIC 3E06 A/B on the same instrument. 12 one-hour meetings; one term.
MUSIC 4E03.prerequisites: MUSIC 3E03 or 3E06 A/B ; and registration in a program in Music

MUSIC 4EE3.name: Solo Performance
MUSIC 4EE3.description: A continuation of MUSIC 3EE3 or 3EE6 A/B . 12 one-hour meetings; one term.
MUSIC 4EE3.antirequisites: MUSIC 4E03 , 4E09 A/B , 4EE6 A/B Lesson fees are charged to students taking MUSIC 4EE3. Lesson fees must be paid by September 1 for Term 1 and by January 1 for Term 2.

MUSIC 4H03.name: Investigating Music
MUSIC 4H03.description: Advanced studies in analysis. Topics include: Schenkerian analysis, scales and modes, rhythm and metre, and serialism. Seminar (two hours); one term.
MUSIC 4H03.prerequisites: MUSIC 2CB3 and registration in level III or above; or permission of the program Offered in alternate years.

MUSIC 4K03.name: Brass Methods
MUSIC 4K03.description: A study of the basic techniques of playing brass instruments. Brass literature for various educational levels. The instruments studied differ from those studied in MUSIC 3K03. Two lectures, one lab; one term.
MUSIC 4K03.prerequisites: Registration in level III or above of any program. Students are expected to be able to read music. Non-music students will be required to bring their own instruments. Offered on rotational basis.

MUSIC 4N03.name: Choral Methods
MUSIC 4N03.description: Choral rehearsal techniques and choral literature for K-12 and community choirs. Two lectures, one lab; one term.
MUSIC 4N03.prerequisites: Registration in level III or above of any program. Students are expected to be able to read music. Offered on rotational basis.

MUSIC 4OC3.name: Advanced Conducting: Choral
MUSIC 4OC3.description: Rehearsal and conducting techniques, including warm-up exercises, tone, intonation, balance, attack, sustain, cueing, repertoire, score reading, and score preparation. Three lectures; one term.
MUSIC 4OC3.prerequisites: MUSIC 3O03 and registration in Honours Music; or permission of the program Alternates with MUSIC 4OI3 .

MUSIC 4OI3.name: Advanced Conducting: Instrumental
MUSIC 4OI3.description: A continuation of MUSIC 3O03 . Refinement and development of conducting techniques. Exploration of in-depth score preparation, rehearsal techniques, odd and shifting meters, subdivision. Three lectures; one term.
MUSIC 4OI3.prerequisites: MUSIC 3O03 and registration in Honours Music; or permission of the program Alternates with MUSIC 4OC3 .

MUSIC 4SS3.name: Special Studies in Chamber Music or Accompanying II
MUSIC 4SS3.description: Advanced supervised studies in chamber music performance or instrumental accompanying. Times to be arranged between the students and instructor; one term.
MUSIC 4SS3.prerequisites: MUSIC 3SS3 ; and registration in Level III or IV of a Music program, and permission of the School of the Arts . Students requesting this course must submit a written proposal to the School of the Arts by April 15th. This course is primarily for students pursuing the Diploma in Music Performance. This course cannot be repeated. Students taking MUSIC 4SS3 must pay additional lesson fees to the School of the Arts by September 1 for Term One and by January 1 for Term Two.

MUSIC 4X03.name: Advanced Independent Study
MUSIC 4X03.description: Advanced supervised study in any area offered and approved by the School of the Arts . Times to be arranged between the student and instructor; one term.
MUSIC 4X03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of an Honours Music program and permission of the School of the Arts . Students requesting this course must submit a written proposal to the School of the Arts by April 15th.

MUSIC 4Y03.name: Topics in Music History: Advanced Musicology Seminar
MUSIC 4Y03.description: An intensive examination of a composer, period, genre, or issue from the style areas of ‘classical’ music, film music, popular music, or jazz. Seminar (two hours); one term.
MUSIC 4Y03.prerequisites: MUSIC 1CB3 ; and one of MUSIC 1MH3 or MUSIC 2CU3 ; and 6 additional units of Music; or permission of the program. MUSIC 4Y03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

MUSIC 4Z03.name: Composing Music
MUSIC 4Z03.description: The composition of various instrumental or vocal works. Times to be arranged between the student and instructor; one term.
MUSIC 4Z03.prerequisites: MUSIC 2CB3 and registration in level III or above; or permission of the instructor

MUSIC 4ZZ3.name: Advanced Composition
MUSIC 4ZZ3.description: The composition of various instrumental or vocal works. Times to be arranged between the student and instructor; one term.
MUSIC 4ZZ3.prerequisites: MUSIC 4Z03; or permission of the instructor

THTRFLM 2AA3.name: Acting as Devising I
THTRFLM 2AA3.description: Students receive studio training in voice and body, and explore how the performer’s creative process reflects and challenges the norms that structure contemporary social relationships. Two studios; one term.
THTRFLM 2AA3.prerequisites: Registration in a program in Theatre and Film Studies or IARTS, or permission of the program Corequisite(s): WHMIS 1A00 if not already completed; successful completion of WHMIS is required prior to studio work Cross-list(s): IARTS 2AD3

THTRFLM 2BB3.name: Designing for Devised Performance
THTRFLM 2BB3.description: Students work in studio to learn basic techniques for using visual and sound design as a basis for creating performance pieces. Two two-hour  studios; one term.
THTRFLM 2BB3.prerequisites: One of IARTS 1T03, THTRFLM 1T03, or MMEDIA 1A03 or MEDIAART 1A03 and registration in Level II or above of any program Cross-list(s): IARTS 2BB3

THTRFLM 2CC3.name: Performance, Art, and Visual Culture in Canada
THTRFLM 2CC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program Cross-list(s): IARTS 2CC3

THTRFLM 2DP3.name: Devised Performance Processes
THTRFLM 2DP3.description: Devised performance is collectively created work that responds to the world we live in and the social issues we face. Students learn foundational workshop practices for the devising of live performances, integrating design experimentation, acting exercises, and games. Two two-hour studios; one term.
THTRFLM 2DP3.prerequisites: IARTS 1T03 or THTRFLM 1T03; and registration in Level II or above of any program

THTRFLM 2FA3.name: Film Analysis
THTRFLM 2FA3.description: An introduction to an interrelated set of approaches to film study, all of which are defined by their attention to the filmic text and which provide students with a grasp of the fundamentals of film analysis. Two lectures, plus one weekly film screening; one term.
THTRFLM 2FA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): IARTS 2FA3 , ARTHIST 2FA3

THTRFLM 2MM3.name: Movies and Me
THTRFLM 2MM3.description: An examination of popular film as a social practice, considering both how mainstream movies take up social issues and how audiences interact with films and film culture. Two hour lecture, one film screening; one term.
THTRFLM 2MM3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): IARTS 2MM3

THTRFLM 3AA3.name: Modernist Drama and Theatre in Europe
THTRFLM 3AA3.description: This course studies representative dramas and theatre productions that highlight the diversity of plays on the 20th century stage. One seminar (two hours), plus weekly play readings/screenings (two hours); one term.
THTRFLM 3AA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Offered in alternate years.

THTRFLM 3DD3.name: Contemporary Canadian Drama and Theatre
THTRFLM 3DD3.description: An examination of changing approaches to plays and performances in contemporary Canadian theatre, with an emphasis on post-colonialism, cultural diversity and the performance of gender and class. Three lectures; one term.
THTRFLM 3DD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
THTRFLM 3DD3.antirequisites: ENGLISH 3DD3, THTRFLM 3F03 Offered in alternate years.

THTRFLM 3FF3.name: Early Cinema History
THTRFLM 3FF3.description: An introduction to the history of narrative film from its beginnings to the Second World War. It focuses on narrative cinema’s development from aesthetic, social, technological and economic perspectives while also touching on a selected number of issues in film theory. Two lectures, plus one weekly film screening; one term.
THTRFLM 3FF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program Cross-list(s): ARTHIST 3FL3

THTRFLM 3L03.name: Cinema History from WWII
THTRFLM 3L03.description: An exploration of narrative film from 1941 to the present day, incorporating a study of a variety of narrative cinema styles. Theoretical issues will include questions of cinema’s relationship to other art forms, narrative, genre and authorship. Two lectures, plus one weekly film screening; one term.
THTRFLM 3L03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

THTRFLM 3N03.name: Artists’ Alternative Film and Video
THTRFLM 3N03.description: An exploration of artists’ film and video produced outside of dominant institutions, including such practices as documentary, autobiography, community projects, experimental film, short film and video art. Lecture and discussion (two hours), plus one weekly film screening; one term.
THTRFLM 3N03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above and one of CMST 2BB3 or THTRFLM 2CP3, 2FA3

THTRFLM 3P03.name: Gender and Visual Culture
THTRFLM 3P03.description: Students will explore ideas about representation, spectatorship and production in relation to issues of social difference, such as gender, race and class. Emphasis is on visuality in forms such as film, video, television, advertising, et cetera. Lecture and discussion (two hours), plus one weekly film screening; one term.
THTRFLM 3P03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above

THTRFLM 3PC3.name: Performance and Community Engagement
THTRFLM 3PC3.description: Working in collaboration with the Student Success Centre, the class will conduct theatre workshops to gather material about the lived experiences of McMaster students. They will learn how to organize and analyze the material they gather, and use it to create short scenes for the following year’s production of the Welcome Week play, IRIS, which is presented to most incoming McMaster undergraduates within days of their arrival on campus. Two studios (four hours), plus one lecture; one term.
THTRFLM 3PC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any program

THTRFLM 3PR3.name: Text-based Devising: Research and Development
THTRFLM 3PR3.description: Students will learn the basic skills necessary for the research and planning phase of public performance through preparatory work for departmental productions. Students will learn the research and studio skills necessary to devise productions from previously scripted texts. This class will begin the creative process for the departmental production in the Fall term. Studio fees are a course requirement. Consult with the instructor to determine the cost before the end of the drop and add period. Three hours (studio and lectures); one term.
THTRFLM 3PR3.prerequisites: Registration in level II or above and permission of the instructor Offered during the Spring/Summer term only. This course may be repeated to a maximum of 6 units. Alternates with THTRFLM 3PS3.

THTRFLM 3PS3.name: Devising New Plays: Research and Development
THTRFLM 3PS3.description: Students will learn the research and studio skills necessary to devise new plays. This class will begin the creative process for the departmental production in the Fall term. Studio fees are a course requirement. Consult with the instructor to determine the cost before the end of the drop and add period. Three hours (studio and lectures); one term.
THTRFLM 3PS3.prerequisites: Registration in level II or above and permission of the instructor This course may be repeated to a maximum of 6 units. Alternates with THTRFLM 3PR3. Offered during the Spring/Summer term only.

THTRFLM 3QA3.name: Documentary, Politics, and Social Change
THTRFLM 3QA3.description: Critical approaches to the social function of nonfiction film and performance. Topics may include the ethics and representational politics of documentary film and/or theatre, the role of documentary in witnessing injustice, and the potential for documentary to contribute to social change. Three hours; one term.
THTRFLM 3QA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

THTRFLM 3RR3.name: ‘Cripping’ Performance: Deaf, Mad and Disabled Performance in Canada
THTRFLM 3RR3.description: This course will explore the history and culture of disabled, Mad and Deaf theatre and performance. Delving in Canada’s rich 45 year history of disabled, Deaf and Mad theatre, the course will consider intersectionality, access and interdependence as core tenets of this milieu. This course is rooted in understandings of disability justice and will touch on the intermingling of disabled activism with performance and the current push for changes in the Canadian theatre landscape for Deaf, Mad and disabled creators. Three hours; one term.
THTRFLM 3RR3.prerequisites: Registration in level II or above of any program Cross-list(s): GENDRST 3RR3 , IARTS 3RR3

THTRFLM 3S06.name: Major Production Workshop
THTRFLM 3S06.prerequisites: Registration in Level III of any program in Theatre & Film Studies, Media Arts or Multimedia, and permission of the School of the Arts.

THTRFLM 3SD3.name: Scripting the Devised Performance
THTRFLM 3SD3.description: A practical study of the structural qualities and social impact of different dramatic forms and their use in scripting performances for specific audiences. Studio (two hours), lecture and discussion (one hour); one term.
THTRFLM 3SD3.prerequisites: A grade of at least B- in THTRFLM 2AA3 , 2BB3 , or 2DP3 ; and registration in Level III or above of a program in Theatre & Film Studies

THTRFLM 3U03.name: Pleasure and Critique in Dramatic Performance
THTRFLM 3U03.description: An exploration of the relationship between pleasure and critique in a range of dramatic performances for theatre, cinema and related art forms. Lecture and discussion (three hours); one term.
THTRFLM 3U03.prerequisites: THTRFLM 1T03; and registration in Level III or above

THTRFLM 3VS3.name: Visual Storytelling
THTRFLM 3VS3.description: This course examines the theories underlying the visual aesthetics of cinema and theatre. These are analyzed alongside narrative structure and put into practice by students in projects. Three hours (lectures and demonstrations); one term.
THTRFLM 3VS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program Offered in alternate years.

THTRFLM 3WW3.name: Acting and the Voice: Devising from Classical Texts
THTRFLM 3WW3.description: Using classical texts as a springboard, students will learn to use their voices as an important resource in the devising of new work. Two studios; one term.
THTRFLM 3WW3.prerequisites: Registration in a program in Theatre & Film Studies, or permission of the program Alternates with THTRFLM 3XX3 . THTRFLM 2AA3 is recommended.

THTRFLM 3XX3.name: Acting and the Body: Devising Physical Theatre
THTRFLM 3XX3.description: A practical investigation of the ways actors can use their own bodies as a central resource in the devising of new work. Two studios; one term.
THTRFLM 3XX3.prerequisites: Registration in a program in Theatre & Film Studies, or permission of the program Alternates with THTRFLM 3WW3 . THTRFLM 2AA3 is recommended.

THTRFLM 4C03.name: Performance and Society
THTRFLM 4C03.description: Senior Seminar: Contemporary theories about the relationship of performance and social structures. Seminar (two hours); one term.
THTRFLM 4C03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of an Honours program in Theatre & Film Studies Priority will be given to students registered in Level IV of any Theatre & Film Studies program. Offered in alternate years.

THTRFLM 4D03.name: Theatre, Society and Early Cinema
THTRFLM 4D03.description: Senior seminar: A study of the relationship between theatre and film. It is organized by topics that have been the focus of recent scholarship. Seminar (two hours); one term.
THTRFLM 4D03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of an Honours program in Theatre & Film Studies Priority will be given to students registered in Level IV of any Theatre & Film Studies program.

THTRFLM 4E03.name: Cinema and Society
THTRFLM 4E03.description: Senior seminar: Students work with interdisciplinary theories and examine how selected films produce social meanings. Seminar (two hours); one term.
THTRFLM 4E03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of an Honours program in Theatre & Film Studies; or registration in Level IV of an Honours program in Communication Studies THTRFLM 3FF3 is recommended. Priority will be given first to students registered in Level IV of any Theatre & Film Studies program and then to students registered in Level IV of the Communication Studies program.

ABLD 3BA3.name: Topics in Black, African and African Diaspora Studies
ABLD 3BA3.description: This interdisciplinary course will explore selected topics from Black, African, and African Diaspora Studies, as determined by the instructor. Topics will focus on historical and contemporary issues that connect Black and African communities around the world. This course will interrogate the intersections of race with other concepts and experiences including gender, class, sexuality, culture, power, politics, violence, and globalization. Lectures (three hours); one term.

ABLD 3CD3.name: Topics in the Black Caribbean and its Diasporas
ABLD 3CD3.description: This interdisciplinary course will introduce students to topics that demonstrate the Caribbean region’s rich and nuanced Black histories and cultures. Focusing on short, contemporary cultural productions-including written and spoken-word poetry, short stories, music, and news publications created by Afro-Caribbean artists-this course will offer a grounding in the rich geographies, multi-linguistic traditions, and socio-political landscapes of the Black Caribbean and its diasporas in Canada, the United States, and England. Lectures (three hours); one term.

ANTHROP 1AA3.name: Introduction to Anthropology: Sex, Food and Death
ANTHROP 1AA3.description: This course examines major issues in Anthropology in contemporary and past societies from archaeological, biological, cultural and linguistic perspectives. It will focus on sex, food, illness, death and related themes. Lectures, discussion (three hours).

ANTHROP 1AB3.name: Introduction to Anthropology: Race, Religion, and Social Justice
ANTHROP 1AB3.description: This course introduces students to Anthropology and its sub-disciplines through a discussion of some of the big questions and issues that anthropologists investigate in contemporary and past societies. These include issues of religion and worldview, race and racism, power and inequality, and social justice from archaeological, biological, and sociocultural perspectives. Through this course you will develop an understanding of how anthropological approaches can be used to better understand humanity, past and present. Lectures, discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 1R03, SCAR 1R03.

ANTHROP 2AN3.name: The Anthropology of Food and Nutrition
ANTHROP 2AN3.description: An anthropological perspective on nutrition at the population level. Prehistoric, historic and contemporary human nutrition, emphasizing links with the environment. Lecture (two hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
