ANTHROP 2AN3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology or HLTHAGE 1AA3 (HEALTHST 1A03); and registration in Level II or above in any program Cross-list(s): HLTHAGE 2AN3

ANTHROP 2BB3.name: Ancient Mesoamerica: Aztecs to Zapotecs
ANTHROP 2BB3.description: This course addresses the lifeways of ancient Mesoamerican societies through the material traces of daily and ritual practices, using diverse scientific methods and theoretical perspectives. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2BB3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology and registration in Level II or above in any program.

ANTHROP 2C03.name: Archaeology of Environmental Crisis and Response
ANTHROP 2C03.description: Examination of the influence of natural and human-induced environmental crises on long term culture histories. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2C03.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology and registration in Level II or above in any program

ANTHROP 2D03.name: DNA Meets Anthropology
ANTHROP 2D03.description: Introduction to the many uses of genetics in anthropology (modern human origins, migrations, domestication, primate conservation, primate genetics, forensics.) Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2D03.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology, registration in Level II or above in any program

ANTHROP 2DA3.name: Traditional Indigenous Ecological Knowledge
ANTHROP 2DA3.description: This course is a study of the ecological teachings of Indigenous peoples and of their relationships with the natural environment in historical and contemporary times. Lectures and seminars (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2DA3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Indigenous Studies or permission of the Instructor Cross-lists(s): ENVSOCTY 2EK3, INDIGST 2D03 This course is administered by the Indigenous Studies Program.

ANTHROP 2E03.name: Introduction to Biological Anthropology
ANTHROP 2E03.description: The course examines the biological and cultural basis for human variation, past and present. Lectures (two hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
ANTHROP 2E03.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology and registration in Level II or above in any program This course is required of all students enrolled in an Honours Program in Anthropology, and is a prerequisite for advanced courses in Physical Anthropology.

ANTHROP 2EE3.name: Sport and/as Religion
ANTHROP 2EE3.description: An examination of relationships between sport and religion, including ritual aspects of sport, connections between social collectivities and sports teams, and sport as meaning-making activity. Three hours (lecture and discussion); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2SP3 Cross-list(s): SCAR 2SP3.

ANTHROP 2F03.name: Introduction to Sociocultural Anthropology: Listening Across Difference
ANTHROP 2F03.description: An introduction to concepts, theories and current debates in cultural anthropology. This course is designed to prepare students for more advanced courses in social and cultural anthropology. Lecture (two hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
ANTHROP 2F03.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology and registration in Level II or above in any program This course is required of all students enrolled in an Honours Program in Anthropology, and is a prerequisite for advanced courses in Sociocultural Anthropology.

ANTHROP 2FF3.name: Human Skeletal Biology and Bioarchaeology
ANTHROP 2FF3.description: Study of the human skeleton (bones and dentition) for application in archaeology and forensic anthropology. Includes determination of sex, age, stature and other individual characteristics. Lectures, labs (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2FF3.prerequisites: Registration in an Honours Anthropology program

ANTHROP 2G03.name: Readings in Indo-European Myth
ANTHROP 2G03.description: This course will acquaint students with the myths of Ancient Greece, Ancient India, the Kelts and the Norse. Other traditions may also be examined. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2G03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above in any program

ANTHROP 2HE3.name: Heritage, Economy, and Ethics
ANTHROP 2HE3.description: This course examines the ethics and reasons for the current heritage boom. It will be of interest to students in anthropology, public history, and museum work. Lecture and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2HE3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology and registration in Level II or above in any program

ANTHROP 2HH3.name: Science, Technology & Society: Archaeological Perspectives
ANTHROP 2HH3.description: This course details the feats of engineering that gave us the pyramids, the million-year history of mining, and how elites rise with new technologies: from the wheel to steel. We locate the studies of fracture mechanics, quarrying, and smelting within a broader consideration of how engineering and technological innovations came to be, and their impact on past societies. Lecture and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2HH3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above in any program

ANTHROP 2HI3.name: Medical Anthropology
ANTHROP 2HI3.description: This course is an introduction to the sub-discipline of medical anthropology, and cultivates an understanding of the intersection between disease, health, society, bodies, culture, and global political economy. Lecture (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2HI3.prerequisites: Three units of level I Anthropology

ANTHROP 2MA3.name: Art and Activism
ANTHROP 2MA3.description: Why do people summon art to mobilize against violence and oppression? This course explores how is art has historically been summoned in activism, from opposing dictatorships in Latin America to present-day political movements, such as BLM, the #metoo movement, among others. We will study why people appeal to the arts to find shelter from or mobilize against racism, sexism, and political repression. This course builds on academic scholarship, podcasts, and films, and in-class interviews with invited guests.
ANTHROP 2MA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above in any program
ANTHROP 2MA3.antirequisites: ANTHROP 3MA3 This course also includes experiential learning methods, e.g. in the form of museum visits; the creation of small exhibits, and so forth.

ANTHROP 2O03.name: Themes in the Archaeological History of North America
ANTHROP 2O03.description: An examination of the origins and development of the major indigenous cultural groups of prehistoric North America. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2O03.prerequisites: Three units of Anthropology and registration in Level II or above in any program. ANTHROP 2PA3 is strongly recommended.

ANTHROP 2PA3.name: Introduction to Anthropological Archaeology
ANTHROP 2PA3.description: An introduction to the theory, methods and ethics of anthropological archaeology with a focus on specific problems in the human past. Lectures, labs, discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2PA3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology and registration in Level II or above in any program This course is required of all students registered in an Honours Program in Anthropology.

ANTHROP 2PC3.name: Aliens, Curses and Nazis: Archaeology and Hollywood
ANTHROP 2PC3.description: This course uses popular representations of archaeology from Agatha Christie to Indiana Jones to critically review the discipline’s practice and practitioners from past to present. Lectures, tutorials (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2PC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above in any program.

ANTHROP 2R03.name: Religion, Magic and Witchcraft
ANTHROP 2R03.description: Selected issues in the study of religion, magic and witchcraft, science and the supernatural. Perspectives from history, psychology and sociology also will be discussed. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2R03.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology and registration in Level II or above in any program

ANTHROP 2RP3.name: Religion and Power in the Past
ANTHROP 2RP3.description: A critical examination of the relationship between religion, political power and warfare in a sample of prehistoric and historic states and empires. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2RP3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology and registration in Level II or above in any program

ANTHROP 2U03.name: Plagues and People
ANTHROP 2U03.description: A consideration of the role played by infectious disease in human evolution. The social and biological outcomes of major epidemics and pandemics, past and present, will be explored. Lecture (two hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
ANTHROP 2U03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above in any program

ANTHROP 2WA3.name: Neanderthals to Pyramids: Introduction to World Archaeology
ANTHROP 2WA3.description: This course introduces students to major debates in World Archaeology, including the origins of: humanity, art, first peoples of the Americas, farming, social differentiation and state-level societies. Global case studies highlight the approaches archaeologists employ in their search for answers. Lectures, tutorials (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 2WA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above in any program

ANTHROP 3AR3.name: Culture and Religion
ANTHROP 3AR3.description: This course introduces key theorists and theories, classic and current topics, and issues of methodology and writing in the study of religion and culture. Lectures and tutorial (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3AR3.prerequisites: Three units of any Anthropology or Religious Studies course and registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): SCAR 3AR3 This course is administered by the Department of Religious Studies

ANTHROP 3AS3.name: Archaeology and Society
ANTHROP 3AS3.description: A critical examination of the history of archaeology and the social and political implications of our understanding of the ancient human past. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3AS3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology

ANTHROP 3BA3.name: Special Topics in Biological Anthropology
ANTHROP 3BA3.description: The topic varies with each instructor (e.g. one class may examine current issues on the study of the human skeleton for application in archaeology and forensic anthropology and other classes may focus on the anthropological perspective on nutrition at the population level. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3BA3.prerequisites: Registration in any program in Anthropology

ANTHROP 3BB3.name: Ancient Agriculture to Criminal Investigations: Paleoethnobotany in Practice
ANTHROP 3BB3.description: This course trains students in laboratory methods and interpretations of botanical evidence through hands-on practice. We explore the major classes of plant remains likely to be encountered in forensic cases and archaeological sites; identify botanical residues and organize the data to make interpretable results; and address major issues within the discipline including preservation, analytical methods, sampling, collection, and interpretation. Three hours (lectures, discussion, and lab); one term.
ANTHROP 3BB3.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2PA3 ; and credit or registration in WHMIS 1A00 . This requirement must be completed prior to the first lab.

ANTHROP 3BD3.name: The Black Death
ANTHROP 3BD3.description: This class studies the underlying causes and consequences of the Black Death and the second plague pandemic of 1346 -1722 across Europe and Western Asia. We consider the synergistic effects that ultimately led to the 30-70% mortality from a biological and cultural/social perspective with guest lectures from leading historians, climatologists, geneticists and rodent ecologists. What were the pandemic’s origins, its root causes (biological and other) and the ultimate consequences on the socio-economic fabric of Europe? We consider the ongoing epidemics in Madagascar, South America and the American Southwest. Lecture (two hours); tutorial (one hour); one term.

ANTHROP 3BF3.name: Bioarchaeological Field School
ANTHROP 3BF3.description: This course allows students to travel overseas to participate in the excavation of human skeletal remains. Students will develop skills in the documentation and analysis of skeletal remains and associated burial artifacts. Offered during the Spring/Summer term only; one term.
ANTHROP 3BF3.prerequisites: Permission of the instructor Travel and subsistence costs are responsibility of the student.

ANTHROP 3CA3.name: Ceramic Analysis
ANTHROP 3CA3.description: Examination of theories and methods used by archaeologists to analyze ceramics and understand past ceramic technologies. The class will include strong hands-on and original research components. Three hours (lectures, labs, discussion); one term.
ANTHROP 3CA3.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2PA3 and credit or registration in WHMIS 1A00 . This requirement must be completed prior to the first lab.

ANTHROP 3CC6.name: Archaeological Field School
ANTHROP 3CC6.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2PA3 or an equivalent course in archaeological methods and credit or registration in WHMIS 1A00 . This requirement must be completed prior to the first day of field school.

ANTHROP 3DD3.name: Archaeology of Death
ANTHROP 3DD3.description: Archaeological analysis and interpretation of burial practices and other death-rituals. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.

ANTHROP 3E03.name: Special Topics in Archaeology I
ANTHROP 3E03.description: Topic: TBA The topic varies with each instructor (e.g. one class may examine Ancient Mesoamerican Cities and another focus on The Archaeology of Hierarchy.) Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.

ANTHROP 3EE3.name: Special Topics in Archaeology II
ANTHROP 3EE3.description: Topic: TBA The topic varies with each instructor (e.g. one class may examine Ancient Mesoamerican Cities and another may focus on The Archaeology of Hierarchy.) Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.

ANTHROP 3ET3.name: Anthropology of Ethics
ANTHROP 3ET3.description: This course explores the classical anthropological question of how ethical value is shaped and contested. Grounded in ethnography studies of specific ethical traditions (both religious and secular), course topics may include the problem of suffering, the prospect of human freedom, the cultivation of virtue, and the development of moral obligations. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3ET3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology or three units of Level I SCAR or permission of the instructor. Cross-list(s): SCAR 3ET3

ANTHROP 3F03.name: Anthropology and the ‘Other’
ANTHROP 3F03.description: As a discipline, anthropology is effectively predicated on the notion of the ‘othered’. This course asks about the constructions, representations, and political uses of the ‘othered.’ Lectures, discussion (three hours); one term.

ANTHROP 3FA3.name: Forensic Anthropology
ANTHROP 3FA3.description: This course examines the detection, recovery, and analysis of human remains within a medico-legal context. Students will explore the role of the forensic anthropologist in the investigation of criminal cases, human rights cases, and mass disasters. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3FA3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology

ANTHROP 3FF3.name: Key Debates in Andean Archaeology
ANTHROP 3FF3.description: This class explores debates in Andean research, from the development of religious ideologies to the origins of social hierarchy, through archaeological, ethnohistorical and ethnographic data. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.

ANTHROP 3G03.name: Comparative Mythology
ANTHROP 3G03.description: The reconstruction of lost mythic traditions by means of comparative techniques drawn from historical linguistics. The Indo-European traditions of Eurasia will be examined. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3G03.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2G03 or permission of the instructor

ANTHROP 3GH3.name: Interdisciplinary Global Health Field Course: Maternal and Infant Health in Morocco
ANTHROP 3GH3.description: An integrated linguistic, cultural, historical, and public health field school in Morocco, with a focus on maternal and infant health, womens rights, and family. Spring; one term.
ANTHROP 3GH3.prerequisites: Permission of the instructor Co-requisite(s): ARABIC 3GH3
ANTHROP 3GH3.antirequisites: RELIGST 3GH3 Cross-list(s): SCAR 3GH3 Available as a study-abroad experience in the Spring only. This course is intended for students who are entering Level III or above in the following Fall/Winter Session. Students interested in this course must contact Dr. E. Amster by February 15 for application instructions. There is an additional cost associated with this course. This course is administered by the Department of Religious Studies.

ANTHROP 3HH3.name: Globalization, Social Justice and Human Rights
ANTHROP 3HH3.description: This course examines competing theories, issues and debates relating to the promotion of social justice and human rights in a globalizing world. Students use course-integrated social justice and networking to interact and collaborate with peers from partner universities across the globe where versions of this course are simultaneously taught. Lectures (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3HH3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology Cross-list(s): GLOBALZN 3A03 This course is administered by the Institute on Globalization and the Human Condition.

ANTHROP 3IS3.name: Independent Study in Anthropology
ANTHROP 3IS3.description: Independent study of a research problem through published materials and/or fieldwork. It is incumbent upon the student to secure arrangements with the supervising instructor prior to registration in this course; otherwise, no grade will be submitted. Lectures, (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3IS3.prerequisites: Registration in any program in Anthropology and permission of the instructor. ANTHROP 3IS3 may be repeated, if on a different study, to a total of six units. See Department Note 2.

ANTHROP 3K03.name: Archaeological Interpretation
ANTHROP 3K03.description: Techniques and methodologies in the investigation of archaeological material. Lectures, labs and discussion (three hours); one term.

ANTHROP 3LA3.name: Lithics Analysis
ANTHROP 3LA3.description: A global approach to the theories and methods used by the archaeologists to analyse stone tools and the major debates surrounding these data. The class has a strong hands on and original-research component. Lecture and lab (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3LA3.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2PA3 ; and credit or registration in WHMIS 1A00 . This requirement must be completed prior to the first lab.

ANTHROP 3LL3.name: Of Beauty and Violence
ANTHROP 3LL3.description: What is the place of beauty in human experience and how does it find articulation in words? Using an interdisciplinary approach, this course explores the unexpected expressions and uses of beauty in a variety of social and ethnographic contexts marked by violence. Lecture (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3LL3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology or permission of the Instructor

ANTHROP 3P03.name: Doing Ethnography: Research Methods
ANTHROP 3P03.description: This course introduces research methods utilized by sociocultural anthropologists and others in related disciplines, focusing throughout on the collection, interpretation, and presentation of ethnographic (and other) data. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3P03.prerequisites: Registration in level II or above

ANTHROP 3PA3.name: Haudenosaunee Health, Diet and Traditional Botany
ANTHROP 3PA3.description: Working with traditional knowledge holders, this course will explore the relationship between ethnobotany and agricultural practice to Haudenosaunee cultural beliefs and concepts of health and wellness. Lectures (2 hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
ANTHROP 3PA3.prerequisites: Six units of Level I or II Indigenous Studies, Mohawk or Cayuga language, or permission of the Instructor. Cross-lists(s): INDIGST 3P03 This course is administered by the Indigenous Studies Program

ANTHROP 3PD3.name: Anthropological Perspectives and Debates
ANTHROP 3PD3.description: This course explores themes of importance to the various sub-disciplines of Anthropology. The goal is to show how varying analytical perspectives on these broad themes produce divergent views of past and present human cultures. Students are strongly encouraged to complete this course, prior to completion of Level III. Three hours ( lectures, discussion ); one term.
ANTHROP 3PD3.prerequisites: Registration in an Honours Anthropology program or permission of the instructor. This course is required of all students registered in an Honours Program in Anthropology

ANTHROP 3PH3.name: Dissent, Power and History
ANTHROP 3PH3.description: This course addresses questions of power, agency, and resistance in historical and contemporary cultural contexts. Drawing on visual materials and ethnographic forms of writing, it looks at a range of issues, including nationalism, neoliberalism, democracy, and various forms of organizing. Lectures, discussion, visual materials (three hours); one term.

ANTHROP 3PP3.name: Paleopathology
ANTHROP 3PP3.description: The origins and evolution of human diseases and methods of identifying disease in ancient human remains. Lectures, discussion and lab (three hours); one term.

ANTHROP 3SS3.name: Sacred Journeys
ANTHROP 3SS3.description: A study of the significance of travel in various religious traditions, focusing on shrines, pilgrimages, and the inter-relationships between secular and sacred travel. Lectures and tutorial (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3SS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
ANTHROP 3SS3.antirequisites: RELIGST 3EE3 Cross-list(s): SCAR 3EE3 This course is administered by the Department of Religious Studies.

ANTHROP 3ST3.name: Anthropology of Postcolonial Science and Technology
ANTHROP 3ST3.description: This course introduces students to the interdisciplinary field of science and technology studies (STS) and postcolonial studies, with a geographic focus on Africa. We will engage scholarship and media produced by anthropologists, historians, artists, and postcolonial theorists to challenge narratives that construct the continent as a passive recipient of knowledge, projects, ‘development’, and technological innovations that originate in the global North. Each week, our focus will be on tracing the itineraries of a single technoscientific object, such as pharmaceuticals, water pumps, malaria bed nets, biometric technologies, mobile phones, motorbikes, soap, and no-flush toilets. We will attend to what kinds of relations, politics, emotions, and economies assemble around these objects, and explore science and place, technology and culture, traveling technologies, and the many diverse meanings, stories and politics that adhere to (post)colonial science and technology. Lecture (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3ST3.prerequisites: Registration in level III or above in any program. ANTHROP 2F03 is recommended.

ANTHROP 3TR3.name: The Anthropology of Tourism
ANTHROP 3TR3.description: An exploration of the intersections between various forms of tourism (e.g. food tourism, sex tourism, heritage and archaeology tourism) with narratives of identity, inequality, colonialism, and globalization. Lecture (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3TR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above in any program

ANTHROP 3W03.name: Special Topics in Anthropology
ANTHROP 3W03.description: The topic varies with each instructor (e.g. one class may examine Current Issues in Medical Anthropology and other classes may focus on Readings in Myth or Contemporary Issues in Archaeology.) One term.
ANTHROP 3W03.prerequisites: Registration in any program in Anthropology ANTHROP 3W03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

ANTHROP 3X03.name: Zooarchaeology
ANTHROP 3X03.description: Study of the long-term histories of human-environment interaction through analysis of archaeologically recovered animal remains. Labs and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 3X03.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2PA3 and credit or registration in WHMIS 1A00 ; this requirement must be completed prior to the first lab

ANTHROP 3Y03.name: Indigenous Community Health and Wellbeing
ANTHROP 3Y03.description: A critical examination of the determinants of health in Indigenous communities, processes of community revitalization and recent government policy initiatives. Three hours (lecture and discussion); one term.
ANTHROP 3Y03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above in any program Cross-list(s): HLTHAGE 3YY3

ANTHROP 4AA3.name: Materiality, Matter and Social Lives
ANTHROP 4AA3.description: This course explores the relationship between humans and the material world. Lectures (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4AA3.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2PA3 or permission of the instructor
ANTHROP 4AA3.antirequisites: ANTHROP 4E03 , if taken during the Winter term 2017

ANTHROP 4AH3.name: Archaeology and Heritage: Ethics, Politics, and Practice
ANTHROP 4AH3.description: This course will examine the ways in which archaeology is political, and how its practice and practitioners are deeply entangled with Western values and epistemologies. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4AH3.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2PA3 or permission of the instructor

ANTHROP 4B03.name: Current Problems in Sociocultural Anthropology I
ANTHROP 4B03.description: Topic: TBA The topic varies with each instructor. Three hours (seminar); one term.
ANTHROP 4B03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV Honours Anthropology or permission of the instructor ANTHROP 4B03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

ANTHROP 4BB3.name: Current Problems in Sociocultural Anthropology II
ANTHROP 4BB3.description: As per ANTHROP 4B03. Three hours (seminar); one term.
ANTHROP 4BB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV Honours Anthropology or permission of the instructor ANTHROP 4BB3 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

ANTHROP 4CC3.name: Archaeology of Foodways
ANTHROP 4CC3.description: This course addresses the deep history of particular foodways and the diversity of foodways over time, as gleaned from archaeological residues and early historic documents. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4CC3.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2PA3 , or permission of the instructor

ANTHROP 4CL3.name: Archaeology of Climate Change and Culture
ANTHROP 4CL3.description: Examination of the effects of climate change on the histories of past cultures, emphasizing archaeological debates on the timing and extent of climate events and their importance for understanding culture change. Seminar (three hours); one term.

ANTHROP 4CP3.name: Cultural Politics of Food and Eating
ANTHROP 4CP3.description: This course focuses on food and the complex field of networks, expectations, and choices that are contested, negotiated, and often unequal. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4CP3.prerequisites: Registration in Honours Anthropology or Level IV of any Honours program or permission of the instructor

ANTHROP 4D03.name: Practicing Anthropology: Ethics, Theory, Engagement
ANTHROP 4D03.description: An examination of how anthropology is applied to solve human problems. Includes discussion of how students can use their anthropological training in non-academic occupations. Students may be involved in academic placements within the community. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4D03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV Honours Anthropology or permission of the instructor

ANTHROP 4DD3.name: Anthropology of Zombies and the Undead
ANTHROP 4DD3.description: This course explores ethnographic and popular culture narratives of zombies and the undead through the lens of nationalism, colonialism, race, gender and other phenomena. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4DD3.prerequisites: Registration in any Anthropology program or permission of the Instructor
ANTHROP 4DD3.antirequisites: Students who have taken ANTHROP 4B03 or 4BB3 (Special Topic: Anthropology of Zombies and the Undead) cannot enroll in this class

ANTHROP 4DN3.name: Diet & Nutrition: Biocultural and Bioarchaeological Perspectives
ANTHROP 4DN3.description: Study of diet and nutrition in past and contemporary populations using a biocultural approach. Focus on methods, interpretations of data and perspectives. Lectures (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4DN3.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2AN3 or ANTHROP 2E03 ; registration in Level IV Honours Anthropology or permission of the instructor
ANTHROP 4DN3.antirequisites: ANTHROP 4J03 , if the topic was “Diet and Nutrition: Biocultural and Bioarchaeological Perspectives”

ANTHROP 4E03.name: Advanced Topics in Archaeology I
ANTHROP 4E03.description: Study at an advanced level of selected topics in the sub-discipline. Topics may change from year to year. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4E03.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2PA3 or permission of the instructor

ANTHROP 4EE3.name: Advanced Topics in Archaeology II
ANTHROP 4EE3.description: As per ANTHROP 4E03 ; but on a different topic. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4EE3.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2PA3 or permission of the instructor

ANTHROP 4FF3.name: Digging the City: The Archaeology of Urbanism
ANTHROP 4FF3.description: What is a city? What assumptions do we bring to the study of ancient cities? And how have archaeologists traced urban histories and the topographies of city spaces? This seminar investigates the archaeology of early cities, focusing on ancient urban spaces and their relationship to our understanding of issues of the modern city. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4FF3.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2PA3 , or with permission of the instructor

ANTHROP 4G03.name: Independent Research I
ANTHROP 4G03.description: Independent study of a research problem through published materials and/or fieldwork. Study may include museum internship, participation in faculty research, or student-initiated practica or library research. Students will be required to write up the results of their inquiry in scholarly form. It is incumbent upon the student to secure arrangements with the supervising instructor prior to registration in this course; otherwise, no grade will be submitted. One term.
ANTHROP 4G03.prerequisites: Registration in any program in Anthropology and permission of the instructor See Department Note 2.

ANTHROP 4GG3.name: Independent Research II
ANTHROP 4GG3.description: As per ANTHROP 4G03, but on a different topic. One term.
ANTHROP 4GG3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV Honours Anthropology and permission of the instructor See Department Note 2.

ANTHROP 4GS3.name: Genetics and Society
ANTHROP 4GS3.description: The word ‘DNA’ has perfused almost all aspects of society and culture. This class will explore the uses and misuses of DNA in politics, consumerism, ethics, forensics and the film and arts community. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4GS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV Honours Anthropology; or permission of the instructor

ANTHROP 4HF3.name: Archaeology of Hunter-Fisher-Gatherers
ANTHROP 4HF3.description: Study of the prehistoric technologies and organizational strategies used in making a living from the natural environment and examination of the cultural contexts of foraging economies. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4HF3.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2PA3 or permission of the instructor

ANTHROP 4HH3.name: Archaeologies of Space and Place
ANTHROP 4HH3.description: This seminar explores how archaeologists study space, place and landscape, drawing on theoretical frameworks and global case studies from the deep past and recent history. Three hours (seminar); one term.
ANTHROP 4HH3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology and registration in Level II or above in any program or permission of the instructor.

ANTHROP 4J03.name: Advanced Topics in Biological Anthropology I
ANTHROP 4J03.description: Topic: TBA Study at an advanced level of selected topics within the subdiscipline. Topics may change from year to year. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4J03.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2E03 or permission of the instructor ANTHROP 4J03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

ANTHROP 4JJ3.name: Advanced Topics in Biological Anthropology II
ANTHROP 4JJ3.description: Topic: TBA Study at an advanced level of selected topics within the subdiscipline. Topics may change from year to year. Three hours (seminar); one term.
ANTHROP 4JJ3.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2E03 or permission of the instructor ANTHROP 4JJ3 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

ANTHROP 4KK3.name: The Archaeology of Neanderthals and Other Early Humans
ANTHROP 4KK3.description: This seminar engages with the archaeology of our early ancestors, asking: what constitutes humanity, when did we become ‘modern’, and what became of the Neanderthals? Three hour seminar; one term.
ANTHROP 4KK3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology and registration in Level II or above in any program or permission of the Instructor.

ANTHROP 4LL3.name: Critical Global Health
ANTHROP 4LL3.description: Global health constitutes a diversity of actors, institutions, and projects that mobilize immense resources, interventions, and technologies to address complex health issues across the globe. This seminar exposes students to the theories, methodologies, and approaches adopted by anthropologists and others who critically examine how global health reconfigures local practices, politics, and concepts of care, health, and the body. Drawing on case studies from across the globe and using an interdisciplinary lens, the seminar analyzes initiatives, projects, and interventions carried out to improve health in the past and present. We will critically examine topics including: histories of global health, social, cultural, and political aspects of health, health governance, measuring and quantifying health, global health technologies, cultures and ethics of global health research, health and human rights, and global health’s development paradigms. Students will come to appreciate the value of anthropologically informed perspectives and methods for understanding the social, cultural, economic, and political complexities of improving health. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4LL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV Honours Anthropology or permission of the instructor

ANTHROP 4MM3.name: Borders, Migration, Refuge
ANTHROP 4MM3.description: This course addresses historical and contemporary instances of displacement and forced migration. Although grounded in ethnographic studies, it takes an interdisciplinary approach to topics which may include border politics, humanitarianism, hospitality, and the figure of the refugee. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4MM3.prerequisites: Three units of level I Anthropology or permission of the instructor Anthirequisite(s):

ANTHROP 4R03.name: Advanced Bioarchaeology and Skeletal Biology
ANTHROP 4R03.description: The analysis of human skeletal samples, including such topics as paleopathology, paleodemography, paleonutrition and biological distance analyses. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4R03.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2FF3 or permission of the instructor

ANTHROP 4S03.name: The Anthropology of Infectious Disease
ANTHROP 4S03.description: The critical examination of the role of infectious diseases in the course of human history and contemporary society. Self-directed learning format. Seminar (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4S03.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2E03 and registration in Level IV Honours Anthropology; or permission of the instructor

ANTHROP 4SG3.name: The Secret of the Gift
ANTHROP 4SG3.description: This course is a story about returns, an attempt to invoke the notion of The Secret of the Gift into history, geography, economy, and culture. We are talking about the passage of time and the apparent passing of the gift economy from the European encounter and now into the neoliberal free market of a global world. The stories to follow are about the prices countless countries have to pay for being seduced by the gift economy. These are stories about imperialism that have been replicated in countless places all over the world. Lectures and discussions (three hours); one term.
ANTHROP 4SG3.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2F03 or permission of the instructor
ANTHROP 4SG3.antirequisites: ANTHROP 4B03 , if taken during the Fall term in 2010

ARABIC 2AA3.name: Introduction to Modern Standard Arabic
ARABIC 2AA3.description: This course introduces students to the basics of the Arabic language. Students will learn the Arabic alphabet, pronunciation, verb forms, and basic grammar. No prior knowledge of Arabic is necessary. Lectures and discussion (four hours); one term Cross-list(s): SCAR 2AA3 Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2AA3 NOTE: this course is intended for students with no background in Arabic. Students with any background in Arabic must contact the instructor for an assessment/placement test to determine the appropriate level of Arabic: 2AA3, 2AR3, or 3AA3.

ARABIC 2AR3.name: Introduction to Modern Standard Arabic II
ARABIC 2AR3.description: This course builds on the fundamentals covered in ARABIC 2AA3 / SCAR 2AA3 . The course expands students’ vocabulary, reading fluency, composition skills, and knowledge of grammatical constructions. Lectures and tutorials (four hours); one term Cross-list(s): SCAR 2AR3.

ARABIC 3AA3.name: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic
ARABIC 3AA3.description: An intermediate course enhancing skills in modern standard Arabic through reading materials with the goal of improving comprehension in both written and spoken contexts. Four hours (lectures); one term.
ARABIC 3AA3.prerequisites: One of ARABIC 2AR3 , RELIGST 2AR3, or SCAR 2AR3 ; or permission of the instructor Cross-list(s): SCAR 3AA3

ARABIC 3GH3.name: Spoken Moroccan Arabic
ARABIC 3GH3.description: Intensive training in spoken Moroccan Arabic through Latin transliteration and communicative method; no previous Arabic necessary. Students will learn to ask questions and understand responses, express facts and opinions, and engage in basic conversations in Moroccan Arabic. Spring; one term.
ARABIC 3GH3.prerequisites: Permission of the instructor Co-requisite(s): ANTHROP 3GH3 , HISTORY 3GH3, RELIGST 3GH3 Available as a study abroad experience in the Spring only. This course is intended for students who are entering Level III or above in the following Fall/Winter Session. Students interested in this course must contact Dr. E. Amster by February 15 for application instructions. There is an additional cost associated with this course.

ART 1TI3.name: Making Art and Understanding Technology & Images
ART 1TI3.description: Creating art utilizing a range of media, including digital tools and creative research, students will gain an understanding of art, images and cultures of technology. No previous artistic experience is required. Three hours; one term.
ART 1TI3.prerequisites: Registration in Level I or above of any program
ART 1TI3.antirequisites: Enrolment in or completion of MMEDIA 2B06

ART 1UI3.name: Making Art and Understanding Images
ART 1UI3.description: Utilizing sketchbooks, collage, colour exercises and creative research, students will gain widely applicable skills in manipulating and analyzing the communicative power of images. No previous artistic experience is required. Three hours; one term.
ART 1UI3.prerequisites: Registration in Level I or above of any program

ART 2AA3.name: Introduction to the Practice of Art Therapy
ART 2AA3.description: An introduction to the practice of art therapy, with an overview of its history, the diversity of its applications within psychodynamic, solution-focused, cognitive behavioural principles, embodiment theory, and its clinical implications including neuroscience, mindfulness, Post-traumatic Stress Disorder, and pain management. Three lectures; one term Prerequisite(s) : Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s) : ARTHIST 2AA3 May be offered virtually or online.

ART 2ER3.name: Environmentally Responsible Art
ART 2ER3.description: This course focuses on environmentally sustainable studio production with a comprehensive approach that promotes understanding of how materials are manufactured, why they are selected, how they are used and implications of disposal. A student-centered approach will determine media use and concepts. Three hours; one term Offered on a rotational basis.
ART 2ER3.prerequisites: Credit or registration in WHMIS 1A00 (successful completion of WHMIS is required prior to studio work) and registration in Level II or above of any program. Recommended for students pursuing a Minor in Sustainability. Cross-listing(s): IARTS 2ER3

ART 3EA3.name: Social Practice and Community-Engaged Art
ART 3EA3.description: Students will explore and develop an understanding of social practice and community-engaged art working with diverse publics including: large public performances, pedagogical work with K-12 students in schools, walking and place-based projects, and activist oriented long-term engagements. Social practice refers to artwork created through social interaction that aims to create social and/or political change through collaboration with communities. In this interdisciplinary class students will be engaged in concept discussions, and hands-on activities, and writing exercises while considering the ethical and political dimensions of working with diverse communities from feminist, queer, anti-racist and anti-colonial frameworks. Guest lectures and presentations will examine the depth and breadth of social practice. The course will culminate in a group project(s) for the McMaster community. Three hours; one term.
ART 3EA3.prerequisites: Registration in level III or above of any program Cross-list(s): IARTS 3EA3

ART 3FW3.name: Field Work: On-Site Explorations
ART 3FW3.description: This course investigates the campus environment and its resources to promote the potential of place and local opportunities as they inform the production of site-based drawing and mixed-media work. This course may be offered as a concentrated week-long session (e.g. camping excursion). Extra cost will apply. One term. Consult the School of the Arts for details.
ART 3FW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program and credit or registration in WHMIS 1A00

ART 3BA3.name: Concentrated Study - Book Arts
ART 3BA3.description: This course integrates traditional techniques with contemporary concepts and applications of the artist book. Hand-made, imported and found paper will be utilized in a variety of formats responding to student-centered concepts. Sustainable practices, collaboration and exchange will be promoted. Three hours; one term.
ART 3BA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV Honours Studio Art (B.F.A.) (Effective for Students who Entered 2022-2023 and Earlier) program. Offered on a rotational basis. Consult the Master Timetable for offerings.

ART 3CC3.name: Concentrated Study - Ceramics
ART 3CC3.description: Focused on contemporary applications and concepts of 2D and 3D ceramics, this course fuses traditional techniques and alternative methods incorporating a range from hand building to new technologies. Concepts are student-centered. Three hours; one term.
ART 3CC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II, III or IV Honours Studio Art (B.F.A.) (Effective for Students who Entered 2022-2023 and Earlier) program Students completing an Interdisciplinary Minor in Archaeology may be given special permission to register in this course if space is available. Offered on a rotational basis. Consult the Master Timetable for offerings.

ART 3CF3.name: Concentrated Study - Foundry
ART 3CF3.description: This course offers an in-depth investigation of foundry practices and the application of metal casting processes focused on lost-wax in bronze and sand-casting in Aluminum. Concepts are student-centered. Three hours; one term.
ART 3CF3.prerequisites: ART 2SC3 and registration in Level III or IV Honours Studio Art (B.F.A.) (Effective for Students who Entered 2022-2023 and Earlier) program. Offered on a rotational basis. Consult the Master Timetable for offerings.

ART 3CI3.name: Concentrated Study - Intaglio
ART 3CI3.description: This course focuses on intaglio processes exploring traditional and alternative approaches including hand-drawn, found impression, Estisol transfers and photographic/digital image making and etching. Three hours; one term.
ART 3CI3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II, III or IV Honours Studio Art (B.F.A.) (Effective for Students who Entered 2022-2023 and Earlier) program. Offered on a rotational basis. Consult the Master Timetable for offerings.

ART 3CL3.name: Concentrated Study - Lithography
ART 3CL3.description: This course provides concentration on lithography processes without the use of Volatile Organic Compounds. It includes stone lithography using Estisol, Computer-to-Plate photolithography using a Xante Platemaker and other planographic methods involving hand-drawn, transferred and digital applications. Three hours; one term.
ART 3CL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II, III or IV Honours Studio Art (B.F.A.) (Effective for Students who Entered 2022-2023 and Earlier) program Offered on a rotational basis. Consult the Master Timetable for offerings.

ART 3D03.name: Practical Issues
ART 3D03.description: This course is designed to familiarize students with an extensive range of topics associated with creative careers and the professional infrastructure that supports them. Students will gain experience in situating their art into community contexts. Three hours; one term.
ART 3D03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III of Honours Studio Art program

ART 3ID3.name: Integrated Dimensional Media Concentration
ART 3ID3.description: This course investigates points of intersection where installation, site-specific approaches, performance, time-based practice, kinetics and digital technologies interweave. Three hours; one term.
ART 3ID3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV Honours Studio Art (B.F.A.) (Effective for Students who Entered 2022-2023 and Earlier) program. Offered on a rotational basis. Consult the Master Timetable for offerings.

ART 3IM3.name: Integrated Media Concentration
ART 3IM3.description: Student-centered concepts will direct investigations where print, drawing and paint media interweave to create hybrid practices. Environmental compatible materials and processes will be promoted. Three hours; one term.
ART 3IM3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV Honours Studio Art program Offered on a rotational basis. Consult the Master Timetable for offerings

ART 3PD3.name: New Directions in Painting/drawing
ART 3PD3.description: This course explores new directions and technologies that expand definitions of painting and drawing incorporating digital technologies, installations, urban interventions, sculptural approaches and alternative materials. Three hours; one term.
ART 3PD3.prerequisites: ART 2PG3, ART 2DG3 and registration in Level III or IV Honours Studio Art (B.F.A.) (Effective for Students who Entered 2022-2023 and Earlier) program. Offered on a rotational basis. Consult the Master Timetable for offerings

ART 3VA3.name: Video Art and Digital Cinema
ART 3VA3.description: Explores intersections between contemporary art and the moving image, with an emphasis on current movements in Digital Cinema and Video Art. Students will explore the boundaries of conventional filmic production: challenging and expanding on existing skill sets to develop unique and engaging aesthetic sensibilities. Topics will include understanding Digital Cinema, anti-narrative approaches, composite and hybrid/multi-channel video, HD and UHD work flows, audio/video output for the professional sphere, and professional practices (i.e. festivals, residencies, film school, grants, graduate programs, etc.). Three hours (combined lecture and lab); one term.
ART 3VA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Media Arts or Multimedia program; or ART 2DP3 or IARTS 2DP3 and registration in Level III or above in a Studio Art or iArts program Cross-list(s): MEDIAART 3VA3
ART 3VA3.antirequisites: MMEDIA 3VA3 This course is administered by the Department of Communication Studies and Media Arts.

ART 4AP3.name: Contemporary Art Practices of Intervention, Performance and Conceptual Art
ART 4AP3.description: Students will explore and develop an understanding of how 20th century provocations of Dadaism, Fluxus, and Feminist art impact and resonate with contemporary art practices in the 21st century. The course will also examine how the canon of Euro-Western art erased and de-valued work by Indigenous, Black, and Artists of Colour. Departing from a chronological approach to studying art history, the course is structured around issues and/or concepts that dynamically intersect historical and contemporary practices. The course is designed as an interdisciplinary arts-based seminar course, involving readings, lectures, and class discussions, but also field trips, arts-based activities, and collaborative experiential learning. Three hours; one term Cross-list(s): ARTHIST 4AP3 , IARTS 4AP3.
ART 4AP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above in any program.

ART 4AR3.name: Advanced Research and Presentation Strategies
ART 4AR3.description: This course refines and focuses research strategies relevant to the student’s artistic direction. Problem-solving sessions focus on connecting exploration and presentation options to ideas. Attendance at Visiting Artist lectures is mandatory. Three hours; one term.
ART 4AR3.prerequisites: ART ART 3D03 ; ART 3TS3 and ART 3GS3, or ART 3GS6 A/B ; and registration in Level IV Honours Studio Art program.

ART 4CC3.name: Concentrated Study - Ceramics
ART 4CC3.description: This course is an advanced study of contemporary applications and concepts of ceramics, which students will build on techniques and process taught in ART 3CC3 . Students are required to work independently to fulfill a body or work that fuses traditional techniques and concepts in order to hone their skills in the area of ceramics. Three hours; one term.
ART 4CC3.prerequisites: ART 2SC3 and ART 3CC3 and registration in Level III or IV Honours Studio Art (B.F.A.) (Effective for Students who Entered 2022-2023 and Earlier) program. Students completing an Interdisciplinary Minor in Archaeology may be given special permission to register in this course if space is available. Offered on a rotational basis. Consult the Master Timetable for offerings.

ART 4CI3.name: Concentrated Study - Intaglio
ART 4CI3.description: This course provides an in-depth concentration on intaglio processes exploring traditional and alternative approaches of etching, which students will build on techniques and process taught in ART 3CI3 . Students are required to work independently to fulfill a body or work that fuses traditional/contemporary techniques and concepts in order to hone their skills in the area of etching. Three hours; one term.
ART 4CI3.prerequisites: ART 2PM3, ART 3CI3 and registration in Level III or IV Honours Studio Art (B.F.A.) (Effective for Students who Entered 2022-2023 and Earlier) program Offered on a rotational basis. Consult the Master Timetable for offerings.

ART 4CL3.name: Concentrated Study - Lithography
ART 4CL3.description: This course provides in-depth concentration on lithography processes without the use of Volatile Organic Compounds. Students will build on techniques and process taught in ART 3CL3 . Students are required to work independently to fulfill a body or work that fuses traditional/contemporary techniques and concepts in order to hone their skills in the area of Lithography. Three hours; one term.
ART 4CL3.prerequisites: ART 2PM3, ART 3CL3 , and registration in Level III or IV Honours Studio Art (B.F.A.) (Effective for Students who Entered 2022-2023 and Earlier) program Offered on a rotational basis. Consult the Master Timetable for offerings.

ART 4EP3.name: Exhibition Preparation and Documentation
ART 4EP3.description: This advanced course provides hands-on experience in exhibition preparation including: catalogue and invitation design, development of advertising/publicity, fundraising strategies, and project documentation. Three hours; one term.
ART 4EP3.prerequisites: ART 3TS3, ART 3GS3, or ART 3GS6 A/B and registration in Level IV Honours Studio Art program

ART 4PR3.name: Professional Residency
ART 4PR3.description: Students may obtain credit for a self-initiated, professional residency resulting in a portfolio equivalent to 3 units. Residency applications must be approved by a Faculty Supervisor prior to submission. Final portfolio must be submitted to the Supervisor for presentation and assessment. Students are responsible for all associated expenses.
ART 4PR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV Honours Studio Art (B.F.A.) (Effective for Students who Entered 2022-2023 and Earlier) program and departmental approval

ARTHIST 2AA3.name: Introduction to the Practice of Art Therapy
ARTHIST 2AA3.description: An introduction to the practice of art therapy, with an overview of its history, the diversity of its applications within psychodynamic, solution focused, cognitive behavioural principles, embodiment theory, and its clinical implications including neuroscience, mindfulness, Post-traumatic Stress Disorder, and pain management. Three lectures; one term.
ARTHIST 2AA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): ART 2AA3 May be offered virtually or online.

ARTHIST 2B03.name: Greek Art
ARTHIST 2B03.description: The architecture, sculpture and painting of the Greek and Hellenistic worlds. Three lectures; one term.
ARTHIST 2B03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program Cross-list(s): GKROMST 2B03
ARTHIST 2B03.antirequisites: CLASSICS 2B03 This course is administered by the Department of Greek and Roman Studies. Offered on rotation.

ARTHIST 2C03.name: Roman Art
ARTHIST 2C03.description: The architecture, sculpture and painting of the Roman world. Three lectures; one term.
ARTHIST 2C03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program Cross-list(s): GKROMST 2C03
ARTHIST 2C03.antirequisites: CLASSICS 2C03 This course is administered by the Department of Greek and Roman Studies. Offered on rotation.

ARTHIST 2DF3.name: Art and Revolutions in France, 1789-1914
ARTHIST 2DF3.description: This course examines the intersections of visual culture and the political revolutions of 1789, 1830, 1848 and 1870, as well as stylistic innovations in art including Romanticism, Realism, Impressionism, Pointillism, Fauvism, and Cubism. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ARTHIST 2DF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): HISTORY 2DF3 This course is administered by the Department of History .

ARTHIST 2FA3.name: Film Analysis
ARTHIST 2FA3.description: An introduction to an interrelated set of approaches to film study, all of which are defined by their attention to the filmic text and which provide students with a grasp of the fundamentals of film analysis. Two lectures, plus one weekly film screening; one term.
ARTHIST 2FA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): THTRFLM 2FA3 , IARTS 2FA3 This course is administered by the Theatre & Film Studies program.

ARTHIST 2H03.name: Aesthetics
ARTHIST 2H03.description: An introduction to some main theories of the nature of art, criticism and the place of art in life and society. Three lectures; one term.
ARTHIST 2H03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
ARTHIST 2H03.antirequisites: CMST 2O03 Cross-list(s): PHILOS 2H03 This course is administered by the Department of Philosophy . Offered in alternate years.

ARTHIST 2Y03.name: Performance, Art and Visual Culture in the Middle East
ARTHIST 2Y03.description: An introduction to aspects of the history of the arts and visual cultures in the Middle East, with special attention to religious and cultural diversities and with an emphasis on intercultural transmissions. Three hours (lectures and tutorial); one term.
ARTHIST 2Y03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): IARTS 2ME3 Offered on a rotational basis.

ARTHIST 2Z03.name: Performance, Art and Visual Culture in East and South Asia
ARTHIST 2Z03.description: An introduction to aspects of the history of the arts and performance in South and East Asia from antiquity to modern times, highlighting the impact of cultural exchange and diversity. Three lectures; one term.
ARTHIST 2Z03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): IARTS 2AS3 Offered on a rotational basis.

ARTHIST 3AB3.name: Applied Art History: Experiential Learning with Placement as an Intern
ARTHIST 3AB3.description: This course offers a student the opportunity of learning to research or catalogue art works in either a private or public collection, or other aspects of curatorial research, collection management, exhibition design or art education. The student-initiated internship could take place at arts institutions such as: museums, galleries, heritage sites, historical societies, and other such possibilities reviewed and approved by program faculty.
ARTHIST 3AB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of an Honours Art History Program Departmental permission required.

ARTHIST 3B03.name: Aspects of Canadian Art
ARTHIST 3B03.description: A survey of the visual arts in Canada from the earliest explorations and settlements to the present. Three lectures; three hours; one term.
ARTHIST 3B03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any program Offered on a rotational basis.

ARTHIST 3BB3.name: Indigenous Art and Visual Culture in Canada, 1960 to the Present
ARTHIST 3BB3.description: A survey of the visual art production from Indigenous Canadian communities since c. 1960 including: painting, sculpture, installation, film/video, performance and hip hop. The course focuses on First Nations’ and Métis’ artistic practices and examines how those are framed in the context of museums in the 21st century. Three hours; one term.
ARTHIST 3BB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of a program in Art History, Art or Indigenous Studies, or permission of the instructor Cross-list(s): INDIGST 3F03 Offered on a rotational basis.

ARTHIST 3DF3.name: Art and Politics in Second Empire France
ARTHIST 3DF3.description: This course examines the intersections of politics and visual culture in France 1852-1870 and critical issues related to photography, painting, sculpture, printmaking, architecture and the Universal Expositions of 1855 and 1867. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ARTHIST 3DF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
ARTHIST 3DF3.antirequisites: ARTHIST 3J03 Cross-list(s): HISTORY 3DF3 This course is administered by the Department of History .

ARTHIST 3FL3.name: Early Cinema History
ARTHIST 3FL3.description: An introduction to the history of narrative film from its beginnings to the Second World War. It focuses on narrative cinema’s development from aesthetic, social, technological and economic perspectives while also touching on a selected number of issues in film theory. Two lectures, plus one weekly film screening; one term.
ARTHIST 3FL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): THTRFLM 3FF3

ARTHIST 3P03.name: Issues in Studio Criticism
ARTHIST 3P03.description: A course that allows non-Art students to explore current studio practice and to investigate approaches to the evaluation of quality in contemporary art. Students taking this course are required to attend a preset number of Studio Critiques and Visiting Artists’ Talks.* Seminar (two hours); one term.
ARTHIST 3P03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above; and at least 12 units of Art History *Studio Art Critiques are regularly scheduled sessions during which the work of Art students is discussed by their peers, faculty members and visiting professionals from the art world. Visiting Artists’ talks are held on weekday evenings on the same day as the Studio Critiques. Offered on a rotational basis.

ARTHIST 3Q03.name: Colours of the World
ARTHIST 3Q03.description: The traditional ways of extracting colour from plants, minerals, and animals and the ways for using colour that range from 1) making art, 2) ornamenting food, clothing, housing and transportation, and 3) symbolic/ritual purposes and visual communication (for example, sexuality, theatre, and warfare) in different cultures in early times. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ARTHIST 3Q03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
ARTHIST 3Q03.antirequisites: HISTORY 3QA3 Offered on a rotational basis.

ARTHIST 3QQ3.name: Greek Sanctuaries
ARTHIST 3QQ3.description: Ancient Greek sanctuaries and their social and political context. Topics will include architecture and art, as well as activities such as sacrifice, athletic games healing and oracular consultation. Three lectures; one term.
ARTHIST 3QQ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program Cross-list(s): GKROMST 3Q03
ARTHIST 3QQ3.antirequisites: CLASSICS 3Q03 Alternates with ARTHIST 3SS3 ( GKROMST 3S03 ). This course is administered by the Department of Greek and Roman Studies.

ARTHIST 3SS3.name: Pompeii, Herculaneum, and Ostia
ARTHIST 3SS3.description: The archaeology of three cities in Italy (Pompeii, Herculaneum, Ostia) will be examined, with a focus on urbanism, public space, and domestic architecture and decoration. Three lectures; one term.
ARTHIST 3SS3.prerequisites: One of CLASSICS or GKROMST 1A03 , 2BB3 , 2CC3 , 2LC3, 2LD3 or ARTHIST 2B03 or 2C03 , and registration in Level II or above of any program Cross-list(s): GKROMST 3S03
ARTHIST 3SS3.antirequisites: CLASSICS 3S03 Alternates with ARTHIST 3QQ3 ( GKROMST 3Q03 ). This course is administered by the Department of Greek and Roman Studies.

ARTHIST 3XX3.name: Cinema History from WWII
ARTHIST 3XX3.description: An exploration of narrative film from 1941 to the present day, incorporating a study of a variety of narrative cinema styles. Theoretical issues will include questions of cinema’s relationships to other art forms, narrative, genre and authorship. Two lectures, plus one weekly film screening; one term.
ARTHIST 3XX3.prerequisites: One of ARTHIST 2FL3, ARTHIST 3FL3 , THTRFLM 2FF3 or THTRFLM 3FF3 is recommended
ARTHIST 3XX3.antirequisites: CMST 3XX3 Cross-list(s): THTRFLM 3L03 This course is administered by Theatre & Film.

ARTHIST 3Z03.name: The Silk Road Visual Cultures
ARTHIST 3Z03.description: An examination of how recent archaeological finds are changing our understanding of the pluralistic achievements in the arts accomplished by peoples of different cultures along the Silk Road at various times. Three lectures; one term.
ARTHIST 3Z03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Offered on a rotational basis.

ARTHIST 4AA3.name: Seminar in Contemporary Art and Visual Culture
ARTHIST 4AA3.description: An in-depth examination of one or more significant movements in contemporary art, theory and criticism from c. 1970 to the present. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ARTHIST 4AA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of an Honours program in Art, Art History, Classics, English & Cultural Studies, or History. Prior completion of ARTHIST 3JA3 is recommended. ARTHIST 4AA3 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units. Offered on a rotational basis.

ARTHIST 4AP3.name: Contemporary Art Practices of Intervention, Performance and Conceptual Art
ARTHIST 4AP3.description: Students will explore and develop and understanding of how 20th century provocations of Dadaism, Fluxus, and Feminist art impact and resonate with contemporary art practices in the 21st century. The course will also examine how the canon of Euro-Western art erased and de-valued work by Indigenous, Black, and Artists of Colour. Departing from a chronological approach to studying art history, the course is structured around issues and/or concepts that dynamically intersect historical and contemporary practices. The course is designed as an interdisciplinary arts-based seminar course, involving readings, lectures, and class discussions, but also field trips, arts-based activities, and collaborative experiential learning. Three hours; one term Cross-list(s): ART 4AP3 , IARTS 4AP3.
ARTHIST 4AP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of any program.

ARTHIST 4E03.name: Seminar in Art and Visual Culture 1400 - 1750
ARTHIST 4E03.description: A focused study of issues concerning art and visual culture of the Early Modern in different parts of the globalized world. Consult the School of the Arts concerning the topic to be offered. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ARTHIST 4E03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of an Honours program in Art or Art History; or permission of the department. ARTHIST 4E03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units. Offered on a rotational basis.

ARTHIST 4LP3.name: The Cultural History of Paris, 1789-1914
ARTHIST 4LP3.description: Topics to be examined include: developments in architecture and city planning; the conservation of historic buildings and monuments; cultural institutions such as museums and art exhibitions; and the impact of gender, race and economics on experiences and concepts of identity in France’s capital. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ARTHIST 4LP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of any Honours program in Art or Art History Cross-list(s): HISTORY 4LP3 Departmental permission required. This course is administered by the Department of History and students should apply using seminar ballots that will be available from the History Department following Reading Week.

ARTHIST 4U03.name: The Severe Style in Greek Art
ARTHIST 4U03.description: This course examines the birth of the Classical Greek style and its earliest manifestation, the Severe style. Sculpture, vase painting and architectural examples will be considered and placed in their appropriate political and cultural contexts. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ARTHIST 4U03.prerequisites: Nine units of ARTHIST, including ARTHIST 2B03 , or registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in Art History Cross-list(s): GKROMST 4U03
ARTHIST 4U03.antirequisites: CLASSICS 4U03 This course is administered by the Department of Greek and Roman Studies.

ARTHIST 4V03.name: The Study, Criticism and Evaluation of Art
ARTHIST 4V03.description: A seminar to introduce students to the history, theory and practice of connoisseurship. Its focus will be to develop skills in confronting the single work of art. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ARTHIST 4V03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of a program in Art or Art History, Communication Studies or Media Arts. Offered on a rotational basis.

ARTHIST 4X03.name: Introduction to Art Galleries and Museums
ARTHIST 4X03.description: A study of the history and methods of institutions created for the purpose of collecting, preserving, displaying and interpreting art objects. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ARTHIST 4X03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of a program in Art, Art History, Classics, English & Cultural Studies, or History Offered on a rotational basis.

ARTHIST 4Z03.name: The Textile Arts
ARTHIST 4Z03.description: This seminar will critically examine issues related to changes in the art and technology of textile-making and ornamentation of various cultures at different time periods: visuality, materiality, function, power, wealth, usage, taste, distribution, and gender. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ARTHIST 4Z03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of any Honours program in Art, Art History or Theatre and Film Studies Departmental permission required. Offered on a rotational basis.

ARTSSCI 1A03.name: Practices of Knowledge
ARTSSCI 1A03.description: An examination of significant themes in intellectual history through a reading of major works in philosophy and literature that shed light on the conceptual foundations of contemporary life. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 1A03.prerequisites: Registration in Level I of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 1AA3.name: Contemporary Indigenous Studies
ARTSSCI 1AA3.description: This course will explore the relationship between Indigenous peoples and mainstream society in the 20th century with regard to governmental policy, land claims, economic development, and self-determination. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 1AA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level I of the Arts & Science Program Cross-list(s): INDIGST 1AA3 This course is administered by the Indigenous Studies Department.

ARTSSCI 1B03.name: Writing
ARTSSCI 1B03.description: This course aims to develop students’ ability to use language in written communication, with a focus on academic writing in particular. Students will develop their writing skills through assignments and activities that ask them to produce, analyze and reflect on written work in a range of genres. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 1B03.prerequisites: Registration in Level I of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 1BB3.name: Argumentation
ARTSSCI 1BB3.description: This course provides students with some of the conceptual tools needed to recognize, understand, evaluate, formulate, and attack arguments. Students will have the opportunity to develop such skills in their oral and written work. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 1BB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level I of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 2E03.name: Economics: Principles and Policy
ARTSSCI 2E03.description: An introduction to the core principles of economics with the objective of helping students to apply economic reasoning to issues that are central to modern societies, such as: the role of government in a market-oriented setting; equity and efficiency; growth and the environment; and fiscal and monetary stability. Lectures (three hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
ARTSSCI 2E03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 2R03.name: Applied Statistical Inference
ARTSSCI 2R03.description: Inferential statistics, with an emphasis on applications. Topics include data description, graphical methods, probability, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, one-way ANOVA, analysis of categorical data, regression and correlation. Use of a statistics software package. Lectures (three hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
ARTSSCI 2R03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 3B03.name: Technology and Society I
ARTSSCI 3B03.description: The Culture of Technology. Technological practices and approaches are studied as cultural activities in the contexts of beliefs, philosophies, values and social structures both past and present. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 3B03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 3BB3.name: Technology and Society II
ARTSSCI 3BB3.description: The Social Control of Technology. The dominant mechanisms of the social control of technology will be studied, with attention to the role of ethics. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 3BB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 3C03.name: Coding Inquiry
ARTSSCI 3C03.description: This course focuses on computer programming as both a technical and a social practice. Students will have an opportunity to learn and apply basic coding skills; to consider the intersections between coding and user experience; and to explore ways in which software design might contribute to addressing (or exacerbating) social challenges. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 3C03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 3CL3.name: Theatre, Self, and Social Development
ARTSSCI 3CL3.description: Theatre skills are life skills. Class exercises, creative work, and online discussions will allow students to explore the practice and ethics of Applied Drama and to learn how theatre can be used as a tool for social development and change. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 3CL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 3CU3.name: Alumni Experience Inquiry
ARTSSCI 3CU3.description: Using an inquiry methodology, students will explore the practical applications of an interdisciplinary degree through interaction with, and mentorship from, graduates of the Arts & Science Program. Emphasis will be on problem-based learning, with the professional experiences of alumni informing the exploration of complex and multifaceted issues. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 3CU3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 3DS1.name: Deep Skills Development
ARTSSCI 3DS1.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of the Arts & Science Program This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis.

ARTSSCI 3EH3.name: Exploring Hamilton Inquiry
ARTSSCI 3EH3.description: This course encourages students to ask questions and explore topics focused on the City of Hamilton, Ontario. Through the exploration of Hamilton from a number of disciplinary perspectives, including cultural, economic, and geological, students will have an opportunity to gain insight into the city that McMaster University calls home. This course will include excursions during class time and may require small fees for travel. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 3EH3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of the Arts & Science Program .

ARTSSCI 3F03.name: Experiential Project in Teaching and Learning
ARTSSCI 3F03.description: This course allows students to explore in depth an issue related to teaching and learning in higher education under the supervision of faculty/staff affiliated with the Paul R. MacPherson Institute for Leadership, Innovation and Excellence in Teaching (MacPherson Institute). Students may propose research questions of their own or contribute to the development of existing initiatives within the Institute. Proposal form and deadlines are available on the Arts & Science Program website https://artsci.mcmaster.ca . One term.
ARTSSCI 3F03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of the Arts & Science Program and permission of the Arts & Science Program.

ARTSSCI 3GJ3.name: Global Justice Inquiry
ARTSSCI 3GJ3.description: Using an inquiry methodology, students will explore issues pertaining to global justice through an interdisciplinary lens. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 3GJ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above

ARTSSCI 3RL3.name: Religion and Law
ARTSSCI 3RL3.description: The notion of law has deep roots in religious thought and writing. This course will survey the historical development of law in the western world in connection with various religious traditions, with a focus on Judaism and Christianity. It will also address some contemporary issues and tensions between religion and law in pluralistic, secular societies. Three hours (lecture and discussion); one term.
ARTSSCI 3RL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III and above of the Arts & Science Program Cross-list(s): SCAR 3RL3 This course is administered by the Department of Religious Studies.

ARTSSCI 3S03.name: The East Asian Religious Tradition
ARTSSCI 3S03.description: Readings of East Asian texts in translation will centre around themes such as culture vs. nature, virtue vs. power, social responsibility vs. personal cultivation, bookish learning vs. meditation. Lecture (two hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
ARTSSCI 3S03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III and above of the Arts & Science Program Cross-list(s): SCAR 3S03
ARTSSCI 3S03.antirequisites: RELIGST 3S03 This course is administered by the Department of Religious Studies.

ARTSSCI 3TR3.name: Trees and Their Histories
ARTSSCI 3TR3.description: Inspired by the trees on McMaster’s campus, this course examines trees and their significance in history and the present through multiple lenses including: biology; colonial and economic histories; visual, material, and performing arts practices; indigenous and environmental studies; poetry, prose, and psychology. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 3TR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of the Arts & Science Program Cross-list(s): HISTORY 3TR3 This course is administered by the Department of History.

ARTSSCI 3X03.name: Individual Study
ARTSSCI 3X03.description: This course consists of study under the supervision of a McMaster faculty member. Proposal form and deadlines are available on the Arts & Science Program website https://artsci.mcmaster.ca . One term.
ARTSSCI 3X03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III and above of the Arts & Science Program and permission of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 4CB3.name: Education Inquiry
ARTSSCI 4CB3.description: Students will have the opportunity in this course to use an inquiry-based approach to focus on social, cultural, political, and economic issues that influence and are influenced by education. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 4CB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 4CD3.name: Research and Creative Writing
ARTSSCI 4CD3.description: The course exposes students to creative writing that is grounded in research. It also invites students to explore ways in which research findings might be disseminated through creative expression. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 4CD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of the Arts & Science Program.

ARTSSCI 4CF3.name: How Science Speaks to Power
ARTSSCI 4CF3.description: A case study approach is used to examine how science is shaped by politics and how science advice is filtered by political processes. Possible case studies include Mad Cow disease, the ozone hole, and genetically modified foods. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 4CF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of the Arts & Science Program or an Honours Biology program.

ARTSSCI 4CI3.name: Diversity and Human Rights Inquiry
ARTSSCI 4CI3.description: This course explores issues of diversity and the role of human rights protection regimes in both Canadian and international contexts. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 4CI3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 4CP3.name: Media Inquiry
ARTSSCI 4CP3.description: This course consists of four sections dealing with theoretical and analytical perspectives, political economy of the media, news media, and entertainment media and their cultural effects. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 4CP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 4CT3.name: Medical Humanities Inquiry
ARTSSCI 4CT3.description: This course exposes students to the rapidly developing international field known as medical humanities. It explores the interconnections between health, medicine, the arts, and the humanities, with a particular focus on issues of medical ethics and narrative in medicine. Three hours; one term.
ARTSSCI 4CT3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of the Arts & Science Program

ARTSSCI 4DS3.name: Digital Society and Public Policy
