COMPSCI 3IS3.description: Basic principles of information security; threats and defences; cryptography; introduction to network security and security management. Three lectures; one term.
COMPSCI 3IS3.prerequisites: COMPSCI 2AC3 or 2FA3 or SFWRENG 2FA3 , and COMPSCI 2C03 or SFWRENG 2C03 Offered on an irregular basis.

COMPSCI 3MI3.name: Principles of Programming Languages
COMPSCI 3MI3.description: Principles of definition of and reasoning about programming languages and domain-specific languages; use of semantics for interpretation and in program analyses for correctness, security and efficiency. Three lectures; one tutorial (one hour); first term.
COMPSCI 3MI3.prerequisites: COMPSCI 2C03 , and COMPSCI 2LC3 or 2DM3, and COMPSCI 2AC3 or 2FA3, and COMPSCI 2ME3

COMPSCI 3N03.name: Computer Networks and Security
COMPSCI 3N03.description: Physical networks, TCP/IP protocols, switching methods, network layering and components, network services. Information security, computer and network security threats, defence mechanisms, encryption. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); second term.

COMPSCI 3RA3.name: Software Requirements and Security Considerations
COMPSCI 3RA3.description: Software requirements gathering. Critical systems requirements gathering. Security requirements. Traceability of requirements. Verification, validation, and documentation techniques. Software requirements quality attributes. Security policies. Measures for data confidentiality. Design principles that enhance security. Access control mechanisms. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.

COMPSCI 3SH3.name: Computer Science Practice and Experience: Operating Systems
COMPSCI 3SH3.description: Processes and threads, synchronization and communication; scheduling, memory management; file systems; resource protection; structure of operating systems. Two lectures, one tutorial, two labs (one hour each); first term.

COMPSCI 3TB3.name: Syntax-Based Tools and Compilers
COMPSCI 3TB3.description: Lexical analysis, syntax analysis, type checking; syntax-directed translation, attribute grammars; compiler structure; implications of computer architecture; mapping of programming language concepts; code generation and optimization. Two lectures, one tutorial, two labs (one hour each); second term.
COMPSCI 3TB3.prerequisites: COMPSCI 2C03 or SFWRENG 2C03, and COMPSCI 2GA3 or SFWRENG 2GA3 or 3GA3, and COMPSCI 2AC3 or 2FA3 or SFWRENG 2FA3, and COMPSCI 3MI3 or registration in Level IV or above of a Software Engineering program

COMPSCI 4AD3.name: Advanced Databases
COMPSCI 4AD3.description: Advanced topics in database systems technology and design. Topics include: query processing; query optimization; data storage; indexing; crash recovery; physical database design; introductory data mining techniques. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
COMPSCI 4AD3.antirequisites: SFWRENG 4AD3 Cross-list(s): SFWRENG 4AD3 Offered on an irregular basis.

COMPSCI 4AR3.name: Software Architecture
COMPSCI 4AR3.description: Software architecture concepts; architectural styles; design patterns, components, libraries, configurations; modelling languages; software re-engineering. Three lectures; one term.
COMPSCI 4AR3.prerequisites: Credit or registration in COMPSCI 3RA3 or 3SR3 Offered on an irregular basis.

COMPSCI 4C03.name: Computer Networks and Security
COMPSCI 4C03.description: Physical networks, TCP/IP protocols, switching methods, network layering and components, network services. Information security, computer and network security threats, defence mechanisms, encryption. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); second term.
COMPSCI 4C03.prerequisites: Credit or registration in COMPSCI 3MH3 or COMPSCI 3SH3

COMPSCI 4DC3.name: Distributed Computing
COMPSCI 4DC3.description: Models of distributed computation, formal reasoning about distributed systems, time and message complexity, distributed agreement under adversarial attacks, distributed coordination and symmetry breaking, peer-to-peer computing, simulation as a tool for building more advanced functionality, actor-model programming. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
COMPSCI 4DC3.prerequisites: One of COMPSCI 2C03 or SFWRENG 2C03 or SFWRENG 2MD3, and one of COMPSCI 2SD3 or 3SD3 or SFWRENG 3BB4 or SFWRENG 3SH3 Offered on an irregular basis.

COMPSCI 4E03.name: Performance Analysis of Computer Systems
COMPSCI 4E03.description: Use of queuing models and simulation to predict computer system performance and find bottlenecks in a system. Types of models, distributions. Markov models. Modelling storage and network behaviour, locks, critical sections, concurrency. Introduction to analytical system reliability. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); second term.

COMPSCI 4EN3.name: Software Entrepreneurship
COMPSCI 4EN3.description: Issues in starting up a new software enterprise, with the focus on independent startups. This course will cover the technical, financial, legal and operational issues encountered by software startups. Small groups of students will take an idea and turn it into a prototype, a business plan, and a sales pitch. Lectures will cover issues from team formation to appropriate software development processes to patent protection to venture capital. Three lectures; one term.
COMPSCI 4EN3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Computer Science program Offered on an irregular basis.

COMPSCI 4F03.name: Parallel Computing
COMPSCI 4F03.description: Parallel architectures, design and analysis of parallel algorithms; distributed-memory, shared-memory and GPU computing; communication cost, scalability; MPI, OpenMP and OpenACC; tuning parallel programs for performance. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.
COMPSCI 4F03.prerequisites: COMPSCI 2SD3 or credit or registration in COMPSCI 3SD3. Completion of COMPSCI 3N03 or 4C03 is recommended.
COMPSCI 4F03.antirequisites: SFWRENG 4F03 ; not open for students in a Computer Science program. Cross-list(s): SFWRENG 4F03 Offered on an irregular basis.

COMPSCI 4FP3.name: Functional Programming
COMPSCI 4FP3.description: A selection of topics in advanced functional programming (focusing on Haskell and its derivatives). Example topics: Techniques for embedded domain-specific languages, generic and type-level programming, reasoning about programs, and (co)effects. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.
COMPSCI 4FP3.prerequisites: COMPSCI 1JC3 or SFWRENG 3FP3, COMPSCI 1XC3 or SFWRENG 2S03 or SFWRENG 2XC3, COMPSCI 2C03 or SFWRENG 2C03, COMPSCI 2LC3 or 2DM3 or SFWRENG 2DM3, COMPSCI 2ME3 or SFWRENG 2AA4
COMPSCI 4FP3.antirequisites: COMPSCI 3FP3 Offered on an irregular basis.

COMPSCI 4HC3.name: Human Computer Interfaces
COMPSCI 4HC3.description: Design of user interfaces. Principles of good interface design. Task-oriented design. User experience design. Inclusive design. Communicating with graphics. Modes and mode awareness problem. Human cognition (memory, perception, motor systems). Help systems. Interface design tools. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.

COMPSCI 4ML3.name: Introduction to Machine Learning
COMPSCI 4ML3.description: Regression, Classification and Decision Theory, Bias-Variance Trade-off, Linear Models, Kernel Methods, Probabilistic Models, Neural Networks, Model Aggregation, Unsupervised Learning. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
COMPSCI 4ML3.prerequisites: One of COMPSCI 2C03 or SFWRENG 2C03 or SFWRENG 2MD3. One of STATS 1L03, STATS 2D03, STATS 3Y03, IBEHS 4C03. One of COMPSCI 4O03 or 4TE3 or 4X03 or SFWRENG 3O03 or 4TE3 or 4X03 is recommended.
COMPSCI 4ML3.antirequisites: COMPENG 4SL3, 4SL4 Offered on an irregular basis.

COMPSCI 4O03.name: Linear Optimization
COMPSCI 4O03.description: Modelling and solutions for engineering and science problems using linear optimization, including networks, transportation, assignment, and scheduling problems. Solution methods include combinatorial algorithms such as simplex methods, primal-dual formulations, branch and bound formulations for mixed integer programming, and heuristics. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); first term.

COMPSCI 4TB3.name: Syntax-Based Tools and Compilers
COMPSCI 4TB3.description: Lexical analysis, syntax analysis, type checking; syntax-directed translation, attribute grammars; compiler structure; implications of computer architecture; mapping of programming language concepts; code generation and optimization. Two lectures, one tutorial, two labs (one hour each); second term.
COMPSCI 4TB3.prerequisites: COMPSCI 2C03 or SFWRENG 2C03 , and COMPSCI 2GA3 or SFWRENG 2GA3 or 3GA3, and COMPSCI 2AC3 or 2FA3 or SFWRENG 2FA3 , and COMPSCI 3MI3 or registration in Level IV or above of a Software Engineering program Last offered 2022-2023.

COMPSCI 4TE3.name: Continuous Optimization
COMPSCI 4TE3.description: Fundamental algorithms and duality concepts of continuous optimization. Motivation, applicability, information requirements and computational cost of the algorithms is discussed. Practical problems will illustrate the power of continuous optimization techniques. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.

COMPSCI 4TH3.name: Theory of Computation
COMPSCI 4TH3.description: Formal languages, models of computation, decidability, reduction techniques, time and space complexity classes. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.
COMPSCI 4TH3.antirequisites: SFWRENG 4TH3 Cross-list(s): SFWRENG 4TH3 Offered on an irregular basis.

COMPSCI 4TI3.name: Fundamentals of Image Processing
COMPSCI 4TI3.description: Discrete-time signals and systems, digital filter design, photons to pixels, linear filtering, edge-detection, non-linear filtering, multi-scale transforms, motion estimation. Three lectures; one term.
COMPSCI 4TI3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a program offered by the Department of Computing and Software Offered on an irregular basis.

COMPSCI 4WW3.name: Web Systems and Web Computing
COMPSCI 4WW3.description: Network protocols underlying the world wide web; client-side programming: markup, styles, scripts, design, mobile/desktop; server-side programming: databases, dynamic languages; web services; cloud technologies; security. Three lectures; one term.
COMPSCI 4WW3.prerequisites: COMPSCI 2ME3 or SFWRENG 2AA4 ; completion of COMPSCI 2DB3 or 2DB3 , 3IS3 , or 3N03 or 4C03 is recommended. Offered on an irregular basis.

COMPSCI 4X03.name: Scientific Computation
COMPSCI 4X03.description: Computer arithmetic, stability, sensitivity. Numerical methods for polynomial manipulation, interpolation, data fitting, integration, differentiation, solving linear and non-linear systems, ordinary differential equations and eigenvalue problems. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.
COMPSCI 4X03.prerequisites: MATH 1AA3 or 1ZB3, and MATH 1B03 or 1ZC3. One of MATH 2C03 or 2Z03 is recommended.

COMPSCI 4Z03.name: Directed Readings
COMPSCI 4Z03.description: Directed readings in an area of computer science of interest to the student and the instructor.
COMPSCI 4Z03.prerequisites: Departmental permission, and registration in Level IV of an Honours program in Computer Science

CHALLENG 2CC3.name: Engineering and Science for Humanity’s Critical Challenges
CHALLENG 2CC3.description: Explores the role of engineering and science in addressing four critical challenges for humanity: energy sources for the future; climate change; deployment of artificial intelligence and biotechnology; and confronting the prospects of nuclear war and high-impact pandemics. Three lectures; first term.
CHALLENG 2CC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

DATASCI 2G03.name: Scientific Computing
DATASCI 2G03.description: A hands-on introduction to modern scientific structured programming using standard C/C++ under Linux. Assumes no prior programming experience. Students develop a programming project on a research topic of their choosing (e.g. living populations, disease simulation, dynamics, economics). The course covers programming fundamentals, floating point and number representation and introduces algorithms and numerical methods. Class discussions include topics such as scripting, web content, objects/classes, graphics and parallel programming, according to student interest. Students are required to have a laptop for in-class work. Two lectures, two labs; one term.
DATASCI 2G03.prerequisites: One of ARTSSCI 1D06 A/B, ISCI 1A24 A/B, MATH 1A03, 1LS3, 1X03, 1ZA3
DATASCI 2G03.antirequisites: PHYSICS 2G03 This course is administered by the Department of Physics and Astronomy.

DATASCI 3ML3.name: Introduction to Neural Networks and Machine Learning
DATASCI 3ML3.description: A practical introduction to neural network algorithms and their applications in machine learning using Python. Supervised learning (logistic regression, perceptrons, classification, trees, cost functions, non-linear regression, boosting) and unsupervised learning (autoencoder, principal component analysis, clustering, k-means) will be discussed. Students will conduct a series of projects to explore topics such as optimization, spam classification, image recognition, fraud detection and medical data analysis. Three lectures; one term.
DATASCI 3ML3.prerequisites: One of COMPSCI 1MD3, DATASCI 2G03, MATH 1MP3, PHYSICS 2G03; one of MATH 1B03, 1ZC3; and one of ARTSSCI 1D06 A/B, ISCI 1A24 A/B, MATH 1AA3, 1LT3, 1XX3, 1ZB3; or permission of the instructor
DATASCI 3ML3.antirequisites: PHYSICS 3G03 This course is administered by the Department of Physics and Astronomy.

DATASCI 4X03.name: Data Analysis Project Course
DATASCI 4X03.description: A project-based course covering the basics of modern scientific data acquisition, mining and analysis. Students will complete a series of projects in data analysis using experimental data covering topics such as the fundamentals of image reduction and analysis, time-series analysis and spectroscopy. Lectures, laboratory/tutorial; one term.
DATASCI 4X03.prerequisites: One of COMPSCI 1MD3, DATASCI 2G03, MATH 1MP3, PHYSICS 2G03; and registration in Level III or above in a program in the Faculty of Science.
DATASCI 4X03.antirequisites: ASTRON 4X03 May be offered in alternate years. This course is administered by the Department of Physics and Astronomy.

EARTHSC 1G03.name: Earth and the Environment
EARTHSC 1G03.description: An introduction to Earth’s composition and processes including topics such as rocks, fossils, plate tectonics, earthquakes, volcanoes, and glaciers. We will consider the interactions between people and Earth’s environments and the implications for sustainable development. Two field trips will be held during regular lab periods. Three lectures, one lab (two hours); one term Antirequisite(s): ENVIRSC 1G03.

EARTHSC 2E03.name: Earth History
EARTHSC 2E03.description: Geological evolution of the Earth and paleontological evidence for the evolution of marine life, with emphasis on the geological history of North America. Students enrolling in this course must purchase a field kit available through the School of Earth, Environment & Society. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.

EARTHSC 2FE3.name: Introduction to Field Methods in Earth Sciences
EARTHSC 2FE3.description: A field camp to introduce students to field equipment and methodologies used by earth and environmental scientists focusing on recognition and description of rock types, construction of geological maps and cross-sections. Most of this course occurs outside the regular academic term, usually the first two weeks of May; details and applications are available in January. Students enrolling in this course must pay both the incidental fees as prescribed by the School of Earth, Environment & Society and the regular tuition fees. Students intending to enrol in this course must submit an application by February 15 of the academic year prior to registration. Application forms are available from the School of Earth, Environment & Society main office after January 15. Students will be informed of acceptance of their application by March 1 subject to fulfillment of the requirements.
EARTHSC 2FE3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 1G03 , ENVIRSC 1G03, ISCI 1A24 A/B ; and permission of the instructor

EARTHSC 2G03.name: Earth Surface Process
EARTHSC 2G03.description: An introductory geomorphology course outlining the major landscape features on the Earth’s surface and the processes that lead to their formation through gravity, water, wind, and ice. A local field trip will be held during regular lab hours. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.

EARTHSC 2GG3.name: Natural Disasters
EARTHSC 2GG3.description: A study of natural processes including plate tectonics, earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides, river erosion and climate change and their impacts on human populations. Lectures (three hours); one term.
EARTHSC 2GG3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above This course may be offered in-person or virtually. Students are encouraged to check scheduling information and the course outline to confirm the course offering details.

EARTHSC 2K03.name: Optical Crystallography and Mineralogy
EARTHSC 2K03.description: Introduction to crystallography, optical theory, and the polarizing microscope. Identification of minerals in igneous and sedimentary rocks and discussion of their structure and chemistry. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
EARTHSC 2K03.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 1G03 , ENVIRSC 1G03, ISCI 1A24 A/B

EARTHSC 2T03.name: Geology of Canada
EARTHSC 2T03.description: Description and understanding of the tectonic processes involved in the development and evolution of the Precambrian rocks of Canada. Students enrolling in this course must purchase a field kit available through the School of Earth, Environment & Society. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
EARTHSC 2T03.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 1G03 , ENVIRSC 1G03, ISCI 1A24 A/B

EARTHSC 3CC3.name: Earth’s Changing Climate
EARTHSC 3CC3.description: The earth’s climatic history including natural causes of past climate change and human influences on climate will be explored. Lectures (three hours); one term.
EARTHSC 3CC3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2C03, 2E03 , 2Q03, ENVIRSC 2C03 , 2E03, 2Q03 , ISCI 2A18 A/B ; and registration in Level III or above

EARTHSC 3E03.name: Sedimentary Environments
EARTHSC 3E03.description: Sedimentary processes, stratigraphy and depositional environments of clastic and carbonate systems. A mandatory local field trip will be included. Three lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
EARTHSC 3E03.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2E03, ENVIRSC 2E03, ISCI 2A18 A/B

EARTHSC 3FE3.name: Field Camp
EARTHSC 3FE3.description: A field camp to introduce students to field equipment and methodologies used by earth and environmental scientists. Most of this course occurs outside the regular academic term, usually the two weeks preceding the start of term in September; details and applications are available in March. Students enrolling in this course must pay both the incidental fees as prescribed by the School of Earth, Environment & Society and the regular tuition fees. Students intending to enrol in this course must submit an application by April 1 of the academic year prior to registration. Application forms are available from the School of Earth, Environment & Society main office after March 1. Students will be informed of acceptance of their application by April 15 subject to fulfillment of the requirements.
EARTHSC 3FE3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2E03 , ENVIRSC 2E03, ISCI 2A18 A/B ; and EARTHSC 2T03 ; and registration in Level III or above of Honours Earth and Environmental Sciences; and permission of the instructor

EARTHSC 3K03.name: Petrology
EARTHSC 3K03.description: Introduction to igneous and metamorphic petrology, including thin section examination of rock suites, use of phase diagrams in petrology, and discussion of petrogenesis. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.

EARTHSC 3P03.name: Paleoecology
EARTHSC 3P03.description: Fossil communities and their past environmental interactions. Methods in paleoecology and aspects of the major invertebrate fossil groups will be examined. One mandatory two-day long fieldtrip will occur on a weekend during the term. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
EARTHSC 3P03.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2E03, ENVIRSC 2E03, ISCI 2A18 A/B

EARTHSC 3RD3.name: Research Design and Dissemination in Earth and Environmental Sciences
EARTHSC 3RD3.description: Review of approaches to the formulation of research questions, and to the gathering and interpretation of evidence, using a variety of environmental and earth sciences-based topics. The course includes the formulation of a research proposal, and develops skills in the communication of research results. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); one term.
EARTHSC 3RD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of an Honours B.Sc. program in the School of Earth, Environment & Society (Faculty of Science)

EARTHSC 3V03.name: Environmental Geophysics
EARTHSC 3V03.description: Introduction to principles and applications of geophysics in groundwater and environmental investigations. Practical demonstrations in magnetics, gravity, shallow seismic, radar, borehole logging, surface EM and electrical methods. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
EARTHSC 3V03.prerequisites: EARTHSC 2E03 or ENVIRSC 2E03; and one of PHYSICS 1A03 , 1C03 ; or ISCI 2A18 A/B

EARTHSC 3W03.name: Physical Hydrogeology
EARTHSC 3W03.description: Mechanisms and processes of water movement in the subsurface including the saturated zone (groundwater) and the unsaturated zone (soil water). Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
EARTHSC 3W03.prerequisites: One of CIVENG 2J04, EARTHSC 2B03, 2W03, ENVIRSC 2B03 , 2W03 ; and one of ISCI 1A24 A/B , MATH 1A03 , 1B03 , 1K03 , 1LS3 , 1M03, 1N03, 1ZA3

EARTHSC 3Z03.name: Structural Geology
EARTHSC 3Z03.description: Introduction to mapping and geometric description of geologic structures and analysis of stress and strain in the subsurface. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
EARTHSC 3Z03.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2E03 , 2T03 , ENVIRSC 2E03, ISCI 2A18 A/B . Completion of PHYSICS 1A03 (or 1C03 ) is strongly recommended.

EARTHSC 4CC3.name: Stable Isotopes in Earth and Environmental Systems
EARTHSC 4CC3.description: Stable isotopes are widely used in modern earth and environmental sciences because of their unique chemical properties that enable us to trace past and current environmental processes. This course will discuss the basic principles of stable isotope geochemistry and their applications to paleo and modern climate and environmental reconstruction. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
EARTHSC 4CC3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2Q03, 3CC3 , ENVIRSC 2Q03 , 3CC3. One of EARTHSC 2E03 , ENVIRSC 2E03, ISCI 2A18 A/B is strongly recommended. Co-requisite(s): WHMIS 1A00 , if not already completed, must be completed prior to the first lab.

EARTHSC 4FF3.name: Topics of Field Research
EARTHSC 4FF3.description: Selected topics in field research in the environmental and earth sciences. Topics may vary from year to year, and the timing of the course will depend on the destination. Details will be posted in the School. Students enrolling in this course must pay the incidental fees, as prescribed by the School of Earth, Environment & Society, and the regular tuition fees. Students intending to enrol in this course must submit an application by April 1 of the academic year prior to registration. Application forms are available from the School of Earth, Environment & Society main office after March 1. Students will be informed of acceptance of their application by April 15 subject to fulfillment of the requirements. Two lectures (one hour); one term.
EARTHSC 4FF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of an Honours B.Sc. program and permission of the instructor
EARTHSC 4FF3.antirequisites: ENVIRSC 4FF3 EARTH SC 4FF3 may be repeated, if on a different topic, with the permission of the School of Earth, Environment & Society.

EARTHSC 4G03.name: Glacial Sediments and Environments
EARTHSC 4G03.description: The development and movement of glaciers, glacial depositional processes and sedimentary successions in terrestrial, lacustrine and marine environments. A mandatory one day, local field trip will be included. Students enrolling in this course must pay both the incidental fees as prescribed by the School of Earth, Environment & Society and the regular tuition fees. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); one term.

EARTHSC 4PA3.name: Paleoenvironmental Analysis
EARTHSC 4PA3.description: Reconstructing past environmental change using sediment archives in lakes and ocean basins. Practical aspects of reconstructing anthropogenic and climate change including age dating, lithological, biological and geochemical proxies. One mandatory day-long fieldtrip will occur on a weekend during the term. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
EARTHSC 4PA3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2E03, EARTHSC 2G03, ENVIRSC 2E03, ISCI 2A18 A/B Priority will be given to students in an Honours Earth & Environmental Sciences program or an Honours Environmental Sciences program.

EARTHSC 4T03.name: Plate Tectonics and Ore Deposits
EARTHSC 4T03.description: Synthesis of plate tectonics, with application to crustal evolution and genesis of ore deposits. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); one term.
EARTHSC 4T03.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2E03 , ENVIRSC 2E03, ISCI 2A18 A/B . EARTHSC 2K03 and EARTHSC 2T03 are strongly recommended.

EARTHSC 4V03.name: Exploration Geophysics
EARTHSC 4V03.description: Advanced geophysical mapping and modelling; applications in environmental geosciences and resource exploration. Selected topics in gravity, magnetic, electromagnetic, and seismic field data acquisition and interpretation. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
EARTHSC 4V03.prerequisites: EARTH 2E03 or ENVIRSC 2E03; and one of EARTHSC 3V03 or EARTHSC 4VV3

EARTHSC 4WB3.name: Contaminant Hydrogeology
EARTHSC 4WB3.description: Physical and chemical aspects of the fate and transport of contaminants in soils and groundwater, including fundamental processes, multiphase flow and groundwater remediation. One lecture (two hours), one lab (two hours); one term.
EARTHSC 4WB3.prerequisites: Credit or registration in EARTHSC 3W03 or ENVIRSC 3W03

ECON 1B03.name: Introductory Microeconomics
ECON 1B03.description: An introduction to the method and theory of microeconomics, and their application to the analysis of contemporary economic problems. In-class and online; one term Antirequisite(s): ARTSSCI 2E03 , ECON 1BX3 ECON 1B03 and ECON 1BB3 can be taken in either order or concurrently.

ECON 1BB3.name: Introductory Macroeconomics
ECON 1BB3.description: An introduction to the method and theory of macroeconomics, and their application to the analysis of contemporary economic problems. In-class and online; one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): ARTSSCI 2E03 Cross-list(s): ECON 1BA3 ECON 1B03 and 1BB3 can be taken in either order or concurrently.

ECON 1ME3.name: Introduction to Mathematical Economics
ECON 1ME3.description: This course is an introduction to mathematical and statistical methods applied in economics. It will improve the mathematical skills required to study intermediate economic theories and analyze economic data. Topics include partial derivatives, optimization, basic probability and statistics, and linear algebra. The mathematical results are illustrated through fundamental economic applications. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
ECON 1ME3.prerequisites: Registration in Economics I; Registration in Social Sciences 1 or Honours Health and Society I and completion of Grade 12 Calculus or MATH 1F03

ECON 2A03.name: Economics of Labour-Market Issues
ECON 2A03.description: This course applies economic analysis to issues of importance in the labour market. Topics vary and may include: women in the Canadian labour market; discrimination in hiring and promotion; unemployment; job loss and workplace closing; work sharing. Three lectures; one term.
ECON 2A03.prerequisites: One of ECON 1B03, 1BX3 and one of ECON 1BB3, 1BA3; or ARTSSCI 2E03 Cross-list(s): WORKLABR 3A03

ECON 2B03.name: Analysis of Economic Data
ECON 2B03.description: Application of statistical concepts to the analysis of economic data, with attention to Canadian sources. Regression analysis and the use of spreadsheets are included. Topics may also include index numbers. Three lectures; one term.
ECON 2B03.prerequisites: One of ECON 1B03, 1BX3 and one of ECON 1BB3, 1BA3; or ARTSSCI 2E03; and one of ECON 1ME3, COMMERCE 1DA3, STATS 1L03, STATS 1LL3, or Grade 12 Mathematics of Data Management U, or permission of the department

ECON 2CC3.name: Health Economics and its Application to Health Policy
ECON 2CC3.description: Economic analysis of health and health care, with a special emphasis on policy issues in the Canadian health care system. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
ECON 2CC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

ECON 2D03.name: Economic Issues
ECON 2D03.description: Applications of economics to important public issues, from a general interest perspective. Since topics vary from year to year, interested students should consult the Economics Department for further details. Three lectures; one term.
ECON 2D03.prerequisites: One of ECON 1B03 , 1BX3 and one of ECON 1BB3 , 1BA3; or ARTSSCI 2E03

ECON 2H03.name: Intermediate Macroeconomics I
ECON 2H03.description: Determinants of national income, employment, the rate of interest and the price level; introduction to the open economy. Three lectures; one term.
ECON 2H03.prerequisites: One of ECON 1BB3 , 1BA3, or ARTSSCI 2E03 ; and one of MATH 1K03 or Grade 12 Advanced Functions U. Students without credit in one of MATH 1F03 , 1M03, Grade 12 Calculus and Vectors U (or Grade 12 Advanced Functions and Introductory Calculus U) or equivalent are strongly advised to register in MATH 1F03 or MATH 1M03, 1MM3 concurrently with ECON 2H03.

ECON 2HH3.name: Intermediate Macroeconomics II
ECON 2HH3.description: This course uses macroeconomic theory based on microeconomic underpinnings to study common topics including business cycles, growth and financial crises. Three lectures; one term.
ECON 2HH3.prerequisites: ECON 2H03; and one of ECON 1ME3, MATH 1F03, 1M03, 1MM3, Grade 12 Calculus and Vectors U (or Grade 12 Advanced Functions and Introductory Calculus U) or equivalent

ECON 2I03.name: Financial Economics
ECON 2I03.description: Detailed investigation of the financial sector. Topics include the role of capital markets in facilitating investment and growth, bond markets, stock markets, financial statements and taxation. Three lectures; one term.
ECON 2I03.prerequisites: One of ECON 1B03, 1BX3 and one of ECON 1BB3, 1BA3; or ARTSSCI 2E03

ECON 2J03.name: Environmental Economics
ECON 2J03.description: Allocation of environmental services: efficiency and market failure; measuring environmental benefits; environmental regulation in Canada and elsewhere: taxes, tradable permits and other instruments; further topics. Three lectures; one term.

ECON 2K03.name: Economic History of Canada
ECON 2K03.description: A survey of the changing structure of the Canadian economy from the colonial period to the present; early significance of primary production for export markets; emerging domestic markets and industrialization; government’s role in promoting the development of the national economy. Fully online; one term.
ECON 2K03.prerequisites: ECON 1B03 (or 1BX3) and one of ECON 1BB3, 1BA3; or ARTSSCI 2E03

ECON 2N03.name: Public Policy Toward Business
ECON 2N03.description: The economic effects of federal competition policy and the regulation of business by all levels of government. Three lectures; one term.

ECON 2P03.name: Economics of Professional Sports
ECON 2P03.description: The application of economic principles to team and individual professional sports. Theory of sports leagues, demand for sports, the market for athletes, broadcasting rights, competition policy issues, the public finance aspects of stadium financing. Fully online; one term.

ECON 2Q03.name: Economics of Bad Behaviour
ECON 2Q03.description: This course will apply economic principles to analyze human behaviour. Topics include ‘bad’ behaviour on the part of individuals, firms, and society. Fully on-line; one term.
ECON 2Q03.prerequisites: One of ECON 1B03, 1BX3 and one of ECON 1BB3, 1BA3; or ARTSSCI 2E03

ECON 2T03.name: Economics of Trade Unionism and Labour
ECON 2T03.description: Topics include the economics of the labour market, of trade unionism, of work, the impact of trade unions on the labour market, economic theories of strikes and trade unions and the state. Three lectures; one term.
ECON 2T03.prerequisites: One of ECON 1B03, 1BX3 and one of ECON 1BB3, 1BA3; or ARTSSCI 2E03 Cross-list(s): WORKLABR 3B03

ECON 2Z03.name: Intermediate Microeconomics I
ECON 2Z03.description: Theory of consumer choice; elements of production and cost; price and output determination in perfectly competitive markets. Two lectures; one tutorial; one term.
ECON 2Z03.prerequisites: One of ECON 1B03 (or 1BX3), 1BA3 (or 1BB3), or ARTSSCI 2E03; and credit or registration in ECON 1ME3, or one of MATH 1A03, 1LS3, or 1M03 or 1MM3 (or equivalent such as ARTSSCI 1D06 A/B, MATH 1N03, 1X03, 1Z04, or 1ZA3)

ECON 2ZZ3.name: Intermediate Microeconomics II
ECON 2ZZ3.description: Firm and consumer behaviour in imperfectly competitive markets and the markets for factors of production; the role of taxes and subsidies; theory of exchange, welfare economics and general equilibrium analysis. May include other special topics. Three lectures; one term.
ECON 2ZZ3.prerequisites: ECON 2Z03; and one of ECON 1ME3, MATH 1A03, 1LS3, 1M03, or 1MM3 (or equivalent such as ARTSSCI 1D06 A/B, MATH 1N03, 1X03, 1Z04, or 1ZA3)

ECON 3B03.name: Public Sector Economics: Expenditures
ECON 3B03.description: Theory and practice of public finance. Topics are selected from growth of the public sector, market failure, theory of public goods, incentive mechanisms, logic of group decisions and the political process, theory of benefit-cost analysis, intergovernmental fiscal relations, government budgeting. Three lectures; one term.

ECON 3BE3.name: Behavioural Economics
ECON 3BE3.description: Economic theory rests upon the assumptions that all economic actors (consumers, firms, governments) are fully rational and narrowly self-interested. Behavioural economics examines the consequences and realism of these assumptions by designing laboratory and field experiments and conducting empirical analyses that test economic theory and its core assumptions and by incorporating psychologically plausible assumptions and motivations into economic theory. This course provides a survey of some of the central and current topics in behavioural economics. Three lectures; one term.

ECON 3C03.name: Public Sector Economics: Taxation
ECON 3C03.description: Theory and practice of public finance: analysis and comparison of the efficiency, equity and distribution effects of the taxation of income, wealth and expenditure, analysis of social insurance, intergovernmental fiscal relations. Three lectures; one term.

ECON 3D03.name: Labour Economics
ECON 3D03.description: Introduction to the economics of the labour market; demand for labour by the firm and industry; supply of labour by the individual; investment in human capital. Three lectures; one term.

ECON 3E03.name: Applied Econometrics
ECON 3E03.description: Formerly ECON 3WW3 Students acquire hands-on experience, using statistical software, in the application of econometric methods to empirically analyze economic issues. This course emphasizes understanding economic data, economic model estimation, hypothesis testing, and interpretation of results. Three hours; one tutorial; one term.
ECON 3E03.prerequisites: ECON 2G03, 2Z03 or 2X03; and 2H03 ; and 2B03 and enrolment in an Honours Economics program
ECON 3E03.antirequisites: ECON 3U03 [Inactive], ECON 3WW3, ECON 3EE3 ECON 2B03 may be substituted with one of CHEMENG 4C03, COMMERCE 2QA3 , POLSCI 3N06 A/B, 3NN3 , PNB 2XE3 , 3XE3 , SOCIOL 3H06 A/B, STATS 2D03 or another course that is approved by a departmental counselor as equivalent to ECON 2B03 .

ECON 3EE3.name: Econometrics I
ECON 3EE3.description: Formerly ECON 3U03 Elaboration of regression techniques developed in ECON 2B03 and their applications. Problems of inference and interpretation in the analysis of economic data. Introduction to forecasting in economics. Three lectures; one tutorial; one term.
ECON 3EE3.prerequisites: ECON 2G03, 2Z03 or 2X03; and 2H03 ; and 2B03 with a grade of at least B-; and registration in an Honours Economics program with a GPA of at least 6. The ECON 2B03 prerequisite can be met by getting a grade of at least B+ in one of the following alternative statistics courses: CHEMENG 4C03, COMMERCE 2QA3 , POLSCI 3N06 A/B, POLSCI 3NN3 , PNB 2XE3 , 3XE3 , SOCIOL 3H06 A/B, STATS 2D03 or another course that is approved by a departmental counselor as equivalent to ECON 2B03 .

ECON 3G03.name: Introduction to Advanced Economic Theory
ECON 3G03.description: An introduction to the application of mathematics in economic theory. Three lectures; one term.
ECON 3G03.prerequisites: ECON 1ME3 or MATH 1M03 (or 1MM3) or equivalent; and a grade of at least B- in each of ECON 2ZZ3 (or 2GG3) and ECON 2HH3 and registration in an Economics program

ECON 3H03.name: International Monetary Economics
ECON 3H03.description: Macroeconomic problems of an open economy with special reference to Canada; the international financial system and proposals for its reform. Lectures and seminars (three hours); one term.

ECON 3HH3.name: International Trade
ECON 3HH3.description: Real theory of international trade; interregional and international specialization; effect of commercial and industrial policies. Three lectures; one term.

ECON 3K03.name: Monetary Economics
ECON 3K03.description: Introduction to a modern treatment of monetary theory. Topics include why does money exist; links between monetary policy, inflation and business cycles; how might inflation and economic growth be connected? Three lectures; one term.

ECON 3M03.name: Introduction to Game Theory
ECON 3M03.description: An introduction to the theory of games, including strategic, extensive and coalitional games. Applications in economics, political science and evolutionary biology are discussed. Three lectures; one term.
ECON 3M03.prerequisites: One of ECON 1B03, 1BX3, or ARTSSCI 2E03; and MATH 1K03 (or equivalent)

ECON 3Q03.name: The Economics of Aging
ECON 3Q03.description: Topics include the macroeconomics of population aging and its impact on national pension and health plans and the microeconomics of retirement and income security. Three lectures; one term.

ECON 3S03.name: Industrial Organization
ECON 3S03.description: A study of the structure, conduct and performance of industrial markets. Three lectures; one term.

ECON 3T03.name: Economic Development
ECON 3T03.description: Topics may include the measurement of structural change, dual economies, agriculture and production, technical and institutional change, and health and nutrition. Three lectures; one term.

ECON 3W03.name: Natural Resources
ECON 3W03.description: Competitive and socially optimal management of nonrenewable resources; market failure as illustrated by mineral cartels, fisheries and forestry, including analysis of bioeconomic models. Three hours (lectures and seminars); one term.
ECON 3W03.prerequisites: One of ECON 2G03, 2Z03 , ECON 2J03 , or ECON 2X03

ECON 3Y03.name: Selected Topics
ECON 3Y03.description: Topics will vary from year to year depending on student interests and faculty availability. Students should consult the Department on topics to be offered. Three hours; one term.

ECON 3Z03.name: Health Economics
ECON 3Z03.description: Analysis of allocation of resources in health care. Topics include markets for health care, insurance, biomedical research, technology assessment, organization and public policy. Three lectures; one term.
ECON 3Z03.prerequisites: ECON 2G03, 2Z03 or ECON 2X03. ECON 2B03 or another course in statistics is recommended.

ECON 4A03.name: Honours Economic Analysis
ECON 4A03.description: Students discuss papers on a theme that is specific to each section and write short paper reviews and policy briefs on current economics issues. Three hours (seminars); one term.
ECON 4A03.prerequisites: ECON 4F03 (or 3F03) or ECON 4FF3 (or 3FF3); and ECON 3E03 (or 3WW3) or ECON 3EE3 (or 3U03); and ECON 2GG3 (or 2ZZ3 ), and ECON 2HH3 ; and enrolment in level IV of an Honours Economics Program

ECON 4AA3.name: Economic Specialist Seminar
ECON 4AA3.description: Under the supervision of a faculty member students present and discuss papers and write a paper presenting original research. 3 hours; one term.
ECON 4AA3.prerequisites: ECON 4FF3 (or 3FF3) with a grade of at least B-, and ECON 3EE3 (or 3U03) with a grade of at least B-; or ECON 3E03 (or 3WW3) with a grade of at least A-, and an average of at least 6 in ECON 2G03 (or 2Z03 ), 2GG3 (or 2ZZ3 ), 2H03 , and 2HH3 , and enrolment in Level III or Level IV Honours Economics (Specialist Option) with a GPA of at least 6.

ECON 4B03.name: Selected Topics
ECON 4B03.description: Topics will vary from year to year depending on student interests and faculty availability. Students should consult the Department on topics to be offered. Three hours; one term.

ECON 4F03.name: Methods of Inquiry in Economics
ECON 4F03.description: Formerly ECON 3F03 This course develops skills for investigating a research question in economics, through workshops (eg. writing, library, internet, data), and the subsequent application of the skills to an economic issue. Three hours; one term.
ECON 4F03.prerequisites: ECON 2G03, 2Z03 or 2X03; and 2H03 ; Credit or registration in ECON 3E03 (or 3WW3) or ECON 3EE3 (or 3U03), registration in Level III or Level IV of an Honours Economics program
ECON 4F03.antirequisites: ECON 3FF3, ECON 3F03, ECON 4FF3 This course is only offered in the Fall term.

ECON 4FF3.name: Research Methods in Economics
ECON 4FF3.description: Formerly ECON 3FF3 Students discuss and present papers, learn research methods and write a critical review of the literature on an economic topic of their choice. 3 hours; one term Prerequisite(s) : ECON 2G03 (or 2Z03 ) with a grade of at least C+; and ECON 2H03 with a grade of at least C+; and Credit or enrolment in ECON 3EE3 (or 3U03); or a grade of at least A- in ECON 3E03 (or 3WW3); and registration in Level III or Level IV of an Honours Economics program with a GPA of at least 6. Antirequisite(s): ECON 3F03, ECON 3FF3, ECON 4F03 This course is only offered in the Fall term.

ECON 4G03.name: Econometrics II
ECON 4G03.description: Development of regression models appropriate to economics. Illustrations from applied micro- and macroeconomics. Three lectures; one tutorial; one term.
ECON 4G03.prerequisites: ECON 2G03, 2Z03 or 2X03; and ECON 2H03 ; and at least B- in ECON ECON 3EE3 (or 3U03) or at least A- in ECON 3E03 (or 3WW3) or another course that is approved by a departmental counselor

ECON 4T03.name: Advanced Economic Theory I
ECON 4T03.description: Mathematically oriented approaches to the analysis of the behaviour of individual consumers, workers and firms. Three lectures; one term.
ECON 4T03.prerequisites: A grade of at least C in one of ECON 3G03 , MATH 2Q04, MATH 2X03 (or MATH 2A03); and a grade of at least B- in ECON 2GG3 (or 2ZZ3 ) and ECON 2HH3 and registration in an Economics program.

ECON 4TT3.name: Advanced Economic Theory II
ECON 4TT3.description: Analysis of dynamic macroeconomic models including models of endogenous growth and other selected topics. Three lectures; one term.
ECON 4TT3.prerequisites: A grade of at least C in one of ECON 3G03 , MATH 2Q04, MATH 2X03 (or MATH 2A03); and a grade of at least B- in ECON 2GG3 (or 2ZZ3 ) and ECON 2HH3 and registration in an Economics program.

ELECENG 2CF3.name: Circuits and Waves
ELECENG 2CF3.description: Advanced circuit analysis; sinusoids and complex numbers; Laplace transforms with applications; frequency response; 2-port networks; fundamentals of wave propagation; transmission lines and impedance match; radiation and antennas Three lectures, one tutorial; second term.

ELECENG 2CI4.name: Introduction to Electrical Engineering
ELECENG 2CI4.prerequisites: Registration in a Computer Engineering or Electrical Engineering program

ELECENG 2FH4.name: Electromagnetics I
ELECENG 2FH4.prerequisites: ELECENG 2CI5 or ELECENG 2CI4 and PHYSICS 1E03, registration in Electrical Engineering or the Integrated Biomedical Engineering and Health Sciences (IBEHS) Program

ELECENG 2MM3.name: Electrical Circuits and Power
ELECENG 2MM3.description: Fundamentals of electromechanical energy conversion. Motors and generators, transformers, single and polyphase power circuits, synchronous and induction machines, power measurements. Two lectures and one lab or tutorial; first term.

ELECENG 3EJ4.name: Electronic Devices and Circuits II
ELECENG 3EJ4.prerequisites: ELECENG 2CJ4 or ELECENG 2CF3, ELECENG 2EI5 or ELECENG 2EI4, ELECENG 2CI5 or ELECENG 2CI4

ELECENG 3EY4.name: Electrical Systems Integration Project
ELECENG 3EY4.prerequisites: COMPENG 2DX4 or 2DX3, ELECENG 3TP3 or ELECENG 3TP4 or IBEHS 3A03, ELECENG 2CI5 or ELECENG 2CI4, ELECENG 2CJ4, COMPENG 2DI4, COMPENG 2SH4

ELECENG 3N03.name: Electronics and Instrumentation
ELECENG 3N03.description: Semiconductor devices; diodes, transistors and silicon-controlled rectifiers. Transistor characteristic and load lines. Amplifier circuits with and without feedback. Rectifier and passive filter circuits. Operational amplifiers and active filters. Digital circuits, Microcomputers, Interfacing. Two lectures, one tutorial, one lab (three hours) every other week; second term.
ELECENG 3N03.prerequisites: One of ENGINEER 2M04, 2MM3 or 3M03 or ENGPHYS 2E03 or ELECENG 2MM3

ELECENG 3PI4.name: Energy Conversion
ELECENG 3PI4.prerequisites: ELECENG 2CJ4, ELECENG 2FH3 or ELECENG 2FH4, and ELECENG 2CI5 or ELECENG 2CI4

ELECENG 3TP3.name: Signal & Systems
ELECENG 3TP3.description: Complex variables and integration in the complex plane; Fourier transforms, properties; Laplace transforms and inversion; input-output relations of linear systems; discrete time systems. Three lectures, one tutorial; first term.

ELECENG 3TQ3.name: Advanced Probability and Random Processes
ELECENG 3TQ3.description: Probability theory; random variables; expectations; random processes; autocorrelation; power spectral densities. Three lectures, one tutorial; first term.

ELECENG 3TR4.name: Communication Systems
ELECENG 3TR4.prerequisites: ELECENG 3TP4 or ENGPHYS 3W04; One of  ELECENG 3TQ4, ELECENG 3TQ3 or STATS 3Y03; or ENGPHYS 3W04 A/B

ELECENG 4BB3.name: Cellular Bioelectricity
ELECENG 4BB3.description: Generation and transmission of bioelectricity in excitable cells; ionic transport in cellular membranes; propagation of electricity within and between cells; cardiac and neural physiology; measurement of extracellular fields; electrical stimulation of excitable cells. Three lectures, one tutorial; second term.
ELECENG 4BB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III Electrical and Biomedical Engineering or level IV or V of the Integrated Biomedical Engineering and Health Sciences (IBEHS) Program or level IV of Electrical Engineering

ELECENG 4BD4.name: Biomedical Instrumentation
ELECENG 4BD4.prerequisites: One of ELECENG 3EJ4 , ENGINEER 3N03 or PHYSICS 3B06; and registration in Biomedical and Electrical Engineering Level IV, or permission of the department. Cross-list(s): IBEHS 4F04

ELECENG 4BF4.name: Advanced Medical Imaging
ELECENG 4BF4.prerequisites: ELECENG 2FH3 or 2FH4 or ENGPHYS 2A04 , ELECENG 3TP4 or 3TP3 or IBEHS 3A03

ELECENG 4CL4.name: Control System Design
ELECENG 4CL4.prerequisites: ELECENG 3CL4 or IBEHS 4A03 , ELECENG 3TP4 or 3TP3 or IBEHS 3A03

ELECENG 4EM4.name: Photonic Devices and Systems
ELECENG 4EM4.prerequisites: ELECENG 3EJ4 ; or ENGPHYS 3BA3 or 3BA4 and ENGPHYS 3BB3 or 3BB4

ELECENG 4FJ4.name: Devices and Antennas for Wireless Systems

ELECENG 4OH4.name: Advanced Research Project
ELECENG 4OH4.prerequisites: COMPENG 4OJ4 or ELECENG 4OJ4 ; Prior arrangement with an Electrical and Computer Engineering faculty member, a minimum cumulative GPA of 9.5, registration in Level IV or V of any program in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; or permission of the department.

ELECENG 4OJ4.name: Research Project
ELECENG 4OJ4.prerequisites: Prior arrangement with an Electrical and Computer Engineering faculty member, a minimum cumulative GPA of 9.5, registration in Level IV or V of any program in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; or permission of the department.

ELECENG 4PP4.name: Smart and Micro Grids
ELECENG 4PP4.prerequisites: ELECENG 3CL4 , or IBEHS 4A03 , and ELECENG 3PI4 , and ELECENG 4PK4 , and ELECENG 4PM4

ENRTECH 3EP3.name: Power Systems and Electrical Machines
ENRTECH 3EP3.description: Basic electric circuits, basic electrical theorems, network analysis, phasors, three phase systems, transformers, motors, electric power generation, power plants components (transformers, motors, exciters, synchronous machines). Three lectures; one lab (two hours every other week); one term.
ENRTECH 3EP3.prerequisites: Registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENRTECH 3IE3.name: Industrial Electronics
ENRTECH 3IE3.description: Introduction to power electronic devices: diodes, transistors, triacs, SCRs, IGBTs. Electrical machines characteristics: motors, transformers. Power control circuits, solid state converter drives. Harmonics and filtering. Three lectures; one term.
ENRTECH 3IE3.prerequisites: ENRTECH 3EP3 , 3MA3 and registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENRTECH 3IN3.name: Industrial Networks and Communication Systems
ENRTECH 3IN3.description: Corporate and industrial network standards; proprietary buses and protocols and interfaces; distributed I/O; drivers and devices and their implementation in PC and PLC based systems. Three lectures; one lab (two hours every other week); one term.
ENRTECH 3IN3.prerequisites: Registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENRTECH 3MI3.name: Measurements and Instrumentation
ENRTECH 3MI3.description: Transducers, logic circuits, basic electronic devices and their applications. Calculate/measure the input(s) and output(s) of various systems. Recognize, install and apply instruments within power plants. Three lectures; one lab (two hours every other week); one term.
ENRTECH 3MI3.prerequisites: Registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENRTECH 3PD3.name: Power Distribution I
ENRTECH 3PD3.description: Principle concepts and theories of power distribution. Skills required to work at an industrial environment and/or power utilities (generation, transmission, distribution). Based on the Ontario Hydro system, a power flow computer program will be introduced. Three lectures; one term.
ENRTECH 3PD3.prerequisites: ENRTECH 3EP3 and registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENRTECH 4CA3.name: Computer Applications in Power System Engineering
ENRTECH 4CA3.description: Analysis of load flow, short circuit, transient stability and electromagnetic transients by commercial power system software packages. Three lectures; one term.
ENRTECH 4CA3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3ET0 , ENRTECH 3PD3 , 4PM3 , and registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENRTECH 4EM3.name: Transmission Lines and Electromagnetics
ENRTECH 4EM3.description: Field concepts. Maxwells equations, integral and differential forms. Free space and guided wave propagation, transmission lines. Radiation from current elements. Three lectures; one term.
ENRTECH 4EM3.prerequisites: ENRTECH 3EP3 , ENGTECH 3MA3 and registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENRTECH 4PD3.name: Power System Analysis and Control
ENRTECH 4PD3.description: This course introduces the different types of operating constraints as encountered by power system operators and engineers during real time operation of interconnected power grids. For each type of operating constraint, the most common operating strategies and control measures will be discussed and analyzed. Three lectures; one term.
ENRTECH 4PD3.prerequisites: ENRTECH 3PD3 and registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENRTECH 4PM3.name: Power Protection and Maintenance I
ENRTECH 4PM3.description: Various power devices such as relays, circuit breaker, power monitor, control devices and other components used in a power system protection. Other devices such as CTs, and Pts and substation hardware will also be covered. Three lectures; one term.
ENRTECH 4PM3.prerequisites: ENRTECH 3MI3 , 3PD3 , and registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENRTECH 4PP3.name: Power Protection and Maintenance II
ENRTECH 4PP3.description: New generation of digital fault detection systems. Balanced faults, computer-based fault studies, symmetrical components and sequence networks, unbalanced short-circuit and open-circuit faults. Three lectures; one lab (two hours every other week); one term.
ENRTECH 4PP3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3ET0 , ENRTECH 4PM3 and registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENRTECH 4PQ3.name: Power Quality
ENRTECH 4PQ3.description: Analyze and monitor power quality. Case studies for EMI/RFI related problems that are commonly encountered in commercial and industrial loads. Three lectures; one term.
ENRTECH 4PQ3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3ET0 , ENRTECH 3EP3 , 3PD3 , and registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENRTECH 4RG3.name: Renewable Generation
ENRTECH 4RG3.description: Operation and planning of renewable generation resources including wind, solar, hydro, biomass, geothermal and fuel cells. The environmental and economical impacts of such technologies, rules, regulations. Three lectures; one term.
ENRTECH 4RG3.prerequisites: ENRTECH 3EP3 , ENGTECH 3TD3 , and registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENGINEER 1EE0.name: Introduction to the Engineering Co-op Program
ENGINEER 1EE0.prerequisites: Registration in a Co-op program in the Faculty of Engineering

ENGINEER 1PA3.name: Introduction to Engineering Design and Practice
ENGINEER 1PA3.description: Introduction to professional engineering including ethics, health and safety, engineering communication; design skills; completion of a design project. Graphical visualization and communication; technical sketching, 2D and 3D computer-aided design; use of solid modelling software. Two lectures, one tutorial (two hours); one term.
ENGINEER 1PA3.prerequisites: Registration in any Engineering program, and permission of the department
ENGINEER 1PA3.antirequisites: ENGINEER 1P13 A/B, IBEHS 1P10 A/B, ENGINEER 1C03 Offered only during Spring/Summer term.

ENGINEER 1PB3.name: Structure and Properties of Materials
ENGINEER 1PB3.description: An introduction to the structure of both crystalline and amorphous solids; the physical and chemical basis for properties exhibited by materials; an overview of material properties including mechanical, electrical, magnetic and thermal behaviour. Three lectures; one term.
ENGINEER 1PB3.prerequisites: Registration in any Engineering program, and permission of the department
ENGINEER 1PB3.antirequisites: ENGINEER 1P13 A/B, IBEHS 1P10 A/B, MATLS 1M03 Offered only during Spring/Summer term.

ENGINEER 1PC3.name: Engineering Computation
ENGINEER 1PC3.description: Development and analysis of simple algorithms. Implementation of algorithms in computer programming language. Design and testing of computer programs. One lecture, one tutorial (two hours), one lab (three hours); one term.
ENGINEER 1PC3.prerequisites: Registration in any Engineering program, and permission of the department
ENGINEER 1PC3.antirequisites: ENGINEER 1P13 A/B, IBEHS 1P10 A/B, ENGINEER 1D04 Offered only during Spring/Summer term.

ENGINEER 2EC0.name: Engineering Work Term
ENGINEER 2EC0.prerequisites: Registration in a Co-op program in the Faculty of Engineering and ENGINEER 1EE0 and permission from the Engineering Co-Op and Career Services

ENGINEER 2IW3.name: Inclusion in the Engineering Workplace
ENGINEER 2IW3.description: Engineering workplaces are diverse but can pose challenges to underrepresented groups. Students will develop the vocabulary and tools to master perceptual, institutional, and psychological mechanisms of inclusion as allies and targets. One term Lectures (three hours); second term.
ENGINEER 2IW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any Engineering Program

ENGINEER 2PX3.name: Engineering Design 2: Communications and Social Impact
ENGINEER 2PX3.description: Multi-disciplinary integrated learning course that develops engineering design and technical communication skills through a group-based project addressing a current issue. Students communicate and critique their conceptual designs through technical, social, environmental, political, and regulatory lenses. Two lectures, one tutorial (three hours); winter term.
ENGINEER 2PX3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above in any program leading to a B.Eng, B.Eng.Mgt, or a B.Eng.Soc degree
ENGINEER 2PX3.antirequisites: CHEMENG 2G03; CIVENG 2I03; COMPENG 2DX4; ENGPHYS 3EC4; MECHENG 2A03; MATLS 2H04; SFWRENG 3I03

ENGINEER 3IC0.name: Full-Time Internship for International Students
ENGINEER 3IC0.prerequisites: ENGINEER 1EE0 and permission of the Engineering Career and Co-Op Services.

ENGINEER 3PX3.name: Engineering Design 3: Engineering Economics
ENGINEER 3PX3.description: Multi-disciplinary integrated learning course that develops skills in engineering design, project management, and engineering economics through projects addressing current issues in society. The engineering economics topics include time value of money, value engineering, and cash flow analysis; these along with project management skills are applied in the context of the proposed design solution. Two lectures, one tutorial (three hours); winter term.
ENGINEER 3PX3.prerequisites: ENGINEER 2PX3 ; Registration in Level III or above in any program leading to a B.Eng, B.Eng.Mgt, or a B.Eng.Soc degree

ENGINEER 4A03.name: Ethics, Equity and Law in Engineering
ENGINEER 4A03.description: General introduction to the ethical, equitable and legal aspects of engineering practice. Topics include the engineering act and code of ethics, employment equity, legal duties and liabilities of the professional engineer, contracts, and the tort of negligence. Three lectures; both terms.
ENGINEER 4A03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of any Engineering program except Engineering and Society

ENGSOCTY 2X03.name: Inquiry in an Engineering Context I
ENGSOCTY 2X03.description: Inquiry is a non-disciplinary approach to the study of issues of public concern. In terms of the design process, inquiry focuses on the problem definition stage, in which formulating questions, researching underlying issues, and analysing opposing arguments are essential. The first course involves teaching how to use the university and community resources in research, how to write a research paper, and how to express ideas orally. Three hours (lectures, discussion, group work); first term.
ENGSOCTY 2X03.prerequisites: Registration in the Engineering & Society Program or permission of the instructor

ENGSOCTY 2Y03.name: Case Studies in History and Technology
ENGSOCTY 2Y03.description: History and philosophy of technology, from antiquity to modern times, with a special emphasis on the cultural aspects of technology, are addressed on a case study basis. Three hours (lectures, discussion, group work); second term.
ENGSOCTY 2Y03.prerequisites: Registration in the Engineering & Society Program

ENGSOCTY 3X03.name: Inquiry in an Engineering Context II
ENGSOCTY 3X03.description: This inquiry course builds on the skills developed in previous courses, focusing on a specific issue related to the role of engineering and technology in society. The course is devoted to the study of one topic such as: social control of technology, technology and the quality of life, the deteriorating environment, or the information society. Three hours (lectures, discussion, group presentations); second term.
ENGSOCTY 3X03.prerequisites: ENGSOCTY 2X03  and registration in Level IV of the Engineering & Society Program

ENGSOCTY 3Y03.name: Technology and Society
ENGSOCTY 3Y03.description: A study of the nature and structure of technology, the nature of culture, and the role and place of different groups, including engineers, in a culture dominated by technology; and mechanisms for the social control of technology. Lectures, discussion, group work, seminars (three hours); first term.
ENGSOCTY 3Y03.prerequisites: ENGSOCTY 2Y03 and registration in Level III or above of the Engineering & Society Program

ENGSOCTY 3Z03.name: Preventive Engineering: Environmental Perspectives
ENGSOCTY 3Z03.description: This experiential course focuses on the application of preventive engineering with specific attention to impacts on the natural environment. Students explore first-hand, through guided site visits and discussion with organizational leaders, the potential solutions and risks of this approach Three hours (lectures, discussion, group projects); first term.
ENGSOCTY 3Z03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of the Engineering & Society Program

ENGSOCTY 4Y03.name: Society Capstone Design
ENGSOCTY 4Y03.description: In multi-disciplinary teams, students will complete a capstone design project that incorporates holistic design, social sustainability, community resilience and aesthetic elements. Two lectures; design studio (one hour); first term.
ENGSOCTY 4Y03.prerequisites: Registration in Level V of the Engineering & Society Program

ENGNMGT 2AA3.name: Communication Skills
ENGNMGT 2AA3.description: Writing skills including formal reports; speaking, listening and presentation skills, speeches, technical presentations and electronic communication technology. One lecture (three hours); first term.
ENGNMGT 2AA3.prerequisites: Registration in the Engineering & Management program

ENGNMGT 4A03.name: Innovation Driven Project Development and Management
ENGNMGT 4A03.description: What is innovation and how is it managed? Team-based creativity skills will be developed with a focus on delivering innovation. Participants develop teamwork skills while using project management tools to develop a project. One lecture (three hours); first term.
ENGNMGT 4A03.prerequisites: One of CHEMENG 2G03 or ENGNMGT 2AA2 or ENGNMGT 2AA3; and registration in the Engineering & Management program

ENGNMGT 5B03.name: Engineering & Management Capstone
ENGNMGT 5B03.description: Capstone course: Students work in multidisciplinary teams to solve an integrated engineering and business problem in an organization. Team, project and client management skills are developed. One lecture (three hours); first term.
ENGNMGT 5B03.prerequisites: ENGNMGT 4A03 and registration in the Engineering & Management program

ENGPHYS 2A04.name: Electricity and Magnetism
ENGPHYS 2A04.prerequisites: Registration in any Engineering Physics or Mechatronics Engineering Program; PHYSICS 1E03; and credit or registration in ENGPHYS 2E04 and MATH 2ZZ3

ENGPHYS 2CD4.name: Computational Mechanics: Dynamics
ENGPHYS 2CD4.prerequisites: PHYSICS 1D03 and credit or registration in MATH 2Z03. Registration in ENGPHYS 2P04 is recommended.

ENGPHYS 2CM4.name: Computational Multiphysics
ENGPHYS 2CM4.prerequisites: ENGPHYS 2CD4, 2P04, MATH 2Z03, and credit or registration in ENGPHYS 2A04 and MATH 2ZZ3

ENGPHYS 2E04.name: Analog and Digital Circuits
ENGPHYS 2E04.prerequisites: PHYSICS 1E03 , credit or registration in MATH 2Z03 , and registration in an Engineering program

ENGPHYS 2NE3.name: Thermal Systems Design
ENGPHYS 2NE3.description: Thermal Systems Design covers the physics, thermodynamics and design of energy conversion systems utilized in many engineering systems. The topics include the first and second law of thermodynamics, irreversibility, the Rankine and Brayton cycles, and common refrigeration cycles. Three lectures, one tutorial; first term.
ENGPHYS 2NE3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of an Engineering program

ENGPHYS 2P04.name: Computational Mechanics: Statics
ENGPHYS 2P04.prerequisites: PHYSICS 1D03; and credit or registration in MATH 2Z03. Registration in ENGPHYS 2CD4 is recommended.

ENGPHYS 2QM3.name: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics
ENGPHYS 2QM3.description: Basic foundations of quantum mechanics; wave-particle duality, uncertainty principle, Hydrogen atom, Schrodinger Equation, barriers and tunnelling, probability, spin, quantum statistics, selected applications. Three lectures, one tutorial; second term.
ENGPHYS 2QM3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of an Engineering program

ENGPHYS 3BA3.name: Circuits with Non-Linear and Active Components
ENGPHYS 3BA3.description: P-N junctions, diodes, bipolar junction transistors, field effect transistors, DC and AC modeling, differential amplifiers and operational amplifiers, feedback and oscillators, digital circuits and multivibrators, signal processing. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); first term.

ENGPHYS 3BB3.name: Embedding and Programming a Micro-Controller
ENGPHYS 3BB3.description: Design and synthesis project in electronics, focused on integrating analog electronics with a microcontroller to create a PID controlled device. Programming and interfacing the microcontroller are taught in weeks 1-6; the device is designed and built in weeks 7-12. Prior knowledge of basic electronics, including op-amps and transistors is required. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); second term.

ENGPHYS 3D04.name: Principles of Nuclear Engineering
ENGPHYS 3D04.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of an Engineering program

ENGPHYS 3E04.name: Fundamentals of Physical Optics
ENGPHYS 3E04.prerequisites: Registration in any Engineering Program, and one of ISCI 2A18 A/B, MATH 2X03, 2ZZ3; and one of MATH 2C03, 2Z03; and one of PHYSICS 2B03 or ENGPHYS 2A04

ENGPHYS 3ES3.name: Introduction to Energy Systems
ENGPHYS 3ES3.description: A survey course on energy systems with emphasis on the analytic tools needed to evaluate them in terms of performance, resources and environmental sustainability, costs, and other relevant factors over their life cycles. Three lectures; first term.
ENGPHYS 3ES3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of an Engineering program

ENGPHYS 3L04.name: Engineering Metrology
ENGPHYS 3L04.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of any Engineering Physics program

ENGPHYS 3NM4.name: Numerical Methods for Engineering
ENGPHYS 3NM4.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of an Engineering program
ENGPHYS 3NM4.antirequisites: ENGPHYS 2CE4, CHEMENG 2E04 , CIVENG 2E03 , MECHENG 3F04 , COMPSCI 4X03 , MECHTRON 3X03 , SFWRENG 4X03

ENGPHYS 3O04.name: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics and Heat Transfer
ENGPHYS 3O04.prerequisites: MATH 2Z03 and credit or registration in MATH 2ZZ3

ENGPHYS 3PD4.name: Photonic Devices
ENGPHYS 3PD4.prerequisites: One of ENGPHYS 3E03 or 3E04 or PHYSICS 3N03 or 3N04

ENGPHYS 3PN4.name: Semiconductor Junction Devices
ENGPHYS 3PN4.prerequisites: Credit in at least one of the following: ELECENG 2EI4 , ENGPHYS 3BA3 , 3BA4, 3SM3 , MATLS 2Q03 or Registration in ENGPHYS 3SM3

ENGPHYS 3SM3.name: Statistical Mechanics
ENGPHYS 3SM3.description: An introduction to statistical distributions and their properties, and the statistical basis of thermodynamics at the microscopic level, with applications to problems originating in a modern laboratory or engineering environment. Three lectures, one tutorial; second term.
ENGPHYS 3SM3.prerequisites: Credit or registration in ENGPHYS 2NE3 , 2QM3 , and 3L04

ENGPHYS 3SP3.name: Space Systems Engineering
ENGPHYS 3SP3.description: A survey of topics required for the development of near-Earth missions, including orbital mechanics (with a relativity primer), propulsion and power systems, radio and optical communications, effects of radiation, and observational instrumentation. Three lectures; first term.
ENGPHYS 3SP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of an Engineering or Honours Physics program

ENGPHYS 3W03.name: Signals and Systems for Engineering
ENGPHYS 3W03.description: A systems approach to measurement in which synthesis of topics such as Fourier transforms, signal processing and enhancement, data reduction, modelling and simulation is undertaken. Three lectures, one lab (two hours) every other week; first term.
ENGPHYS 3W03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of any Engineering or Science program

ENGPHYS 4B03.name: Biosensors - Fundamentals and Applications
ENGPHYS 4B03.description: This course covers the underlying operating principles and defining metrics of biological sensors, and it will discuss the integration of these sensors into systems for diagnostics and health monitoring applications. Three lectures; first term.
ENGPHYS 4B03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above in any Engineering program or registration in Level IV or above in the Integrated Biomedical Engineering & Health Sciences (IBEHS) Program.

ENGPHYS 4I03.name: Introduction to Biophotonics
ENGPHYS 4I03.description: This course covers the basic principles of light interaction with biological systems and specific biomedical applications of photonics such as optical light microscopy, endoscopic imaging, spectroscopy in clinical diagnosis, flow cytometry, micro-optical sensors, etc. Three lectures; second term.
ENGPHYS 4I03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above in the Faculties of Engineering, Science, or Health Sciences, or the Integrated Biomedical Engineering & Health Sciences (IBEHS) Program Cross-list(s): MEDPHYS 4I03

ENGPHYS 4MD3.name: Nanoscale Semiconductor Devices
ENGPHYS 4MD3.description: Nanoscale semiconductor materials and devices including quantum confinement, quantum dots, dipole radiation, quantum radiation physics, molecular and bulk excitons, advanced molecular electronics, tight-binding modelling, emerging nanoscale MOSFETs, 2-dimensional metal dichalcogenides and graphene. Three lectures; second term.
ENGPHYS 4MD3.prerequisites: Credit or registration in at least one of the following: ENGPHYS 3PN4 , MATLS 3Q03

ENGPHYS 4NE3.name: Advanced Nuclear Engineering
ENGPHYS 4NE3.description: Energy generation and conversion, heat transfer and transport in a nuclear reactor. Characteristics and performance of nuclear fuels. Thermal margins and safety limits. Aging of core structural materials. Structural integrity of components. Three lectures; second term.

ENGPHYS 4P03.name: Nuclear Power Plant Systems and Operation
ENGPHYS 4P03.description: Systems and overall unit operations relevant to nuclear power plants; includes all major reactor and process systems; self-study using interactive nuclear power plant. Three lectures; second term.
ENGPHYS 4P03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of any Engineering program (familiarity with ENGPHYS 4D03/ 4D04 or other nuclear course desirable)

ENGPHYS 4PP3.name: Plasma Physics Applications
ENGPHYS 4PP3.description: An introduction to plasma physics with emphasis on occurrence of plasmas in nature, and applications of plasmas in thermonuclear fusion and other engineering disciplines. Three lectures; one-time demonstration lab (three hours); first term.
ENGPHYS 4PP3.prerequisites: ENGPHYS 2A04 , or PHYSICS 2B03 and 2BB3 , or ELECENG 2FH3

ENGPHYS 4QC3.name: Introduction to Quantum Computing
ENGPHYS 4QC3.description: An introduction to quantum computing including qubits, entanglement, quantum key cryptography, teleportation, quantum circuits and algorithms, spin qubits. Three lectures; first term.

ENGPHYS 4QM3.name: Quantum Optics and Metrology
ENGPHYS 4QM3.description: An introduction to quantum optics including single photon states, coherent states, standard quantum limit, Heisenberg limit, squeezed light, entanglement, and applications in metrology. Three lectures; second term.

ENGPHYS 4S04.name: Lasers and Electro-Optics
ENGPHYS 4S04.prerequisites: One of ENGPHYS 3E03 or 3E04 , PHYSICS 3N03 or 3N04 , or ELECENG 3FK4 or 4EM4

ENGPHYS 4US2.name: Smart Systems Design & Implementation Laboratory
ENGPHYS 4US2.prerequisites: ENGPHYS 3BB3 or 3BB4 and registration in an Engineering Physics program

ENGPHYS 4X03.name: Introduction to Photovoltaics
ENGPHYS 4X03.description: A review of photovoltaic devices including solar cell operation, characterization, manufacturing, economics and current and next generation technologies. Three lectures; first term.
ENGPHYS 4X03.prerequisites: One of ENGPHYS 3BA3, 3BA4, or ELECENG 2EI5 or 2EI4 , or permission of the instructor with MATLS 3Q03

ENGTECH 1AC3.name: Analytical Chemistry
ENGTECH 1AC3.description: Introduction to laboratory procedures used in chemical analysis for classical wet and instrumental methods; statistical data treatment, gravimetric analysis, volumetric analysis, pH measurements and optical methods. Three lectures, one lab (three hours); second term.
ENGTECH 1AC3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 1CH3 and registration Automation Systems Engineering Technology or Biotechnology

ENGTECH 1BI3.name: Biology
ENGTECH 1BI3.description: This course provides basic introduction to the following topics: chemistry of life, cells, genetics, evolution and diversity and plant and animal form and function. Two lectures, one lab (three hours every other week); second term.

ENGTECH 1CH3.name: Chemistry
ENGTECH 1CH3.description: Basic chemical concepts, calculations and laboratory procedures. Chemical formulae and equations, chemical stoichiometry, nomenclature, acids and bases, gases, chemical equilibrium, thermochemistry and thermodynamics, redox reactions and electrochemistry. Two lectures, two tutorials, one lab (three hours every other week); first term.
ENGTECH 1CH3.prerequisites: Registration in Automation Systems Engineering Technology, or Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

ENGTECH 1CP3.name: C++ Programming
ENGTECH 1CP3.description: Programming concepts and introduction to C++ programming. C++ syntax, functions, decision-making, looping, pointers, and arrays, strings, data structures, and file operations. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); first term.
ENGTECH 1CP3.prerequisites: Registration in Automation Systems Engineering Technology, or Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 1EL3.name: Electricity and Electronics I
ENGTECH 1EL3.description: Introduction to electronic circuits; DC and AC sources, resistors, inductors, and capacitors; phasors and impedance; transient and steady-state analysis; network analysis; energy and power. Two lectures, two tutorials, one lab (three hours); second term.
ENGTECH 1EL3.prerequisites: Registration in Automation Systems Engineering Technology, or Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

ENGTECH 1ET0.name: Introduction to the Technology Co-op Program
ENGTECH 1ET0.prerequisites: Registration in a Degree Completion Technology program

ENGTECH 1MC3.name: Mathematics I
ENGTECH 1MC3.description: Pre-calculus concepts: algebra, trigonometry, complex numbers, exponential and logarithmic functions, systems of equations, matrices, determinants and vectors. Limits, continuity, differential calculus, partial derivatives, applications, sequences and series. Two lectures, two tutorials; first term.
ENGTECH 1MC3.prerequisites: Registration in Automation Systems Engineering Technology, or Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

ENGTECH 1ME3.name: Statics and Mechanics of Materials
ENGTECH 1ME3.description: Statics and kinematics of particles and rigid bodies: force vectors; equilibrium; trusses, frames and machines; internal forces; centroids; friction; axial load, torsion, bending and shear; stress and strain. Newton’s Second Law; moments of inertia; plane motion. Four lectures; second term.
ENGTECH 1ME3.prerequisites: Registration in Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 1MT3.name: Mathematics II
ENGTECH 1MT3.description: Integral calculus involving all the techniques of integration, applications, improper integrals, multiple integrals and integral theorems, infinite sequences and series. Two lectures, two tutorials; second term.
ENGTECH 1MT3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 1MC3 and registration Automation Systems Engineering Technology, or Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

ENGTECH 1PH3.name: Physics
ENGTECH 1PH3.description: Sound, light, kinematics, forces, work, energy, fluid and thermal physics. Four lectures, one lab (two hours every other week); first term.
ENGTECH 1PH3.prerequisites: Registration in Automation Systems Engineering Technology, or Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

ENGTECH 1PP3.name: Python Programming
ENGTECH 1PP3.description: Programming concepts and introduction to Python programming. Python syntax, functions, decision-making, looping, operators, arrays and data structures. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); first term.

ENGTECH 1PR3.name: Object-Oriented Programming
ENGTECH 1PR3.description: Project-based course covering computer programming. Pointers, structured data, object-oriented concepts, inheritance, polymorphism, abstract class and overloading functions. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); second term.
ENGTECH 1PR3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 1CP3 and registration in Automation Systems Engineering Technology or Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 2EE0.name: Four Month Co-op Experience I
ENGTECH 2EE0.prerequisites: ENGINEER 1EE0 and registration in a Four-Year Technology Program and permission of the Engineering Co-op and Career Services Office

ENGTECH 2ES3.name: Engineering Statistics
ENGTECH 2ES3.description: An introductory statistics course covering the following topics with engineering applications: organization and description of data, probability and distributions, confidence intervals and hypothesis testing and bivariate data analysis using regression. Two lectures, one tutorial; first term.
ENGTECH 2ES3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 1MT3 ; and registration in Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 2ET0.name: Four Month Co-op Experience I
ENGTECH 2ET0.prerequisites: ENGTECH 1ET0 , registration in a Degree Completion Technology Co-op program, and permission of the Engineering Co-op and Career Services Office

ENGTECH 2MA3.name: Mathematics III
ENGTECH 2MA3.description: Techniques for solving first and second order ordinary differential equations with applications; initial value and boundary value problems, systems of differential equations, partial differential equations. Two lectures, two tutorials; first term.
ENGTECH 2MA3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 1MT3 ; and registration in Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

ENGTECH 2MS3.name: Modelling and Numerical Solutions
ENGTECH 2MS3.description: Number systems and errors; solutions to nonlinear equations; interpolation by polynomials; matrices and systems of linear equations; numerical integration; spline functions, differential equations; engineering applications. Two lectures, one tutorial; second term.
ENGTECH 2MS3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 1CP3 , ENGTECH 1MT3 ; and registration in Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 2MT3.name: Mathematics IV
