ENGTECH 2MT3.description: Continuous time signals and systems; convolution; Laplace transform, Fourier series and transform; Discrete time signals and systems. Two lectures, two tutorials; second term.
ENGTECH 2MT3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 2MA3 ; and registration in Automation Systems Engineering Technology or Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 3DM3.name: Discrete Mathematics
ENGTECH 3DM3.description: Fundamental discrete mathematics concepts relevant to IT: sets, relations, functions, graphs, propositional logic. State machines. Input/output specifications. Invariants. Three lectures; one term.
ENGTECH 3DM3.prerequisites: Registration in Software Engineering Technology This course is graded on a pass/fail basis.

ENGTECH 3EE0.name: Four Month Co-op Experience II
ENGTECH 3EE0.prerequisites: ENGTECH 2EE0 ; registration in a Four-Year Technology Program; and permission of the Engineering Co-op and Career Services Office

ENGTECH 3ES3.name: Engineering Statistics
ENGTECH 3ES3.description: An introductory statistics course covering the following topics with engineering applications: organization and description of data, probability and distributions, confidence intervals and hypothesis testing and bivariate data analysis using regression. Two lectures, one tutorial; first term.
ENGTECH 3ES3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 1MT3 ; and registration in Level III of Automation Systems Engineering Technology or Biotechnology

ENGTECH 3ET0.name: Four Month Co-op Experience II
ENGTECH 3ET0.prerequisites: ENGTECH 2ET0 , registration in a Degree Completion Technology Co-op program, and permission of the Engineering Co-op and Career Services Office

ENGTECH 3FE3.name: Finite Element Analysis
ENGTECH 3FE3.description: Matrix techniques; eigenvalue problems: equations of elasticity: plane stress, plane strain, 3D problems; variational methods; element types, element stiffness, mass matrices and load vector; assemblage of elements, boundary conditions. Three lectures; first term.
ENGTECH 3FE3.prerequisites: AUTOTECH 2AC3 , AUTOTECH 2TS3 , and registration in Level III of Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 3MA3.name: Mathematics V
ENGTECH 3MA3.description: Ordinary and partial differential equations; Laplace transforms; Fourier series; vector calculus; integral theorems, with engineering applications. Three lectures; one term.
ENGTECH 3MA3.prerequisites: Registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 3ML3.name: Strength of Materials
ENGTECH 3ML3.description: Stresses under combined loads, generalized Hooke’s Law; two and three dimensional stresses, stress transformation, principal stresses, Mohr’s circle; deflections by integration; energy methods, Castagliano’s theorem; columns; yield criteria. Three lectures; one term.
ENGTECH 3ML3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3MA3 , 3SD3 , and registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology or Manufacturing Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 3MN3.name: Modelling and Numerical Solutions
ENGTECH 3MN3.description: Number systems and errors; solutions to nonlinear equations; interpolation by polynomials; matrices and systems of linear equations; differentiation and integration; differential equations; applications to mechanical systems. Two lectures, one tutorial; first term.
ENGTECH 3MN3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 1CP3 , ENGTECH 2MA3 ; and registration in Level IV or above of Automation Systems Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 3SD3.name: Statics and Dynamics
ENGTECH 3SD3.description: Two and three dimensional force vectors, equilibrium of a particle; moments and couples; equilibrium rigid bodies; centroids, second moment of area, moment of inertia; truss, and static analysis. Planar kinematics and planar kinetics of particles and rigid bones; work and energy, impulse, and momentum. Two lectures, one lab; one term.
ENGTECH 3SD3.prerequisites: Registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology or Manufacturing Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 3SP3.name: Structure and Properties of Materials
ENGTECH 3SP3.description: Structure of crystalline solids; imperfections in solids; mechanical properties of metals, dislocations and strengthening mechanisms, failure, phase diagrams, phase transformation in metals, processing of metal alloys, composites, structures and properties of ceramics, processing of ceramics. Three lectures; one term.
ENGTECH 3SP3.prerequisites: Registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology or Manufacturing Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 3ST3.name: Probability and Statistics
ENGTECH 3ST3.description: Probability and statistics for engineering and technology. Descriptive statistics, discrete and continuous random variables and probability distributions, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, analysis of variance, correlation and regression. Three lectures; one term.
ENGTECH 3ST3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3MA3 and registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology

ENGTECH 3TD3.name: Thermodynamics
ENGTECH 3TD3.description: Introduction to thermodynamics, properties of pure substances, first and second laws of thermodynamics, entropy, vapor power cycles, refrigeration cycles, and combined power cycles. Three lectures; one term.
ENGTECH 3TD3.prerequisites: Registration in Manufacturing Engineering Technology or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 4AI3.name: Artificial Intelligence
ENGTECH 4AI3.prerequisites: Registration in level IV of Biotechnology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, OR ENGTECH 3ET0 and registration in Manufacturing Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 4CT3.name: Systems and Control
ENGTECH 4CT3.description: Mathematical models of physical systems; differential equations, Laplace transforms; block diagrams, transfer functions; system transient response; stability analysis in s-, frequency-, and time-domain; Routh-Hurwitz criteria, root-locus analysis, Bode plots, Nyquist criterion, state-space representation; simple PID control systems; lead-lag compensation; digital simulations of control systems. Three lectures; one term.
ENGTECH 4CT3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3MA3 and registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology or Manufacturing Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 4ED3.name: Senior Engineering Design Project
ENGTECH 4ED3.description: A project involving design and synthesis that reinforces concepts gained from previous semesters. Such a project involves research, design, and assessment. Two lectures, one lab; one term.
ENGTECH 4ED3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3ET0 , CIVTECH 4SD3 or 4RC3 ; and registration in Level IV of Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology CIVTECH 4SD3 or 4RC3 may be taken concurrently with this course.

ENGTECH 4EE0.name: Four Month Co-op Experience III
ENGTECH 4EE0.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3EE0 ; registration in a Four-Year Technology Program; and permission of the Engineering Co-op and Career Services Office

ENGTECH 4EP3.name: Senior Engineering Project
ENGTECH 4EP3.description: A project that is based on the knowledge gained from previous semesters. Such a project involves research, design, development and implementation of a process. Three lectures; one term.
ENGTECH 4EP3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3ET0 , ENGTECH 4CT3 , 4PD3, 4PM3, and one of ENRTECH 4RG3 , 4RE3, 4RT3 and registration in Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 4EX0.name: Four Month Co-op Experience
ENGTECH 4EX0.prerequisites: ENGTECH 4EE0 ; registration in a Four-Year Technology program; and permission of the Engineering Co-op and Career Services Office

ENGTECH 4FA3.name: Finite Element Analysis
ENGTECH 4FA3.description: Formerly ENGTECH 3FA3. Matrix techniques, eigenvalue problems, equation of elasticity, 3D problems, variational methods, element types, element stiffness, mass matrix and load vector, assemblage of elements, boundary conditions. Two lectures, one lab; one term.
ENGTECH 4FA3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3ML3 and ENGTECH 4MA3 or CIVTECH 3MN3, and registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology or Manufacturing Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 4FD3.name: Senior Engineering Project
ENGTECH 4FD3.description: Project-based course using the agglomeration of previously acquired knowledge. Research, design, implement and document a software solution to a problem in a real-world application domain. Three lectures, one term.
ENGTECH 4FD3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3ET0 , permission of the Chair and registration in Level IV Software Engineering Technology
ENGTECH 4FD3.antirequisites: SFWRTECH 4FD3 This course is graded on a pass/fail basis.

ENGTECH 4MA3.name: Advanced Mathematics
ENGTECH 4MA3.description: Sequence and series, Fourier series, Matrix algebra, Formulating engineering process models, Numerical solutions techniques, Root findings, Curve fittings, Numerical integration, Numerical differentiation, Ordinary differential equations. Three lectures; one term.
ENGTECH 4MA3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3MA3 and registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENGTECH 4TF3.name: Mechanics of Fluids
ENGTECH 4TF3.description: Fluid statics, flow in closed conduits, dimensional analysis and similarity, energy and Bernoulli’s equation, flow kinematics, hydraulic cross-sections, energy loss in piping system, fluid Machinery. Three lectures, one lab; one term.
ENGTECH 4TF3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3MA3 and registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

ENGLISH 2TP3.name: Literary and Cultural Studies: Theory and Practice
ENGLISH 2TP3.description: This course will offer a grounding in reading literary texts and culture from a range of contemporary critical approaches. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2TP3.prerequisites: Registration in a program in English and Cultural Studies

ENGLISH 3A03.name: Critical Race Studies
ENGLISH 3A03.description: This course examines contemporary debates in critical race theory in an attempt to critically decode the operations of race in literary and cultural texts. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3A03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above in a program in English and Cultural Studies, Justice, Political Philosophy and Law, or Peace Studies.

ENGLISH 3AA3.name: Theories of Gender and Sexuality
ENGLISH 3AA3.description: This course explores a range of theories of gender and sexuality by working through readings from the intersecting fields of feminist, queer and masculinity studies. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3AA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above in a program in English and Cultural Studies, or Justice, Political Philosophy and Law.

ENGLISH 3CR3.name: Writing Out
ENGLISH 3CR3.description: Through a series of modules on the transition from the private world of composition to the increasingly public phases of submitting one’s work for publication to the processes of editing, reviewing, copy-editing, and publication, this course walks students through the steps towards getting their work into the public realm. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3CR3.prerequisites: Registration in the Concurrent Certificate in Creative Writing and Narrative Arts (CWNA) .

ENGLISH 3RW3.name: Reading and Writing in the Field: Experiential Learning in Theory and Practice
ENGLISH 3RW3.description: This course studies the theory and practice of community engagement in connection with literary and cultural studies. Students will integrate an experiential learning opportunity (normally requiring a four-hour a week volunteer placement with a departmental community partner) with academic research, discussion, and writing on relevant topics. Seminar (two hours), and placement hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3RW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of a program in English and Cultural Studies Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 1CS3.name: Studying Culture: A Critical Introduction
ENGLISH 1CS3.description: The course will introduce fundamental concepts and questions in the field of cultural studies, and will prepare students to use those tools in analyzing culture as a site of meaning, identities, power, and pleasure. The course aims to develop your ability to think critically about your own engagements with a broad range of manifestations of culture (e.g. popular culture, social institutions, everyday practices, digital culture, consumer culture). Considerable emphasis will be placed on the development of critical skills in reading and writing. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): CSCT 1CS3.

ENGLISH 1F03.name: The Written World
ENGLISH 1F03.description: What does the world look like when it takes a literary form? We will read and write about one or more literary genres or forms from various times and places, and reflect on the shape of literature, its place in the world, and the place of the world in it. The course functions as an introduction to the study of literature, equipping students with conceptual, analytical and writing tools that will help them become informed readers of the many modes and manners of imaginative expression. Considerable emphasis will be placed on the development of critical skills in reading and writing. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.

ENGLISH 1G03.name: Making and Unmaking Literary Traditions
ENGLISH 1G03.description: This introductory course explores literatures written in English from the perspective of literary historical periods, genres, and critical approaches. We will trace how particular literary traditions emerge in relation to developments in the cultural narratives of, for example, gender and sexuality, selfhood, nation and empire, capitalism, and the environment. We will consider how a literary text is an expression of a particular cultural moment, with all its social and material preoccupations, and yet makes meaning through a complex dialogue with past traditions. The course functions as an introduction to the study of literature, equipping students with conceptual, analytical, and writing tools that will help them become an informed reader of the many modes and manners of imaginative expression. Considerable emphasis will be placed on the development of critical skills in reading and writing. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): ENGLISH 1C06 A/B.

ENGLISH 1H03.name: Words in Place
ENGLISH 1H03.description: Many public ceremonies in Canada now include acknowledgements of whose land we are meeting on. What does it mean to acknowledge the people and the place where we live and work? How do places come into focus when we write and speak about them? This introductory course examines oral narratives, art, poetry, film, documentary, fiction, and/or literary non-fiction that emphasize the dynamics of particular places in relation to Indigenous and colonial histories; diasporic histories of movement, displacement, emigration and immigration; natural, economic, and political geographies; as well as the particular languages – i.e. different Englishes, Indigenous languages – that places give rise to. Considerable emphasis will be placed on the development of critical skills in reading and writing. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.

ENGLISH 2AA3.name: American Literature and Culture Before 1900
ENGLISH 2AA3.description: This course surveys American literary and cultural production up to 1900. Issues may include: settler and colonial culture, the foundations of African-American literature, Indigenous literatures, ante- and post-bellum literatures, dark romanticism, American Renaissance, spiritual narrative. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2AA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 2BB3.name: American Literature and Culture After 1900
ENGLISH 2BB3.description: A specialized approach to studies in 20th and 21st-century American literary and cultural production, focussing on selected movements, issues, genres or traditions. Eg. Native American Renaissance, Asian-American literature and cinema, the Beat Generation, the Harlem Renaissance, American underground commix. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2BB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 2BL3.name: Twentieth- and Twenty-First Century British Literature and Film
ENGLISH 2BL3.description: An introduction to the twentieth- and twenty-first-century literary texts and films from the British Isles, with attention to their historical, cultural, and socio-political contexts. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2BL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 2C03.name: Contemporary Canadian Fiction
ENGLISH 2C03.description: A study of the themes and structure of the contemporary Canadian novel, usually with emphasis on the relationship between Canada’s cultural patterns and its literature. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2C03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 2CC3.name: Settler Colonialism and Writing in Canada
ENGLISH 2CC3.description: This course looks at ways literary writing has contributed to and contested the formation of Canada as a settler colony. Examining a selection of literary works from the stories of European explorers to the present, this course traces how many works have provided the rationale for colonial domination of land and people in Canada, while many others have voiced resistance and imagined alternatives. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2CC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 2CL3.name: Canadian Literature of Dissent and Social Justice
ENGLISH 2CL3.description: This course critically examines the way social justice concerns in Canadian literature, film, and music have grown out of and critiqued dominant narratives about Canadas culture, makeup, and purpose. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2CL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 2CR3.name: Shakespeare: Comedies, Problem Plays, and Romances
ENGLISH 2CR3.description: A close study of selected plays in these genres, together with relevant literary, cultural, theatrical, and historical contexts. May include plays by other dramatists. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2CR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 2CW3.name: Genre in Creative Writing
ENGLISH 2CW3.description: This course combines features of a creative writing workshop with the challenges of working in literary genre. Lectures will introduce the genres available to writers, concentrating on verse forms and short narrative. Students will present installments of their own work in workshops. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2CW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 2HT3.name: Shakespeare: Histories and Tragedies
ENGLISH 2HT3.description: A close study of selected plays in these genres, together with relevant literary, cultural, theatrical, and historical contexts. May include plays by other dramatists. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2HT3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 2KA3.name: Indigenous Futurisms and Wonderworks
ENGLISH 2KA3.description: Through a focus on Indigenous articulated realities and futures, this course refuses colonial narratives of the ‘disappearing Indian’ and insists upon Indigenous presence in past, present, and future as essential for envisioning a human future. Genres of study will include fiction, graphic novels, film, non-fiction, performance, and wonderworks.
ENGLISH 2KA3.prerequisites: One of INDIGST 1A03, 1AA3, 1B03, RECONCIL 1A03; or three units of Level I English; or permission of the Instructor Cross-list(s): INDIGST 2K03 This course is administered by the Indigenous Studies program.

ENGLISH 2KK3.name: Studies in Women Writers
ENGLISH 2KK3.description: A closely focused course on women’s writing in English. The topic for the course varies, sometimes concentrating on specific issues, sometimes on an historical period or national literature. Relevant feminist theory will be a component of the course. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2KK3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program
ENGLISH 2KK3.antirequisites: CSCT 2K06 A/B, CSCT 2KK3, ENGLISH 2K06 A/B, WOMENST 2K06 A/B, 2KK3

ENGLISH 2M03.name: Concepts of Culture
ENGLISH 2M03.description: An analysis of the concept of culture from the Enlightenment to the present. Theoretical readings combined with the analysis of specific cultural texts, objects, forms, and practices will allow students to trace historical and contemporary debates concerning culture. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2M03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program
ENGLISH 2M03.antirequisites: ARTHIST 2M03, CMST 2M03, CSCT 2M03, CSCT 2M06 A/B, ENGLISH 2M06 A/B

ENGLISH 2NH3.name: Narratives of Health
ENGLISH 2NH3.description: This course inquires into representations of health with reference to a range of media. Critical frameworks may include critical disability studies, environmental humanities, feminist research, critical race studies, science and technology studies, narrative medicine, and Indigenous studies. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2NH3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 2PC3.name: Popular Culture
ENGLISH 2PC3.description: This course examines the study of everyday culture, its underlying assumptions, its locations, and the capacity of audiences to engage actively and critically with it. Possible areas of study may include: advertising, fandom, film, TV, social media, youth culture, celebrity, memes, comics, online apps, popular music, video. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2PC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 2VC3.name: Topics in Visual Culture
ENGLISH 2VC3.description: This course examines visual texts in a select media and genres through an exploration of a variety of theoretical discourses and representational practices. Approaches can include cultural studies, film theories, and gender, queer, and critical race theories. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2VC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program.

ENGLISH 2Z03.name: Reading Environmental Humanities
ENGLISH 2Z03.description: A study of representations of nature in a variety of written and visual texts. Topics may include food, environmental crisis, development, humans and other animals. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 2Z03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 3CP3.name: Writing Practices
ENGLISH 3CP3.description: This course focuses on creative writing as a practice rather than a process towards material products, exploring the relationship between habitual writing exercises and an understanding of how writing–as activity, discourse, archive–helps shape the world as we experience it. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3CP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 3CW3.name: Creating Writing in/for/with Communities
ENGLISH 3CW3.description: This creative writing inquiry class engages students in the staged development of a creative writing project in consultation with and on behalf of a community of their choice. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3CW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 3EC3.name: Enlightenment and its Shadows
ENGLISH 3EC3.description: A study of British Literature and Culture of the long eighteenth-century (1660-1800), including plays, poetry, fiction, and essays. Themes include sexual politics, consumerism, globalization, the public sphere, and subjectivity. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3EC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 3GF3.name: Topics in Popular Genres
ENGLISH 3GF3.description: This course will provide an in-depth exploration of the conventions and consumption of one or more popular genres, such as graphic narrative, science fiction, romance, horror, crime writing, fantasy, chicklit or memoir. Three lectures; one term.
ENGLISH 3GF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program
ENGLISH 3GF3.antirequisites: CSCT 3GF3 ENGLISH 3GF3 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

ENGLISH 3GG3.name: Theories of Decolonization and Resistance
ENGLISH 3GG3.description: A study of theoretical and cultural works that examine the effects of empire and chart projects for decolonization. Introduces debates in Indigenous and postcolonial studies, including as they engage with theories of racial capitalism, gender and sexuality, globalization, war, environmental change. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3GG3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program
ENGLISH 3GG3.antirequisites: CSCT 3R06 A/B, ENGLISH 3R06 A/B, PEACEST 3E06 A/B, PEACEST 3GG3 Cross-list(s): PEACJUST 3GG3

ENGLISH 3GS3.name: Reading the Embodied Past: Gender and Sexuality
ENGLISH 3GS3.description: A study of representations of gender, sexuality, and/or their institutions and intimacies in pre-20th century literature and culture, with attention to their material, cultural, and socio-political contexts. Students will examine social issues through the study of early fiction, non-fiction, drama, and poetry. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3GS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 3H03.name: Jane Austen
ENGLISH 3H03.description: A critical evaluation of a selection of Jane Austen’s work with a focus on exploring late 18th- and early 19th-century British culture. Three lectures; one term.
ENGLISH 3H03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 3NH3.name: Narratives of Health
ENGLISH 3NH3.description: This course inquires into representations of health with reference to a range of media. Critical frameworks may include critical disability studies, environmental humanities, feminist research, critical race studies, science and technology studies, narrative medicine, and Indigenous studies. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3NH3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 3QQ3.name: Contemporary Critical Theory
ENGLISH 3QQ3.description: This course examines selected issues in contemporary critical theory. Areas of investigation may include: representation, power/knowledge, discourse, subjectivity and the body. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3QQ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 3V03.name: Global Anglophone Literature and Film
ENGLISH 3V03.description: A study of literature, film and other forms of popular culture by artists from South Asia, Africa, and the Caribbean, and their overseas diasporas. Introduces students to theories of race, gender, sexuality, indigeneity, citizenship, and the nation as these take up histories of colonialism, imperialism, and globalization. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3V03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program
ENGLISH 3V03.antirequisites: CSCT 3R06 A/B, ENGLISH 3R06 A/B, PEACEST 3E06 A/B Cross-list(s): PEACJUST 3V03

ENGLISH 3VC3.name: ‘We Other Victorians’: Victorian Literature and Culture and Its Afterlives
ENGLISH 3VC3.description: Drawing on a broad range of literary and cultural texts, this course explores the continuing legacy of Victorian Britain (1832-1901) in setting the agendas for Western modernity. Topics include the contested discourses on sexuality, poverty, evolution, technology, and imperialism. Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3VC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 3W03.name: Contemporary Native Literature in Canada
ENGLISH 3W03.description: A study of significant works by Native writers who give voice to their experience in Canada. Issues examined include appropriation of voice, native identity, women in indigenous societies and stereotyping. Three hours (lectures and seminars); one term.
ENGLISH 3W03.prerequisites: Six units of Level II Indigenous Studies or six units of Level II English and Cultural Studies or permission of the instructor
ENGLISH 3W03.antirequisites: CSCT 3W03, PEACEST 3W03 Cross-list(s): INDIGST 3D03 , PEACJUST 3W03 This course is administered by Indigenous Studies.

ENGLISH 3WE3.name: British Romantic Literature and Culture: Revolution, War, Empire
ENGLISH 3WE3.description: The course explores British Literature and culture between the advent of the French Revolution (1789) and the turbulent decade following the world-shaking violence of the Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars (1792-1815). Three hours; one term.
ENGLISH 3WE3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

ENGLISH 3X03.name: Contemporary Native Literature in the United States
ENGLISH 3X03.description: A study of contemporary works by Native writers in the United States within the context of American society and Post-Modern and Post-Colonial Literary Theory. Three hours (lectures and seminars); one term.
ENGLISH 3X03.prerequisites: Six units of Level II Indigenous Studies or six units of Level II English and Cultural Studies or permission of the instructor
ENGLISH 3X03.antirequisites: CSCT 3X03, PEACEST 3X03 Cross-list(s): INDIGST 3E03 , PEACJUST 3X03 This course is administered by Indigenous Studies.

ENGLISH 4AN3.name: Nineteenth-Century Adaptations
ENGLISH 4AN3.description: This course inquires into the ideological, political, and aesthetic motivations that inform recent adaptations in fiction and film of the British nineteenth century. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4AN3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies

ENGLISH 4CA3.name: Under the Gaze of the Nonhuman: Critical Animal Studies
ENGLISH 4CA3.description: This seminar introduces students to a range of contemporary debates about nonhuman animals, and in particular investigates our ethical and political responsibilities towards them. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4CA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies. Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 4CC3.name: Creative Writing Capstone
ENGLISH 4CC3.description: In this course students will design and execute a creative-writing project of approximately 20 to 25 pages. Installments will be shared with the class on a weekly basis under the supervision of mentors. Project (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4CC3.prerequisites: ENGLISH 2CW3 ; 3 units of ENGLISH 3CP3 , 3CR3 , 3CW3 , 4FW3 , or 4SD3 ; credit or registration in an additional 3 units of ENGLISH 3CP3 , 3CR3 , 3CW3 , 4FW3 , or 4SD3 ; registration in the Concurrent Certificate in Creative Writing and Narrative Arts (CWNA) .

ENGLISH 4CF3.name: Contemporary Fiction
ENGLISH 4CF3.description: A study of recent English and American fiction, with emphasis on metafiction as well as the relationship between contemporary literary theory and fiction. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4CF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies

ENGLISH 4DL3.name: Digital Lives
ENGLISH 4DL3.description: A critical investigation of the burgeoning domain of online life writing, concentrating on 2-4 selected “automedia” modes, such as digital photography, iphoneographies, public social media accounts, online diaries, vlogs, blogs, podcasts, multi-platform projects, and/or hashtag campaigns. A main concern will be the possibilities and the limitations of online life writing modalities for “self-authoring” and social justice activism. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4DL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 4E03.name: Literature, Culture and Climate Catastrophe
ENGLISH 4E03.description: Drawing on environmental humanities, Anthropocene studies, anti-colonial, feminist, and critical race theories, this seminar considers how different creative genres (eg. fiction, poetry, film) imagine forms of belonging amid the dislocations of the climate catastrophe. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4E03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 4ED3.name: Windrush Writing/Writing Windrush: Empire, Race and Decolonization
ENGLISH 4ED3.description: This course will examine work by writers of the Windrush generation (1950s and 1960s) and the stories told about Windrush migration. Topics include Empire, decolonization, British multiculturalism, commemorations and the Windrush scandal. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4ED3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 4FW3.name: Forms of Creative Writing
ENGLISH 4FW3.description: This seminar will combine a hands-on study of form with an opportunity for students to exercise and focus their own creative energies. In any given year, the course will concentrate on either verse or fictional form. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4FW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 4GN3.name: Graphic Narrative in Canada
ENGLISH 4GN3.description: This seminar examines graphic narrative in Canada, focusing on: its divergent engagements with national narratives; Indigenous storytelling; national regimes of belonging/dispossession; and transnational relations. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4GN3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies

ENGLISH 4IW3.name: Twenty-First Century Indigenous Writing and Film
ENGLISH 4IW3.description: A critical examination of recent works by Indigenous authors and filmmakers that give voice to contemporary social, cultural, and political realities in Canada. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4IW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies Cross-list(s): INDIGST 4IW3 Departmental permission required. This course is administered by the Department of English and Cultural Studies.

ENGLISH 4LF3.name: Diné and Dene Literature and Film
ENGLISH 4LF3.description: This course will analyze the ways Diné (Navajo) and Dene literature and film challenge and reframe self (subjectivity) and place (dislocated, relocated, diasporic, and decolonized). Texts may include film, fiction, poetry, orality, autobiography, literary criticism, and scholarly prose. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4LF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies Cross-list(s): INDIGST 4LF3 Departmental permission required. This course is administered by the Department of English and Cultural Studies.

ENGLISH 4ML3.name: What is Millennial Literature?
ENGLISH 4ML3.description: What gathers under the sign of “millennial”? Do millennial writers cohere into a unique generational voice? How have they redefined artistic genres like the novel? Topics may include polyvocality, neoliberalism, surveillance, pandemic, inequality, and climate change. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4ML3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 4QA3.name: Queerness in the Archives: Lesbian and Gay Writing, Art and Activism in Canada, 1969-1989
ENGLISH 4QA3.description: This course examines lesbian and gay writing, art and activism in Canada during the period of 1969 to 1989. The course will include a trip to the Canadian Lesbian and Gay Archives in Toronto, and students will be trained in archival research methods. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4QA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 4RD3.name: Renaissance Drama, Excluding Shakespeare
ENGLISH 4RD3.description: An intensive study of transgression (economic, erotic, social and literary) in popular and elite drama by Shakespeare’s contemporaries, including women writers. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4RD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 4RI3.name: Colonialism and Resistance in Representations of Indigenous Womanhood
ENGLISH 4RI3.description: This course looks to representations of Indigenous womanhood in a range of contemporary and historical cultural productions for insights into how colonialism shapes all of our lives, in radically different ways. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4RI3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies
ENGLISH 4RI3.antirequisites: CSCT 4RI3 Cross-list(s): INDIGST 4RI3 Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 4RS3.name: Reading, Spirituality and Cultural Politics
ENGLISH 4RS3.description: Through a course of readings from a variety of historical and contemporary sources this class will investigate the relations between spirituality, reading and living in the public, social world. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4RS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies

ENGLISH 4SD3.name: Sentenced to Death
ENGLISH 4SD3.description: This is a course about the grammar, syntax, rhetoric, and expressive potential of language’s most familiar unit of meaning; the sentence. Students’ weekly creative writing exercises will provide the materials for our exploration. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4SD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 4ST3.name: Even Stranger Things: The Early Gothic
ENGLISH 4ST3.description: One of the more paradoxical legacies of the British Enlightenment is the Gothic, with its attraction to the ghastly and the supernatural. This seminar will chart the emergence of Gothic writing in the eighteenth century, with particular attention to how this literature responds to the social ills and anxieties that attend the emergence of modern life. Seminar (two hours); one term.
ENGLISH 4ST3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 4X03.name: Honours Essay
ENGLISH 4X03.description: Under the supervision of a member of the Department of English and Cultural Studies , students will write an essay in second term of Level IV. Interested students should contact the faculty member chairing the ENGLISH 4X03 committee early in the first term.
ENGLISH 4X03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 4Y03.name: Experiential Practicum I
ENGLISH 4Y03.description: This practicum provides students with experience in experiential education under the mentorship of a faculty member. Faculty members will advertise their available projects in the spring, or students may develop a proposal in consultation with a member of the department. Final proposals are due to the Department in May of the previous academic year.
ENGLISH 4Y03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies
ENGLISH 4Y03.antirequisites: ENGLISH 4Y06 A/B S Departmental permission required.

ENGLISH 4YY3.name: Experiential Practicum II
ENGLISH 4YY3.description: This practicum provides students with additional experience in experiential education under the mentorship of a faculty member. Faculty members will advertise their available projects in the spring, or students may develop a proposal in consultation with a member of the department. Final proposals are due to the Department in May of the previous academic year.
ENGLISH 4YY3.prerequisites: ENGLISH 4Y03 and registration in Level IV of an Honours program in English and Cultural Studies
ENGLISH 4YY3.antirequisites: ENGLISH 4Y06 A/B S Departmental permission required.

ENVIRSC 1C03.name: Climate, Water and Environment
ENVIRSC 1C03.description: An introduction to the science of environmental issues and sustainability through the study of the soil, climate and water processes. Lectures, web modules (three hours), one lab (two hours); one term Co-requisite(s): WHMIS 1A00 , if not already completed, must be completed prior to the first lab. Antirequisite(s): ENVIRSC 1A03, 1B03.

ENVIRSC 2B03.name: Soils and the Environment
ENVIRSC 2B03.description: An introduction to the physical, chemical and biological properties of soil. Application to environmental and land-use impacts. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
ENVIRSC 2B03.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 1G03, ENVIRSC 1C03, 1G03, ISCI 1A24 A/B

ENVIRSC 2C03.name: Surface Climate Processes and Environmental Interactions
ENVIRSC 2C03.description: The surface heat and water balance of natural and human-modified landscapes. Emphasis on interactions of people and the biosphere with climate. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); one term.
ENVIRSC 2C03.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 1G03, ENVIRSC 1C03, 1G03, ISCI 1A24 A/B

ENVIRSC 2Q03.name: Introduction to Environmental Geochemistry
ENVIRSC 2Q03.description: Introductory study of the interactions of geochemistry (water-rock interaction) and biology in determining pH, oxygen status and ionic strength in water, and their implications will be explored through lecture and laboratory work. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
ENVIRSC 2Q03.prerequisites: ISCI 1A24; or CHEM 1A03 and one of EARTHSC 1G03, ENVIR SC 1C03, ENVIR SC 1G03; or registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Engineering. ENVIR SC 1C03 is recommended.

ENVIRSC 2W03.name: Physical Hydrology
ENVIRSC 2W03.description: Hydrological processes including precipitation, snowmelt, hillslope runoff, streamflow and hydrological data analysis. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); one term.
ENVIRSC 2W03.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 1G03, ENVIRSC 1C03, 1G03 or ISCI 1A24 A/B. ENVIRSC 1C03 or ISCI 1A24 A/B is strongly recommended.

ENVIRSC 2WW3.name: Water and the Environment
ENVIRSC 2WW3.description: An introduction to environmental issues related to water, including the impacts of climate change, effects of water management projects, pollution, the societal dimensions of these problems, and paths to sustainability. Lectures, (three hours); one term.
ENVIRSC 2WW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above.

ENVIRSC 3B03.name: Ecosystems and Global Change
ENVIRSC 3B03.description: An examination of both the impacts of global change on ecosystem form and function and the restoration of ecosystems as nature-based solutions to address global change. A strong emphasis is placed on understanding how soil, water, vegetation, ecosystems and climate processes occur and interact at landscape, regional and global scales. One lecture (two hours), one lab (two hours); one term.

ENVIRSC 3IN3.name: Internship in Earth and Environmental Sciences
ENVIRSC 3IN3.description: The integration of academic learning with an employment or a volunteer experience, providing students the opportunity to explore careers and develop linkages between classroom knowledge and professional practice. Students are responsible to arrange a suitable internship and agreement of the supervisor. Normally, students complete 130 hours of academic work through the duration of the employment or volunteer experience. One meeting (one hour); one term.
ENVIRSC 3IN3.prerequisites: SCIENCE 2C00 ; and registration in Level III or above of an Honours B.Sc. program in the School of Earth, Environment & Society (Faculty of Science); and permission of the internship coordinator
ENVIRSC 3IN3.antirequisites: EARTHSC 3IN3 Note: Students participating in this course must be authorized to work in Canada (International students must provide proof of work authorization permit). Students intending to enrol in this course should submit an application to the internship coordinator two months prior to registration. Application forms are available on the School of Earth, Environment & Society (Faculty of Science) website. ENVIRSC 3IN3 may be repeated with permission of the School of Earth, Environment & Society (Faculty of Science) if based on a different employment or volunteer experience.

ENVIRSC 3ME3.name: Environmental Field Camp
ENVIRSC 3ME3.description: Within the context of a field project, this course introduces students to field techniques in environmental science and to the potential effects of environmental issues on human health and well-being. The field camp component occurs outside of the regular academic term, usually two weeks preceding the start of term in September. Details and applications are available in March through the School of Earth, Environment & Society. Students enrolling in this course must pay both the incidental fees as prescribed by the School of Earth, Environment & Society and the regular tuition fees. Students intending to enrol in this course must submit an application by April 1 of the academic year prior to registration. Application forms are available from the School of Earth, Environment & Society main office after March 1. Students will be informed of acceptance of their application by April 15 subject to fulfillment of the requirements. One term.
ENVIRSC 3ME3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2B03, 2E03 , 2EI3, 2Q03, ENVIRSC 2B03, 2E03, 2Q03 , ENVSOCTY 2EI3 , GEOG 2EI3, ISCI 2A18 A/B ; and registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in the School of Earth, Environment & Society; and permission of the instructor. One of EARTHSC 2Q03, ENVIRSC 2Q03  is recommended. Co-requisite(s): WHMIS 1A00 , if not already completed, must be completed prior to the first lab.

ENVIRSC 3O03.name: Contaminant Fate and Transport
ENVIRSC 3O03.description: Focuses on the primary mechanisms controlling the distribution, transport and fate of contaminants, particularly organic contaminants, throughout the environment with an emphasis aquatic pollution and atmosphere-aquatic interactions. Topics include partitioning processes (dissolution, volatilization, sorption), degradation and contaminant remediation processes (abiotic, biotic) and analytical techniques used to measure concentrations in environmental samples. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
ENVIRSC 3O03.prerequisites: One of CHEM 2OA3 , 2P03 , CHEMBIO 2OA3, 2OG3 , 2P03 , EARTHSC 2L03, 2Q03, ENVIRSC 2L03, 2Q03 , ISCI 2A18 A/B , or registration in an Honours Biology or Honours Chemistry program, or a program in the Faculty of Engineering

ENVIRSC 4BB3.name: Field Techniques in Hydrology
ENVIRSC 4BB3.description: A primarily field-based course that examines the field methods, techniques and equipment used to study watershed hydrology and ecohydrological function in natural, human-impacted and restored ecosystems. One lecture (two hours), one lab (four hours); one term.
ENVIRSC 4BB3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 3B03, 3W03 , ENVIRSC 3B03 , 3W03 with a minimum grade of C+. Completion of ENVIRSC 3ME3 is strongly recommended.

ENVIRSC 4C03.name: Advanced Physical Climatology
ENVIRSC 4C03.description: This course develops energy and mass exchange processes in the near surface layer, the lower atmosphere and at the earth-atmosphere interface. Sensitivities of these processes to environmental change and feedback mechanisms are examined. Seminars and individual presentations are emphasized. One lecture (two hours), one lab (two hours); one term.

ENVIRSC 4EA3.name: Environmental Assessment
ENVIRSC 4EA3.description: Technical and policy issues involved in the production and the appraisal of environmental impact assessments. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); one term.
ENVIRSC 4EA3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2EI3, ENVIRSC 2EI3, ENVSOCTY 2EI3 , GEOG 2EI3; or registration in Honours Biology, a Civil Engineering program, an Engineering and Society program, an Honours Integrated Science program or an Honours program in the School of Earth, Environment & Society

ENVIRSC 4MI3.name: Independent Study in Earth and Environmental Sciences
ENVIRSC 4MI3.description: An independent study under the supervision of a faculty member. Students will typically complete a major review paper or research paper on a topic of their choice, in the field of Earth and Environmental Sciences. One meeting (one hour); one term.
ENVIRSC 4MI3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in the School of Earth, Environment & Society (Faculty of Science); and permission of the supervising faculty member

ENVIRSC 4N03.name: Global Biogeochemical Cycles
ENVIRSC 4N03.description: This course focusses on global cycles of elements and energy, the role of biological processes in these cycles, and the concurrent influence of these cycles on biology and its environment. Topics will include the use of isotopic analysis to understand modern and past cycles, the interaction between global and local processes, and natural and anthropogenic effects on biogeochemical cycles. Two lectures, one lab (three hours); one term.
ENVIRSC 4N03.prerequisites: One of BIOLOGY 2F03 , CHEM 2P03 , CHEMBIO 2P03 , EARTHSC 2L03, 2Q03, ENVIRSC 2L03, 2Q03 , ISCI 2A18 A/B . One of EARTHSC 3CC3 , 3O03, ENVIRSC 3CC3, 3O03 is strongly recommended.

ENVIRSC 4W03.name: Hydrologic Modelling
ENVIRSC 4W03.description: Principles of numerical modelling and examination of selected hydrologic models including deterministic, conceptual and statistical models. One lecture (two hours), one lab (two hours); one term.
ENVIRSC 4W03.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2W03, 3W03 , ENVIRSC 2W03 , 3W03; and one of EARTHSC 3MB3, ENVSOCTY 3MB3 , GEOG 3MB3, ENVIRSC 3MB3, STATS 2B03 , 3J04

ENVSOCTY 1HA3.name: Society, Culture and Environment
ENVSOCTY 1HA3.description: Formerly GEOG 1HA3 An introduction to human (societal) - environment interactions, mostly through a human geographic perspective. Topics include: the spatial significance of culture and cultural difference; cities as forms of cultural settlements; the rise of urban societies; the meanings of cultural landscapes; geographical perspectives on local and global politics; humans’ changing relationship with the environment; and contemporary environmental issues. Two lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term Antirequisite(s): GEOG 1HA3.

ENVSOCTY 1HB3.name: Population, Cities and Development
ENVSOCTY 1HB3.description: Formerly GEOG 1HB3 An introduction to the study of relationships between people and their environments. The natural, built, social and economic environments are examined through human geography, urban studies, population and development studies, and environmental studies. Topics include: the meaning, and changing significance, of globalization; the causes and consequences of uneven economic and social development; the nature of changes in world population via demographic change and migration; the nature and consequences of global urbanization; and urban planning. Three hours; one term Antirequisite(s): GEOG 1HB3 This course may be offered in-person or online.  Students are encouraged to check scheduling information and the course outline to confirm the course offering details.

ENVSOCTY 2EI3.name: Environment & Society: Challenges and Solutions
ENVSOCTY 2EI3.description: Formerly GEOG 2EI3 A discussion of perspectives and approaches to local, regional, national, and global environmental problems. Lectures (two hours), one tutorial (one hour); one term.
ENVSOCTY 2EI3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above. One of BIOLOGY 1M03, EARTHSC 1G03, ENVIRSC 1C03, 1G03, ENVSOCTY 1HA3, 1HB3, GEOG 1HA3, 1HB3, ISCI 1A24 A/B is recommended.

ENVSOCTY 2EK3.name: Traditional Indigenous Ecological Knowledge
ENVSOCTY 2EK3.description: Formerly GEOG 2EK3 This course is a study of the ecological teachings of Indigenous peoples and of their relationships with the natural environment in historical and contemporary times. Three hours (lectures and seminars); one term.
ENVSOCTY 2EK3.prerequisites: Three units Level 1 Indigenous Studies or permission of the instructor
ENVSOCTY 2EK3.antirequisites: GEOG 2EK3 Cross-list(s): ANTHROP 2DA3, INDIGST 2D03 This course is administered by the Indigenous Studies Program.

ENVSOCTY 2GI3.name: Geographic Information Systems
ENVSOCTY 2GI3.description: Formerly GEOG 2GI3 Introduction to the principles and techniques underlying the use of geographic information systems (GIS) for capturing and visualizing spatially referenced information. Databases, models and cartographic principles are also introduced emphasizing the production of effective thematic maps using GIS software. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 2GI3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

ENVSOCTY 2HI3.name: Health and Place
ENVSOCTY 2HI3.description: Formerly GEOG 2HI3 Introduction to health geography. Contemporary trends and patterns of global mortality and morbidity are explored using examples from different parts of the world. A range of perspectives are used to compliment a geographical viewpoint, including: medical, cultural, ecological, social and demographic. Two lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.

ENVSOCTY 2LE3.name: Economic Geography: Innovation, Inequality and Identity
ENVSOCTY 2LE3.description: Formerly GEOG 2LE3 An introduction to the spatial organization of the capitalist economy. Students will critically examine economic activities at different scales using case studies such as global commodity chains, urban and regional economies, and the home as a site of economic power. Emphasis is placed on understanding the fundamentals of capitalism, its production of uneven development, and post-capitalist visions for our economies. Two lectures; one term.

ENVSOCTY 2OC3.name: Regional Geography of Canada
ENVSOCTY 2OC3.description: Formerly GEOG 2OC3 An introduction to the human and physical geography of Canada from a regional perspective. Emphasis is placed on the similarities and differences among Canada’s regions. Topics include historical and contemporary perspectives on economic, social, and cultural geographies as well as environmental issues. On-line web modules, discussions and testing; one term.
ENVSOCTY 2OC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above. Completion of ENVSOCTY 1HA3 or 1HB3 , GEOG 1HA3 or 1HB3 is recommended.

ENVSOCTY 2RC3.name: Regional Geography of Canada
ENVSOCTY 2RC3.description: Formerly GEOG 2RC3 An introduction to the human and physical geography of Canada from a regional perspective. Emphasis is placed on the similarities and differences between Canada’s regions. Topics include historical and contemporary perspectives on economic, social, and cultural geographies as well as environmental issues. Three lectures; one term.
ENVSOCTY 2RC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above. Completion of ENVSOCTY 1HA3 or 1HB3 , GEOG 1HA3 or 1HB3 is recommended.

ENVSOCTY 2RU3.name: Regional Geography of the United States
ENVSOCTY 2RU3.description: Formerly GEOG 2RU3 An introduction to the human and physical geography of the United States of America from a regional perspective. Emphasis is placed on the human and physical elements that make each region unique. Topics include economic, social, political and cultural geographies, as well as environmental issues and problems. Three lectures, fully online; one term.
ENVSOCTY 2RU3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above. Completion of ENVSOCTY 1HA3 or 1HB3 , GEOG 1HA3 or 1HB3 is recommended.

ENVSOCTY 2RW3.name: World Regional Geography
ENVSOCTY 2RW3.description: Formerly GEOG 2RW3 An introduction to regional geography and global issues. The study of the human and physical geographic patterns of the world. Emphasis is placed equally on what makes places and regions different or unique, and the key global issues that relate to one or more regions. Topics include urbanization, economic change, cultural difference, geopolitics, and environmental issues. Three lectures, fully online; one term.
ENVSOCTY 2RW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above. Completion of ENVSOCTY 1HA3 or 1HB3 , GEOG 1HA3 or 1HB3 is recommended.

ENVSOCTY 2TF3.name: Food, Power and Place
ENVSOCTY 2TF3.description: Who really controls the food system? Are food banks helping or hurting the fight against hunger? Why are grocery stores organized the way they are? How do families negotiate gender roles in the kitchen? This course takes a critical approach to these and other questions about our food system. We consider how our relationship to food is mediated by the state, private business, and charity. We explore global strategies to create more just, equitable and sustainable food systems. Two lectures (two hours and one hour); one term.
ENVSOCTY 2TF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

ENVSOCTY 2TS3.name: Society and Space
ENVSOCTY 2TS3.description: Formerly GEOG 2TS3 This course introduces key concepts and perspectives in social geography. Emphasis is placed on the importance of key binaries that structure the spatial organization of social life (e.g., urban/rural, public/private, and space/place). Three lectures; one term.
ENVSOCTY 2TS3.prerequisites: One of ENVSOCTY 1HA3 , 1HB3 , GEOG 1HA3, 1HB3; and registration in Level II or above

ENVSOCTY 2UI3.name: The Urban Experience
ENVSOCTY 2UI3.description: Formerly GEOG 2UI3 Key concepts and perspectives in the study of urbanization, urban systems and city life. Emphasis is placed on North American urban experience. Two lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.

ENVSOCTY 3EC3.name: Environmental Catastrophes
ENVSOCTY 3EC3.description: Formerly GEOG 3EC3 A discussion of environmental catastrophes such as large-scale releases of environmental contaminants, their context and their effects on human populations. Examples include the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico and the Chernobyl nuclear catastrophe. Human and systemic errors will be explored historically, politically and economically. Two lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.
ENVSOCTY 3EC3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2EI3, ENVIRSC 2EI3, ENVSOCTY 2EI3 , GEOG 2EI3

ENVSOCTY 3EE3.name: Energy and Society
ENVSOCTY 3EE3.description: Formerly GEOG 3EE3 An introduction to conventional and alternative sources of energy as they are used in Canadian and global contexts. The social, political and economic costs and benefits of different sources of energy will be highlighted. Two lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.
ENVSOCTY 3EE3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2EI3, ENVIRSC 2EI3, ENVSOCTY 2EI3 , GEOG 2EI3, ISCI 2A18 A/B

ENVSOCTY 3EG3.name: Politics of a Dying Planet
ENVSOCTY 3EG3.description: Formerly GEOG 3EG3 An examination of the politics that is steering humanity to the brink of catastrophic climate change and planetary mass extinction. It investigates the politics that generates, and is generated by, a dying planet. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 3EG3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above

ENVSOCTY 3EN3.name: Northern Environments and Societies
ENVSOCTY 3EN3.description: Exploration of the environmental, social, cultural, economic, and political opportunities and challenges that shape the Canadian North. Particular emphasis is placed on diversity and change. Two lectures (two hours and one hour); one term.

ENVSOCTY 3ER3.name: Sustainability and the Economy
ENVSOCTY 3ER3.description: Formerly GEOG 3ER3 This course explores the triple bottom line: the intersection of economic, ecological and social costs and benefits. Examples are drawn from sectors such as climate change, fisheries, forestry and water. Two lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.
ENVSOCTY 3ER3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2EI3, ENVIRSC 2EI3, ENVSOCTY 2EI3 , GEOG 2EI3

ENVSOCTY 3GI3.name: Advanced Raster GIS
ENVSOCTY 3GI3.description: Formerly GEOG 3GI3 Advanced treatment of geographic information systems (GIS) focusing on raster data models and techniques. Real-world problem solving emphasizes site selection and environmental applications. Topics include multicriteria evaluation, terrain mapping and analysis, 3D visualization, spatial interpolation and watershed analysis. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 3GI3.prerequisites: A minimum grade of C- in one of EARTHSC 2GI3, ENVIRSC 2GI3, ENVSOCTY 2GI3 , GEOG 2GI3

ENVSOCTY 3GV3.name: Advanced Vector GIS
ENVSOCTY 3GV3.description: Formerly GEOG 3GV3 Advanced treatment of GIS focusing on vector data models and techniques. Real-world problem solving emphasizes health, business, public sector and transportation applications. Topics include geodatabase design, geocoding, networks and network applications, location-allocation modeling and GIS tool development using ModelBuilder. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 3GV3.prerequisites: A minimum grade of C- in one of EARTHSC 2GI3, ENVIRSC 2GI3, ENVSOCTY 2GI3 , GEOG 2GI3

ENVSOCTY 3HP3.name: Population, Health and Aging
ENVSOCTY 3HP3.description: Formerly GEOG 3HP3 Differential growth of human populations and their changing age and sex structures with an emphasis on birth, death, and immigration processes. The connections between population structures and processes and various aspects of environments and societies, including aging and health, are emphasized. One lecture (two hours), one tutorial (one hour); one term.

ENVSOCTY 3LT3.name: Transportation Geography
ENVSOCTY 3LT3.description: Formerly GEOG 3LT3 Transportation is studied as a geographical phenomenon, including important conceptual, analytical, and practical issues. From the conceptual foundations of transportation, through methods to describe, predict, and manage transportation systems, this course covers movement at various geographical scales. Labs complement lectures with data analysis problems in transportation applications. Math equivalent to high school algebra is used in parts of the course. Two lectures, one tutorial (two hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 3LT3.prerequisites: One of ECON 1B03 , 1BB3 , ENVSOCTY 1HA3 , 1HB3 , GEOG 1HA3, 1HB3; and registration in Level III or above

ENVSOCTY 3MA3.name: Research Methods
ENVSOCTY 3MA3.description: Formerly GEOG 3MA3 An introduction to research methods in human geography. Emphasis is placed on the application of various methods to understanding human spatial behaviour. Two lectures, one tutorial (two hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 3MA3.prerequisites: One of ENVSOCTY 1HA3 , 1HB3 , GEOG 1HA3, 1HB3; and registration in Level II or above of a program in the School of Earth, Environment & Society (Faculty of Science)
ENVSOCTY 3MA3.antirequisites: CMST 2B03, GEOG 2MA3, 3MA3, GERONTOL 2C03, HEALTHST 2B03, HLTHAGE 2A06, 3Z06, SOCIOL 2Z03

ENVSOCTY 3MB3.name: Data Analysis
ENVSOCTY 3MB3.description: Formerly GEOG 3MB3 An introduction to the nature of geographic data and organization, descriptive spatial statistics and inferential statistics. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 3MB3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 1G03, ENVIRSC 1C03, 1G03, ENVSOCTY 1HA3, 1HB3, GEOG 1HA3, 1HB3, ISCI 1A24 A/B

ENVSOCTY 3MF3.name: Urban Field Camp
ENVSOCTY 3MF3.description: Formerly GEOG 3MF3 An experiential and problem-based introduction to field techniques used in human geography, urban studies and planning, with a focus on how people experience and transform the built, social and natural environments of cities. Most of this course occurs outside the regular academic term, usually in one of the two weeks prior to the start of term in September. Details and applications are available in March. Students enrolling in this course must pay both the incidental fees as prescribed by the School of Earth, Environment & Society as well as the regular tuition fees. Students intending to enrol in this course must submit an application by April 1 of the academic year prior to registration. Application forms are available from the School of Earth, Environment & Society main office after March 1. Students will be informed of acceptance of their application by April 15 subject to fulfillment of the requirements. One term.
ENVSOCTY 3MF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in the School of Earth, Environment & Society; and permission of the instructor

ENVSOCTY 3MI3.name: Internship in Environment and Society
ENVSOCTY 3MI3.description: Formerly GEOG 3MI3 The integration of academic learning with an employment experience, providing students the opportunity to explore careers and develop linkages between classroom knowledge and professional practice. Students are responsible to arrange a suitable internship and agreement of the supervisor. This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis. Normally, students complete 130 hours of academic work through the duration of the employment or volunteer experience.
ENVSOCTY 3MI3.prerequisites: SOCSCI 2EL0 ; and registration in Level III or above of an Honours B.A. program in the School of Earth, Environment & Society; and permission of the internship coordinator
ENVSOCTY 3MI3.antirequisites: GEOG 3MI3 Note: Students participating in this course must be authorized to work in Canada (International students must provide proof of work authorization permit). Students intending to enrol in this course should submit an application to the internship coordinator two months prior to registration. Application forms are available from the School of Earth, Environment & Society main office.

ENVSOCTY 3RA3.name: Africa’s Human Geographies
ENVSOCTY 3RA3.description: The course adopts an interdisciplinary approach to introduce students to issues related to the African continent. Through case studies drawn from different regions of Africa, we will challenge our misconceptions about Africa, address critical questions about the challenges facing the continent and seek new knowledge of Africa and its peoples. Three lectures; one term.
ENVSOCTY 3RA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

ENVSOCTY 3RW3.name: Regional Geography of a Selected World Region
ENVSOCTY 3RW3.description: Formerly GEOG 3RW3 The study of the human and physical geography of a selected region of the world. Topics typically include economic, social, cultural, demographic, and political geographies, as well as physical geographic and environmental issues. Three lectures; one term.
ENVSOCTY 3RW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above. One of ENVSOCTY 2OC3 , 2RC3 , 2RU3 , 2RW3 , GEOG 2OC3, 2RC3, 2RU3, 2RW3 is recommended.
ENVSOCTY 3RW3.antirequisites: GEOG 3RW3 ENVSOCTY 3RW3 may be repeated, if on a different topic, with permission of the School of Earth, Environment & Society.

ENVSOCTY 3SR3.name: Remote Sensing
ENVSOCTY 3SR3.description: Formerly GEOG 3SR3 An introduction to images, sensors and techniques used to gather and process data on the Earth and other planets. Students will also learn about the principles of interaction of energy with the atmosphere and Earth materials such as vegetation, soil, water, rock, and urban structures. Two lectures, one lab (two hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 3SR3.prerequisites: A minimum grade of C- in one of EARTHSC 2GI3, ENVIRSC 2GI3, ENVSOCTY 2GI3 , GEOG 2GI3

ENVSOCTY 3TG3.name: Geographies of Globalization
ENVSOCTY 3TG3.description: Formerly GEOG 3TG3 An introduction to a geographical understanding of globalization. This understanding is illustrated through an examination of the social, cultural, political, and economic aspects of globalization. Case studies such as women’s labour, global care chains, and the ready-made garment industry are used to illustrate the significance and deeply political nature of globalization. Three lectures; one term.
ENVSOCTY 3TG3.prerequisites: One of ENVSOCTY 1HA3 ​, 1HB3 , GEOG 1HA3, 1HB3; and registration in Level II or above

ENVSOCTY 3UP3.name: Urban Planning
ENVSOCTY 3UP3.description: Formerly GEOG 3UP3 An introduction to urban planning, including the theory and practice of community plan-making in Canada. One seminar (three hours); one term.

ENVSOCTY 3UR3.name: Urban Social Geography
ENVSOCTY 3UR3.description: Formerly GEOG 3UR3 The social geography of North American cities, with an emphasis on urban housing. Topics include, housing and housing markets; experiences and meanings of home; homelessness; and housing policy. Two lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.

ENVSOCTY 3UW3.name: Cities of the Developing World
ENVSOCTY 3UW3.description: Formerly GEOG 3UW3 The nature and consequences of urbanization in the developing world, and the character of cities therein. Emphasis is placed on identifying similarities and differences between cities of the developing and the more developed worlds. One lecture (two hours), one tutorial (one hour); one term.

ENVSOCTY 4EA3.name: Environmental Assessment
ENVSOCTY 4EA3.description: Formerly GEOG 4EA3 Technical and policy issues involved in the production and the appraisal of environmental impact assessments. One lecture (two hours), one tutorial (two hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 4EA3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2EI3, ENVIRSC 2EI3, ENVSOCTY 2EI3 , GEOG 2EI3; or registration in Honours Biology, a Civil Engineering program, an Engineering and Society program, an Honours Integrated Science program or an Honours program in the School of Earth, Environment & Society (Faculty of Science)

ENVSOCTY 4ET3.name: Environmental Policy, Ethics and Risk
ENVSOCTY 4ET3.description: Formerly GEOG 4ET3 An exploration of current issues in environmental ethics, economics and law, with a focus on conflicts between science and policy making. One seminar (three hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 4ET3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2EI3, ENVIRSC 2EI3, ENVSOCTY 2EI3 , GEOG 2EI3; and registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in the School of Earth, Environment & Society

ENVSOCTY 4GA3.name: Applied Spatial Statistics
ENVSOCTY 4GA3.description: Formerly GEOG 4GA3 Spatial data analysis and statistics, including descriptive and inferential spatial statistics. Class is offered in a flipped classroom format to support experiential learning that draws on examples from geography, earth sciences, and the environment. Emphasis on the use of R open-source software. Labs complement classes with extensive use of statistical and GIS software. One lecture (two hours), one lab (two hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 4GA3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 3MB3, ENVIRSC 3MB3, ENVSOCTY 3MB3 , GEOG 3MB3, STATS 2B03 ; and one of EARTHSC 2GI3, ENVIRSC 2GI3, ENVSOCTY 2GI3 , GEOG 2GI3

ENVSOCTY 4GS3.name: GIS Programming
ENVSOCTY 4GS3.description: Formerly GEOG 4GS3 Advanced treatment of GIS focusing on the creation of scripts to enhance productivity by automating time-consuming and repetitive tasks. Through in-class discussions, demonstrations, and regular hands-on exercises, students are introduced to Python scripting in ArcGIS. One lab (three hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 4GS3.prerequisites: A minimum grade of B in one of EARTHSC 3GI3, 3GV3, ENVIRSC 3GI3, 3GV3, ENVSOCTY 3GI3 , 3GV3 , GEOG 3GI3, 3GV3

ENVSOCTY 4GT3.name: Special Topics in GIS
ENVSOCTY 4GT3.description: Formerly GEOG 4GT3 Advanced treatment of selected topics in GIS and Spatial Analysis; specific topics will vary from year to year, with potential topics including, but not limited to 3D GIS, Internet GIS and geomatics of health and urban social problems. One lab (three hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 4GT3.prerequisites: A minimum grade of B in one of EARTHSC 3GI3, 3GV3 , ENVIRSC 3GI3, 3GV3, ENVSOCTY 3GI3 , 3GV3 , GEOG 3GI3, 3GV3
ENVSOCTY 4GT3.antirequisites: GEOG 4GT3 ENVSOCTY 4GT3 may be repeated, if on a different topic, with permission of the School of Earth, Environment & Society (Faculty of Science).

ENVSOCTY 4HC3.name: Public and Community Health
ENVSOCTY 4HC3.description: Formerly GEOG 4HC3 An examination of how geography informs the practice of public and community health, from GIS applications through to changes in home-based care for elderly dependents. One lecture (three hours); one term.

ENVSOCTY 4HD3.name: Disability, Society and Environment
ENVSOCTY 4HD3.description: Formerly GEOG 4HD3 Competing theories on the social and spatial marginalization of persons with disabilities; contemporary and historical case studies are used to illustrate the social, political and cultural determinants of disability. One seminar (three hours); one term.

ENVSOCTY 4HH3.name: Environment and Health
ENVSOCTY 4HH3.description: Formerly GEOG 4HH3 An exploration of environmental health research. Emphasis is placed on the distribution and effects of environmental toxins and disease-causing micro-organisms. Topics include cancer clusters, food safety, and water-borne diseases. Two lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.
ENVSOCTY 4HH3.prerequisites: One of EARTHSC 2EI3, ENVIRSC 2EI3, ENVSOCTY 2EI3 , 2HI3 , GEOG 2EI3, 2HI3; and registration in Level IV or above

ENVSOCTY 4LE3.name: Geographies of the North American Political Economy
ENVSOCTY 4LE3.description: Formerly GEOG 4LE3 A critical analysis of North America’s economic geography with an emphasis on uneven development, growth regions, and the social and cultural embeddedness of economic activity. One seminar (three hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 4LE3.prerequisites: One of GEOG 2LE3, ENVSOCTY 2LE3 or WORKLABR 2G03 (or LABRST 2G03); and registration in Level III or above.

ENVSOCTY 4LP3.name: Transport Policy
ENVSOCTY 4LP3.description: Formerly GEOG 4LP3 An introduction to policy analysis and issues from the perspective of transportation. Conceptual and methodological foundations are enhanced with local, regional, national, and global case studies in transportation. Course is offered in seminar format and requires students to work in small groups. One seminar (three hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 4LP3.prerequisites: One of ENVSOCTY 3LT3 , GEOG 3LT3; or permission of the instructor

ENVSOCTY 4LW3.name: Work and the Environment
ENVSOCTY 4LW3.description: Formerly GEOG 4LW3 Who bears the cost of environmental degradation? How does our current economic system shape possibilities for environmental justice? Is there such a thing as working-class environmentalism? And how do issues of environmental justice get taken up by trade unions? Struggles for environmental justice include everything from fighting against climate change and fighting for access to clean drinking water, to battles over health and safety in the workplace. In this course we will examine how social relations under capitalism shape our interactions with nature and create patterns of work and inequality. We will also explore the varied ways workers and workers organizations have responded to issues of environmental injustice. One seminar (three hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 4LW3.prerequisites: One of ENVSOCTY 2EI3, 2LE3, GEOG 2EI3, 2LE3; or permission of the Director of the School of Labour Studies
ENVSOCTY 4LW3.antirequisites: GEOG 4LW3 Cross-list(s): WORKLABR 4F03 This course is administered by the School of Labour Studies.

ENVSOCTY 4MF3.name: Senior Urban Field Camp
ENVSOCTY 4MF3.description: Formerly GEOG 4MF3 Field study of a North American city focusing on social and/or environmental issues. Topics may vary from year to year, and the timing of the course will depend on the offerings. Students enrolling in this course must pay the incidental fees, as prescribed by the School of Earth, Environment & Society, and the regular tuition fees. Students intending to enrol in this course must submit an application by April 1 of the academic year prior to registration. Application forms are available from the School of Earth, Environment & Society main office after March 1. Students will be informed of acceptance of their application by April 15 subject to fulfillment of the requirements.
ENVSOCTY 4MF3.prerequisites: One of ENVSOCTY 2UI3 , GEOG 2UI3; and one of ENVSOCTY 3MF3 , GEOG 3MF3; and registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in the School of Earth, Environment & Society; and permission of the instructor

ENVSOCTY 4MS3.name: Independent Study
ENVSOCTY 4MS3.description: Formerly GEOG 4MS3 An independent study under the supervision of a faculty member. Students will typically complete one or more major review or research papers on a topic of their choice. One meeting (one hour); one term.
ENVSOCTY 4MS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in the School of Earth, Environment & Society; and permission of the supervising faculty member

ENVSOCTY 4SR3.name: Advanced Remote Sensing
ENVSOCTY 4SR3.description: This course focuses on computer-based methods for extraction of information from remotely sensed data using digital image processing techniques. Techniques addressed include image pre-processing and calibration, image enhancement, spectral data transformation, thematic information extraction, classification, digital change detection, LiDAR, RADAR and hyperspectral remote sensing. One lecture (two hours), one lab (two hours); one term.

ENVSOCTY 4UD3.name: Special Topics in Urban Planning
ENVSOCTY 4UD3.description: Formerly GEOG 4UD3 An advanced examination of key challenges in contemporary urban planning. The course emphasizes how planners work to resolve complex and difficult urban issues, while balancing competing social, environmental, political and economic interests. One seminar (three hours); one term.

ENVSOCTY 4UF3.name: The Geography of Gender
ENVSOCTY 4UF3.description: Formerly GEOG 4UF3 An advanced treatment of key themes and issues in the geography of gender. Emphasis is placed on the ways in which society and space are ‘gendered’ and on critical assessment of the geography of gender literature and reflection on pressing issues facing women and men today. Topics include gender and global change, the global sex trade, gender and the city, gender and sexuality, domestic violence and violence in conflict zones. One seminar (three hours); one term.
ENVSOCTY 4UF3.prerequisites: ENVSOCTY 2UI3  or GEOG 2UI3 and registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in the School of Earth, Environment & Society (Faculty of Science)

ENVSOCTY 4US3.name: Sustainable Cities
ENVSOCTY 4US3.description: Formerly GEOG 4US3 An exploration of social, environmental, and economic dimensions of urban sustainability agendas in the Global North. Emphasis is placed on key debates and controversies surrounding sustainable urbanism, and the role that planners, politicians, municipal actors and citizens play in enacting or resisting visions of sustainable cities. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.

EXPLORE 3IE3.name: Interdisciplinary Experiences
EXPLORE 3IE3.description: Interdisciplinary experiential learning opportunities selected from an assortment of modules. Content and schedules vary annually. Details may be found on the School of Interdisciplinary Science (SIS) website ( https://www.science.mcmaster.ca/sis/ ) or by contacting the School of Interdisciplinary Science (SIS). Some EXPLORE courses may require an application prior to enrollment. Refer to the SIS website for more details. One term.
EXPLORE 3IE3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
EXPLORE 3IE3.antirequisites: ISCI 3IE3, ARTSSCI 3IE3 EXPLORE 3IE3 may be repeated, if on a different topic. This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis. Some modules may require a fee to cover costs of travel and accommodation. This course is administered by the School of Interdisciplinary Science (SIS).

EXPLORE 3IS0.name: Interdisciplinary Science Field Work
EXPLORE 3IS0.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of an Honours Program in the Faculty of Science or Arts & Science program; and permission of the instructor
