EXPLORE 3IS0.antirequisites: ISCI 3IS0, SCIENCE 3IS0 This course is evaluated on a Complete/Not Complete basis. Students must register in EXPLORE 3IS3 in the same or subsequent session as EXPLORE 3IS0. EXPLORE 3IS0 may be repeated, if on a different topic. This course is administered by the School of Interdisciplinary Science (SIS).

EXPLORE 3IS3.name: Interdisciplinary Science Field Camp
EXPLORE 3IS3.description: An interdisciplinary field camp experience to introduce students to field investigations, equipment and methodologies used by a range of professionals including ecologists, Earth and environmental scientists. Most of this course occurs outside the regular academic term, usually within the two weeks following the end of term in April or within the two weeks preceding the start of term in September; details and applications are available on the School of Interdisciplinary Science (SIS) website . Students enrolling in this course must pay both the incidental fees as prescribed by the School of Interdisciplinary Science (SIS) and the regular tuition fees. Students intending to enrol in this course must submit an application by November 15 of the academic year prior to registration. Application forms are available on the School of Interdisciplinary Sciences (SIS) website.
EXPLORE 3IS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of an Honours Program in the Faculty of Science or Arts & Science program; and permission of the instructor Co-requisite(s): Credit or registration in EXPLORE 3IS0
EXPLORE 3IS3.antirequisites: ISCI 3IS3, SCIENCE 3IS3 EXPLORE 3IS3 may be repeated, if on a different topic. Enrolment is limited. This course is administered by the School of Interdisciplinary Science (SIS).

FARSI 1Z03.name: Introductory Farsi I
FARSI 1Z03.description: Students will become familiar with Farsi alphabet and will start learning to read and write using Farsi characters and to communicate about everyday topics through dialogues, pronunciation and vocabulary exercises, grammar quizzes and role-plays. Three hours; one term.

FARSI 1ZZ3.name: Introductory Farsi II
FARSI 1ZZ3.description: Students will expand their ability to communicate through dialogues, pronunciation and vocabulary exercises, grammar quizzes and role-plays, becoming proficient with Farsi alphabet, will communicate in Farsi using a growing set of expressions, and gain elementary understanding of Persian history and culture. Three hours; one term.

FRENCH 2AC3.name: Introduction to Francophone Literatures and Cultures
FRENCH 2AC3.description: An overview of the francophone literatures and cultures outside of Europe and Canada (Africa, Caribbean and Asia) in both their specificity and their interconnectedness. Three hours; one term.
FRENCH 2AC3.prerequisites: One of FRENCH 1A06 A/B or FRENCH 2M06 A/B

FRENCH 2B03.name: French Language Practice I
FRENCH 2B03.description: Oral and written production and comprehension (level B2 of the CEFRL). Four hours (including three hours of lecture and one hour of tutorial); one term.
FRENCH 2B03.prerequisites: One of FRENCH 1A06 A/B or FRENCH 2M06 A/B

FRENCH 2BB3.name: French Language Practice II
FRENCH 2BB3.description: Continuation of FRENCH 2B03 . Oral and written production and comprehension (level B2 of the CEFRL). Four hours (including three hours of lecture and one hour of tutorial); one term.

FRENCH 2CC3.name: Women’s Writing
FRENCH 2CC3.description: Examination of key themes of French and francophone women’s writing. Three hours; one term.
FRENCH 2CC3.prerequisites: One of FRENCH 1A06 A/B or 2M06 A/B

FRENCH 2E03.name: Survey of Quebec Literature and Culture
FRENCH 2E03.description: Selected novels, plays and poems representative of the main currents of Quebec literature and culture. Three hours; one term.
FRENCH 2E03.prerequisites: One of FRENCH 1A06 A/B or 2M06 A/B

FRENCH 2F03.name: Survey of French and Francophone Literature
FRENCH 2F03.description: Examination of a representative sampling of texts from various periods and genres. Three hours; one term.
FRENCH 2F03.prerequisites: One of FRENCH 1A06 A/B or 2M06 A/B

FRENCH 2G03.name: Elementary Translation from English to French
FRENCH 2G03.description: An introduction to translation and comparative stylistics. The translation of texts from English to French will also serve as an exercise in applied grammar. Three hours; one term.

FRENCH 2I03.name: Professional French I
FRENCH 2I03.description: An introduction to Professional French through study of terminology from several fields, placed in context. Will focus on case studies and current media. May include medical, legal or journalistic French, among other areas. Three hours; one term.
FRENCH 2I03.prerequisites: One of French 1A06 A/B or French 2M06 A/B or permission of the Department

FRENCH 2JJ3.name: Nineteenth-Century French Literature
FRENCH 2JJ3.description: Aspects of the development of 19th-century French literature. Three hours; one term.
FRENCH 2JJ3.prerequisites: One of FRENCH 1A06 A/B or FRENCH 2M06 A/B

FRENCH 2L03.name: Introduction to Literary Analysis
FRENCH 2L03.description: Introduction to various techniques and approaches in literary analysis, with practical application to Francophone texts from different eras and literary genres. Three hours; one term.

FRENCH 3AA3.name: The Modern French-Canadian Novel
FRENCH 3AA3.description: A study of representative novels by contemporary authors with emphasis upon the relationship between representation and meaning. A discussion of how the novel breaks away from the past, to focus on a present and future of self-affirmation open to individual freedom, diversity and difference. Three hours; one term.
FRENCH 3AA3.prerequisites: Six units of French above Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and 2Z06 A/B

FRENCH 3AC3.name: Francophone Writers
FRENCH 3AC3.description: A choice of important figures of the Francophone world outside of Europe and Canada. The course examines questions raised by Francophone writers. It will emphasize the application of conceptual methodologies drawn from textual and discourse analysis, cultural and postcolonial studies. Three hours; one term.
FRENCH 3AC3.prerequisites: Six units of French above Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and 2Z06 A/B

FRENCH 3C03.name: French Language Practice III
FRENCH 3C03.description: Oral and written production and comprehension (level C1 of the CEFRL). Four hours (including three hours of lecture and one hour of tutorial); one term.

FRENCH 3CC3.name: Intermediate Translation from English to French
FRENCH 3CC3.description: A follow-up to FRENCH 2G03 , elementary translation and from English to French. The emphasis will be on the translation into French of complex sentence structures, as well as texts of general interest. Three hours; one term.

FRENCH 3EE3.name: Recent French Literature
FRENCH 3EE3.description: Major trends and texts of French literature from the 1970s to the present. Three hours; one term Prerequisites: Six units of French above Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and 2Z06 A/B.

FRENCH 3FF3.name: Francophone Cinemas
FRENCH 3FF3.description: In this course students will view and analyze Francophone films from around the world. Connections will also be drawn with corresponding literary works. Two hours (plus one film screening every other week); one term.

FRENCH 3GG3.name: Elementary Translation from French to English
FRENCH 3GG3.description: An introduction to translation and comparative stylistics. The translation of texts from French to English will also serve as an exercise in applied grammar. Three hours; one term.

FRENCH 3HH3.name: Francophone Voices in Canada
FRENCH 3HH3.description: A survey of Francophone Canadian literature produced outside of Quebec (most notably in Ontario and the Maritimes) as well as North American Indigenous literature written in French. Three hours; one term.
FRENCH 3HH3.prerequisites: Six units of French above Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and 2Z06 A/B

FRENCH 3II3.name: Professional French II
FRENCH 3II3.description: Follow-up to FRENCH 2I03. Will include study of terminology from different fields, placed in context. Three hours; one term.

FRENCH 3KK3.name: Revolutionary Literature Before the Revolution: Voltaire, Rousseau and Beaumarchais
FRENCH 3KK3.description: Texts representing the main aspects of Enlightenment thought and literature from Candide to the Revolution. Three hours; one term.
FRENCH 3KK3.prerequisites: Six units of French above Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and 2Z06 A/B

FRENCH 3P03.name: History and Philosophy of Education
FRENCH 3P03.description: An overview of education from ancient Greece to modernity: philosophical grounds, institutions, knowledge dissemination methods, and role of language teaching. Three hours; one term.
FRENCH 3P03.prerequisites: Six units of French above Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and FRENCH 2Z06 A/B

FRENCH 3Q03.name: Seventeenth-Century French Literature
FRENCH 3Q03.description: A consideration of selected themes as they appear in the works of major French writers of the 17th century. Three hours; one term.
FRENCH 3Q03.prerequisites: Six units of French above Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and 2Z06 A/B

FRENCH 3W03.name: Twentieth-Century French Literature
FRENCH 3W03.description: Key movements and texts of 20th century literature, to the 1960s. Three hours; one term.
FRENCH 3W03.prerequisites: Six units of French above Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and FRENCH 2Z06 A/B

FRENCH 4A03.name: French Language Practice IV
FRENCH 4A03.description: Oral and written production and comprehension (levels C1-C2 of the CEFRL). Four hours (including three hours of lecture and one hour of tutorial); one term.
FRENCH 4A03.prerequisites: FRENCH 3C03 and registration in an Honours program in French

FRENCH 4CC3.name: Theoretical Reflections on Interdisciplinarity
FRENCH 4CC3.description: This course explores the formation of academic disciplines and the emergence of interdisciplinary thought in Western science and humanities. Aspects of theoretical reflection on interdisciplinarity by post-structuralist thinkers will also be discussed. Seminar (two hours); one term.
FRENCH 4CC3.prerequisites: 12 units of French beyond Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and FRENCH 2Z06 A/B

FRENCH 4DD3.name: Animals in French and Francophone Literatures
FRENCH 4DD3.description: Thematic study of the various roles animals play in French and francophone texts. Seminar (two hours); one term.
FRENCH 4DD3.prerequisites: 12 units of French above Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B or 2Z06 A/B

FRENCH 4I03.name: French Poetry from the Renaissance to the Present
FRENCH 4I03.description: An introduction to major thematic, historical and linguistic concerns of French poetry from the Renaissance to the present (e.g. Poets and Humour, Love Poetry, Women Poets, Poètes maudits.) Seminar (two hours); one term.
FRENCH 4I03.prerequisites: 12 units of French above Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and 2Z06 A/B

FRENCH 4LL3.name: Topics in Francophone Literatures
FRENCH 4LL3.description: Topics may include: important issues in Francophone literatures outside of Europe and Canada, such as women and literature, margins in literature, representation of the self and the other; questions of genres in Francophone literatures; Francophone cinema; literature and history, culture, etc. Seminar (two hours); one term.
FRENCH 4LL3.prerequisites: 12 units of French above Level l, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and 2Z06 A/B FRENCH 4LL3 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

FRENCH 4MM3.name: Sex, Violence and Elegance: The 18th-Century Novel
FRENCH 4MM3.description: A study of the genesis and themes of representative 18th-century novels. Seminar (two hours); one term.
FRENCH 4MM3.prerequisites: 12 units of French above Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and FRENCH 2Z06 A/B

FRENCH 4T03.name: Independent Study
FRENCH 4T03.description: The student will prepare under the supervision of a faculty member a research paper involving independent research in an area of study in which the student has already demonstrated a high level of basic knowledge. It is the student’s responsibility to complete a proposal and secure the agreement of an instructor prior to registration.
FRENCH 4T03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of an Honours program in French and permission of the Department

FRENCH 4U03.name: Topics in Literature and Culture of Quebec and Francophone Canada
FRENCH 4U03.description: Topics may include: Paraliteratures: from nineteenth century tales and legends to contemporary science-fiction; Quebec women authors; Quebec cinema; the representation of France and America; the representation of otherness; Montreal in Quebec literature and culture. Seminar (two hours); one term.
FRENCH 4U03.prerequisites: 12 units of French above Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and 2Z06 A/B FRENCH 4U03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

FRENCH 4Y03.name: Topics in 20th-Century French Literature
FRENCH 4Y03.description: Previous topics include: Women’s Writing, The Essay, Gay and Lesbian Novel in France. Consult the Department concerning topic to be offered. Seminar (two hours); one term.
FRENCH 4Y03.prerequisites: 12 units of French above Level I, excluding FRENCH 2M06 A/B and 2Z06 A/B FRENCH 4Y03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

GENDRST 1A03.name: Gender, Race, Culture, Power
GENDRST 1A03.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to Gender Studies and Critical Race Theory focusing on how gender and race shape and are shaped by culture (including popular culture), systems of power and institutional ideologies. Two lectures, one tutorial (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): WOMENST 1A03.

GENDRST 1AA3.name: Gender, Feminism and Social Justice
GENDRST 1AA3.description: An interdisciplinary and intersectional introduction to feminism as a tool for critical analysis and as a shaping force deployed (or challenged) by activists in diverse movements to make and sustain social change. Two lectures, one tutorial (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): WOMENST 1AA3.

GENDRST 2AA3.name: Feminist Thought
GENDRST 2AA3.description: History of feminist theorizing, including liberal, radical, socialist, multiracial, poststructural, Black, postcolonial, third wave, intersectional, queer and global feminist approaches. Two lectures, one tutorial (three hours); one term.
GENDRST 2AA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

GENDRST 2BB3.name: Images of the Divine Feminine
GENDRST 2BB3.description: An examination of some of the ways the divine has been portrayed as feminine in diverse cultures. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Cross-list(s): SCAR 2BB3 Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2BB3, WOMENST 2BB3 This course is administered by the Department of Religious Studies.

GENDRST 3BB3.name: Gender and Visual Culture
GENDRST 3BB3.description: Students will explore ideas about representation, spectatorship and production in relation to issues of social difference, such as gender, race and class. Emphasis is on visuality in forms such as film, video, television, advertising, et cetera. Two hour lecture and discussion, plus one weekly film screening; one term Cross-list(s): THTRFLM 3P03.
GENDRST 3BB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above

GENDRST 3BW3.name: Gender in Ancient Eastern Mediterranean
GENDRST 3BW3.description: This course analyzes gender roles in Biblical literature and other texts of Ancient Near East and Mediterranean regions. By examining how gender is depicted in different genres of literature and material artifacts, we will learn about ancient authors’ understanding of gender identities. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Cross-list(s): SCAR 3BW3 Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2B03, WOMENST 2B03, WOMENST 3BW3 This course is administered by the Department of Religious Studies.

GENDRST 3FF3.name: Gender and Religion
GENDRST 3FF3.description: An examination of gender in one or more religious traditions. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
GENDRST 3FF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): SCAR 3FF3
GENDRST 3FF3.antirequisites: RELIGST 2SS3, 3FF3, WOMENST 3FF3 This course is administered by the Department of Religious Studies.

GENDRST 3RR3.name: ‘Cripping’ Performance: Deaf, Mad and Disabled Performance in Canada
GENDRST 3RR3.description: This course will explore the history and culture of disabled, Mad and Deaf theatre and performance. Delving in Canada’s rich 45 year history of disabled, Deaf and Mad theatre, the course will consider intersectionality, access and interdependence as core tenets of this milieu. This course is rooted in understandings of disability justice and will touch on the intermingling of disabled activism with performance and the current push for changes in the Canadian theatre landscape for Deaf, Mad and disabled creators. Three hours; one term.
GENDRST 3RR3.prerequisites: Registration in level II or above of any program Cross-list(s): THTRFLM 3RR3 , IARTS 3RR3 This course is administered by School of the Arts.

GENTECH 1BZ3.name: Foundations of Business
GENTECH 1BZ3.description: Students are given an introduction to the functional areas within businesses and an overview of the local and global business environments. The fundamentals of micro-economics and macro-economics are introduced, as well as sustainability in the environment of business. Two lectures; one tutorial (one hour); second term.
GENTECH 1BZ3.prerequisites: Registration in Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

GENTECH 1PC3.name: Professional Communications
GENTECH 1PC3.description: Students will develop their written and oral communications skills with an emphasis on styles appropriate for a technology-based workplace including technical report writing. They will also develop their teamwork, problem solving, and research skills. Two lectures; one tutorial (two hours): first term.
GENTECH 1PC3.prerequisites: Registration in Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

GENTECH 2EE3.name: Engineering Economics
GENTECH 2EE3.description: Costing methods of engineering designs and processes; minimum attractive rate of return, return sensitivities, time value of money, internal rates of return, pay-back period, amortization of equipment and capital cost allowance structures. Three lectures; second term.
GENTECH 2EE3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

GENTECH 2HR3.name: Human Resource Fundamentals
GENTECH 2HR3.description: This course provides and overview and introduction to the human resource functions that support an organization’s goals and objectives. Topics include: Designing and analyzing jobs; recruitment and selection; onboarding and training; career development; and performance management. Three lectures: second term.
GENTECH 2HR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

GENTECH 2MP3.name: Management Principles
GENTECH 2MP3.description: The course examines fundamental management principles of planning, organizing, leading, and controlling in technology organizations. Emphasis is placed on understanding and application of human resource management practices to engage people in attaining organizational goals. Three lectures: first term.
GENTECH 2MP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

GENTECH 3DM3.name: Creativity, Innovation and Technology
GENTECH 3DM3.description: This course is a blend of hands-on and theoretical treatment on the subject of creating new technological product and service value in our society. Three lectures; one term; may be offered in an in-person or virtual format.
GENTECH 3DM3.prerequisites: Registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

GENTECH 3EE3.name: Engineering Economics
GENTECH 3EE3.description: Costing methods for engineering designs and processes; minimum attractive rate of return, return sensitivities, time value of money, internal rates of return, payback period, amortization of equipment and capital cost allowance structures. Three lectures; one term; may be offered in an in-person or virtual format.
GENTECH 3EE3.prerequisites: Registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

GENTECH 3FF3.name: Financial Systems
GENTECH 3FF3.description: The course focuses on departmental budget methodologies, understanding and interpretation of various financial statement components in terms of their relevance to managerial decision making. Three lectures; first term.
GENTECH 3FF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

GENTECH 3FS3.name: Financial Systems
GENTECH 3FS3.description: The course focuses on departmental budget methodologies, understanding and interpretation of various financial statement components in terms of their relevance to managerial decision making. Three lectures; one term; may be offered in an in-person or virtual format.
GENTECH 3FS3.prerequisites: Registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

GENTECH 3LS3.name: Quality Control and Assurance Methods
GENTECH 3LS3.description: Statistical tools, tests, design and analysis of planned experiments, Taguchi methods, control charts for variables and attributes, capability analysis, acceptance sampling, elements of reliability, quality assurance, and ISO 9000 certification. Three lectures; first term.
GENTECH 3LS3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 2ES3 or 3ES3 ; and registration in Level II or above Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

GENTECH 3MB3.name: Fundamentals of Marketing
GENTECH 3MB3.description: This course introduces the 4Ps of marketing: product, price, promotion, and place with a Business-to-Business focus. Global and high technology markets and their unique challenges will be presented. Students will learn to make marketing decisions within a strategic framework. Three lectures; first term.
GENTECH 3MB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

GENTECH 3MP3.name: Management Principles
GENTECH 3MP3.description: The course examines fundamental management principles of planning, organizing, leading and controlling in technology organizations. Emphasis is placed on understanding and application of human resource management practices to engage people in attaining organizational goals. Three lectures; one term; may be offered in an in-person or virtual format.
GENTECH 3MP3.prerequisites: Registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

GENTECH 3MT3.name: Project Management
GENTECH 3MT3.description: Introduction to best practice in the management of technical projects including the use of planning, software and the management of people. Three lectures; first term.
GENTECH 3MT3.prerequisites: GENTECH 2MP3 and registration in Level II or above of Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

GENTECH 4EM3.name: Legal and Regulatory Issues
GENTECH 4EM3.description: This course is an introduction to the legal, ethical, and regulatory frameworks that professional engineers and related professions must observe in the Province of Ontario. Three lectures; one term, may be offered in an in-person or virtual format.
GENTECH 4EM3.prerequisites: Registration in one of Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

GENTECH 4EN3.name: Entrepreneurial Thinking and Innovation
GENTECH 4EN3.description: This course introduces students to the interrelationship of entrepreneurial thinking and innovation at both the industry and firm level. Three lectures; one term; may be offered in an in-person or virtual format.
GENTECH 4EN3.prerequisites: GENTECH 3EE3 and registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

GENTECH 4EP3.name: Entrepreneurial Thinking and Innovation
GENTECH 4EP3.description: This course introduces students to the interrelationship of entrepreneurial thinking and innovation at both the industry and firm level. Three hours virtual blended delivery; second term.
GENTECH 4EP3.prerequisites: GENTECH 2MP3 , 3FF3 and registration in Level II or above of Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

GENTECH 4FT3.name: Strategic Management
GENTECH 4FT3.description: Formerly GENTECH 3FT3 This capstone course examines the ‘total’ view of the organization and how it relates and interacts with various factors in its environment to gain long-term sustainable advantage. Three hours virtual blended delivery; first term.
GENTECH 4FT3.prerequisites: GENTECH 1FT3 or 3FF3 , 3ET3 or 4EP3 , ENGTECH 4EE0 and registration in Level III or above of Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

GENTECH 4LM3.name: Lean Thinking and Practices
GENTECH 4LM3.description: The course focuses on lean thinking and approaches to enable the deployment and adaption of tools aimed at minimizing waste, removing non-value added activities, and pursuing incremental improvements across organizations. Three lectures; one term, may be offered in an in-person or virtual format.
GENTECH 4LM3.prerequisites: Registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

GENTECH 4MK3.name: Fundamentals of Marketing
GENTECH 4MK3.description: This course introduces the 4Ps of marketing: product, price, promotion, and place with a Business-to-Business focus. Global and high technology markets and their unique challenges will be presented. Students will learn to make marketing decisions within a strategic framework. Three lectures; one term; may be offered in an in-person or virtual format.
GENTECH 4MK3.prerequisites: Registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

GENTECH 4OM3.name: Operations Management
GENTECH 4OM3.description: Formerly GENTECH 4SC3 This course addresses the management of operations at the strategic, tactical and operations levels. Emphasizing decisions required to successfully design, create and deliver goods and services in a globalized marketplace. Three lectures; second term.
GENTECH 4OM3.prerequisites: GENTECH 3LS3 and registration in Level III or above of Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

GENTECH 4PM3.name: Project Management
GENTECH 4PM3.description: Introduction to best practice in the management of technical projects including the use of planning, software and the management of people. Three lectures; one term; may be offered in an in-person or virtual format.
GENTECH 4PM3.prerequisites: Registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

GENTECH 4SE3.name: Technology Ethics and Sustainability
GENTECH 4SE3.description: The course explores the social implications and environmental impacts of technologies and the ethical challenges they impose on technology professionals. Critical thinking skills and professional responsibility are examined using real-ethical dilemmas to help students develop a professional ethical identity that can be carried forward into their career. Three lectures; one term; may be offered in an in-person or virtual format.
GENTECH 4SE3.prerequisites: Registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

GENTECH 4SF3.name: Strategic Management
GENTECH 4SF3.description: This course examines the ‘total’ view of the organization and how it relates and interacts with various factors in its environment to game long-term sustainable advantage. Three lectures; one term; may be offered in an in-person or virtual format.
GENTECH 4SF3.prerequisites: GENTECH 3FS3 and registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

GENTECH 4ST3.name: Contemporary Issues in Management
GENTECH 4ST3.description: Students are offered a selection of three to four emerging issues of the day as those issues relate to current and emerging technology and management technology practices. These topics could include supply chain management, ERP, knowledge management, 6 sigma methods, etc. Three lectures; one term; may be offered online or in-person.
GENTECH 4ST3.prerequisites: Registration in Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

GENTECH 4TC3.name: Technical Communications
GENTECH 4TC3.description: This course introduces students to the best practices for essential written, spoken, and graphic communications used in technology workplaces. Emphasis is placed on how to conduct research, analyze information, and design communication materials that are succinct and customized to the readers’ needs. Three lectures; one term, may be offered in an in-person or virtual format.
GENTECH 4TC3.prerequisites: Registration in one of Civil Engineering Infrastructure Technology, Manufacturing Engineering Technology, or Power and Energy Engineering Technology

GENTECH 4TE3.name: Technology Ethics and Sustainability
GENTECH 4TE3.description: The course explores the social implications and environmental impacts of technologies and the ethical challenges they impose on technology professionals. Critical thinking skills and professional responsibility are examined using real-ethical dilemmas to help students develop a professional ethical identity that can be carried forward into their career. Three lectures; first term.
GENTECH 4TE3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 4EE0 , and registration in Level III or above of Automation Systems Engineering Technology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Biotechnology

PEACJUST 1A03.name: Peace, Justice, Human Rights
PEACJUST 1A03.description: From Black Lives Matter to #MeToo, migration crises and climate change news, this course examines values and ideologies in local and global struggles for peace, justice and human rights. Concepts: peace, conflict, war, injustice, violence, nonviolence, oppression, are introduced. Historical and contemporary case studies. Lectures and tutorial (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): IBH 1BD3 , PEACEST 1A03.

PEACJUST 1VM3.name: Voices at Mac: Understanding our World
PEACJUST 1VM3.description: Innovative, multidisciplinary introduction to key issues in peace, social and global justice through perspectives of award-winning McMaster scholars and national/international visiting speakers. Community-based learning is integrated by attending public events. Power relations, structural inequities and resistance; understanding how we are positioned by/how we can position ourselves in relation to the past and present, anchor the course. Lecture, tutorial and event attendance (three hours); one term.

PEACJUST 2A03.name: Conflict Transformation: Theory and Practice
PEACJUST 2A03.description: An examination of ways of preventing, resolving and transforming conflicts in everyday life, in our own culture and others, and in the arenas of family, business, the law, schools and large-scale political conflicts. Lectures and tutorial (three hours); one term.
PEACJUST 2A03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

PEACJUST 2B03.name: Human Rights and Social Justice
PEACJUST 2B03.description: An introduction to the growing national and international discussion of human rights, exploring the value and limitations of universal rights, equality under the law and social justice. Lecture and tutorial (three hours); one term Cross-list(s): LABRST 2W03.
PEACJUST 2B03.prerequisites: One of GENDRST 1A03 , 1AA3 , PEACEST 1A03, PEACJUST 1A03 , 1VM3 , WOMENST 1A03, WOMENST 1AA3, or IBH 1BD3 ; or registration in Level II or above of a program in Indigenous Studies, Labour Studies, Peace Studies, Global Peace and Social Justice or Justice, Political Philosophy and Law

PEACJUST 2C03.name: Peace, Justice, and Popular Culture
PEACJUST 2C03.description: This course investigates how and why popular culture and media normalize or challenge inequities, injustice, and ecological destruction in historical and contemporary contexts. Lectures and tutorial (three hours); one term.
PEACJUST 2C03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

PEACJUST 2CS3.name: Decolonization and Activism: Creating Social Change
PEACJUST 2CS3.description: From sit-ins to street theatre, reconciliation, peacebuilding and media campaigns, diverse modes of struggle against injustice abound. Using interdisciplinary anti-oppression approaches, this course examines strategies used around the world to foster social change. Lectures and tutorials (three hours); one term.
PEACJUST 2CS3.prerequisites: Registration in level II or above of any program

PEACJUST 2GW3.name: A History of Global War
PEACJUST 2GW3.description: A survey of the course and development of the two global wars of the twentieth century covering the period from 1914 to 1945. The emphasis is on the military, economic, and political events that characterised the conflicts. Lectures (three hours); one term Cross-list(s): HISTORY 2GW3.
PEACJUST 2GW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
PEACJUST 2GW3.antirequisites: HISTORY 2S03, 2Y03, PEACEST 2GW3 This course is administered by the Department of History.

PEACJUST 2LS3.name: Language and Society
PEACJUST 2LS3.description: An introduction to sociolinguistics covering such topics as linguistic variation (regional, social, situational), language and gender, language and disadvantage/power, language choice, language change, pidgin and creole languages. Three hours; one term Cross-list(s): LINGUIST 2S03.
PEACJUST 2LS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
PEACJUST 2LS3.antirequisites: CMST 3G03, LINGUIST 3X03, PEACEST 2LS3 This course is administered by the Department of Linguistics and Languages.

PEACJUST 2XX3.name: Social & Structural Determinants of Health
PEACJUST 2XX3.description: Social inequities often make it difficult for individuals, families, groups and communities to attain or maintain health. This class is designed to critically analyze the social and structural determinants that create health disparities. The social determinants of health include social identities that influence health outcomes, such as race, socio-economic status, culture, gender identity, sexual orientation, age, disability, and citizenship status. The structural determinants of health is a concept that considers how these social identities shape policies within our social structures that impact our social and economic well-being and health. Students will explore their own attitudes, beliefs and experiences around these determinants of health and acquire the knowledge and skills to influence and intervene on decisions, actions and policies that drive transformative health systems in Canada and globally. Three hours; one term.
PEACJUST 2XX3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

PEACJUST 3B03.name: Peace-Building and Health Initiatives
PEACJUST 3B03.description: An examination of the multiple links between health and peace, concentrating on social determinants; conflict reduction; food, sanitation and water supplies; and violence prevention; in crisis and non-crisis situations. Three hours; one term.
PEACJUST 3B03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

PEACJUST 3C03.name: Researching Global Peace and Social Justice
PEACJUST 3C03.description: Approaches, theories, and methods to conducting research and translating, sharing, and mobilizing knowledge to diverse audiences to address the intersections of global peace and social justice. Students will develop an appreciation for the key epistemological, philosophical, and ethical considerations that need to be made in conducting research at the intersection of peace and social justice, and hone their skills in generating research questions, conducting secondary research, analyzing and applying research methodologies, and identifying conceptual frameworks and theories that will help frame research findings. Three hours; one term.
PEACJUST 3C03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program; at least three units in PEACEST or PEACJUST; and an additional three units of PEACEST, PEACJUST or GENDRST; or permission of the Global Peace and Social Justice program

PEACJUST 3CY3.name: Children, Youth & Media
PEACJUST 3CY3.description: This course explores the relationship between children, youth, and media, including central debates, theories, and research. Core concerns involve media literacy; cultural, educational, and social policy; media analysis; identity, reception; social media and new technologies; and youth media production. Three hours; one term Cross-list(s): CMST 3CY3.
PEACJUST 3CY3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of any program in Communication Studies, Multimedia, Media Arts, Peace Studies or Global Peace and Social Justice
PEACJUST 3CY3.antirequisites: CMST 2EE3 This course is administered by the Department of Communication Studies and Multimedia.

PEACJUST 3D03.name: Globalization and Peace
PEACJUST 3D03.description: Investigation of complex systems approaches to understanding how social-cultural-ecological change influences globalization and peace. Three hours; one term.
PEACJUST 3D03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

PEACJUST 3GG3.name: Theories of Decolonization and Resistance
PEACJUST 3GG3.description: A study of theoretical and cultural works that examine the effects of empire and chart projects for decolonization. Introduces debates in Indigenous and postcolonial studies, including as they engage with theories of racial capitalism, gender and sexuality, globalization, war, environmental change. Three hours; one term Cross-list(s): ENGLISH 3GG3.
PEACJUST 3GG3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program
PEACJUST 3GG3.antirequisites: CSCT 3R06 A/B, ENGLISH 3R06 A/B, PEACEST 3E06 A/B, PEACEST 3GG3 This course is administered by the Department of English and Cultural Studies.

PEACJUST 3P03.name: Practicum: Practical Peace Building
PEACJUST 3P03.description: Exploration of service, entrepreneurship, and other modes of engagement with practical peace building through workplace experience. Student-initiated voluntary placement for one day per week under supervised practice; one term.
PEACJUST 3P03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a program in Peace Studies or Global Peace and Social Justice; or permission of the Global Peace and Social Justice program
PEACJUST 3P03.antirequisites: PEACEST 3P03 This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis.

PEACJUST 3RR3.name: Race, Religion and Media
PEACJUST 3RR3.description: This course examines historical constructions of different races and religions in the media, primarily film, television and the press, and asks how these constructions may manifest themselves in contemporary forms of media and in current events. Students will learn to deconstruct visual and written depictions across a variety of media. Cross-list(s): CMST 3RR3 Three hours; one term.
PEACJUST 3RR3.prerequisites: CMST 1A03, MMEDIA 1A03, MEDIAART 1A03, PEACJUST 1A03 or PEACJUST 1VM3; and registration in Level III or above This course is administered by the Department of Communication Studies and Multimedia.

PEACJUST 3V03.name: Global Anglophone Literature and Film
PEACJUST 3V03.description: A study of literature, film and other forms of popular culture by artists from South Asia, Africa, and the Caribbean, and their overseas diasporas. Introduces students to theories of race, gender, sexuality, indigeneity, citizenship, and the nation as these take up histories of colonialism, imperialism, and globalization. Three hours; one term Cross-list(s): ENGLISH 3V03.
PEACJUST 3V03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program
PEACJUST 3V03.antirequisites: CSCT 3R06 A/B, ENGLISH 3R06 A/B, PEACEST 3E06 A/B This course is administered by the Department of English and Cultural Studies.

PEACJUST 3W03.name: Contemporary Native Literature in Canada
PEACJUST 3W03.description: A study of significant works by Native writers who give voice to their experience in Canada. Issues examined include appropriation of voice, native identity, women in indigenous societies, and stereotyping. Three hours (lectures and seminars); one term Cross-list(s): ENGLISH 3W03 , INDIGST 3D03.
PEACJUST 3W03.prerequisites: Six units of Level II Indigenous Studies or six units of Level II English or permission of the instructor
PEACJUST 3W03.antirequisites: CSCT 3W03, PEACEST 3W03 This course is administered by Indigenous Studies.

PEACJUST 3X03.name: Contemporary Native Literature in the United States
PEACJUST 3X03.description: A study of contemporary works by Native writers in the United States within the context of American society and Post-Modern and Post-Colonial Literary Theory. Three hours (lectures and seminars); one term Cross-list(s): ENGLISH 3X03 , INDIGST 3E03.
PEACJUST 3X03.prerequisites: Six units of Level II Indigenous Studies or six units of Level II English or permission of the instructor
PEACJUST 3X03.antirequisites: CSCT 3X03, PEACEST 3X03 This course is administered by Indigenous Studies.

PEACJUST 3XX3.name: Human Rights in History
PEACJUST 3XX3.description: A thematic examination of the global historical evolution of the notion of human rights from antiquity up to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in the 20th century. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term Cross-list(s): HISTORY 3XX3.
PEACJUST 3XX3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above
PEACJUST 3XX3.antirequisites: PEACEST 3XX3 May be offered in person or online. This course is administered by the Department of History.

PEACJUST 3Y03.name: Special Topics in Peace and Justice
PEACJUST 3Y03.description: Consult the Global Peace and Social Justice Office for the topic to be offered. Lecture and discussion (three hours); one term.
PEACJUST 3Y03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program
PEACJUST 3Y03.antirequisites: PEACEST 3Y03 PEACJUST 3Y03/PEACEST 3Y03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

PEACJUST 4B03.name: Independent Research
PEACJUST 4B03.description: Students develop and execute their own research projects, in regular consultation with a faculty supervisor, and produce and orally defend a substantial paper. May include a practicum component.
PEACJUST 4B03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of the Combined Honours in Peace Studies or Global Peace and Social Justice Program with a Grade Point Average of at least 8.5, and permission of the Global Peace and Social Justice program

PEACJUST 4FC3.name: Community Engaged Experiential Learning
PEACJUST 4FC3.description: Community-engaged experiential learning: examining theory and practice in situ through action learning and/or action research. Students and project-partners will explore problem-based learning opportunities.
PEACJUST 4FC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of any program and permission of the Global Peace and Social Justice program

PEACJUST 4G03.name: Peace Through Health: Praxis
PEACJUST 4G03.description: Exploring global perspectives of peace through health, addressing social determinants of health, gender and environment, and examining individual and institutional leadership, using problem-based and experiential learning. Seminar (two hours); one term.
PEACJUST 4G03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a program in Peace Studies or Global Peace and Social Justice; or permission of the Global Peace and Social Justice program

PEACJUST 4GG3.name: Nation and Genocide in the Modern World
PEACJUST 4GG3.description: A thematic study of genocide and mass murder in the twentieth century from a human rights perspective. The first part of the course covers the theoretical and legal aspects of genocide studies. The second part explores specific case studies of colonial massacres, the Holocaust, and the Cambodian and Rwandan genocides. Cross-list(s): HISTORY 4G03.
PEACJUST 4GG3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History, Peace Studies or Global Peace and Social Justice
PEACJUST 4GG3.antirequisites: PEACEST 4GG3 Departmental permission required. This course is administered by the Department of History.

PEACJUST 4L03.name: Peace, Environment and Health
PEACJUST 4L03.description: Using an intersectional lens, this course examines the link between peace, environment, health and the social factors that shape experiences of pollution, contamination, and climate change inequities globally. Seminar (two hours); one term.
PEACJUST 4L03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a program in Peace Studies or Global Peace and Social Justice; or permission of the Global Peace and Social Justice program

PEACJUST 4RR3.name: Truth and Reconciliation After Atrocity
PEACJUST 4RR3.description: This course explores truth commissions and other truth-seeking mechanisms established globally to address historical atrocities and contemporary human rights abuses. Seminar (two hours): one term Cross-list(s): HISTORY 4RR3.
PEACJUST 4RR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in History, Peace Studies or Global Peace and Social Justice
PEACJUST 4RR3.antirequisites: PEACEST 4RR3 Departmental permission required. This course is administered by the Department of History.

PEACJUST 4ST3.name: Special Topics Seminar
PEACJUST 4ST3.description: A specialized approach to selected topics of current relevance to peace research, for example, social justice, restorative justice, truth and reconciliation, climate change, gender, refugee, and migration. Seminar (two hours); one term.
PEACJUST 4ST3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a program in Peace Studies or Global Peace and Social Justice; or permission of the Global Peace and Social Justice program.
PEACJUST 4ST3.antirequisites: PEACEST 4ST3 This course may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of 6 units.

GLOBALZN 1A03.name: Global Citizenship
GLOBALZN 1A03.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to globalization through a critical engagement with the idea of “global citizenship” in the contemporary context. The political, economic, and cultural dimensions of globalization will be examined. Three hours (lectures and tutorials); one term.

GLOBALZN 3A03.name: Globalization, Social Justice, and Human Rights
GLOBALZN 3A03.description: This course examines competing theories, issues, and debates relating to the promotion of social justice and human rights in a globalizing world. Students use course-integrated social networking to interact and collaborate with peers from partner universities across the globe where versions of this course are simultaneously taught. Three hours (lectures); one term.

GKROMST 1A03.name: Introduction to Greek and Roman Archaeology
GKROMST 1A03.description: A study of the history and methodology of Greek and Roman archaeology illustrated with materials from excavated sites. Three lectures; one term Antirequisite(s): CLASSICS 1A03.

GKROMST 2B03.name: Greek Art
GKROMST 2B03.description: The architecture, sculpture and painting of the Greek and Hellenistic world. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 2B03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program Cross-list(s): ARTHIST 2B03

GKROMST 2BB3.name: Constructing the Ancient World
GKROMST 2BB3.description: This course will examine the architecture of the ancient world. Using examples ranging from Egyptian pyramids to Greek urbanization to Roman aqueducts, we will interrogate the development of architectural styles, forms of monumentality, and the relationship between power and the built environment. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 2BB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

GKROMST 2C03.name: Roman Art
GKROMST 2C03.description: The architecture, sculpture, and painting of the Roman world. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 2C03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program Cross-list(s): ARTHIST 2C03

GKROMST 2CC3.name: Archaeology of the Roman Empire
GKROMST 2CC3.description: This course explores the material culture of the Roman empire, from great monuments like Hadrian’s Wall to the smallest artefacts of glass and pottery, and reveals what this can tell us about the culture and society of the empire’s diverse inhabitants. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 2CC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

GKROMST 3N03.name: Connectivity in the Ancient Mediterranean
GKROMST 3N03.description: This course explores interconnectedness across the ancient Mediterranean and Western Asia through contact with the Greek world will interrogate issues such as colonialism, acculturation, and cultural hybridity in these contexts. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 3N03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program Offered in alternate years.

GKROMST 3Q03.name: Greek Sanctuaries
GKROMST 3Q03.description: Ancient Greek sanctuaries and their social and political context. Topics will include architecture and art, as well as activities such as sacrifice, athletic games, healing, and oracular consultation. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 3Q03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program Cross-list(s): ARTHIST 3QQ3 Alternates with GKROMST 3S03 ( ARTHIST 3SS3 )

GKROMST 3S03.name: Pompeii, Herculaneum, and Ostia
GKROMST 3S03.description: The archaeology of three cities in Italy (Pompeii, Herculaneum, Ostia) will be examined, with a focus on urbanism, public space, and domestic architecture and decoration. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 3S03.prerequisites: One of CLASSICS 1A03, 2B03, 2BB3, 2C03, 2CC3, 2LC3, or 2LD3, GKROMST 1A03 , 2B03 , 2BB3 , 2C03 , 2CC3 and registration in Level II or above of any program. Cross-list(s): ARTHIST 3SS3

GKROMST 1M03.name: History of Greece and Rome
GKROMST 1M03.description: The history of Greece and Rome from the bronze age to the fall of Rome based on literary, documentary and archaeological evidence. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Cross-list(s): HISTORY 1M03 Antirequisite(s): CLASSICS 1M03.

GKROMST 2K03.name: The Society of Greece and Rome
GKROMST 2K03.description: An examination of selected aspects of the social life of Greece and Rome. Attention will be given to subjects such as work and leisure, war and the warrior, slavery, marriage and family, and the role of women. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 2K03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

GKROMST 2HA3.name: Athens and Sparta: Democracy, Oligarchy, and War
GKROMST 2HA3.description: The Classical period of Ancient Greece will be examined from the perspective of its two great rival states, Athens and Sparta, with attention to their rival political and social systems, contrasting cultures, and the generation-long war they fought. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 2HA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

GKROMST 2HB3.name: From Alexander to Cleopatra: Cosmopolis and Empire
GKROMST 2HB3.description: The Hellenistic period of Ancient Greece, examining Alexanders conquests; Seleucid Asia, Antigonid Macedon, Ptolemaic Egypt; dynastic and imperial power struggles; cosmopolitanism and colonialism; Greek and indigenous cultures; science and philosophy; and the triumph of Rome. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 2HB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

GKROMST 2HC3.name: Caesar and the Rise of Autocracy
GKROMST 2HC3.description: This course will consider the growth of Roman power in the Mediterranean, the stresses that this put on Roman institutions, and how the crises that brought an end to the Republic led to the dictatorship of Gaius Julius Caesar and set the stage for autocratic regimes to come. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 2HC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

GKROMST 2HD3.name: Nero, Decadence, and the End of a Dynasty
GKROMST 2HD3.description: The last of the Julio-Claudian emperors, Nero, became notorious for his capriciousness and extravagance. How much of this was myth and how much reality? This course will consider the evolution of the Roman system under the Julio-Claudians and place Nero in his political, economic, and ideological contexts. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 2HD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

GKROMST 1B03.name: An Introduction to Ancient Myth and Literature
GKROMST 1B03.description: A study of Greek and Roman mythology and literature. Texts such as Homer, Virgil and Greek tragedies will be read in translation. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): CLASSICS 1B03.

GKROMST 2D03.name: Greek and Roman Mythology
GKROMST 2D03.description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes, their explanation according to theories on the nature of myths, and their use by Greek and Roman authors, particularly Homer and Virgil. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 2D03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program

GKROMST 2E03.name: The Ancient World in Film
GKROMST 2E03.description: The emphasis is on myth (Amazons, Hercules) and history (slave revolts, banquets, decadent emperors), studied via Greek and Latin accounts (in translation) and cinematic versions (e.g. Electra, Medea, Mighty Aphrodite, Apocalypse Now, Spartacus, I Claudius). Two lectures, plus one weekly film screening; one term.
GKROMST 2E03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program
GKROMST 2E03.antirequisites: CMST 2Y03, THTRFLM 2G03, CLASSICS 2E03 Offered on rotation.

GKROMST 2YY3.name: Greek Tragedy
GKROMST 2YY3.description: Selected plays of the Greek tragic playwrights will be read in translation and considered in their literary, historical or social contexts. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 2YY3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program
GKROMST 2YY3.antirequisites: THTRFLM 2Y03, CLASSICS 2YY3 Offered in alternate years.

GKROMST 3EE3.name: The Greek Historians
GKROMST 3EE3.description: The study in translation of Herodotus, Thucydides, and other Greek historical writers, with consideration of the evolution of their genre and their contributions to the development of historiography. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 3EE3.prerequisites: One of CLASSICS 1M03, 2K03, 2LA3, 2HA3, GKROMST 1M03 , 2HA3 , 2K03 , or registration in Level III or above of any program
GKROMST 3EE3.antirequisites: HISTORY 3EE3, CLASSICS 3EE3 Offered in alternate years.

GKROMST 3ER3.name: Epics of Rome
GKROMST 3ER3.description: This course will examine the great epic poems of Vergil, Ovid and Statius, studying them in the political and cultural context of contemporary Rome and against the background of the tradition of epic poetry. Three hours; one term.
GKROMST 3ER3.prerequisites: Three units from CLASSICS 1B03, 2D03, 2E03, 2Y03, 2YY3, GKROMST 1B03 , 2D03 , 2E03 , 2YY3 ; and registration in Level II or above of any program

GKROMST 3M03.name: Greek Intellectual Revolution
GKROMST 3M03.description: A study of the birth of rationalistic and naturalistic thought in Greece, placing this intellectual revolution in its social, political and cultural context. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 3M03.prerequisites: Three units of CLASSICS, GKROMST, HISTORY, or PHILOSOPHY; and registration in Level II or above of any program
GKROMST 3M03.antirequisites: HISTORY 3M03, CLASSICS 3M03 Offered in alternate years.

GKROMST 3YY3.name: Ovid
GKROMST 3YY3.description: Representative texts of the Latin poet Ovid will be read in translation, especially his erotic poetry and mythical stories. There will be literary analysis and later adaptations in literature and film will be considered. Three hours; one term.
GKROMST 3YY3.prerequisites: Three units from CLASSICS 1B03, 2D03, 2E03, 2Y03, 2YY3, GKROMST 1B03 , 2D03 , 2E03 , 2Y03, 2YY3 ; and registration in Level II or above of any program.

GKROMST 2LW3.name: Ancient Law
GKROMST 2LW3.description: An overview of the law and legal systems of the ancient world, from Mesopotamia, ancient Israel, Greece, and Rome. Themes may include notions of justice, legal status, family law, property law, delict, injury and crime. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 2LW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of any program
GKROMST 2LW3.antirequisites: HISTORY 2LW3, CLASSICS 2LW3 Offered in alternate years.

GKROMST 2MT3.name: Ancient Roots of Medical Terminology
GKROMST 2MT3.description: This course presents Greek and Latin roots out of which is built the vocabulary of contemporary medicine and reveals the predictable patterns by which these roots combine. Students will learn to define new compounds and phrases by analysis of their parts. Three lectures; one term Antirequisite(s): CLASSICS 2MT3.

GKROMST 3HH3.name: Roman Slavery
GKROMST 3HH3.description: An examination of Roman slavery using a variety of sources (historical and juridical texts, funerary inscriptions, archaeological evidence) in order to determine its place in Roman social structure and its importance to the ancient economy and culture. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 3HH3.prerequisites: One of CLASSICS 1M03, 2K03, 2LC3, 2LD3, GKROMST 1M03 , 2K03 ; and registration in Level II or above of any program
GKROMST 3HH3.antirequisites: HISTORY 3HH3, CLASSICS 3HH3 Offered in alternate years.

GKROMST 3MT3.name: Advanced Ancient Roots of Medical Terminology
GKROMST 3MT3.description: This course continues and develops the methods and materials introduced in CLASSICS GKROMST 2MT3, presenting advanced and specialized medical terms and an introduction to the major Latin corpus of anatomical phrases known as the Terminologia Anatomica. Three hours; one term.

GKROMST 3X03.name: Roman Religion
GKROMST 3X03.description: A study of the role of religion in Roman public and private life using literary, documentary and archaeological evidence. Three lectures; one term.
GKROMST 3X03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above any program
GKROMST 3X03.antirequisites: HISTORY 3X03, CLASSICS 3X03 Offered in alternate years.

GKROMST 4E03.name: Seminar in Ancient Culture
GKROMST 4E03.description: Consult the Department for the topic to be offered. Seminar (two hours); one term.
GKROMST 4E03.prerequisites: Six units from Level III CLASSICS or GKROMST or above or registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in Classics or Greek and Roman Studies CLASSICS or GKROMST 4E03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

GKROMST 4F03.name: Seminar in Ancient History
GKROMST 4F03.description: Consult the Department for the topic to be offered. Seminar (two hours); one term.
GKROMST 4F03.prerequisites: Nine units from CLASSICS or GKROMST 2HA3 , 2HB3 , 2HC3 , 2HD3 , 2K03 , 2LA3, 2LB3, 2LC3, 2LD3, 3HH3 , 3M03 , 3X03 or registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in Classics, Greek and Roman Studies or History
GKROMST 4F03.antirequisites: HISTORY 4FA3, CLASSICS 4E03 GKROMST 4F03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units. Offered in alternate years.

GKROMST 4FP3.name: Field Practicum in Greek and Roman Archaeology
GKROMST 4FP3.description: Students will learn the techniques of archaeology in the field (survey, excavation, finds processing) by participating in an excavation at a classical site in the Mediterranean area. Offered during the spring/summer session only.
GKROMST 4FP3.prerequisites: Six units of CLASSICS or GKROMST 2BB3, 2C03, 2CC3, 3B03, 3Q03, 3S03; and permission of the Department

GKROMST 4H03.name: Death and Commemoration in the Roman World
GKROMST 4H03.description: An examination of attitudes to death and commemoration at ancient Rome incorporating written sources and material culture. Seminar (two hours); one term.
GKROMST 4H03.prerequisites: Nine units of CLASSICS or GKROMST including at least three units at Level III or above or registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in Classics or Greek and Roman Studies

GKROMST 4L03.name: Athenian Democracy
GKROMST 4L03.description: A study of the institutional, social and cultural dynamics of popular self-government in Athens, exploring how Athenian democracy compares and contrasts with democracy today. Seminar (two hours); one term.
GKROMST 4L03.prerequisites: Nine units from CLASSICS or GKROMST 2HA3, 2HB3, 2HC3, 2HD3, 2LA3, 2LB3, 2LC3, 2LD3, 3HH3, 3M03, 3X03, GKROMST 3HH3, 3M03, 3X03 or registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in Classics, Greek and Roman Studies or History.

GKROMST 4MR3.name: The Myth and Reality of Troy
GKROMST 4MR3.description: A consideration of the role that the Trojans played in the history, art, and literature of the Greeks and Romans. Seminar (two hours); one term.
GKROMST 4MR3.prerequisites: Nine units of CLASSICS or GKROMST including three units from CLASSICS or GKROMST 2YY3, 2D03, 3EE3, 3YY3, or 3Z03 or registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in Classics or Greek and Roman Studies

GKROMST 4U03.name: The Severe Style in Greek Art
GKROMST 4U03.description: This course examines the birth of the Classical Greek style and its earliest manifestation, the Severe style. Sculpture, vase painting and architectural examples will be considered and placed in their appropriate political and cultural contexts. Seminar (two hours); one term.
GKROMST 4U03.prerequisites: Nine units of CLASSICS or GKROMST, including CLASSICS 2B03 or GKROMST 2B03 or registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in Classics or Greek and Roman Studies

GREEK 1Z03.name: Beginner’s Intensive Ancient Greek I
GREEK 1Z03.description: A rapid introduction to the basic grammar of Ancient Greek. Four hours (lectures and tutorials); one term.

GREEK 1ZZ3.name: Beginner’s Intensive Ancient Greek II
GREEK 1ZZ3.description: This course continues the study of the grammar of Ancient Greek begun in GREEK 1Z03. Four hours (lectures and tutorials); one term.
GREEK 1ZZ3.prerequisites: GREEK 1Z03 . Students with Grade 12 Greek U must obtain special permission to register in the course. This course, with a grade of at least C is accepted as a prerequisite for admission to any Honours program in Greek and Roman Studies, or, with a grade of at least C-, for admission to the B.A. program in Greek and Roman Studies.

GREEK 2A03.name: Intermediate Greek I
GREEK 2A03.description: This course continues the study of Greek grammar begun in GREEK 1Z03 and 1ZZ3 and introduces students to the reading of simple passages from Greek authors. Three lectures; one term.
GREEK 2A03.prerequisites: One of Grade 12 Greek U; or GREEK 1ZZ3 with a grade of at least C-. Students using this course as a Humanities I requirement will register for GREEK 2A03 and 2AA3

GREEK 2AA3.name: Intermediate Greek II
GREEK 2AA3.description: A study of selected passages from Greek authors designed to develop further the student’s proficiency in reading Greek. The course may also include grammatical exercises. Three lectures; one term.

GREEK 3AA3.name: Greek Prose
GREEK 3AA3.description: Selected readings in one or more Greek prose authors. Three lectures; one term.
GREEK 3AA3.prerequisites: GREEK 2A03 , 2AA3 GREEK 3AA3 may be repeated, if on a different author/work, to a total of six units.

GREEK 3BB3.name: Topics in Greek Literature
GREEK 3BB3.description: Consult the Department for the topic to be offered. Three lectures; one term.
GREEK 3BB3.prerequisites: GREEK 2A03 , 2AA3 GREEK 3BB3 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

GREEK 3E03.name: Topics in Greek Poetry
GREEK 3E03.description: Consult the department for the topic to be offered. Three lectures; one term.
GREEK 3E03.prerequisites: Six units of Level II Greek GREEK 3E03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

GREEK 4T03.name: Independent Study in Greek
GREEK 4T03.description: Selected readings from Greek authors supervised by a member of the Department. Tutorials; one term.
GREEK 4T03.prerequisites: Six units of Level III Greek and registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in Classics or Greek and Roman Studies and permission of the Department GREEK 4T03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

LATIN 1Z03.name: Beginner’s Intensive Latin I
LATIN 1Z03.description: A rapid introduction to the basic grammar of Classical Latin. Lectures and tutorials (four hours); one term.

LATIN 1ZZ3.name: Beginner’s Intensive Latin II
LATIN 1ZZ3.description: This course continues the study of Latin grammar begun in LATIN 1Z03. Four hours (lectures and tutorials); one term.
LATIN 1ZZ3.prerequisites: LATIN 1Z03 . Students with Grade 12 Latin U must obtain special permission to register in the course. This course, with a grade of at least C, is accepted as a prerequisite for admission to any Honours program in Greek and Roman Studies, or, with a grade of at least C-, for admission to the B.A. program in Greek and Roman Studies.

LATIN 2A03.name: Intermediate Latin I
LATIN 2A03.description: This course continues the study of Latin grammar begun in LATIN 1Z03 and 1ZZ3 and introduces students to the reading of simple passages from Latin authors. Three lectures; one term.
LATIN 2A03.prerequisites: Grade 12 Latin U; or LATIN 1ZZ3 with a grade of at least C-. Students using this course as a Humanities I requirement will register for LATIN 2A03 and 2AA3 .

LATIN 2AA3.name: Intermediate Latin II
LATIN 2AA3.description: A study of selected passages from Latin authors designed to further the student’s proficiency in reading Latin. Attention will be given to grammar and techniques of literary criticism. Three lectures; one term.

LATIN 3AA3.name: Latin Prose
LATIN 3AA3.description: Selected readings in one or more Latin prose authors. Three lectures; one term.
LATIN 3AA3.prerequisites: LATIN 2A03 , 2AA3 LATIN 3AA3 may be repeated, if on a different author/work, to a total of six units.

LATIN 3BB3.name: Topics in Latin Literature
LATIN 3BB3.description: Consult the Department for the topic to be offered. Three lectures; one term.
LATIN 3BB3.prerequisites: LATIN 2A03 , 2AA3 LATIN 3BB3 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

LATIN 3H03.name: Topics in Latin Poetry
LATIN 3H03.description: Consult the Department for the topic to be offered. Three lectures; one term.
LATIN 3H03.prerequisites: Six units of Level II Latin LATIN 3H03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

LATIN 4T03.name: Independent Study in Latin
LATIN 4T03.description: Selected readings from Latin authors supervised by a member of the Department. Tutorials; one term.
LATIN 4T03.prerequisites: Six units of Level III Latin; and registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program in Classics or Greek and Roman Studies; and permission of the Department. LATIN 4T03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

HLTHAGE 1AA3.name: Introduction to Health and Society
HLTHAGE 1AA3.description: An introduction to the key themes and questions concerning health and health care from within social sciences perspectives. Three hours (lectures and tutorials); one term Antirequisite(s): HLTHAGE 1ZZ3 , HEALTHST 1A03, HTHSCI 2RR3.

HLTHAGE 1BB3.name: Introduction to Aging and Society
HLTHAGE 1BB3.description: Examines issues in aging from a multidisciplinary perspective including such topics as: myths and stereotypes of aging, social ties in later life and the aging of the Canadian population. Provides a deeper understanding of aging and the changing body, mind and self, as well as the meaning and experiences, challenges and opportunities of aging and later life. Three hours (lectures, tutorials and experiential components); one term Antirequisite(s): GERONTOL 1A03.

HLTHAGE 1CC3.name: Introduction to Mental Health and Illness
HLTHAGE 1CC3.description: An introduction to well-being and the basic types of mental disorders from social, psychological, behavioral, and medical perspectives. Lectures and tutorials/discussion (three hours); one term.

HLTHAGE 1ZZ3.name: Inquiry: Introduction to Health and Society
HLTHAGE 1ZZ3.description: This inquiry course is designed to develop skills basic to an introduction to the key themes and questions concerning health and health care from within social sciences perspectives. Three hours (lectures and tutorials); one term.
HLTHAGE 1ZZ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level I of Honours Health and Society

HLTHAGE 2A03.name: Research Methods in Health and in Aging I
HLTHAGE 2A03.description: This course introduces students to the qualitative and quantitative research methods used in the social sciences. Students will develop skills to read, understand and evaluate the quality of research papers employing both methods. Three hours (lectures and discussion/tutorials); one term.
HLTHAGE 2A03.prerequisites: Registration in any Health, Aging and Society program
HLTHAGE 2A03.antirequisites: CMST 2A03; ENVSOCTY 3MA3; GEOG 3MA3; GERONTOL 2C03; HLTHAGE 2A06, 3Z06; HEALTHST 2B03, SOCSCI 2K03, SOCIOL 2Z03 , SOCPSY 2K03 , SOCSCI 2T03

HLTHAGE 2AN3.name: The Anthropology of Food and Nutrition
HLTHAGE 2AN3.description: An anthropological perspective on nutrition at the population level. Prehistoric, historic, and contemporary human nutrition, emphasizing links with the environment. Two hours (lecture), one hour (tutorial); one term.
HLTHAGE 2AN3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology or HLTHAGE 1AA3 (HEALTHST 1A03); and registration in Level II or above in any program
HLTHAGE 2AN3.antirequisites: HEALTHST 2AN3 Cross-list(s): ANTHROP 2AN3 This course is administered by the Department of Anthropology.

HLTHAGE 2B03.name: Social Identity, Health and Illness
HLTHAGE 2B03.description: A critical exploration of the role of class, race, gender, ability and age in patterns of health and illness. Lectures and discussion/tutorials (three hours); one term.
HLTHAGE 2B03.prerequisites: Registration in any Health, Aging and Society program

HLTHAGE 2BB3.name: Perspectives in Health, Aging and Society
HLTHAGE 2BB3.description: Explores social aspects of health and aging at both the individual and societal levels using a variety of approaches such as life course perspective, political economy, social constructionism, self identity, and a feminist perspective of aging. Three hours (lectures and discussions/tutorials); one term.
HLTHAGE 2BB3.prerequisites: HLTHAGE 1AA3 or 1ZZ3 and 1BB3 and registration in any Health, Aging and Society program

HLTHAGE 2C03.name: Health Economics and its Application to Health Policy
HLTHAGE 2C03.description: Economic analyses of health and health care, with a special emphasis on policy issues in the Canadian health care system. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HLTHAGE 2C03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HLTHAGE 2D03.name: Continuum of Care
HLTHAGE 2D03.description: The course will critically examine the continuum of care options for older adults needing support and services in later life. Some of the topics addressed include quality of life and quality of care issues, challenges involved in care integration across the continuum, environmental design, human diversity and long term care needs, formal and informal support, as well as policy and funding issues. Lectures, and discussion (three hours); one term.
HLTHAGE 2D03.prerequisites: Registration in any Health, Aging and Society program

HLTHAGE 2F03.name: Aging and Health Care Systems
HLTHAGE 2F03.description: This course examines the available international evidence on the impact of aging on health and long-term care expenditures and organization, as well as the choices various societies are making around issues of aging, health, and long-term care, and the equity issues such choices raise. Lectures and discussion/tutorials (three hours); one term.
HLTHAGE 2F03.prerequisites: Registration in any Health, Aging and Society Program

HLTHAGE 2GG3.name: Mental Health and Society
HLTHAGE 2GG3.description: An examination of mental health and illness from different social, cultural and historical perspectives, including consideration of changing notions of diagnosis, treatment and prevention. Three hours (lectures and tutorials); one term.
HLTHAGE 2GG3.prerequisites: Registration in level II or above

HLTHAGE 2HI3.name: Health & Place
HLTHAGE 2HI3.description: Introduction to health geography. Contemporary trends and patterns of global mortality and morbidity are explored using examples from different parts of the world. A range of perspectives are used to compliment a geographical viewpoint, including: medical, cultural, ecological, social and demographic. Two lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.
HLTHAGE 2HI3.antirequisites: GEOG 2HI3, HEALTHST 2HI3 Cross-list(s): ENVSOCTY 2HI3 This course is administered by the School of Earth, Environment & Society.

HLTHAGE 2J03.name: Selected Topics in Aging and Society
HLTHAGE 2J03.description: This course will provide an exploration of selected topics in aging. Topics may vary from year to year. Three hours (lectures, discussion); one term.
HLTHAGE 2J03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HLTHAGE 2K03.name: Selected Topics in Health and Society
HLTHAGE 2K03.description: This course will provide an exploration of selected topics in Health Studies. Topics may vary from year to year. 3 hours; one term.
HLTHAGE 2K03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above.

HLTHAGE 2L03.name: Drugs, Sex and Alcohol: Society and its Addictions
HLTHAGE 2L03.description: This course analyzes the place of addictions in modern society. Taking an interdisciplinary perspective, it examines both the social factors that help shape addictive behaviours, as well as those that construct our notions of addiction and dependency. Three hours (lectures and tutorials); one term.
HLTHAGE 2L03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HLTHAGE 2M03.name: Aging in Modern (and Post-Modern) Families
HLTHAGE 2M03.description: This course examines how aging and gender combine to affect a range of relationships across different types of family. The relationships considered include relations with one’s partner, marital transitions, the relationship between adult children and their parents, sibling ties, grandparent/grandchild relationships, and fictive kin. Three hours (lecture, discussion); one term.
HLTHAGE 2M03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HLTHAGE 2N03.name: Treatment Within the World of Mental Illness: Desperation and Debate
HLTHAGE 2N03.description: This course analyzes the treatment of mental health problems. Taking an interdisciplinary perspective, it examines the ideas and ideologies that guide responses to mental illness, as well as the interaction between the social world and psychiatric treatment.
HLTHAGE 2N03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HLTHAGE 3AA3.name: State, Civil Society and Health
HLTHAGE 3AA3.description: This course explores how states, citizens, and civil society act and interact in the definition and pursuit of health. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HLTHAGE 3AA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Health, Aging and Society program

HLTHAGE 3AB3.name: Kindred Species: Animals, Health and Society
HLTHAGE 3AB3.description: This course explores key topics and concepts at the intersection of animals and health. One Health is used as a guiding concept to explore topics such as the public health risks posed to humans by animals; the intersection between health care for humans and animals; and the animal interventions and assisted activities that are currently popular for advancing human health. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
HLTHAGE 3AB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

HLTHAGE 3B03.name: Advanced Research Methods
HLTHAGE 3B03.description: This course provides hands-on learning where students develop skills in planning and conducting research: research question identification, tool development and pilot testing, data analysis, and reporting for both quantitative and qualitative approaches. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
HLTHAGE 3B03.prerequisites: One of GERONTOL 2C03, HEALTHST 2B03 or HLTHAGE 2A03 , and registration in Level III or above of a Health, Aging and Society program

HLTHAGE 3BB3.name: Field Experience
HLTHAGE 3BB3.description: Directed observation of 40 hours in an approved field setting and a weekly seminar focusing on integration of theoretical knowledge and field experience. Approximately four hours field observation per week, and two hours weekly seminar; one term.
HLTHAGE 3BB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of any Health, Aging and Society program

HLTHAGE 3D03.name: Perspectives on Disability, Chronic Illness and Aging
HLTHAGE 3D03.description: Designed to provide a critical examination of the interdisciplinary aspects of disability, chronic illness and aging and to gain deeper insights into the complex nature of living with a disability and/or chronic illness. Issues and challenges related to definitions, concepts, models, research, policy, program and practice implications will be discussed. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HLTHAGE 3D03.prerequisites: One of HLTHAGE 1AA3 or 1ZZ3 (HEALTHST 1A03) or HLTHAGE 1BB3 (GERONTOL 1A03) and Registration in Level III or above

HLTHAGE 3DD3.name: Work: Dangerous to your Health?
HLTHAGE 3DD3.description: An analysis of issues and problems associated with occupational health and safety in Canada and other industrialized countries. Topics will be examined from social, political, economic, legal and medical perspectives. Lectures and discussion; one term.
HLTHAGE 3DD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Health, Aging and Society or Labour Studies program.
HLTHAGE 3DD3.antirequisites: HEALTHST 3C03 Cross-list(s): LABRST 3D03 This course is administered by School of Labour Studies . Generally offered in alternate years.

HLTHAGE 3E03.name: Ethical Issues in Health and Aging
HLTHAGE 3E03.description: Ethical issues of current relevance to debates in aging, health and health care. Topics will vary from year to year. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
HLTHAGE 3E03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of any program
