LIFESCI 3W03.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 2C03 or LIFESCI 2G03 ; and registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in the Faculty of Science

LIFESCI 3XX3.name: Peer Mentoring in the Life Sciences
LIFESCI 3XX3.description: This course explores the pedagogy of peer mentorship. Students apply what they learn by providing support, advice, and guidance to more junior life science students. They will also have the opportunity to assess their progress as mentors and communicate their findings using various science communication strategies. Applications will be available at the beginning of March on the School of Interdisciplinary Science (SIS) website. Applications must be submitted by April 1 of the preceding academic year. Successful students will be notified by May 30. Lectures (three hours), tutorial (two hours); one term.
LIFESCI 3XX3.prerequisites: LIFESCI 2AA3 and registration in Level III or above of an Honours Life Sciences program; or registration in Level III or above of an Honours Life Sciences specialization; and a GPA of at least 7.0; and permission of the instructor

LIFESCI 3Z03.name: Life Sciences Inquiry
LIFESCI 3Z03.description: Provides an opportunity to explore various areas of study within the Life Sciences in a small-group learning environment. Three hours (seminar); one term.
LIFESCI 3Z03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III of an Honours Life Sciences program. Some topics may have additional course requisites. Details may be found on the School of Interdisciplinary Science (SIS) website. LIFE SCI 3Z03 may be repeated, if on a different topic. Some offerings may have a field/experiential component and/or be offered in a condensed term. LIFESCI 3Z03 may not be offered each academic year.

LIFESCI 4A03.name: Independent Study
LIFESCI 4A03.description: An independent study under the supervision of a McMaster University faculty member. More information and the online application can be found on the School of Interdisciplinary Science (SIS) website. Students are responsible for arranging a suitable independent study and supervision, and are required to submit an online application thirty days prior to the date classes begin in each term (see the Sessional Dates section of this Calendar). Lecture (one hour); one term.
LIFESCI 4A03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences (B.Sc.) program and permission of the supervising faculty member and the School of Interdisciplinary Science (SIS) Experiential Education Coordinator. LIFESCI 3RP3 is highly recommended.
LIFESCI 4A03.antirequisites: LIFESCI 4B09 A/B S , 4C12 A/B S , 4D15 A/B S LIFESCI 4A03 cannot be taken concurrently with any other Life Sciences research or thesis course.

LIFESCI 4CM3.name: Foundations of Disease States Inquiry Lab
LIFESCI 4CM3.description: In this inquiry-based lab course, students learn and apply current techniques to study the behavioural, cellular, and molecular basis of human disease states. Lecture (one hour), one lab or workshop (four hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4CM3.prerequisites: LIFESCI 3M03 and registration in Level IV or above of Honours Life Sciences - Origins of Disease Specialization (B.Sc.) ; or permission of the instructor

LIFESCI 4DD3.name: Racism & Health Inequities in Science & Health Care
LIFESCI 4DD3.description: In this course students will explore and discuss how racism, prejudice, and biases have shaped scientific thought and medical practice. Students will also discuss how systemic racism has impacted how racialized and marginalized groups receive health care. Seminars and discussions in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4DD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences (B.Sc.) program Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4E03.name: Science & Storytelling
LIFESCI 4E03.description: Communicating science through stories can increase the visibility and impact of developments in the field. This course will explore the role of storytelling in communicating science across various cultures and to a wide range of audiences. Students will engage with and produce different types of stories and consider how they can be leveraged to make scientific knowledge more accessible. Seminar and discussions in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4E03.prerequisites: LIFESCI 3P03 and registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences program

LIFESCI 4F03.name: Emerging Paradigms in Environmental Change and Health
LIFESCI 4F03.description: Advanced seminar on selected aspects of the relation between environmental change and human health. Seminar and discussions in small groups (three hours); one term Prerequisites: LIFESCI 2X03 and registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences (B.Sc.) program Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4H03.name: Regeneration: What Can We Learn From Animal Models?
LIFESCI 4H03.description: Regeneration is the process by which lost body parts are replaced or restored. There is widespread variability in the ability of organisms to regenerate. In this course we will explore, through the examination of the current scientific literature, what is known about the molecular mechanisms underlying this process and the current tools employed to explore this highly sought after ability. Seminar and discussions in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4H03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Science program Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4I03.name: Research Seminar
LIFESCI 4I03.description: Advanced seminar focusing on selected topics in an area of Life Sciences. Seminar and discussion in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4I03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Science program Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4J03.name: Science Communication in the Media
LIFESCI 4J03.description: Media coverage of scientific discoveries can shape the public opinion of science and influence policy decisions. In this course, students will take a critical look at how journalists portray science and examine the consequences of poor science communication. Students will practice translating complex concepts for diverse audiences and create different forms of science journalism, such as articles, op-eds and podcasts. Seminar and discussions in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4J03.prerequisites: LIFESCI 3P03 and registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences program

LIFESCI 4L03.name: Our Invisible Body: Microbes and Human Health
LIFESCI 4L03.description: This seminar course will investigate the human microbiome and its role in human health. This seminar course will investigate microbes (bacteria, fungi, viruses) and their role in human health. Students will review current research on the different microbial environments within the human body and explore the complex and mysterious relationship struck between ourselves and our microscopic counterparts with respect to health, well-being, and disease. Seminars and discussions in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4L03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences (B.Sc.) program Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4M03.name: Research Seminar
LIFESCI 4M03.description: Advanced seminar focusing on selected topics in an area of Life Sciences. Seminars and discussions in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4M03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences (B.Sc.) program Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4N03.name: Research Seminar
LIFESCI 4N03.description: Advanced seminar focusing on selected topics in an area of Life Sciences. Seminars and discussions in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4N03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences (B.Sc.) program Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4O03.name: Research Seminar
LIFESCI 4O03.description: Advanced seminar focusing on selected topics in an area of Life Sciences. Seminar and discussion in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4O03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Science program Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4P03.name: Research Seminar
LIFESCI 4P03.description: Advanced seminar focusing on selected topics in an area of Life Sciences. Seminars and discussions in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4P03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences program Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4Q03.name: Research Seminar
LIFESCI 4Q03.description: Advanced seminar focusing on selected topics in an area of Life Sciences. Seminars and discussions in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4Q03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences program Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4U03.name: Mechanisms of Disease
LIFESCI 4U03.description: Students will analyze molecular and cellular research on disease pathogenesis, explore how cellular miscommunication results in disease, and investigate the design process behind targeted therapeutics. Seminar and discussion in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4U03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences program. Completion of LIFESCI 3M03 or MOLBIOL 3B03 is strongly recommended. Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4V03.name: Extracellular Vesicles in Health and Disease
LIFESCI 4V03.description: In this course, students critically examine the emerging research on the physiological and pathological roles of extracellular vesicles as well as their potential clinical applications. Seminar and discussion in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4V03.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 2B03 and BIOLOGY 2C03 (or LIFESCI 2G03 ) and registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences (B.Sc.) program Prerequisite(s) (Effective 2024-25): BIOLOGY 2B03 , BIOLOGY 2C03 and registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences (B.Sc.) program Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4W03.name: Advanced Topics in Nutrition
LIFESCI 4W03.description: This course will extend the study of nutrition beyond the examination of macro-, and micro-nutrients to investigating topics such as dietary analysis/planning, supplementation usage, and human health/disease management. Seminar and discussion in small groups (three hours); one term.
LIFESCI 4W03.prerequisites: LIFESCI 2N03 ; and registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences program Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4X03.name: The Biopsychology of Sex
LIFESCI 4X03.description: This course will explore topics in the scientific study of human sexuality from an anatomical, behavioural, and neuroendocrine perspective. Sample topics may include reproductive strategies, fertility, pregnancy and childbirth, sexual development, gender differences, and sexually transmitted diseases. Seminar and discussion in small groups (two hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
LIFESCI 4X03.prerequisites: LIFESCI 3E03 (or 3C03); and registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences program Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LIFESCI 4XX3.name: The Synapse
LIFESCI 4XX3.description: Exploration of classical and current research on the mechanisms of synaptic transmission, with a focus on the neuromuscular junction, sensory receptors, memory formation, and the roles of synapses in disease. Seminar and discussion in small groups (two hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
LIFESCI 4XX3.prerequisites: LIFESCI 3BB3 and registration in Level IV or above of Honours Life Sciences Sensory-Motor Systems Specialization or permission of the instructor

LIFESCI 4Y03.name: Applied Biomechanics
LIFESCI 4Y03.description: A combination of lectures and problem based learning on aspects of human movement facing the modern biomechanist. Topics and problems are taken from occupational, clinical and sport biomechanics. Three hours (lectures, tutorials); one term.
LIFESCI 4Y03.prerequisites: KINESIOL 2Y03 , 2YY3 , LIFESCI 3J03 , and registration in Level IV or above of an Honours Life Sciences program
LIFESCI 4Y03.antirequisites: KINESIOL 4AA3 Preferential enrolment is done by preregistration ballot (See Department Note 2 above).

LINGUIST 2E03.name: The Nature of Texts: From Slang to Formal Discourse
LINGUIST 2E03.description: This course introduces students to the field of discourse analysis and investigates a variety of styles and registers from the conversational to the literary and from the journalistic to the academic. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 2E03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

LINGUIST 2FL3.name: Introduction to Forensic Linguistics
LINGUIST 2FL3.description: An introduction to the discipline of language and the law. Through a consideration of several famous trials and cases, topics covered include: speaker/voice identification, the language of police interrogations, courtroom language, forensic document investigation, the nature of legal language, the linguist as expert witness. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 2FL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

LINGUIST 2S03.name: Language and Society
LINGUIST 2S03.description: An introduction to sociolinguistics covering such topics as linguistic variation (regional, social, situational), language and gender, language and disadvantage/power, language choice, language change, pidgin and creole languages. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 2S03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above; or registration in the Diploma in Indigenous Language Revitalization
LINGUIST 2S03.antirequisites: CMST 3G03,  IBH 1AC3, LINGUIST 3X03, PEACEST 2LS3 Cross-list(s): PEACJUST 2LS3 This course is administered by the Department of Linguistics and Languages.

LINGUIST 3AS3.name: Language and Communication in Autism Spectrum Disorder
LINGUIST 3AS3.description: Students will learn about Autism Spectrum Disorder and theories put forth to explain it, with a focus on language and social impairments. Conflicting views on language deficits in ASD will be explored and current research into language abilities in ASD will be introduced. Cross-list(s): INSPIRE 3AS3.
LINGUIST 3AS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

LINGUIST 3TT3.name: Perspectives on Translation
LINGUIST 3TT3.description: This course introduces theories, concepts, and problems in Translation Studies. It examines cognitive, linguistic, computational, cultural, artistic and ethical aspects of translation using a multidisciplinary approach. Note: knowledge of a second language is not required to enroll. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 3TT3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

LINGUIST 2L03.name: Phonetics
LINGUIST 2L03.description: A study of the sounds of language, human articulatory capabilities and speech production, human auditory and speech perception (ear and brain) and phonetic transcription. Three hours (lectures and tutorial); one term.

LINGUIST 2LC3.name: Historical Linguistics: Language Evolution and Change
LINGUIST 2LC3.description: An examination of key concepts in language change including: grammatical change (e.g. phonological change), comparative and internal reconstruction, socio-historical considerations (language contact and variation), the birth and death of languages. Three hours; one term.

LINGUIST 2LL3.name: Languages of the World and Linguistic Universals
LINGUIST 2LL3.description: The study of diversity in the languages of the world, language universals, and the parameters of cross-linguistic analysis of grammatical systems. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 2LL3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 1A03 and 1AA3; or registration in the Diploma in Indigenous Language Revitalization

LINGUIST 2PS3.name: Psycholinguistics
LINGUIST 2PS3.description: Examines evidence from behavioural experiments to study how the human mind understands sounds, words, and sentences. The class involves team-based projects; regular attendance is vital. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 2PS3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 1A03 and 1AA3; or registration in the Diploma in Indigenous Language Revitalization

LINGUIST 2SY3.name: Syntax
LINGUIST 2SY3.description: The study of sentence structure in many languages. The emphasis is on using empirical data to test theoretical proposals. Three hours (lectures and tutorial); one term.

LINGUIST 3C03.name: Child Language Acquisition
LINGUIST 3C03.description: Language behaviour and development in children, from birth to school age. The course examines how data from children’s language acquisition can inform linguistic theory. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 3C03.prerequisites: LINGUIST 1A03 ; and one of LINGUIST 1AA3 , PNB 2XA3 or PSYCH 2H03 Cross-list(s): PSYCH 3C03 This course is administered by the Department of Linguistics and Languages .

LINGUIST 3E03.name: Teaching English as a Second Language (ESL)
LINGUIST 3E03.description: A survey of methods for teaching English as a Second or Other Language, including Canadian Language Benchmarks and worldwide standards. Three hours; one term.

LINGUIST 3F03.name: Anatomy and Physiology for Speech, Language and Hearing
LINGUIST 3F03.description: Anatomy and physiology of human speech production and hearing. Systems for speech production (lungs, glottis, vocal tract, jaw, lips) and perception (outer/middle/inner ear, auditory processing) and anatomy of brain areas for speech perception. Three hours; one term.

LINGUIST 3LA3.name: Introduction to Second Language Acquisition
LINGUIST 3LA3.description: The course introduces the students to major theories in second language acquisition through readings and problem-based assignments. The objective is to learn about theories as well as practise using them as a basis for generating ideas for both practical applications and research. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 3LA3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 1AA3 and registration in Level II or above

LINGUIST 3PG3.name: Introduction to Programming for Linguistics
LINGUIST 3PG3.description: An introduction to the fundamental principles of computing and developing programming skills using simple examples from programming languages/environments such as Matlab, Praat, Python, or R. The course applies practical examples from different core areas of Linguistics. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 3PG3.prerequisites: Three units of LINGUIST 1A03, 1E03 or 1Z03; and three units of LINGUIST 1AA3, 1EE3 or 1ZZ3

LINGUIST 1A03.name: Introduction to Linguistics: Speaking, Signing and Hearing
LINGUIST 1A03.description: An introduction to language science, focusing how speakers and signers use the body to produce and perceive language, and the systematic similarities between signed and spoken languages. Three hours (lecture, web module); one term LINGUIST 1A03 and 1AA3 prepare students for further study in Linguistics and Cognitive Science of Language.

LINGUIST 1AA3.name: Introduction to Linguistics: Words, Sentences and Meaning
LINGUIST 1AA3.description: A further introduction to the scientific study of language. The course focuses on how the mind organizes words into sentences and assigns meanings to words and sentences, concentrating on elements that are universal to all human languages. Three hours (lecture, web module); one term LINGUIST 1A03 and 1AA3 prepare students for further study in Linguistics and Cognitive Science of Language.

LINGUIST 1E03.name: Introduction to English Linguistics I
LINGUIST 1E03.description: This course introduces students to the study of the linguistic structure of contemporary English, particularly the distinctive sounds of English and how they are organized (phonetics and phonology), and the analysis of the structure of words (morphology) and their meaning in modern English. Three hours (lecture), one hour (tutorial); one term.
LINGUIST 1E03.prerequisites: Registration in the McMaster English Language Development Diploma (MELD) program

LINGUIST 1EE3.name: Introduction to English Linguistics II
LINGUIST 1EE3.description: This course explores the linguistic structure of contemporary English, focusing on the analysis of sentence structure (syntax), the meaning of words (lexical semantics) and the interaction of sentence structure, meaning and language use (pragmatics). Three hours (lecture), one hour (tutorial); one term.
LINGUIST 1EE3.prerequisites: Registration in the McMaster English Language Development Diploma (MELD) program

LINGUIST 1Z03.name: Structure of Modern English I
LINGUIST 1Z03.description: This course introduces students to the description and transcription of sounds in contemporary English, to the rules governing pronunciation, and to the study of word formation and meaning in contemporary English. Three hours; one term Antirequisite(s): LINGUIST 1E03.

LINGUIST 1ZZ3.name: Structure of Modern English II
LINGUIST 1ZZ3.description: This course examines the structure of contemporary English sentences, and how sentences are used to build larger meaningful units of written and spoken communication. Three hours; one term Antirequisite(s): LINGUIST 1EE3.

LINGUIST 2D03.name: Research Methods
LINGUIST 2D03.description: An introduction to qualitative and quantitative approaches to research in linguistics, including topics such as research ethics, principles of data gathering and analysis, and fundamentals of statistical analysis and inference, including ANOVA. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 2D03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language; or registration in the Diploma in Indigenous Language Revitalization
LINGUIST 2D03.antirequisites: GEOG 3MA3, HLTHAGE 2A03 , POLSCI 3NN3 , POLSCI 3N06 A/B, SOCIOL 2Z03 , SOCIOL 3H06 A/B

LINGUIST 2DD3.name: Statistics for Language Research
LINGUIST 2DD3.description: The course explores the use and analysis of quantitative data in empirical linguistic research using the statistical software package R. The covered techniques include descriptive and inferential statistics, ANOVA, and regression. Three hours (lectures and tutorials); one term.
LINGUIST 2DD3.antirequisites: ECON 2B03, GEOG 3MB3, PNB 2XE3, POLSCI 3N06 A/B, POLSCI 3NN3, PSYCH 2RA3, SOCSCI 2J03, SOCIOL 3H06 A/B, STATS 2B03 Students registered in a Combined Honours program with a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences should consult an academic advisor to confirm which courses satisfy their statistics requirements.

LINGUIST 2PH3.name: Phonology
LINGUIST 2PH3.description: A study of the patterns of distinctive sounds in the world’s languages. Three hours; one term.

LINGUIST 2SL3.name: Introduction to American Sign Language
LINGUIST 2SL3.description: This course introduces students to concepts related to people, places and things within the immediate environment, as well as the basic values and norms of the Deaf culture. Students will learn how to conduct simple, everyday conversations and will gain basic numeracy skills. Three hours; one term.

LINGUIST 3AA3.name: Applied Linguistics
LINGUIST 3AA3.description: The course provides students a contrast to formal linguistics. Incorporating both sociocultural and cognitive perspectives, the course explores how linguistics contributes to real-world issues. Students will learn about the fundamental themes, tools, and participants of applied linguistics through a survey of specialist areas such as: language teaching and education, literacy and language disorders; language variation; language policy and planning; lexicography; multilingualism; translation. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 3AA3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 1A03 or 1Z03 , and 1AA3 or 1ZZ3 ; registration in Level III or above

LINGUIST 3DS3.name: ASL & Deaf Studies
LINGUIST 3DS3.description: This course develops an understanding of the concept of Deaf people and users of American Sign Language (ASL). We then focus on the complexities and varieties of Deaf experiences. Students will engage with the course material through multi-disciplinary approaches in order to gain a critical appreciation of Deaf lives and an understanding of the importance of ASL within historical, political, and global contexts. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 3DS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above

LINGUIST 3II3.name: Semantics
LINGUIST 3II3.description: The study of patterns of meaning in language; a critical survey of theories and issues. Three hours; one term.

LINGUIST 3M03.name: Morphology
LINGUIST 3M03.description: The study of word formation in the languages of the world; a critical survey of current theories and issues. Three hours; one term.

LINGUIST 3NL3.name: Cognitive Neuroscience of Language
LINGUIST 3NL3.description: A survey of the current scientific literature dealing with brain function related to language processes in typical and special populations. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 3NL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of a program in Linguistics, Cognitive Science of Language, Psychology, Human Behaviour or Neuroscience

LINGUIST 3P03.name: Pragmatics
LINGUIST 3P03.description: A discussion of the problems confronting the linguist in the study of text and discourse at the level beyond the sentence. The course will deal with the interaction between grammar and situational factors. Three hours; one term.

LINGUIST 3SL3.name: Intermediate American Sign Language
LINGUIST 3SL3.description: Expands students vocabulary and grammar for communication in American Sign Language. Further explores the attributes of Deaf culture. Three hours; one term.

LINGUIST 4AS3.name: Topics in Advanced Semantics
LINGUIST 4AS3.description: This course examines advanced issues in formal semantics, seeking to evaluate the current formal semantics theory and to address the data that fall beyond the basic theory introduced in LINGUIST 3II3 . Seminar (three hours); one term.
LINGUIST 4AS3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 3II3 and registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language

LINGUIST 4BP3.name: Bilingual Phonology
LINGUIST 4BP3.description: This course examines theories of acquisition and production of bilingual phonology in populations of early bilinguals, late bilinguals, and heritage bilinguals. This course exposes students to recent findings in the literature of bilingual phonology and prepares them to conduct independent research in populations of bilingual speakers. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 4BP3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 2L03 and 2PH3 ; and registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language

LINGUIST 4D03.name: Computers and Linguistic Analysis
LINGUIST 4D03.description: This course studies the applications of computer technology to language processing, including corpus research, parsers and machine translation. Lecture and lab (three hours); one term.
LINGUIST 4D03.prerequisites: LINGUIST 2DD3 and registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language

LINGUIST 4EL3.name: Laboratory in Experimental Linguistics
LINGUIST 4EL3.description: Students collaborate to plan, carry out, and analyze an experiment addressing a cognitive aspect of language processing or acquisition. Students write a report of their findings and present a poster at the department’s Student Research Day. Two hours plus lab work; one term.
LINGUIST 4EL3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 2D03 ; and one of LINGUIST 2PS3 , 3C03 , 3LA3 , 3NL3 or 4F03 and registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language

LINGUIST 4G03.name: Language, Sex and Gender
LINGUIST 4G03.description: This course investigates how patterns of language behaviour interact with social categories of gender and sexuality, and how speakers use language to express their gender and sexual identities. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 4G03.prerequisites: LINGUIST 2S03 ; and registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language, or permission of the department for students pursuing a minor in Gender Studies

LINGUIST 4HL3.name: Heritage Languages in the Hamilton Diaspora
LINGUIST 4HL3.description: In this experiential, problem-based learning course, students will engage with community partners to study linguistic aspects of identity formation among immigrants to the Hamilton region. Students will use interviews, historical archives and other ethnographic and sociolinguistic tools to explore and document linguistic and cultural diversity in Hamilton. Seminar (two hours) plus off-campus fieldwork; one term.
LINGUIST 4HL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language or permission of the department

LINGUIST 4LB3.name: Advanced Phonetics and Phonology
LINGUIST 4LB3.description: This course examines advanced issues in phonetics and phonology, seeking to evaluate current theory and to address data that fall beyond the explanatory capacities of those paradigms. The course is data oriented, with material taken from several languages. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 4LB3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 2L03 and 2PH3 ; and registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language

LINGUIST 4LC3.name: Advanced Syntax and its Interfaces
LINGUIST 4LC3.description: This course examines advanced issues in syntax with a special focus on syntax interfaces (morphology, semantics). The course exposes students to the current theory of syntax. The course is data oriented, with material taken from several languages. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 4LC3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 2SY3 and LINGUIST 3M03 ; and registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language

LINGUIST 4LX3.name: The Structure of X
LINGUIST 4LX3.description: This course will offer the student an opportunity to examine one or more languages in detail in order to apply in a realistic setting abstract principles and techniques learned in topical courses. Methods of elicitation and recording will also be taught. Seminar (two hours); one term.
LINGUIST 4LX3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language

LINGUIST 4NN3.name: Cognitive Neurolinguistics Laboratory
LINGUIST 4NN3.description: Cognitive neuroscience methods used to study language. Hands-on experience using electrophysiological methods and EEG/ERP analysis techniques. Students write a report of their findings and present a poster at the department’s Student Research Day. Seminar (two hours) plus lab work; one term.
LINGUIST 4NN3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 2D03 and 3NL3 and registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language

LINGUIST 4PL3.name: Advanced Programming for Linguistics
LINGUIST 4PL3.description: An advanced experiential study of natural language processing applications using programming languages/environments such as Matlab, Praat, Python or R. Topics might include word categorization and tagging, text classification, or speech analysis and synthesis. Three hours; one term.
LINGUIST 4PL3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 3PG3 and registration in Level III or IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language.

LINGUIST 4R03.name: Cross-Cultural Communication
LINGUIST 4R03.description: Students will explore the links between language and culture and learn skills necessary to be intermediaries between cultures. Topics include: communication between genders, the cognitive role of metaphor, language and perception, emotions across cultures, culture and advertising, body language and cultural stereotyping. Seminar (two hours); one term.
LINGUIST 4R03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language

LINGUIST 4S03.name: Interpersonal Communication
LINGUIST 4S03.description: This course offers an introduction to contemporary interpersonal communication theories and research. Topics include: small group communication, persuasive communication, argumentation strategies, conflict resolution and computer mediated, intercultural, international and political communication. Seminar (two hours); one term.
LINGUIST 4S03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language

LINGUIST 4SL3.name: SLP Practicum
LINGUIST 4SL3.description: In this Experiential Learning course, students complete at least 36 hours observing and working under the supervision of a registered Speech-Language Pathologist and complete a Learning Portfolio documenting their experience. Consult the department website for instructions on requesting permission for this course. One term.
LINGUIST 4SL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of the Honours Cognitive Science of Language program with a Grade Point Average of 9.0; and permission of the Department

LINGUIST 4SS3.name: Seminar in Sociolinguistics
LINGUIST 4SS3.description: Topics may include pidgins & creoles, language and gender, language variation & change, or others. Seminar (two hours); one term.
LINGUIST 4SS3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 2S03 , or 3X03; and registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language

LINGUIST 4TE3.name: TESL Practicum
LINGUIST 4TE3.description: In this Experiential Learning course, students complete at least 36 hours observing and practice teaching under the supervision of an accredited ESL instructor and complete a Learning Portfolio documenting their experience. Consult the department website for instructions on requesting permission for this course. One term.
LINGUIST 4TE3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 3E03 or 4E03; registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics (minimum cumulative Grade Point Average of 9.0); and permission of the Department.

LINGUIST 4XX3.name: Topics in Linguistic Theory
LINGUIST 4XX3.description: Issues in different aspects of Linguistic Theory and Advanced Philology. Consult the Department for the topic to be offered. Seminar (two hours); one term.
LINGUIST 4XX3.prerequisites: LINGUIST 2PH3 and 2SY3 ; and registration in Level IV of a program in Linguistics or Cognitive Science of Language

MANTECH 3LS3.name: Quality Control and Assurance Methods
MANTECH 3LS3.description: Formerly MANTECH 4LS3 Detail understanding of Six sigma, Kaizen, KANBAN, supply chain and outsourcing. Concepts on planning, measurement, control, improvement of quality, analysis of variation and sampling techniques. Two lectures, one lab; one term.
MANTECH 3LS3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3MA3 and registration in Manufacturing Engineering Technology

MANTECH 3MF3.name: Micro Manufacturing and Fabrication
MANTECH 3MF3.description: Joining, welding, casting, forming, grinding, abrasive waterjet, ultrasonic machining, grinding, laser processes, micro-scale cutting, chemical etching, polishing, electric discharge machining, lithographic process, ion beam technology, inspection. Three lectures; one term.
MANTECH 3MF3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3SP3 and registration in Manufacturing Engineering Technology Cross-list(s): MECHENG 3C03 This course is administered by the Department of Mechanical Engineering.

MANTECH 4AI3.name: Artificial Intelligence
MANTECH 4AI3.description: Theories and practice of machine intelligence with focus on statistical learning methods, artificial neural networks, naturally inspired algorithms, deep learning, big data management, and pattern recognition. Three lectures, one term; may be offered in an in-person or virtual format.
MANTECH 4AI3.prerequisites: Registration in level IV of Biotechnology, Automotive and Vehicle Engineering Technology, or Manufacturing Engineering Technology,

MANTECH 4DA3.name: Design and Advanced Manufacturing
MANTECH 4DA3.description: Fundamental concepts in design and manufacturing strategies; computer aided manufacturing; non conventional machining; 3D metallic printing; rapid prototyping. Three lectures; one term.
MANTECH 4DA3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3ET0 , MANTECH 3MF3 and registration in Manufacturing Engineering Technology

MANTECH 4FM3.name: CIM and Flexible Manufacturing
MANTECH 4FM3.description: Facility layout; cellular manufacturing; flexible manufacturing systems; programmable logic controllers (PLCs); computer-aided process control; quality control and inspection principles; inspection technologies; coordinate measuring machines (CMM). Two lectures, one lab; one term.
MANTECH 4FM3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3ET0 , MANTECH 3MF3 and registration in Manufacturing Engineering Technology

MANTECH 4MM3.name: Design and Manufacturing of Machine Elements
MANTECH 4MM3.description: Theory and methodology related to conceptual design; simple design factor; variable loads; stress concentrations; bolted joints; shaft and bearing design; characterization of manufacturing in design. Three lectures; one term.
MANTECH 4MM3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3ET0 , ENGTECH 4FA3 , and registration in Manufacturing Engineering Technology or ENGTECH 3FE3 and registration in Automotive Engineering Technology

MANTECH 4PM3.name: Production Management
MANTECH 4PM3.description: Identification of technical, economic, social, characteristics in the production system; forecasting techniques; inventory models; aggregate planning of production; materials requirements planning; scheduling; sequencing; production control. Three lectures; one term.
MANTECH 4PM3.prerequisites: MANTECH 3LS3 or 4LS3 and registration in Manufacturing Engineering Technology

MANTECH 4RM3.name: Robot Mechanics and Mechatronics
MANTECH 4RM3.description: Basic robot categories; robot components; mobility/constraint analysis; workspace analysis; manipulator kinematics and motion trajectories; non-redundant and redundant sensing/actuation of manipulators; manipulator statics; singularities; manipulator dynamics. Two lectures, one lab; one term.
MANTECH 4RM3.prerequisites: ENGTECH 3CT3 or 4CT3 and registration in Manufacturing Engineering Technology

MATLS 2A04.name: Introduction to Materials Engineering
MATLS 2A04.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above in Materials Engineering

MATLS 2B03.name: Introduction to the Thermodynamics of Materials
MATLS 2B03.description: First and Second Laws. Reversible and irreversible processes. State functions, variables, relations among them. The Third Law. Thermodynamics of reactions. Unary systems. Real gases. Electrochemistry. Two lectures, one lab (two hours every other week), two tutorials; first term.
MATLS 2B03.prerequisites: CHEM 1A03 or CHEM 1E03 ; and registration in Level II or above in Materials Engineering

MATLS 2D03.name: Thermodynamics of Alloys and Phase Diagrams
MATLS 2D03.description: Configurational entropy. Molar Gibbs energies. Activities, chemical potentials. Raoult’s and Henry’s Laws. Regular solutions. Eutectic, peritectic, other types of phase diagrams. Phase rule. Multicomponent solutions. Two lectures, one lab (two hours every other week), two tutorials; second term.
MATLS 2D03.prerequisites: CHEM 1A03 or 1E03 ; and MATLS 2B03 ; and Registration in Level II or above in Materials Engineering

MATLS 2Q03.name: Electronic Properties of Materials
MATLS 2Q03.description: An introduction to the electronic structure and properties of materials: electrons and their behaviour in vacuum and in a crystal lattice, electronic structure of elements, crystal bonding, free electron theory of metals and band structure of solids, electrical and thermal properties of solids. Three lectures; one lab (three hours every other week); second term.
MATLS 2Q03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above in Materials Engineering

MATLS 3B03.name: Manufacturing Engineering of Multifunctional and Biomedical Materials
MATLS 3B03.description: Surface science and technology related to the preparation of fine particles of minerals, metals and ceramics for industrial production. Application of electrochemistry for diverse materials processing, such as electrometallurgy, thin film production and anodizing. Three lectures; second term.
MATLS 3B03.prerequisites: MATLS 2D03 ; and Registration in Level II or above in Materials Engineering

MATLS 3C03.name: Applied Thermodynamics
MATLS 3C03.description: Gaseous systems. Phase rule. Systems with gas phase and pure condensed phases. Ellingham diagram. Predominance diagrams. Systems with gas phase and condensed solutions. Pourbaix diagrams. Thermodynamics of multi-component systems. Two lectures, one lab (three hours every other week), two tutorials; first term.
MATLS 3C03.prerequisites: MATLS 2D03 ; and Registration in Level II or above in Materials Engineering

MATLS 3E04.name: Mass Transfer
MATLS 3E04.prerequisites: MATLS 2D03 and MATH 2ZZ3 ; and Registration in Level II or above in Materials Engineering

MATLS 3F03.name: High-Temperature Materials Production
MATLS 3F03.description: Fundamentals of processing, building on a knowledge of heat and mass transfer. High temperature processing of materials, focusing on heat sources, solid state processing of powders and liquid state processing, high temperature production routes for most important metals. Three lectures, one tutorial; second term.
MATLS 3F03.prerequisites: MATLS 2D03 ; and Registration in Level II or above in Materials Engineering

MATLS 3J03.name: Statistical Methods for Materials Engineers
MATLS 3J03.description: Introduction to probability. Linear and non-linear regression analysis, multi-response estimation, design of experiments including factorial and optimal design, statistical process control. Emphasis on analysis of industrial problems. Three lectures; first term Antirequisite(s): STATS 3Y03.
MATLS 3J03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III and above of Materials Engineering, or Level II and above of Chemical Engineering

MATLS 3M03.name: Mechanical Behaviour of Materials
MATLS 3M03.description: Elastic and Plastic Deformation of Materials. Strengthening Methods.  Fracture Mechanisms. Fatigue and Creep failure. Three lectures, one lab (one hour) every other week; second term.
MATLS 3M03.prerequisites: ENGINEER 2P04 or CIVENG 2P04 and registration in Materials Engineering; or MECHENG 2P04 and Registration in Mechanical Engineering; or permission of the department

MATLS 3MF3.name: Materials Fabrication
MATLS 3MF3.description: Processing methods for a wide range of materials, primarily metals but including ceramics and plastics. The analytical basis for understanding and optimizing materials processes. Three lectures; one term.
MATLS 3MF3.prerequisites: MATLS 3M03 or registration in Level IV or above in Civil Engineering; or permission of the department

MATLS 3Q03.name: Materials for Electronic Applications
MATLS 3Q03.description: Fundamental properties of materials used in electronic applications, operation of devices and fabrication methods of electronic circuits and packaging. Includes description of dielectric, magnetic and optoelectronic properties. Three lectures; one term.
MATLS 3Q03.prerequisites: One of MATLS 2Q03 , 2Q04, ENGPHYS 2QM3 ; or permission of the department

MATLS 3T04.name: Phase Transformations
MATLS 3T04.prerequisites: MATLS 2A04 or 2H04 and 2D03 ; and Registration in Level II or above of Materials Engineering

MATLS 4B03.name: Biomaterials and Tissue Engineering
MATLS 4B03.description: Introduction to biomaterials. Includes material‐tissue interactions, techniques for biomaterials testing, and characterization. Applications of biomaterials and the clinical context of their use will be introduced. Three lectures; one term.
MATLS 4B03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above in Materials Engineering; or Registration in Level IV or above in the Integrated Biomedical Engineering and Health Sciences (IBEHS) program

MATLS 4C03.name: Modern Iron and Steelmaking
MATLS 4C03.description: Theory and practice of iron making. New processes for reduced energy consumption and pollution. Thermodynamics and kinetics of steelmaking. Steel refining. Casting, including new near net shape technologies. Specialty steelmaking. Three lectures; one term.
MATLS 4C03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above in Materials Engineering; or permission of the department Co-requisite(s): MATLS 3F03 Offered on an irregular rotation basis.

MATLS 4D03.name: Corrosion and its Control
MATLS 4D03.description: Thermodynamics, electrochemistry, electrified interface, electrode potential, Faradays Law, Butler-Volmer equation, activation polarization, concentration polarization, mixed potential theory, passivity, rate measurement techniques, galvanic corrosion, stress corrosion cracking, intergranular corrosion, materials selection, cathodic protection, anodic protection, inhibitors/biocides. Three lectures; one term.
MATLS 4D03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III above in Materials Engineering; or permission of the department Offered on an irregular rotation basis.

MATLS 4FF3.name: Synthesis, Applications and Environmental Impact of Nanomaterials
MATLS 4FF3.description: Synthesis routes for nanomaterials, bottom-up and top-down approaches, green chemistry methods, properties of materials: carbon nanotubes, nanoparticles, quantum dots. Environmental and health impact of nanomaterials. Three lectures; one term.
MATLS 4FF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above in Materials Engineering, Engineering Physics or Chemistry; or permission of the department Offered on an irregular rotation basis.

MATLS 4G03.name: Characterization of Nanomaterials
MATLS 4G03.description: Interaction of electrons and photons with matter. Imaging methods with electron microscopy, scanning probe techniques, x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and X-ray absorption analysis with high spatial resolution. Three lectures; one term.
MATLS 4G03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above in Materials Engineering, Chemical Engineering, Engineering Physics or Honours Chemistry; or permission of the department Offered on an irregular rotation basis.

MATLS 4H03.name: X-ray Analysis and Functional Properties of Polycrystalline and Thin Film Materials
MATLS 4H03.description: X-ray analysis of bulk polycrystalline materials and thin films. Deposition and fabrication techniques, surfaces, growth mechanisms, epitaxy, kinetic effects in thin films, structure-property relationships and defects of thin films. Materials for packaging. Two lectures; one tutorial (three hours); one term.
MATLS 4H03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of Materials Engineering; or permission of the department Offered on an irregular rotation basis.

MATLS 4I03.name: Sustainable Manufacturing Processes
MATLS 4I03.description: Sustainable development, ingenuity gap, materials cycles, Eco-Efficiency, Environmental Impact parameters, introduction and computational structure of life cycle analysis, waste treatment and recycling technologies, impact of sustainable practice, stakeholder strategies. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.
MATLS 4I03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of Materials Engineering; or permission of the department

MATLS 4LA2.name: Heat-Treatable Al Alloys
MATLS 4LA2.prerequisites: Registration in the final level of Materials Engineering

MATLS 4LB2.name: Synthesis and Characterization of Biomedical Coatings
MATLS 4LB2.prerequisites: Registration in the final level of Materials Engineering or final level of any Integrated Biomedical Engineering and Health Sciences program

MATLS 4LF2.name: Synthesis, Properties and Application of Thin Films
MATLS 4LF2.prerequisites: Registration in the final Level of Materials Engineering

MATLS 4LS2.name: Physical Metallurgy of Steels
MATLS 4LS2.prerequisites: Registration in the final Level of Materials Engineering

MATLS 4ML3.name: Applications of Machine Learning to Materials and Chemical Engineering
MATLS 4ML3.description: Materials and chemical engineering applications of machine learning with topics in: Bias, neural networks, deep learning and learning theory. Classification, supervised learning, unsupervised learning, generative networks, reinforcement learning. Three lectures; one term.
MATLS 4ML3.prerequisites: MATLS 3J03 Offered on an irregular rotation basis.

MATLS 4MS4.name: Materials Selection in Design
MATLS 4MS4.prerequisites: One of ENGINEER 2P04, MECHENG 2P04 , CIVENG 2P04 and one of CHEMENG 3A04 , MECHENG 3R03 ; or registration in Level IV or above in Civil Engineering; or permission of the department

MATLS 4NN3.name: Computational Modelling in Materials Engineering at the Nano-scale
MATLS 4NN3.description: Microscopic insight to the structure of functional materials used in photovoltaics, light generation, piezoelectronics and origin of their properties from atomic-scale simulations. Three lectures; one term.
MATLS 4NN3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above in Materials Engineering or Engineering Physics; or permission of the department Offered on an irregular rotation basis.

MATLS 4NP3.name: Computational Modelling in Materials Engineering at the Process-Scale
MATLS 4NP3.description: Applications of heat transfer, mass transfer, and fluid flow conservation equations to industrial materials processes in metals and polymers; scaling analysis; finite element analysis. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.
MATLS 4NP3.prerequisites: Two of CHEMENG 2O04 , CHEMENG 3A04 , MATLS 3E04 ; or permission of the department Offered on an irregular rotation basis.

MATLS 4P03.name: Properties of Polymeric Materials
MATLS 4P03.description: Structure of amorphous and crystalline polymeric materials; mechanical, electrical and optical properties, and their modification through processing. Three lectures; one term.
MATLS 4P03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of Materials Engineering; or permission of the department Open to Level III and IV students registered in a program in the Faculty of Science or Engineering with permission of the department. Offered on an irregular rotation basis.

MATLS 4Q03.name: Materials for Sensors in Big Data and AI Systems
MATLS 4Q03.description: Sensors and sensing materials for big data and artificial intelligence systems. Discussion of the theory, design and fabrication of chemical, thermal, electrical, magnetic and optical sensors. Three lectures; one term.
MATLS 4Q03.prerequisites: MATLS 2Q03 or 2Q04 or ENGPHYS 3PN4 Offered on an irregular rotation basis.

MATLS 4T03.name: Properties and Processing of Composites
MATLS 4T03.description: Intrinsic properties of matrix materials and fibres; mechanics and thermodynamics of interfaces; mechanical properties and fabrication of engineering composites. Three lectures; one term.
MATLS 4T03.prerequisites: MATLS 3M03 ; or permission of the department Offered on an irregular rotation basis.

MATLS 4Y03.name: Advanced Biomaterials: Applications and Characterization
MATLS 4Y03.description: Advanced applications of biomaterials including nanobiomaterials, drug delivery, regenerative medicine, microfluidics, biosensing, immunomodulatory materials. Three lectures; one term.
MATLS 4Y03.prerequisites: MATLS 4B03 and registration in Level III or above in Materials Engineering; or Registration in Level IV or above in the Integrated Biomedical Engineering and Health Sciences (IBEHS) program Offered on an irregular rotation basis.

MATH 1A03.name: Calculus For Science I
MATH 1A03.description: For students in science: geared towards applications, with attention to underlying concepts. Functions: limits, continuity, derivatives, optimization, curve sketching. Antiderivative, definite integral, techniques of integration. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 1A03.prerequisites: One of Grade 12 Calculus and Vectors U, MATH 1F03 , MATH 1MM3

MATH 1AA3.name: Calculus For Science II
MATH 1AA3.description: For students in science: additional techniques of integration, applications of definite integrals, differential equations, polar coordinates, parametrized curves. Sequences, infinite series, power series. Partial derivatives, double integrals. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 1AA3.prerequisites: One of MATH 1A03 , 1LS3 , 1X03 , 1ZA3 ; or a grade of at least B- in MATH 1MM3 (or 1M03)

MATH 1B03.name: Linear Algebra I
MATH 1B03.description: Vector spaces given by solutions to linear systems. Linear independence, dimension. Determinants. Eigenvalues, eigenvectors and diagonalisation. Complex numbers. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 1B03.prerequisites: Grade 12 Calculus and Vectors U or MATH 1F03

MATH 1C03.name: Introduction to Mathematical Reasoning
MATH 1C03.description: Inquiry into the ideas and methods of advanced mathematics. Material will include topics selected from algebra, calculus, discrete math, geometry and number theory. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 1C03.prerequisites: Grade 12 Calculus and Vectors U or MATH 1F03

MATH 1F03.name: Introduction to Calculus and Analytic Geometry
MATH 1F03.description: A first course in the techniques of the differential calculus including exponential, logarithmic and trigonometric functions. An introduction to vector geometry. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 1F03.prerequisites: Grade 12 Advanced Functions U or MATH 1K03

MATH 1K03.name: Advanced Functions
MATH 1K03.description: Properties of polynomial, rational, exponential and logarithmic functions. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 1K03.prerequisites: MCR3U (or equivalent) Normally not open to students who have completed Grade 12 Calculus and Vectors U, Grade 12 Advanced Functions U; or credit or registration in MATH 1A03 , 1F03 , 1LS3 , 1M03, 1MM3 , 1ZA3 .

MATH 1LS3.name: Calculus for the Life Sciences I
MATH 1LS3.description: Topics from differential and integral calculus, differential equations, discrete-time dynamical systems, chosen for their relevance to the life sciences. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 1LS3.prerequisites: One of Grade 12 Calculus and Vectors U, MATH 1F03 , MATH 1MM3

MATH 1LT3.name: Calculus for the Life Sciences II
MATH 1LT3.description: Analysis of autonomous differential equations; differential calculus of functions of several variables; introduction to probability as application of calculus and statistics. All topics chosen for their relevance to the life sciences. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 1LT3.prerequisites: One of MATH 1A03 , 1LS3 ; or a grade of at least B- in MATH 1MM3 (or 1M03)

MATH 1MM3.name: Applied Calculus
MATH 1MM3.description: Integral calculus of polynomial, rational, exponential and logarithmic functions. Optimization problems. Applications in Sciences, Social Sciences and Business. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 1MM3.prerequisites: One of Grade 12 Calculus and Vectors U, MATH 1F03 Students considering upper year mathematics courses should take MATH 1A03 or MATH 1LS3 .

MATH 1MP3.name: Introduction to Mathematical Scientific Computation
MATH 1MP3.description: Introduction to mathematical problem-solving using computational methods. Introduction to a programming language; good scientific programming practices. Three lectures, one lab; one term.
MATH 1MP3.prerequisites: Credit or registration in one of MATH 1A03 , 1LS3 , 1X03 (or ISCI 1A24 A/B ); and registration in a program in the Faculty of Science

MATH 1X03.name: Calculus for Math and Stats I
MATH 1X03.description: Algebraic, geometric and numeric approaches to calculus, development of mathematical thinking, intuition and theoretical foundations. Functions: limits, continuity, derivatives, applications. Antiderivative, definite integral, integration techniques. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 1X03.prerequisites: Registration in Level I Mathematics and Statistics

MATH 1XA3.name: Proofs in Calculus
MATH 1XA3.description: Looks behind the scenes of calculus, by discussing notions and ideas needed to prove the theorems encountered in MATH 1X03 and MATH 1XX3 . Three lectures; one term.
MATH 1XA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level I Mathematics and Statistics Co-requisite(s): MATH 1X03 and 1XX3

MATH 1XX3.name: Calculus for Math and Stats II
MATH 1XX3.description: For students in mathematics and statistics. Additional techniques of integration, applications of definite integrals, differential equations, polar coordinates, parametrized curves. Sequences, infinite series, power series. Partial derivatives, double integrals. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 1XX3.prerequisites: MATH 1X03 and registration in Level I Mathematics and Statistics

MATH 1ZA3.name: Engineering Mathematics I
MATH 1ZA3.description: Functions: limits, continuity, derivatives, optimization, curve sketching. Antiderivative, definite integral, techniques of integration, with applications. Three lectures, one tutorial, one lab; one term.
MATH 1ZA3.prerequisites: Registration in a program in Engineering

MATH 1ZB3.name: Engineering Mathematics II-A
MATH 1ZB3.description: Techniques of integration, applications of definite integrals, differential equations, polar coordinates, parametrized curves. Sequences, infinite series, power series. Partial derivatives. Three lectures, one tutorial, one lab; one term.

MATH 1ZC3.name: Engineering Mathematics II-B
MATH 1ZC3.description: Vector spaces given by solutions to linear systems. Linear independence, dimension. Determinants. Eigenvalues, eigenvectors and diagonalisation. Complex numbers. Three lectures, one tutorial, one lab; one term.
MATH 1ZC3.prerequisites: One of Grade 12 Calculus and Vectors U, MATH 1F03 , or credit or registration in MATH 1ZA3

MATH 2C03.name: Introduction to Differential Equations
MATH 2C03.description: First order ordinary differential equations and higher order linear ordinary differential equations including Laplace transforms and series solutions. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 2C03.prerequisites: One of MATH 1AA3 , 1LT3 , 1NN3, 1XX3 , 1ZB3 , ARTSSCI 1D06 A/B , ISCI 1A24 A/B ; and one of MATH 1B03 , 1ZC3

MATH 2FM3.name: Introduction To Mathematical Finance
MATH 2FM3.description: Nominal and effective rates of interest and discount, forces of interest and discount, compound interest, annuities certain; amortization, sinking funds, bonds, security evaluation, determination of yields. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 2FM3.prerequisites: One of MATH 1A03 , 1LS3 , 1M03, 1N03, 1X03 , 1Z04, 1ZA3 , ARTSSCI 1D06 A/B , ISCI 1A24 A/B ; or a grade of at least B- in MATH 1MM3

MATH 2LA3.name: Applications of Linear Algebra
MATH 2LA3.description: This course focuses on applications of linear algebra. Topics include linear programming, applications of matrix decomposition theorems, examples from data science, singular value decomposition and applications to compression. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 2LA3.prerequisites: One of MATH 1AA3, 1LT3, 1NN3, 1XX3, 1ZB3, ARTSSCI 1D06 A/B, ISCI 1A24 A/B; and one of MATH 1B03, 1ZC3, 1ZZ5

MATH 2R03.name: Theory of Linear Algebra
MATH 2R03.description: Abstract vector spaces. Linear transformations. Inner product spaces. Spectral theorems. Orthogonal bases, other topics. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 2R03.prerequisites: One of MATH 1AA3 , 1LT3 , 1NN3, 1XX3 , 1ZB3 , ARTSSCI 1D06 A/B , ISCI 1A24 A/B ; and one of MATH 1B03 , 1ZC3 , 1ZZ5

MATH 2UU3.name: Numbers for Life
MATH 2UU3.description: Principles of quantitative reasoning, problem-solving and critical thinking, discussed in contexts related to, and relevant for, our daily lives, our society and the environment we live in. Content delivered through lecture and class discussion in an engaging and non-threatening way. Course develops core competencies often referred to as numeracy, or numeric literacy. Three lectures; one term.

MATH 2X03.name: Advanced Calculus I
MATH 2X03.description: Multiple integration, line and surface integrals and applications. The classical integration theorems of Green, Gauss and Stokes. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 2X03.prerequisites: One of MATH 1AA3 , 1LT3 , 1XX3 , 1ZB3 , 1ZZ5, ARTSSCI 1D06 A/B , ISCI 1A24 A/B ; and credit or registration in one of MATH 1B03 , 1ZC3 Students who have completed MATH 1LS3 and 1LT3 should contact the Associate Chair, in Mathematics and Statistics, to discuss the recommended independent learning needed for success in MATH 2X03.

MATH 2XX3.name: Advanced Calculus II
MATH 2XX3.description: Theory of functions of several variables: limits, continuity, differentiability, Inverse Function Theorem, Taylor’s Theorem. Extreme values, optimization, introduction to Fourier series. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 2XX3.prerequisites: MATH 2X03 ; or credit or registration in ISCI 2A18 A/B

MATH 2Z03.name: Engineering Mathematics III
MATH 2Z03.description: Ordinary differential equations, Laplace transforms, introduction to partial differential equations, applications. Three lectures, one tutorial, one lab (two hours) every other week; one term.

MATH 2ZZ3.name: Engineering Mathematics IV
MATH 2ZZ3.description: Fourier series, vector calculus, line and surface integrals, integral theorems, applications. Three lectures, one tutorial, one lab (two hours) every other week; one term.

MATH 3A03.name: Real Analysis I
MATH 3A03.description: Metric spaces, continuity, completeness, compactness, uniform convergence. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 3A03.prerequisites: MATH 1XA3 with a grade of at least B+ or MATH 3IA3 ; or permission of the instructor

MATH 3B03.name: Geometry
MATH 3B03.description: Selected topics from: affine and projective geometry, Euclidean, spherical and hyperbolic geometry, differential geometry of curves and surfaces. Three lectures; one term.
MATH 3B03.prerequisites: One of MATH 2X03, ISCI 2A18 A/B; and one of MATH 2R03 or a grade of at least B in MATH 2LA3

MATH 3C03.name: Mathematical Physics I
MATH 3C03.description: Eigenvalue problems, Fourier transforms, special functions, spherical harmonics, partial differential equations, boundary value problems. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 3C03.prerequisites: One of MATH 2A03, 2MM3, 2Q04, 2X03 , 2Z03 , ISCI 2A18 A/B ; and one of MATH 2C03 , 2M03, 2P04, 2ZZ3 . One of PHYSICS 2B06, 2D03, 2E03 is recommended.

MATH 3D03.name: Mathematical Physics II
MATH 3D03.description: Functions of a complex variable, contour integrals, probability and statistics. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.

MATH 3F03.name: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH 3F03.description: Systems of ordinary differential equations, autonomous systems in the plane, phase portraits, linear systems, stability, Lyapunov’s method, Poincare-Bendixson theorem, applications. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 3F03.prerequisites: MATH 1C03, 2C03; and MATH 2X03 (or ISCI 2A18 A/B); and either credit or registration in MATH 2R03 or a grade of at least B in MATH 2LA3

MATH 3FF3.name: Partial Differential Equations
MATH 3FF3.description: First order equations, well-posedness, characteristics, wave equation, heat equation, Laplace equation, boundary conditions, Fourier series, applications. Three lectures; one term.
MATH 3FF3.prerequisites: MATH 2C03; and one of MATH 2R03 or a grade of at least B in MATH 2LA3; and MATH 2XX3

MATH 3FM3.name: Mathematics of Finance
MATH 3FM3.description: Introduction to finance in discrete time: Options and forwards, efficient markets and the no arbitrage condition, binomial asset pricing model, portfolio strategies, stochastic processes, conditional expectation, martingales, optimal portfolio selection, exotic options. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 3FM3.prerequisites: One of ISCI 2A18 A/B, MATH 2X03; and STATS 2D03

MATH 3GR3.name: Abstract Algebra
MATH 3GR3.description: An introduction to groups and rings, with an emphasis on concrete examples. Topics include: groups, subgroups, normal subgroups, quotient groups, group homomorphisms, First Isomorphism Theorem for groups, symmetric and alternating groups, rings, subrings, ideals, quotient rings, ring homomorphisms, and the First Isomorphism Theorem for rings. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 3GR3.prerequisites: MATH 1C03, and one of MATH 2R03 or a grade of at least B in MATH 2LA3

MATH 3I03.name: Partial Differential Equations for Engineering
MATH 3I03.description: Topics in partial differential equations of interest to mechanical, material and ceramic engineering, including the wave equation, the heat diffusion equation and Laplace equation, in various co-ordinate systems. Three lectures, one tutorial; first term.
MATH 3I03.prerequisites: One of MATH 2M03, 2P04, 2ZZ3 or registration in Level III or IV of a program in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering

MATH 3IA3.name: Introduction to Analysis
MATH 3IA3.description: Sequences and series of numbers. Proofs of theorems about continuity; differentiability, Riemann integration. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 3IA3.prerequisites: MATH 1C03, 2X03 (or ISCI 2A18), and either MATH 2LA3 or 2R03; or registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in Mathematics and Statistics; or permission of the instructor

MATH 3MB3.name: Introduction to Modelling
MATH 3MB3.description: Introduction to computational modelling using software such as R or MATLAB. Analytical modelling using algebra and calculus. The development and analysis of models will be illustrated with examples selected from biology, medicine, chemistry, physics, economics, or other areas of natural or social sciences. This course includes a scientific communication component. Three lectures, one lab; one term.
MATH 3MB3.prerequisites: One of MATH 1AA3, 1LT3, 1XX3, ARTSSCI 1D06 A/B, ISCI 1A24 A/B; and one of MATH 1B03, 1ZC3, 1ZZ5

MATH 3NA3.name: Numerical Linear Algebra
MATH 3NA3.description: Conditioning and numerical stability, rounding and truncation errors, convergence rates, linear and nonlinear systems of equations, eigenvalue problems, least squares, QR and singular-value decomposition, optimization. Three lectures; one term.
MATH 3NA3.prerequisites: MATH 2LA3 or MATH 2R03; and one of MATH 1MP3, COMPSCI 1MD3, DATASCI 2G03, PHYSICS 2G03

MATH 3T03.name: Inquiry in Topology
MATH 3T03.description: Size and shape in topology and analysis, compactness, connectedness, limit sets, theory of dimension, fractals and self-similarity. Three lectures; one term.

MATH 3X03.name: Complex Analysis I
MATH 3X03.description: Analytic functions, Cauchy’s theorem, Cauchy’s integral formula, residues, zeroes of analytic functions; Laurent series, the maximum principle. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.

MATH 3Z03.name: Inquiry: History of Mathematics
MATH 3Z03.description: An introduction to the history of mathematics, including interaction with other phases of culture, with special emphasis on the past three centuries. This course includes a scientific communication component. Three lectures; one term.
MATH 3Z03.prerequisites: Completion of at least 6 units of Level II Mathematics or Statistics courses, excluding MATH 2FM3 , (or MATH 2K03), 2L03, 2UU3 .

MATH 4A03.name: Real Analysis II
MATH 4A03.description: Selected topics from: spaces of continuous functions, functions of several variables, inverse and implicit function theorems. Lebesgue integration. Fourier series. Three lectures; one term.

MATH 4FM3.name: Financial Markets and Derivatives
MATH 4FM3.description: Modelling of options, futures, interest rate securities and other financial derivatives in continuous time using Brownian motion and stochastic calculus. Topics include risk-neutral pricing, the Black-Scholes framework, dynamic hedging, volatility and risk. This course includes a scientific communication component. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MATH 4FM3.prerequisites: MATH 3FM3 Prerequisite(s) (Effective 2024-2025): MATH 3FM3 and registration in Level IV or V of an Honours Actuarial and Financial Mathematics program

MATH 4MB3.name: Mathematical Biology
MATH 4MB3.description: Population dynamics: models of discrete and continuous growth; competition and predation; epidemic models. Other topics selected by instructor. Three lectures; one term.

MATH 4W03.name: Reading in Mathematics
MATH 4W03.description: Directed reading in areas of mathematics of interest to the student and the instructor. This course includes a scientific communication component.
MATH 4W03.prerequisites: GPA of at least a 7.0 and permission of the Chair of the Department MATH 4W03 may be repeated, if on a different topic.

MATH 4WW3.name: Reading in Mathematics II
MATH 4WW3.description: Directed reading in areas of mathematics of interest to the student and the instructor. This course includes a scientific communication component.
MATH 4WW3.prerequisites: GPA of at least 7.0 and permission of the Chair of the Department MATH 4WW3 may be repeated, if on a different topic.

MATH 5GT3.name: Graduate Level Topics in Mathematics
MATH 5GT3.description: Undergraduate students may seek permission to enrol in selected graduate level offerings. Refer to the Graduate Calendar for course information.
MATH 5GT3.prerequisites: Permission of the Department of Mathematics and Statistics Undergraduate students will be required to meet all academic obligations of the graduate-level course offering. Not all graduate courses are offered each year. MATH 5GT3 may be repeated, if on a different graduate level topic.

MELD 1M00.name: Mentorship Lab 1
MELD 1M00.prerequisites: Registration in the McMaster English Language Development Diploma (MELD) program

MELD 1MM0.name: Mentorship Lab 2
MELD 1MM0.prerequisites: Registration in the McMaster English Language Development Diploma (MELD) program

MELD 1Q03.name: Critical and Analytic Reading
MELD 1Q03.description: In this course students develop their critical reading and reasoning skills by engaging, summarizing, analyzing, and reflecting on texts representing a variety of academic disciplines. The course emphasizes vocabulary building strategies (vocabulary in context) to communicate information clearly in different academic writing tasks. Two hours lecture; two hours tutorial; two hours lab; one term.
MELD 1Q03.prerequisites: Registration in the McMaster English Language Development Diploma (MELD) program

MELD 1QQ3.name: Grammar, Structure and University Writing
MELD 1QQ3.description: This course focuses on using appropriate language (grammar, vocabulary, style), structure, and source attribution for writing in common post-secondary genres, while developing the critical thinking skills necessary for academic success. Attention will also be paid to less formal modes of online communication, such as email writing. Two hours lecture; two hours tutorial; two hours lab; one term.
MELD 1QQ3.prerequisites: Registration in the McMaster English Language Development Diploma (MELD) program

MELD 1R03.name: Aural Communication and Academic Culture
MELD 1R03.description: This is an intensive course that focuses on the listening and note-taking strategies needed for aural and oral success in university, that also introduces students to problem-based learning. Aural skills are enhanced through exposure to a variety of academic lectures, discussions, debates and podcasts. Two hours lecture; two hours tutorial; two hours lab; one term.
MELD 1R03.prerequisites: Registration in the McMaster English Language Development Diploma (MELD) program

MELD 1RR3.name: Oral Communication for Academic and Social Interactions
MELD 1RR3.description: In this course students are introduced to the fundamentals of oral communication, including listening, for communicating successfully in university contexts, through inquiry-based learning activities and discussions. Pronunciation sessions will reinforce speech production and overall fluency. Two hours lecture; two hours tutorial; two hours lab; one term.
MELD 1RR3.prerequisites: Registration in the McMaster English Language Development Diploma (MELD) program

MELD 1S03.name: Critical Reading, Research and Academic Vocabulary
MELD 1S03.description: This course further develops students’ analytical reading and critical thinking skills. Students will engage, analyze, synthesize, evaluate, and reflect on more challenging scholarly texts from a range of disciplines. The course strengthens students’ contextual vocabulary knowledge to enable effective and accurate written academic communication. Two hours lecture; two hours tutorial; two hours lab; one term.
MELD 1S03.prerequisites: Registration in the McMaster English Language Development Diploma (MELD) program

MELD 1SS3.name: Academic Writing, Reporting and Research
MELD 1SS3.description: This course focuses on the development of research, reading, and composition skills to craft an academic report. Language (grammar, vocabulary, style), structure, source attribution, and critical thinking skills are further developed. Two hours lecture; two hours tutorial; two hours lab; one term.
MELD 1SS3.prerequisites: Registration in the McMaster English Language Development Diploma (MELD) program

MELD 1T03.name: Cross-Cultural Perspectives on Language and Language Learning
MELD 1T03.description: In this course students will explore the relationships between language, culture and society and how those relationships affect English language learning and communication in English. Students will further develop their critical listening and note-taking skills through lectures and inquiry-based learning scenarios. Two hours lecture; two hours tutorial; two hours lab; one term.
MELD 1T03.prerequisites: Registration in the McMaster English Language Development Diploma (MELD) program

MELD 1TT3.name: Oral Communication for Academic Discourse
MELD 1TT3.description: In this course students will learn to apply effective oral communication strategies to a variety of higher education contexts, including case-study presentations and formal discussions. Cultural awareness, aural skills, and advanced features of pronunciation will also be reinforced. One lecture (two hours), one tutorial (two hours), one lab (two hours); one term.
MELD 1TT3.prerequisites: Registration in the McMaster English Language Development Diploma (MELD) program

MECHENG 2B03.name: Mechanical Engineering Measurements
MECHENG 2B03.description: Static and dynamic characteristics of instruments, statistical analysis of measurement errors, variable conversion elements and signal amplification. Metrology, measurement of strain and force, pressure, flow, temperature and power. Two lectures, one lab (three hours every other week); second term.
MECHENG 2B03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of any Mechanical Engineering program

MECHENG 2BA3.name: Mechanical Engineering Measurements
MECHENG 2BA3.description: Static and dynamic characteristics of instruments, statistical analysis of measurement errors, variable conversion elements and signal amplification. Metrology, measurement of strain and force, pressure, flow, temperature and power. Two lectures, one lab (three hours every other week); second term.
MECHENG 2BA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of any Mechatronics Engineering program

MECHENG 2C04.name: Mechanical Engineering Design Project I
MECHENG 2C04.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of any Mechanical Engineering program

MECHENG 2D03.name: Mechanical Engineering Design Elements
MECHENG 2D03.description: Design synthesis, fundamental principles of standard design elements, mechanical and fluid power elements, component specification and optimization. Three lectures, one tutorial; first term.
MECHENG 2D03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of any Mechanical Engineering program

MECHENG 2DA3.name: Mechanical Engineering Design Elements
MECHENG 2DA3.description: Design synthesis, fundamental principles of standard design elements, mechanical and fluid power elements, component specification and optimization. Three lectures, one tutorial; second term.
MECHENG 2DA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III of any Mechatronics Engineering program

MECHENG 2P04.name: Statics and Mechanics of Materials
MECHENG 2P04.prerequisites: PHYSICS 1D03 and registration in Level II of any Mechanical Engineering program

MECHENG 2Q04.name: Engineering Mechanics: Kinetics and Dynamics
MECHENG 2Q04.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of any Mechanical Engineering program

MECHENG 2QA4.name: Engineering Mechanics: Kinetics and Dynamics
MECHENG 2QA4.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of any Mechatronics Engineering program

MECHENG 2W04.name: Thermodynamics
MECHENG 2W04.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of any Mechanical Engineering program

MECHENG 3A03.name: Engineering Mechanics
MECHENG 3A03.description: Singularity functions, generalized Hooke’s law; shear stress, shear flow in beams; shear centre. Biaxial and unsymmetrical bending, analysis of indeterminate beams and frames using energy methods, impact loads. Buckling of compression members. Introduction to yield criteria. Three lectures, one tutorial; second term.
MECHENG 3A03.prerequisites: ENGINEER 2P04 or MECHENG 2P04 and registration in any Mechanical Engineering program

MECHENG 3C03.name: Manufacturing Engineering
MECHENG 3C03.description: A general introduction, encompassing the wide field of activities from iron and steel making through casting, rolling, forging, to cold forming, metal cutting, welding, bonding, electrical machining, surface treatment, mechanical handling, assembly, cleaning, packaging. Three lectures; first term.
MECHENG 3C03.prerequisites: Registration in any Mechanical Engineering, Chemical Engineering or Materials Science and Engineering program, or, registration in Level III or IV of the Manufacturing Engineering Technology Co-op (B.Tech.) program Cross-list(s): MANTECH 3MF3 This course is administered by the Department of Mechanical Engineering .

MECHENG 3F04.name: Modelling and Numerical Solutions
MECHENG 3F04.prerequisites: Registration in any Mechanical Engineering program

MECHENG 3O04.name: Fluid Mechanics
MECHENG 3O04.prerequisites: Both MATH 2M03 and 2MM3 (or 2M06), or both MATH 2Z03 and MATH 2ZZ3 , or both MECHENG 2P04 and 2Q04 ; and registration in any Mechanical Engineering program

MECHENG 3R03.name: Heat Transfer
MECHENG 3R03.description: Application of the laws of conduction, convection and radiation to problems in heat transfer. Steady and transient conduction in solids. Laminar and turbulent convection. Radiation heat transfer processes. Boiling and condensation heat transfer. Three lectures, one tutorial; second term.
MECHENG 3R03.prerequisites: MATH 2M03 (or 2M06), or MATH 2Z03 ; and MECHENG 2W04 or ENGPHYS 2NE3

MECHENG 4AA3.name: Aerodynamics
MECHENG 4AA3.description: Forces and moments associated with flow around airfoils and bodies. Finite wings. Potential flow and introduction to panel methods. Thin airfoil theory and symmetric and cambered airfoils. Introduction to aircraft stability and aeroelasticity. Three lectures; second term.
MECHENG 4AA3.prerequisites: MECHENG 3O04 , CHEMENG 2O04 , 3O04, or ENGPHYS 3O04 ; and MECHENG 4S03

MECHENG 4B03.name: Topics in Product Development
