MECHENG 4B03.description: Case studies using modern product development methods, value engineering, product specification, rapid product development, lean design and continuous improvement. Product liability and robust design. Three lectures, one tutorial; first term.
MECHENG 4B03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of any Mechanical Engineering or Mechatronics Engineering program

MECHENG 4BB3.name: Biomechanics
MECHENG 4BB3.description: Application of mechanical engineering principles to biomechanics problems including cellular biomechanics, hemodynamics, circulatory system, respiratory system, muscles and movement and skeletal biomechanics. Three lectures, one tutorial; first term.
MECHENG 4BB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of any Engineering program Cross-list(s): IBEHS 4B03

MECHENG 4BF3.name: Biofluid Mechanics
MECHENG 4BF3.description: The objective is to learn blood flow mechanics through the circulatory system and its subsystems. The course examines mechanics of circulation, mechanobiology and biomechanics of different components of circulatory system, in-vivo and in-vitro techniques and their medical applications. Three lectures, one tutorial; second term.
MECHENG 4BF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of any Engineering program or Integrated Biomedical Engineering and Health Sciences (IBEHS) program

MECHENG 4C03.name: Production Systems Engineering
MECHENG 4C03.description: Analytical tools to evaluate and design production systems to meet specified performance metrics. Quantitative and qualitative evaluation of production cells, flexible manufacturing systems and production lines. Three lectures; second term.
MECHENG 4C03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of any Mechanical Engineering program or permission of the Department

MECHENG 4CC3.name: Experimental and Computational Biomechanics
MECHENG 4CC3.description: Introduction to experimental and computational biomechanics including biomechanical testing concepts and application of finite element methods in simulations of biomechanical structures/systems. Three lectures; second term.
MECHENG 4CC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of any Engineering program.

MECHENG 4D03.name: Manufacturing Processes (Metal Removal)
MECHENG 4D03.description: Fundamentals of metal removing processes, including mechanics and tribological aspects of material removal. Application of theory to the practice of machining processes such as turning, milling, drilling and grinding. Three lectures; second term.
MECHENG 4D03.prerequisites: MECHENG 3C03 and registration in any Level IV or above of any Mechanical Engineering program

MECHENG 4DD3.name: Introduction to Surface Engineering in Manufacturing
MECHENG 4DD3.description: Fundamentals of surface engineering in manufacturing including surface properties; surface characterization: different techniques and instruments; surface engineering techniques (conversion and deposition methods); thin coatings used in manufacturing: deposition methods, properties, selection, evaluation and applications. Three lectures, first term.
MECHENG 4DD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of any Mechanical Engineering program or permission of the Department

MECHENG 4E03.name: Microelectromechanical Systems (MEMS)
MECHENG 4E03.description: Introduction, microfabrication and micromachining fundamentals, scaling effects, mechanics and transduction at microscale, actuation and sensing methods - Electrostatic, piezoelectric, thermal, electromagnetic, resonant, tunneling and microfluidic techniques. Capacitative sensors, resonators, lab on chip devices, microfluidic devices, micromirrors, assembly techniques for MEMS, microsystem packaging. Three lectures; second term.
MECHENG 4E03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of any Mechanical Engineering, Engineering Physics or Integrated Biomedical Engineering and Health Sciences (IBEHS) program or permission of the Department

MECHENG 4ES3.name: Energy Storage
MECHENG 4ES3.description: An overview of energy storage from the nanosecond scale to the seasonal scale. Concepts such as energy density, specific energy, thermodynamic losses, and cycle efficiency. Topics will include mechanical, thermal, electrochemical, and chemical energy storage. Three lectures; second term.
MECHENG 4ES3.prerequisites: one of MECHENG 2W04 , ENGPHYS 2CD4 , CHEMENG 3D04 or MATLS 2B03 ; and one of MECHENG 3O04 , ENGPHYS 3O04 , CIVENG 2O04 or CHEMENG 2O04

MECHENG 4FM3.name: Advanced Instrumentation and Sensing for Thermo-Fluids
MECHENG 4FM3.description: The theory and practice of experimental analysis of fluid mechanics problems. Modern and traditional experimental facilities and techniques for thermo-fluids sensing and visualization, planning of laboratory experiments, data acquisition, analysis of experimental results and uncertainty estimation Three lectures, one lab (one hour); second term.

MECHENG 4H03.name: Mechatronics
MECHENG 4H03.description: Integration of mechanical engineering with electronics and computer control. Sensors, actuators (including pneumatic and hydraulic), modelling using building block and state space methods, model-based control, programming of PLCs with practical demonstrations. Three lectures; second term.
MECHENG 4H03.prerequisites: IBEHS 4A03 , MECHENG 4R03 , MECHTRON 3DX4 , ELECENG 3CL4 or SFWRENG 3DX4 and registration in any Mechanical Engineering, Mechatronics Engineering or Electrical Engineering program

MECHENG 4I03.name: Noise Analysis and Control
MECHENG 4I03.description: Acoustic quantities; noise measurements and analysis; noise standards; sound generation, propagation, absorption, transmission; acoustic materials; noise control techniques; case studies. Three lectures; first term.
MECHENG 4I03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of any Mechanical Engineering program or permission of the Department

MECHENG 4J03.name: Introduction to Computational Fluid Mechanics and Heat Transfer
MECHENG 4J03.description: Computational Methods for Fluid Mechanics and Heat Transfer covering: concepts of modelling and numerical analysis, governing equations of thermo-fluid problems, finite difference discretization methods. Use of commercial computational software for solving thermo-fluid problems. Three lectures, one tutorial (one and one-half hours); second term.
MECHENG 4J03.prerequisites: MECHENG 3O04 or 4S03 , and MECHENG 3F04 or ENGPHYS 2CE4, or permission of the Department

MECHENG 4K03.name: Robotics
MECHENG 4K03.description: Fundamental theory and practical applications of robotic manipulators and mobile robots. Equations of motion, robot dynamics and statics, motion planning, introduction to machine vision, basics of robot programming. Three lectures; first term.
MECHENG 4K03.prerequisites: ENGINEER 2Q04 or MECHENG 2Q04 or 2QA4 or ENGPHYS 2CD4 and registration in Level IV or above of any Mechanical Engineering or Mechatronics Engineering or Engineering Physics program

MECHENG 4N03.name: Nanobio Engineering
MECHENG 4N03.description: Introduction to nanotechnology, nanomaterials, nanotechnology in living systems, nanotechnology in biomedical devices, nanobiomaterials, characterization of biomaterials, nano-coatings, nano-biofunctional interfaces, biosensing and diagnostics, organs-on-chips. Three lectures; first term.
MECHENG 4N03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of Engineering or Integrated Biomedical Engineering and Health Sciences (IBEHS) program or permission of Department

MECHENG 4O04.name: Sustainable Energy Systems
MECHENG 4O04.prerequisites: MECHENG 2W04 , 3O04 ; or ENGPHYS 2NE3 , 3O04 ; or permission of the Department

MECHENG 4Q03.name: Mechanical Vibrations
MECHENG 4Q03.description: Transient and steady state vibration of single- and multi-degree of freedom systems. Free and forced vibrations of single and multiple degree-of-freedom mechanical systems, transient response, damping and vibration isolation. Three lectures; first term.
MECHENG 4Q03.prerequisites: ENGINEER 2Q04 or MECHENG 2Q04 or 2QA4 or ENGPHYS 2CD4 and registration in any Mechanical Engineering or Mechatronics or Engineering Physics program

MECHENG 4R03.name: Control Systems
MECHENG 4R03.description: Fundamentals of linear, continuous control systems. Control system performance in both time and frequency domains. Design and analysis of controllers. Three lectures; second term.
MECHENG 4R03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III Mechanical Engineering; or Level IV Mechanical Engineering and Management or Mechanical Engineering and Society; or Level IV or above in any Engineering Physics program

MECHENG 4S03.name: Incompressible Flow
MECHENG 4S03.description: Introduction to internal and external laminar and turbulent incompressible flows. Topics include turbulent boundary layers, aerodynamics and convective heat transfer. Three lectures; first term.

MECHENG 4SS3.name: Smart Systems
MECHENG 4SS3.description: This course will teach the fundamentals of smart systems which incorporate elements of sensing, actuation, and control in order to interact with the environment and make decisions in a predictive and intelligent manner. Three lectures; first term.

MECHENG 4T03.name: Finite Element Applications
MECHENG 4T03.description: Theory of the finite element method, element derivation, solution procedures. Applications to static and dynamic mechanical systems using a finite element package. Three lectures, one tutorial; first term.
MECHENG 4T03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of any Mechanical Engineering program

MECHENG 4U03.name: Compressible Flow and Turbomachinery
MECHENG 4U03.description: Compressible flows: Fanno and Rayleigh flows, normal and oblique shocks. Turbomachines: axial flow gas and wind turbines, axial flow compressors and fans. Three lectures; first term.

MECHENG 4V03.name: Thermo-Fluids Systems Design and Analysis
MECHENG 4V03.description: Design, operation and application characteristics of equipment commonly used in thermal systems. Modelling performance characteristics of piping systems, pumps, compressors, fans, heat exchangers, boilers and cooling towers. System simulation and optimization. Selection criteria of thermal equipment. Design optimization and system performance evaluation. Three lectures, one tutorial; first term.
MECHENG 4V03.prerequisites: MECHENG 2W04 , or ENGPHYS 2NE3 ; MECHENG 3O04 and MECHENG 3R03

MECHENG 4W03.name: Air Conditioning and Refrigeration Systems
MECHENG 4W03.description: Re-examination of laws of thermodynamics, multicomponent vapour systems, psychrometry, air conditioning, mechanical vapour compression refrigeration, absorption refrigeration, heating and cooling load calculations, air quality and human thermal comfort. Three lectures; first term.
MECHENG 4W03.prerequisites: MECHENG 2W04 or ENGPHYS 2NE3 , and registration in Level IV or above of any Mechanical Engineering program or Engineering Physics program

MECHENG 4Y03.name: Internal Combustion Engines
MECHENG 4Y03.description: This course focuses on internal combustion engines (ICE), including operations, thermodynamics, combustion, and characteristics of gasoline and diesel engines, as well as hybrid powertrains. Three lectures, first term.
MECHENG 4Y03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of any Mechanical Engineering program or Engineering Physics program

MECHENG 4Z03.name: CAD/CAM/CAE
MECHENG 4Z03.description: Solid modelling theory, part creation, assemblies and rigid bodies, mechanism simulation, B-Splines, data exchange, CNC machining and inspection. Major project using computer laboratory facilities. Three lectures, one lab (one hour); second term.
MECHENG 4Z03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of any Mechanical Engineering or Mechatronics Engineering program

MECHTRON 2MD3.name: Data Structures and Algorithms for Mechatronics
MECHTRON 2MD3.description: Advanced programming with emphasis on embedded systems. Program specifications: Pre- and post-conditions, loop and datatype invariants; use of tools to demonstrate correctness. Selecting data structures for implementation of mathematical abstractions. Finite state machines, automata and languages; lexing and parsing. Algorithm analysis (time and space). Modelling of graphs, relations, corresponding algorithms. Three lectures, one tutorial; second term.
MECHTRON 2MD3.prerequisites: MECHTRON 2MP3 or SFWRENG 2MP3; and registration in a Mechatronics Engineering program

MECHTRON 2MP3.name: Programming for Mechatronics
MECHTRON 2MP3.description: This course focuses on learning programming using the high-level systems programming language C, and on understanding how its features are implemented using the CPU and the memory hierarchy. Mathematical abstractions are implemented using fundamental data structures such as arrays, stacks, queues, etc., with static and dynamic memory allocation. Three lectures, one tutorial; first term.
MECHTRON 2MP3.prerequisites: ENGINEER 1D04 or 1P13 or IBEHS 1P10, and registration in a Mechatronics Engineering program

MECHTRON 2TA4.name: Embedded Systems Design I
MECHTRON 2TA4.prerequisites: ENGPHYS 2E04 or SFWRENG 2DA4 ; MECHTRON 2MP3 or SFWRENG 2MP3 or 2S03; SFWRENG 2GA3 or registration in Level II or above of a Mechatronics program

MECHTRON 3DX4.name: Dynamic Models and Control of Physical Systems
MECHTRON 3DX4.prerequisites: One of MECHTRON 3MX3 or SFWRENG 2MX3 or 3MX3 and registration in a Mechatronics Engineering program

MECHTRON 3K04.name: Software Development
MECHTRON 3K04.prerequisites: One of COMPENG 2SI3, 2SI4, ELEC ENG 2SI4, MECHTRON 2MD3, SFWRENG 2MD3, and registration in a Mechatronics Engineering or Mechatronics and Biomedical Engineering program

MECHTRON 3MX3.name: Signals and Systems
MECHTRON 3MX3.description: Linear systems, signals, filters; time and frequency domains; single input-single output systems; discrete and continuous time; sampling theorem; Fourier series; Fourier, Laplace, and Z-transforms; stability. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); first term.
MECHTRON 3MX3.prerequisites: MATH 2Z03 and registration in a Mechatronics Engineering program

MECHTRON 3TB4.name: Embedded Systems Design II
MECHTRON 3TB4.prerequisites: MECHTRON 2TA4 or 3TA4 and registration in a Mechatronics Engineering or Mechatronics and Biomedical Engineering program

MECHTRON 3X03.name: Scientific Computation
MECHTRON 3X03.description: Computer arithmetic and roundoff error analysis. Interpolation, integration, solving systems of linear and nonlinear equations. Eigenvalues and singular value decomposition. Numerical methods for ordinary differential equations. Three lectures, one tutorial (one hour); first term.
MECHTRON 3X03.prerequisites: Both MATH 1ZB3 and 1ZC3; or both MATH 1AA3 and 1B03; registration in a Mechatronics Engineering or Mechatronics and Biomedical Engineering program

MECHTRON 4AA4.name: Real-Time Systems and Control Applications
MECHTRON 4AA4.prerequisites: SFWRENG 3BB4 or SFWRENG 3SH3; and SFWRENG 3DX4 or MECHTRON 3DX4 or IBEHS 4A03, and registration in a Mechatronics Engineering program

MECHTRON 4AX3.name: Predictive and Intelligent Control
MECHTRON 4AX3.description: This course introduces several concepts used in systems engineering, predictive control and artificial intelligence. A variety of techniques including prediction and estimation, linear models, basic optimization techniques, Monte Carlo techniques, neural networks, and clustering are introduced. The techniques are applied to predictive and smart systems by the example of model predictive control and intelligent control, classification and decision-making. The course is intended for engineering students with understanding in signals and systems and control. Three lectures and one tutorial; one term.
MECHTRON 4AX3.prerequisites: MECHTRON 3DX4 or SFWRENG 3DX4 or IBEHS 4A03 Offered on an irregular basis.

MEDIAART 1A03.name: Media Arts
MEDIAART 1A03.description: Introduction to media arts and its cultural context, including art, design, and digital media. Students complete a series of hands-on creative projects exploring a range of media arts formats. Three hours (lectures and tutorial); one term Antirequisite(s): MMEDIA 1A03.

MEDIAART 2A06.name: Design & Code
MEDIAART 2A06.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of a Multimedia or Media Arts program

MEDIAART 2B06.name: Time-Based Media
MEDIAART 2B06.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of a Multimedia or Media Arts program

MEDIAART 2G03.name: Digital Audio
MEDIAART 2G03.description: Introduction to techniques in audio recording, transformation, and delivery for diverse cultural and technical contexts. Listening, reading, discussions, and demonstrations will support the creation and critique of audio projects. Lecture, web module, tutorial (three hours); one term.
MEDIAART 2G03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of a Multimedia or Media Arts program; or registration in Level II or above of a Music, Theatre & Film, Art History, Studio Art, iArts or Communication Studies program

MEDIAART 3AN3.name: Animation
MEDIAART 3AN3.description: This class is an introduction to the history, types and basic principles of animation. Students are expected to create a significant work of animation in which they display a variety of techniques. The class will view and discuss the history of animation, independent animation, commercial animation and interactive media. In the context of these lectures, projects and screenings, students will develop a firm grasp of animation fundamentals. Three hours (combined lecture and lab); one term.
MEDIAART 3AN3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Multimedia or Media Arts program

MEDIAART 3B03.name: Digital Cultures
MEDIAART 3B03.description: This course explores current contests over access to the production, distribution, and consumption of digital culture across a range of technologies and practices. Assignments will include digital production. Three hours, one term.
MEDIAART 3B03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Multimedia, Media Arts or Communication Studies program

MEDIAART 3BB3.name: New Media Art Practices
MEDIAART 3BB3.description: This course offers a critical perspective on theories and practices of contemporary media art through screenings, production-based projects and field trip engagement with new media work. Three hours, one term.
MEDIAART 3BB3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Multimedia, Media Arts or Communication Studies program

MEDIAART 3C03.name: Interactive and Spatial Audio
MEDIAART 3C03.description: This course covers the creation and delivery of interactive and spatial audio. Projects explore surround and multichannel sound, interactive sound design, software synthesis, and other advanced electroacoustic techniques. Three hours (combined lecture and lab); one term.
MEDIAART 3C03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Multimedia or Media Arts program, or MMEDIA 2G03 (or, if previously taken, MUSIC 2Z03, ART 2Z03 or THTRFLM 2Z03)

MEDIAART 3DS3.name: Documentary Strategies
MEDIAART 3DS3.description: Studio course exploring theory and practice of documentary across numerous media (photo, video, sound). Students will learn documentary techniques and theorize, propose, and produce projects that are informed by the history, theory, and debates foundational to documentary practice. Three hours (combined lecture and lab); one term.
MEDIAART 3DS3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Multimedia or Media Arts program

MEDIAART 3EE3.name: Graphic Design
MEDIAART 3EE3.description: A technical and conceptual exploration of graphic design using computer drawing and illustration tools to solve problems posed within the context of contemporary media design practices. Three hours (combined lecture and lab); one term.
MEDIAART 3EE3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Multimedia or Media Arts program

MEDIAART 3EW3.name: Environmental and Wildlife Photography
MEDIAART 3EW3.description: This course studies the creation of wildlife & environmental photography. Students draw upon readings, photographs, documentaries, and lab instruction to create critically engaged and ethically informed photographs of local wildlife and habitat. Three hours (combined lecture and lab); one term.
MEDIAART 3EW3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Multimedia or Media Arts program

MEDIAART 3I03.name: Narrative Strategies
MEDIAART 3I03.description: Students will consider how meaning is structured and perceived through narrative approaches to time-based media such as video and animation. Concepts include structure, plot, theme, genre, characterization, and point of view. Three hours (combined lecture and lab); one term.
MEDIAART 3I03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Multimedia or Media Arts program

MEDIAART 3K03.name: Game Studies
MEDIAART 3K03.description: A study of the form, content, and playing of digital games. Topics include: form, genre, and technology; time and space; representation and narrative; and participatory play. Assignments include digital production. Three hours (combined lecture and lab); one term.
MEDIAART 3K03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Multimedia or Media Arts program, a program in Communication Studies, or the Software Engineering (Game Design) program

MEDIAART 3L03.name: Game Design
MEDIAART 3L03.description: Students will design and develop digital games, with a game engine, informed by readings and discussion. Three hours (combined lecture and lab); one term.
MEDIAART 3L03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Multimedia, Media Arts, or Communication Studies program

MEDIAART 3MU3.name: Musics, Technologies and Audio Cultures
MEDIAART 3MU3.description: What effects have broadcasting, mechanical and digital reproduction technologies had upon our experience of music? What are the differences between live performances, broadcasting and audio objects? This course addresses these questions by examining diverse musical and sound art genres as reflected in readings, sound recordings, videos and live performances. Three lectures; one term.
MEDIAART 3MU3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above; and completion of one of the following: CMST 1A03 , MMEDIA 1A03, MEDIAART 1A03 , ENGLISH 1CS3 , GENDRST 1A03 , GENDRST 1AA3 , PEACJUST 1A03 , IARTS 1PA3 , or IARTS 1PB3 .

MEDIAART 3PC3.name: Photographic Collage and Composite Images
MEDIAART 3PC3.description: Studio course exploring theory and practice of collage and composite image-making (both analog and digital). Students will develop a series of creative projects, and will learn strategies of camera control, lighting, and digital compositing. No previous technical background required, but basic familiarity with Photoshop and digital photography is recommended. Three hours (combined lecture and lab); one term.
MEDIAART 3PC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Multimedia or Media Arts program; or ART 2DP3 or IARTS 2DP3 and registration in Level III or above in a Studio Art or iArts program

MEDIAART 3S03.name: Sound and Image
MEDIAART 3S03.description: A study of contemporary research and creative practices that explore combined audiovisual perception and digital translations between sound and image. Students will discuss theoretical readings and complete creative projects. Three hours (combined lecture and lab); one term.
MEDIAART 3S03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Multimedia or Media Arts program

MEDIAART 3VA3.name: Video Art and Digital Cinema
MEDIAART 3VA3.description: Explores intersections between contemporary art and the moving image, with an emphasis on current movements in Digital Cinema and Video Art. Students will explore the boundaries of conventional filmic production: challenging and expanding on existing skill sets to develop unique and engaging aesthetic sensibilities. Topics will include understanding Digital Cinema, anti-narrative approaches, composite and hybrid/multi-channel video, HD and UHD work flows, audio/video output for the professional sphere, and professional practices (i.e. festivals, residencies, film school, grants, graduate programs, etc). Three hours (combined lecture and lab); one term Cross-list(s): ART 3VA3.
MEDIAART 3VA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of a Multimedia or Media Arts program; or ART 2DP3 or IARTS 2DP3 and registration in Level III or above in a Studio Art or iArts program

MEDIAART 3Z03.name: Production and Critique
MEDIAART 3Z03.description: The course takes up various theories & practices of critique to support students in the evolution of their independent media arts studio practice. Students will engage in an iterative cycle of production, presentation, critical analysis, and refinement within the context of group critiques. Three hours (combined lecture and lab); one term.
MEDIAART 3Z03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III of a Multimedia or Media Arts program

MEDIAART 4F03.name: Topics in Media Arts Production
MEDIAART 4F03.description: Advanced media arts production projects exploring assigned themes or media formats. Three hours (lecture and lab); one term.
MEDIAART 4F03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV of a Multimedia or Media Arts program
MEDIAART 4F03.antirequisites: MMEDIA 4F03 MEDIAART 4F03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

MEDPHYS 3C03.name: Operational Health Physics: Laboratory & Communication
MEDPHYS 3C03.description: Six practical Health Physics operational exercises are undertaken. These include survey instruments, surveys of radiation fields, contamination surveys, air sampling for radioactivity, radiation dosimetry and radiological incident response. Each topic is introduced, followed by laboratory work and then students report on their findings. Two lectures/seminars, one lab; one term.
MEDPHYS 3C03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of an Honours Medical and Biological Physics (B.Sc.) program; or permission of the instructor May be offered in alternate years.

MEDPHYS 4B03.name: Radioactivity and Radiation Interactions
MEDPHYS 4B03.description: Radioactivity and radiation phenomenology: interaction of radiations with matter, dosimetry, radiation in medicine, biological effects, radiation levels and regulations, radiation protection. Three lectures; one term.
MEDPHYS 4B03.prerequisites: One of BIOPHYS 1S03 , LIFESCI 1D03 , MEDPHYS 1E03, PHYSICS 1AA3 , 1CC3 , 1E03 , ISCI 1A24 A/B ; or permission of the instructor

MEDPHYS 4D03.name: Imaging in Medicine and Biology
MEDPHYS 4D03.description: A theoretical and practical treatment of the math and physics underlying imaging techniques in medicine and biology, such as clinical imaging with computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and deconvolution microscopy. Topics include image formation, 2D and 3D reconstruction, noise, filtering, storage, manipulation, and analysis. The course includes a practical MATLAB programming component to introduce students to image processing. Two lectures, one tutorial (two hours); one term.

MEDPHYS 4F03.name: Fundamentals of Health Physics
MEDPHYS 4F03.description: Introduces students to the fundamentals of occupational and environmental health physics encountered in the nuclear power, medical and research fields. Concepts include principles and regulatory framework for radiation safety; key dosimetric quantities, units and models; doses from internal and external exposures to ionizing radiation; elements of a radiation safety program; and environmental exposure pathways. Three lectures; one term.
MEDPHYS 4F03.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above of a program in the Faculties of Science, Health Sciences, or Engineering. MEDPHYS 4B03 , ENGPHYS 3L04 or ENGPHYS 3D03 is recommended. May be offered in alternate years.

MEDPHYS 4I03.name: Introduction to Biophotonics
MEDPHYS 4I03.description: This course covers the basic principles of light interaction with biological systems and specific biomedical applications of photonics such as optical light microscopy, endoscopic imaging, spectroscopy in clinical diagnosis, flow cytometry, micro-optical sensors, etc. Three lectures; one term.
MEDPHYS 4I03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above in the Faculties of Engineering, Science, or Health Sciences, or the Integrated Biomedical Engineering & Health Sciences (IBEHS) Program Cross-list(s): ENGPHYS 4I03 This course is administered by the Department of Engineering Physics.

MEDPHYS 4RA3.name: Radiation and Radioisotope Methodology I
MEDPHYS 4RA3.description: An introduction to radiation detection and radioisotope production with emphasis on principles of gas filled radiation detectors, scintillation detectors and gamma-ray spectrometry. Two lectures every week, one lab (three hours) every other week.

MEDPHYS 4RB3.name: Radiation and Radioisotope Methodology II
MEDPHYS 4RB3.description: Radiation detector signal processing theory, semiconductor radiation detectors, neutron detection methods. Two lectures every week, one lab (three hours) every other week.

MEDPHYS 4T03.name: Clinical Applications of Physics in Medicine
MEDPHYS 4T03.description: Basic physical concepts underlying medical imaging, nuclear medicine, physiological measurement, radiation therapy and biomedical laser applications with an overview of their technical implementation. Three lectures; one term.
MEDPHYS 4T03.prerequisites: MATH 2X03 (or ISCI 2A18 A/B ); and MATH 2C03 ; and one of ENGPHYS 3L04 , 3D03, or credit or registration in MEDPHYS 4B03

MEDPHYS 4U03.name: Radiation Biology
MEDPHYS 4U03.description: The effects of radiation on biological material at the molecular, cellular, tissue and whole organism level. Three lectures; one term.
MEDPHYS 4U03.prerequisites: One of BIOLOGY 2B03, 2C03, ISCI 2A18 A/B; or registration in Honours Medical and Biological Physics

MEDRADSC 1B03.name: Introduction to Pathology
MEDRADSC 1B03.description: Processes of disease and trauma, from damage and repair processes at the cellular level to tissues and systems. Disease development and recovery, immunity and heredity are examined. Lectures (three hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 1B03.prerequisites: Credit or registration in KINESIOL 1Y03 and registration in Honours Medical Radiation Sciences (Level I)

MEDRADSC 1E03.name: Inquiry in Medical Radiation Sciences
MEDRADSC 1E03.description: An introduction to the process of Inquiry. Library and research tools are used to identify literature and evaluate evidence related to a variety of topics. Lectures or seminars (three hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 1E03.prerequisites: Registration in Honours Medical Radiation Sciences (Level I)

MEDRADSC 1F03.name: Professions in Medical Radiation Sciences
MEDRADSC 1F03.description: The professions and subspecialties within medical radiation sciences are introduced, including legislative and regulatory frameworks, the Canadian health care system, professionalism and reflective practice. Lectures (three hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 1F03.prerequisites: Registration in Honours Medical Radiation Sciences I

MEDRADSC 2A03.name: Patient Care
MEDRADSC 2A03.description: Theoretical foundation and skills development to enable the student to meet the physical and emotional needs of patients in the clinical setting while utilizing self-care concepts and safe practices. Communication (verbal and non-verbal) skills are emphasized. Lecture (two hours), lab (two hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 2A03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 1F03 ; and one of MEDRADSC 2G03 , MEDRADSC 2N03 , 2U03 ; and registration in Level II of a Medical Radiation Sciences specialization

MEDRADSC 2AA3.name: Imaging Procedures in Health Care
MEDRADSC 2AA3.description: An examination of the various imaging modalities and procedures involved in a patient’s diagnostic work-up and treatment. Three hours (lectures); one term.
MEDRADSC 2AA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level ll Medical Radiation Sciences Specialization

MEDRADSC 2D03.name: Relational Anatomy I
MEDRADSC 2D03.description: This course examines spatial relationships of anatomical structures (appendicular and axial skeleton, excepting skull, plus structures of the pelvic and thoracic cavities) using projection, sectional and volume-rendered images. Lecture (two hours), lab (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 2D03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of the Radiography Specialization or Radiation Therapy Specialization

MEDRADSC 2G03.name: Radiographic Skills I
MEDRADSC 2G03.description: Emphasis is on professional behaviours and fundamental radiographic techniques and basic radiography of the appendicular skeleton through image production using anatomical phantoms and performance of simulated examinations on peers. Communication (verbal and non-verbal) skills are emphasized. This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis. Lecture (two hours), lab (four hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 2G03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 1F03 ; and credit or registration in MEDRADSC 2D03 , 2Y03 ; and registration in Level II of the Radiography Specialization

MEDRADSC 2H03.name: Radiographic Skills II
MEDRADSC 2H03.description: Emphasis is on professional behaviours and fundamental radiographic techniques and basic radiography of the axial skeleton, chest and abdomen through image production using anatomical phantoms and performance of simulated examinations on peers. Communication (verbal and non-verbal) skills are emphasized. This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis. Lecture (two hours), lab (four hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 2H03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2D03 , 2G03 and registration in Level II of the Radiography Specialization

MEDRADSC 2I03.name: Pathology and Procedures I
MEDRADSC 2I03.description: Radiological procedures and associated pathologies of the skeletal, digestive, respiratory and urinary systems. Physiological properties of contrast media and their use in radiological procedures are studied. Lectures (three hours), online component (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 2I03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of the Radiography Specialization

MEDRADSC 2J15.name: Radiography Clinical Practicum I
MEDRADSC 2J15.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2A03 , 2G03 , 2H03 , 2I03 , 2RA3 , 2X03 , 2Y03 , and registration in Level II of the Radiography Specialization See Department Note 4 above.

MEDRADSC 2K03.name: Applied Sonographic Physics and Instrumentation I
MEDRADSC 2K03.description: A comprehensive applied examination of sound wave principles, sound and tissue interaction, pulsed wave ultrasound, transducers, instrumentation, Doppler ultrasound, and diagnostic imaging ultrasound artifacts. Lectures (three hours), lab (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 2K03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of the Ultrasonography Specialization

MEDRADSC 2L03.name: Abdominal Ultrasonography I
MEDRADSC 2L03.description: A comprehensive study of the relational anatomy, sonographic technique/appearances of normal major abdominal organs and vasculature; pathology, sonographic correlation, clinical presentation and diagnostic tests of the vascular and reticulo-endothelial systems. Lectures (three hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 2L03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of the Ultrasonography Specialization

MEDRADSC 2M03.name: Obstetrical and Gynecologic Ultrasonography I
MEDRADSC 2M03.description: A comprehensive study of the anatomy, physiology of the normal female pelvis including pregnancy. Sonographic technique, normal appearances, patient care and ethical issues will be examined. Three hours (lectures); Tutorial (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 2M03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of the Honours Medical Radiation Sciences - Ultrasonography Specialization (B.M.R.Sc.)

MEDRADSC 2N03.name: Sonographic Skills I
MEDRADSC 2N03.description: Emphasis is on professional behaviours, patient care, communication skills (verbal and non-verbal), ergonomics, image recognition, image critique and performance of sonography of the abdominal vasculature, liver and biliary systems on peers, including routine and alternative techniques. This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis. Lectures (one hour), lab (four hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 2N03.prerequisites: Credit or registration in MEDRADSC 2K03 , 2L03 and registration in Level II of the Ultrasonography Specialization

MEDRADSC 2O03.name: Abdominal Ultrasonography II
MEDRADSC 2O03.description: A comprehensive study of pathology and sonographic correlation, clinical presentation and diagnostic tests of hepatic, biliary, pancreatic, urinary tract; relational anatomy, sonographic technique/appearances of normal thyroid. Lectures (three hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 2O03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2K03 , 2L03 , 2N03 and registration in Level II of the Ultrasonography Specialization

MEDRADSC 2P03.name: Obstetrical and Gynecological Ultrasonography II
MEDRADSC 2P03.description: A comprehensive study of gynecological pathologies and normal and abnormal sonographic appearances of the female pelvis. Pathologies of the obstetrical patient will be examined. Three hours (lectures), one hour (tutorial); one term.
MEDRADSC 2P03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2M03 and registration in Level II of the Ultrasonography Specialization

MEDRADSC 2Q03.name: Sonographic Skills II
MEDRADSC 2Q03.description: Emphasis is on professional behaviours, patient care, communication skills (verbal and non-verbal), ergonomics, image recognition, image critique and performance of sonography of the pancreas, urinary system, complete abdomen and female pelvis on peers, including routine and alternative techniques. This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis. Lectures (two hours), lab (four hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 2Q03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2K03 , 2L03 , 2M03 , 2N03 ; and registration in Level II of the Ultrasonography Specialization

MEDRADSC 2R15.name: Ultrasonography Clinical Practicum I
MEDRADSC 2R15.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2A03 , 2K03 , 2N03 , 2O03 , 2P03 , 2Q03 and registration in Level II of the Ultrasonography Specialization See Department Note 4 above.

MEDRADSC 2RA3.name: Relational Anatomy II
MEDRADSC 2RA3.description: This course examines the spatial relationships of anatomical structures (contents of cranium, neck and abdominal cavity) using projection, sectional and volume-rendered images. Lectures (three hours), lab (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 2RA3.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2D03 and registration in Level II of the Radiography or the Radiation Therapy Specialization

MEDRADSC 2S03.name: Clinical Oncology I
MEDRADSC 2S03.description: This course introduces the oncologic concepts that characterize all malignancies. Topics include epidemiology, etiology, signs and symptoms, routes of spread, staging and management. An in-depth study of some of the more common disease sites is also undertaken. Three hours (lectures); one term.
MEDRADSC 2S03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of the Radiation Therapy Specialization

MEDRADSC 2T03.name: Clinical Oncology II
MEDRADSC 2T03.description: This course builds on MEDRADSC 2S03 (Clinical Oncology I) through continued in-depth study of prevalent malignancies. Three hours (lectures); one term.
MEDRADSC 2T03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2S03 and registration in Level II of the Radiation Therapy Specialization

MEDRADSC 2U03.name: Radiation Therapy Skills I
MEDRADSC 2U03.description: Emphasis is on professional behaviours, patient care, communication skills (verbal and non-verbal), and basic radiation therapy treatment techniques are taught and evaluated through simulated labs. This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis. Lectures (two hours), lab (four hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 2U03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of the Radiation Therapy Specialization

MEDRADSC 2V15.name: Radiation Therapy Clinical Practicum I
MEDRADSC 2V15.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2A03 , 2AA3 , 2D03 , 2T03 , 2U03 , 2W03 , 2X03 , and registration in Level II of the Radiation Therapy Specialization See Department Note 4 above.

MEDRADSC 2W03.name: Physics and Instrumentation for Radiation Therapy
MEDRADSC 2W03.description: Photon interactions, X-ray production, measurement of radiation, linear accelerator calibration and dose calculation in simple geometries. Lectures (two hours), lab/tutorial (two hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 2W03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of the Radiation Therapy Specialization

MEDRADSC 2X03.name: Radiobiology and Protection
MEDRADSC 2X03.description: Radiation effects on cells, tissues and organs and bodies are covered with emphasis on clinical radiation hazards. Dose minimization and protective practices guidelines and regulations are examined. Lectures (three hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 2X03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2U03 or 2Y03 ; and registration in Level II of the Radiography or the Radiation Therapy Specialization

MEDRADSC 2Y03.name: Radiographic Imaging and Instrumentation I
MEDRADSC 2Y03.description: Production of x-rays, interactions with matter, image production, display and quality; control of beam quality /quantity related to image quality and dose optimization are covered. Lectures (three hours), lab (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 2Y03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II of the Honours Medical Radiation Sciences - Radiography Specialization (B.M.R.Sc.)

MEDRADSC 2ZZ0.name: Pre-Clinical Professional Skills Reassessment I
MEDRADSC 2ZZ0.prerequisites: One of MEDRADSC 2H03 , 2Q03, 2U03 ; and permission of the Department

MEDRADSC 3AA3.name: Interdisciplinary Health Care
MEDRADSC 3AA3.description: Students will collaborate with other health care professions students to develop interdisciplinary care plans for complex patient case scenarios. Students will learn to incorporate the range of domains of care and explore community resources available to support patients and their families/caregivers. Lectures (three hours), one term (Offered in Spring/Summer Term only).
MEDRADSC 3AA3.prerequisites: One of MEDRADSCI 2J15, 2R15 or 2V15 and registration in Level III of a Medical Radiation Sciences specialization

MEDRADSC 3B03.name: Quality Management in Medical Radiation Sciences
MEDRADSC 3B03.description: Examination of various quality management methodologies in health care facilities, external accreditation processes and legislation associated with quality in Medical Radiation Sciences. Lectures (two hours), tutorial (one hour); one term (Offered in Spring/Summer Term only).
MEDRADSC 3B03.prerequisites: One of MEDRADSC 2J15 , 2R15 or 2V15 ; and registration in Level III of a Medical Radiation Sciences specialization

MEDRADSC 3DA3.name: Advanced Studies in Computed Tomography
MEDRADSC 3DA3.description: A study of clinical use of CT in diagnosis, including clinical indications, pathophysiology, imaging appearances, imaging protocols and post-processing tools. Lectures (three hours), lab (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 3DA3.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 3K03 and registration in Level III of the Radiography or Radiation Therapy Specialization

MEDRADSC 3DE3.name: Introduction to Magnetic Resonance Imaging
MEDRADSC 3DE3.description: Of magnetic resonance imaging, including instrumentation, image production, selection and control of magnetic fields, pulse sequences, safety and clinical application. Lectures and web modules (three hours); one term (Offered in Spring/Summer Term only).
MEDRADSC 3DE3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III of a Medical Radiation Sciences Specialization

MEDRADSC 3DJ3.name: Pediatric Sonography
MEDRADSC 3DJ3.description: This course offers a comprehensive overview of pediatric normal and abnormal anatomy including the vascular system, spinal and intracranial structures along with scanning protocols. Lectures (three hours); one term (Offered in Spring/Summer Term only).
MEDRADSC 3DJ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III of the Ultrasonography Specialization

MEDRADSC 3G03.name: Radiographic Imaging and Instrumentation II
MEDRADSC 3G03.description: The main operations of radiographic and fluorographic equipment, from underlying physical principles to clinical application. Three hours (lectures), one hour (lab or tutorial); one term.
MEDRADSC 3G03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2J15 and registration in Level III of the Radiography Specialization

MEDRADSC 3H03.name: Quality Control in Radiography
MEDRADSC 3H03.description: Students perform quality control testing procedures on both analogue and digital radiographic equipment, comparing equipment performance to legislated standards and best practices concepts. Lecture (one hour), lab (two hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 3H03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2J15 , 3G03 and registration in Level III of the Radiography Specialization

MEDRADSC 3J03.name: Pathology and Procedures II
MEDRADSC 3J03.description: Radiological procedures and image appearances of associated pathologies of the cardiovascular, endocrine, nervous and reproductive systems. Three hours (lectures); one term.
MEDRADSC 3J03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2J15 and registration in Level III of the Radiography Specialization

MEDRADSC 3K03.name: Computed Tomography
MEDRADSC 3K03.description: Processes of data acquisition, image reconstruction and post-processing are discussed. Scan protocol optimization in terms of image quality, demonstrated structures and patient dose are examined. Labs include scanning of anatomical phantoms. Lectures (three hours), lab (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 3K03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2RA3 and registration in Level III of the Radiation Therapy or the Radiography Specialization

MEDRADSC 3L03.name: Radiographic Skills III
MEDRADSC 3L03.description: Emphasis is on professional behaviours and radiography of cranio-facial structures and development of case management and adaptation skills in modifying standard radiographic procedures to the special needs patient. Communication skills (verbal and non-verbal) are emphasized. This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis. Lecture (two hours), lab (four hours); one term (Offered in Spring/Summer Term only).
MEDRADSC 3L03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2J15 and registration in Level III of the Radiography Specialization

MEDRADSC 3LA3.name: Radiation Therapy Skills II
MEDRADSC 3LA3.description: Emphasis is on professional behaviours, patient care, communication skills and radiation therapy techniques, with a focus on the management of side-effects associated with radiation therapy. Lectures (two hours), lab (two hours), tutorial (two hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 3LA3.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2V15 and registration in Level III of the Radiation Therapy Specialization
MEDRADSC 3LA3.antirequisites: MEDRADSC 3W03 This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis.

MEDRADSC 3LB3.name: Radiation Therapy Skills III
MEDRADSC 3LB3.description: Emphasis is on professional behaviours, patient care, communication skills and radiation therapy techniques associated with the management of complex patient case scenarios. Lecture (two hours), lab (two hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 3LB3.antirequisites: MEDRADSC 3BB3 This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis.

MEDRADSC 3M03.name: Abdominal Ultrasonography III
MEDRADSC 3M03.description: A comprehensive overview with sonographic correlation of the relational anatomy, normal, anomalous and pathologic conditions of the adrenal glands, abdominopelvic and thoracic cavities, GI tract and specific superficial structures. Lectures (three hours), tutorial (one hour); one term (Offered in Spring/Summer Term only).
MEDRADSC 3M03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2O03 , 2R15 and registration in Level III of the Ultrasonography Specialization

MEDRADSC 3N03.name: Vascular Ultrasonography
MEDRADSC 3N03.description: A comprehensive study of vascular anatomy, physiology, hemodynamics, sonographic interpretation of normal and pathologic conditions in the assessment of the vasculature of the head, neck, abdomen and extremities. Three hours (lectures), one hour (tutorial); one term.
MEDRADSC 3N03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2R15 and registration in Level III of the Ultrasonography Specialization

MEDRADSC 3O03.name: Sonographic Skills III
MEDRADSC 3O03.description: Emphasis is on professional behaviours, patient care, communication skills (verbal and non-verbal), ergonomics, image recognition, image critique and performance of the extracranial arteries, abdominal and peripheral vasculature on peers, including routine and alternative techniques. This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis. Lecture (one hour), lab (four hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 3O03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2R15 , 3N03 and registration in Level III of the Ultrasonography Specialization

MEDRADSC 3P03.name: Obstetrical and Gynecologic Ultrasonography III
MEDRADSC 3P03.description: A comprehensive study of obstetric anomalies and abnormal sonographic appearances of amniotic fluid, fetal growth, fetal syndromes, Doppler studies of the gravid patient and fetal anomalies of each system. Lectures (three hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 3P03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2P03 and registration in Level III of the Ultrasonography Specialization

MEDRADSC 3Q03.name: Applied Sonographic Physics and Instrumentation II
MEDRADSC 3Q03.description: Recent and emerging technological advances in ultrasound instrumentation/imaging such as advanced signal processing, elastography, contrast ultrasound imaging and 3D/4D imaging. Bioeffects and quality assurance associated with diagnostic ultrasound will also be covered. Lectures (three hours), tutorial (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 3Q03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2R15 and registration in Level III of the Ultrasonography Specialization

MEDRADSC 3R03.name: Musculoskeletal Ultrasonography
MEDRADSC 3R03.description: Sonographic correlation of upper/lower extremity joint anatomy; normal and pathologic musculoskeletal structures using standard scanning techniques and protocols. Lectures (three hours), lab (one hour); one term.
MEDRADSC 3R03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2R15 and registration in Level III of the Ultrasonography Specialization

MEDRADSC 3S03.name: Treatment Planning I
MEDRADSC 3S03.description: Students gain the knowledge and skills required to independently plan and calculate radiation therapy treatments for a variety of sites under variable conditions. Lectures (two hours), lab (two hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 3S03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2V15 and registration in Level III of the Radiation Therapy Specialization

MEDRADSC 3V03.name: Treatment Planning II
MEDRADSC 3V03.description: This course further develops problem-solving skills related to dosimetry. Photon and electron beams, brachytherapy, conformal therapy and Intensity Modulated Radiation Therapy principles are emphasized. Lectures (two hours), lab (two hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 3V03.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 3S03 and registration in Level III of the Radiation Therapy Specialization

MEDRADSC 3X03.name: Research Methods in Medical Radiation Sciences
MEDRADSC 3X03.description: Prepares students for applied clinical research in Medical Radiation Sciences. Topics include systematic description of observations, testing hypotheses, distinctives of quantitative and qualitative research and critical review of published literature. Lectures (three hours), tutorials (two hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 3X03.prerequisites: STATS 2B03 ; and registration in Level III of a Medical Radiation Sciences specialization or Level III or above a Life Sciences program

MEDRADSC 3Y03.name: Ethics for Medical Radiation Sciences
MEDRADSC 3Y03.description: An overview of the major areas of clinical biomedical ethics. Extensive use of case discussion and analysis will help to develop the students’ ethical problem-solving skills. Lectures (three hours); one term.
MEDRADSC 3Y03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III of a Medical Radiation Sciences specialization; or Level III or above of an Honours Medical & Biological Physics program

MEDRADSC 3ZZ0.name: Clinical Skill Development for Professionals
MEDRADSC 3ZZ0.prerequisites: Permission of the Director, School of Interdisciplinary Science (or delegate)

MEDRADSC 4A15.name: Radiography Clinical Practicum II
MEDRADSC 4A15.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 3G03 , 3H03 , 3J03 , 3K03 , 3L03 and registration in Level IV of the Radiography Specialization See Department Note 4 above.

MEDRADSC 4B15.name: Radiography Clinical Practicum III
MEDRADSC 4B15.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 4A15 and registration in Level IV of the Radiography Specialization See Department Note 4 above.

MEDRADSC 4C15.name: Ultrasonography Clinical Practicum II
MEDRADSC 4C15.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 2R15 , 3M03 , 3N03 , 3O03 , 3P03 and registration in Level IV of the Ultrasonography Specialization See Department Note 4 above.

MEDRADSC 4D15.name: Ultrasonography Clinical Practicum III
MEDRADSC 4D15.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 4C15 and registration in Level IV of the Ultrasonography Specialization See Department Note 4 above .

MEDRADSC 4E15.name: Radiation Therapy Clinical Practicum II
MEDRADSC 4E15.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 3K03 , 3BB3, 3V03 , 3W03 and registration in Level IV of the Radiation Therapy Specialization See Department Note 4 above.

MEDRADSC 4F15.name: Radiation Therapy Clinical Practicum III
MEDRADSC 4F15.prerequisites: MEDRADSC 4E15 and registration in Level IV of the Radiation Therapy Specialization See Department Note 4 above.

MEDRADSC 4ZZ0.name: Pre-Clinical Professional Skills Reassessment II
MEDRADSC 4ZZ0.prerequisites: Permission of the Director, School of Interdisciplinary Science (or delegate)

MIDWIF 1D03.name: Midwifery The Profession I
MIDWIF 1D03.description: Seminar presentations, discussion and arranged experiences to introduce students to the history, philosophy of care, and role of the midwife in Canada and elsewhere. Seminar (three hours); first term.
MIDWIF 1D03.prerequisites: Registration in the Midwifery Education Program

MIDWIF 1F03.name: Introduction to Research Methods and Critical Appraisal
MIDWIF 1F03.description: Introduction to the principles of clinical research and statistical inference, with particular emphasis on critical assessment of research evidence (both qualitative and quantitative) as presented in the health sciences literature related to midwifery care. Lectures/tutorials (three hours); second term.

MIDWIF 1G03.name: Midwifery The Profession II
MIDWIF 1G03.description: Seminar presentations, discussions, and laboratory practice to introduce students to communication theory and strategies, equity, diversity and inclusion in the provision of midwifery care. Seminar (3 hours); second term.
MIDWIF 1G03.prerequisites: Registration in the Midwifery Education Program

MIDWIF 2F03.name: Pharmacotherapy
MIDWIF 2F03.description: This course is an overview of basic concepts in pharmacy, pharmacology and therapeutics relevant to the practice of midwifery in Ontario. Content areas include pharmacokinetics, toxicology, adverse drug reactions during pregnancy and lactation and pharmacology in the neonate. One lecture (three hours); first term.

MIDWIF 2G06.name: Clinical Skills for Midwifery Practice
MIDWIF 2G06.antirequisites: MIDWIF 2G03 May be taken concurrently with MIDWIF 1D03 with permission of the Program Director.

MIDWIF 2H15.name: Normal Childbearing
MIDWIF 2H15.prerequisites: HTHSCI 2M03, MIDWIF 1D03, MIDWIF 2F03, MIDWIF 2G06 (or 1A06 or 2G03). A minimum GPA of 6.0 in first term is required.

MIDWIF 2M15.name: Fundamentals in Midwifery 1
MIDWIF 2M15.prerequisites: HTHSCI 2M03, MIDWIF 1D03, 2F03, 2G06 (or 1A06 or 2G03). A minimum GPA of 6.0 in first term is required.

MIDWIF 3F03.name: Midwifery Issues
MIDWIF 3F03.description: This course addresses the theoretical basis for inter-professional collaboration and explores related professional issues such as global midwifery, ethics and risk management. The course includes critical analysis of issues in asynchronous online discussion and submission of a major paper.

MIDWIF 3I03.name: Advanced Clinical Skills I
MIDWIF 3I03.description: A five day intensive course using workshop format to focus on emergency interventions, evidence based management of prenatal and intrapartum situations and communication . Students receive instruction  from midwifery faculty and interdisciplinary experts in preparation for community placements and senior midwifery clinical placements.  First term.

MIDWIF 3L03.name: Advanced Clinical Skills II
MIDWIF 3L03.description: Short intensive course of five to six days. The course builds on the skills introduced in MIDWIF 3I03 and focuses on preparing the student for recognizing situations where consultation and transfer of care is required, as well as in being able to initiate and facilitate such consultation. Second term.

MIDWIF 3N15.name: Fundamentals in Midwifery 2
MIDWIF 3N15.prerequisites: HTHSCI 2M03, MIDWIF 1D03, 2F03, 2G06 (or 1A06 or 2G03). A minimum GPA of 6.0 in first term is required.

MOLBIOL 2C03.name: Genetics
MOLBIOL 2C03.description: Structure, function and transmission of genes; chromosomal basis of inheritance; mono- and dihybrid crosses; sequential steps in gene function; linkage maps; sex chromosome inheritance. Lectures (three hours), one lab or tutorial (two hours); one term.
MOLBIOL 2C03.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 1A03, BIOLOGY 1M03 (or ISCI 1A24 A/B) and registration in Honours Molecular Biology and Genetics or Honours Arts and Science and Molecular Biology and Genetics
MOLBIOL 2C03.antirequisites: BIOLOGY 2C03 Students not registered in an Honours Molecular Biology and Genetics program should register in BIOLOGY 2C03.

MOLBIOL 3A03.name: Current Topics in Molecular Biology and Genetics
MOLBIOL 3A03.description: A review of current literature in molecular biology and genetics. A combination of lectures and student presentations on selected topics. One lecture (one hour), one tutorial (two hours); one term.
MOLBIOL 3A03.prerequisites: Registration in Honours Biology, Honours Molecular Biology and Genetics or Honours Molecular Biology and Genetics Co-op

MOLBIOL 3B03.name: Advanced Cell Biology
MOLBIOL 3B03.description: The molecular organisation and function of eukaryotic cells are examined, with a focus on information transfer from the cell surface and from the nucleus. Emphasis is placed upon interpretation of the research literature. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MOLBIOL 3B03.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 2B03 (or ISCI 2A18 A/B ); and one of BIOLOGY 2C03 or MOLBIOL 2C03

MOLBIOL 3D03.name: Experimental Approaches in Cell Biology
MOLBIOL 3D03.description: Intensive laboratory based inquiry course focused on cell biological research. Cell biology techniques from various disciplines will be used to investigate the structure and function of organisms at the cellular and molecular level. Techniques employed may include light and immune fluorescent microscopy, time lapse, tissue culture, biochemistry, genetics and molecular biology. This course will also provide opportunity to develop scientific literacy skills. One lecture, two labs (three hours); one term.
MOLBIOL 3D03.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 2B03 (or ISCI 2A18 A/B )); and BIOLOGY 2C03 or MOLBIOL 2C03 . If not already completed, BIOSAFE 1BS0 (or HTHSCI 1BS0) must be done prior to the first lab

MOLBIOL 3II3.name: Molecular Genetics of Eukaryotes
MOLBIOL 3II3.description: Study of the eukaryotic genome and control mechanisms of gene expression; the emphasis will be on transcriptional control, RNA surveillance and the study of epigenetic mechanisms in several model systems (yeast, nematodes, insects, plants and vertebrates). The histone code and several mechanisms of epigenetic trans-generational inheritance will be discussed. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.

MOLBIOL 3M03.name: Fundamental Concepts of Development
MOLBIOL 3M03.description: Recent advances using genetic and molecular approaches will be discussed in the context of classical experiments. Various model systems (mice, fruitflies, worms) will be examined. Two lectures, one tutorial or lab (three hours); one term.
MOLBIOL 3M03.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 2B03 (or ISCI 2A18 A/B ), BIOLOGY 2C03 or MOLBIOL 2C03

MOLBIOL 3O03.name: Microbial Genetics
MOLBIOL 3O03.description: Molecular genetics of bacteria and bacteriophage. Special emphasis will be placed on relationships between microbial genetics and general problems in genetics and gene regulation. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MOLBIOL 3O03.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 2C03 or MOLBIOL 2C03 ; and credit or registration in BIOLOGY 2EE3

MOLBIOL 3V03.name: Techniques in Molecular Genetics
MOLBIOL 3V03.description: A laboratory course providing hands-on experience in experimental design and molecular biology and molecular genetic techniques. One lecture, two labs (three hours each); one term.
MOLBIOL 3V03.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 2EE3; and credit or registration in MOLBIOL 3O03; and registration in Level III or above of an Honours program in Biology or Molecular Biology and Genetics. If not already completed, BIOSAFE 1BS0 (or HTHSCI 1BS0) and WHMIS 1A00 must be done prior to the first lab.
MOLBIOL 3V03.antirequisites: BIOLOGY 3VV3 Priority will be given to students enrolled in an Honours Molecular Biology and Genetics Research Specialization program.

MOLBIOL 3Y03.name: Plant Responses to the Environment
MOLBIOL 3Y03.description: How plants respond at the genetic, molecular, biochemical and phenotypic levels to environmental stress. Manipulation of these responses to improve crops will be explored. Three lectures; one term.
MOLBIOL 3Y03.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 2B03 (or ISCI 2A18 A/B ); and BIOLOGY 2C03 (or MOLBIOL 2C03 ); and BIOLOGY 2D03

MOLBIOL 4BB3.name: Plant Metabolism and Molecular Biology
MOLBIOL 4BB3.description: Formerly BIOLOGY 4B03 Analysis of plant cell metabolism and the regulation of metabolism at the biochemical and molecular genetic level. Three lectures; one term.
MOLBIOL 4BB3.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 2B03 (or ISCI 2A18 A/B ) and BIOLOGY 2C03 (or MOLBIOL 2C03 ); or one of BIOLOGY 3B03 , MOLBIOL 3Y03 ; or ISCI 2A18 A/B ; and registration in Level III or above of any Honours program. MOLBIOL 3B03 is recommended.

MOLBIOL 4DD3.name: Molecular Evolution
MOLBIOL 4DD3.description: The study of how molecules change over time within and between species. The experimental data, techniques and theories will be examined. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MOLBIOL 4DD3.prerequisites: ANTHROP 2D03 or BIOLOGY 3FF3 or BIOLOGY 3S03 ; and registration in Level III or above of any Honours program

MOLBIOL 4ED3.name: Evolutionary Developmental Biology
MOLBIOL 4ED3.description: A critical analysis of the conceptual and methodological approaches to Evolutionary Developmental biology. Emphasis is on integrating the developmental, genetic and evolutionary approaches towards understanding how phenotypic variation is generated. Lectures (two hours), one tutorial (two hours); one term.
MOLBIOL 4ED3.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 3FF3 or MOLBIOL 3M03 ; and registration in Level III or above of any Honours program

MOLBIOL 4H03.name: Molecular Biology of Cancer
MOLBIOL 4H03.description: Cancer at the cellular and molecular level. Topics include: properties of cancer cells, activation of proto-oncogenes, function of oncoproteins, transgenic mouse models, and tumour viruses, tumour suppressor genes. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
MOLBIOL 4H03.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 2C03 (or MOLBIOL 2C03 ); and MOLBIOL 3B03 ; and registration in Level III or above of any Honours program

MOLBIOL 4K03.name: Research Advances in Biology of Aging
MOLBIOL 4K03.description: A critical analysis of the biology of aging in model organisms and age-related human disorders. Emphasis is on the molecular pathways that regulate the process of aging at the cellular and organismal levels. One lecture (two hours), one tutorial (one hour); one term.
MOLBIOL 4K03.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 2B03 and BIOLOGY 2C03 (or MOLBIOL 2C03 ) and registration in Level IV or above of any Honours program

MOLBIOL 4P03.name: Medical Microbiology
MOLBIOL 4P03.description: Infectious diseases: identification, epidemiology and treatment. One lecture (two hours), one tutorial (three hours); one term.
MOLBIOL 4P03.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 2EE3 and registration in Level III or above of any Honours program. Credit or registration in MOLBIOL 3O03 is strongly recommended.

MOLBIOL 4RR3.name: Human Genetics
MOLBIOL 4RR3.description: Topics include genetic disorders, advanced recombinant DNA technologies, the human genome, physical and genetic mapping of Mendelian characters, linkage, transgenic animals and gene therapy. Two lectures, one tutorial (one hour); one term.
MOLBIOL 4RR3.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 2C03 or MOLBIOL 2C03 and registration in Level III or above of any Honours program

MOHAWK 1Z03.name: Introduction to Mohawk Language and Culture
MOHAWK 1Z03.description: This course will study the Mohawk language, in its spoken and written forms, in the context of Iroquoian cultural traditions, values, beliefs and customs. Lecture and seminars (three hours); one term.

MOHAWK 2Z03.name: Intermediate Mohawk
MOHAWK 2Z03.description: This course expands on the vocabulary and the oral skills for the Mohawk language. In addition, the course reviews the written component of the language. Lecture and seminars (three hours); one term.

MUSICCOG 2MP3.name: Introduction to Music Cognition
MUSICCOG 2MP3.description: This course presents an overview of music cognition, covering such topics as musical acoustics, perception of melody, harmony and rhythm, social and emotional responses to music, and the evolution of music. In addition a basic introduction to music theory is included. Three lectures; one term.
MUSICCOG 2MP3.prerequisites: One of PSYCH 1F03 , 1FF3 , 1X03 , 1XX3  and registration in Level II or above; or registration in Level II or above of an Arts & Science program, a Bachelor of Health Sciences (Honours) program, or an Honours Music Cognition program (B.A., B.Arts&Sc., B.Mus., B.Sc.); or ISCI 1A24 A/B ; or permission of the instructor
MUSICCOG 2MP3.antirequisites: MUSIC 2MC3 , MUSICCOG 2MA3, PSYCH 2MA3 Cross-list(s): PSYCH 2MP3 This course is administered by the School of the Arts.

MUSICCOG 3SP3.name: The Science of Performance
MUSICCOG 3SP3.description: This course explores empirical, methodological and cultural aspects of the study of performance, with a principal focus on the performing arts (music, dance, and theatre). Three lectures; one term.
MUSICCOG 3SP3.prerequisites: MUSICCOG 2MP3 (or MUSICCOG 2MA3) or PSYCH 2MP3 (or PSYCH 2MA3); and registration in a Music Cognition program (B.A., B.Arts.Sc., B.Mus. B.Sc.) or PNB 2XA3 or PSYCH 2E03 and registration in an Honours program, or ISCI 2A18 A/B ; or permission of the instructor. Completion of one of ARTSSCI 2R03 , HTHSCI 2A03, LINGUIST 2DD3 , PNB 2XE3 , 3XE3 , SOCSCI 2J03 , STATS 2B03 , 2D03 is recommended. Prerequisite(s) (EFFECTIVE 2019-2020): PNB 2XA3 or PSYCH 2H03 ; and one of ARTSSCI 2R03 , HTHSCI 2A03, LINGUIST 2DD3 , PNB 2XE3 , 3XE3 , SOCSCI 2J03 , STATS 2B03 , 2D03 ; and registration in Level III or IV of an Honours program; or ISCI 2A18 A/B. PSYCH/MUSICCOG 2MP3is recommended.
MUSICCOG 3SP3.antirequisites: MUSICCOG 3MP3, 3MB3, PSYCH 3MP3, 3MB3 Cross-list(s): PSYCH 3SP3 This course is administered by the Department of Psychology, Neuroscience, and Behaviour.

MUSICCOG 4MP3.name: Neuroscience of Music
MUSICCOG 4MP3.description: This seminar explores theories on how and why music evolved, and how the perception, development, performance and emotional experience of music are mediated by the brain. Primary source materials are discussed in class and experimental designs developed to address critical questions. Three hours (lecture/seminar); one term.
MUSICCOG 4MP3.prerequisites: MUSICCOG 2MP3 (or MUSICCOG 2MA3) or PSYCH 2MP3 (or PSYCH 2MA3) or PSYCH 3H03; and registration in a Music Cognition program (B.A., B.Arts.Sc., B.Mus., B.Sc.), or PNB 2XA3 or PSYCH 2E03 and registration in an Honours program, or ISCI 2A18 A/B ; or permission of the instructor. PSYCH 2E03 is recommended. Cross-list(s): PSYCH 4MP3 This course is administered by the Department of Psychology, Neuroscience & Behaviour.

NEUROSCI 3E03.name: Neuroscience Lab
NEUROSCI 3E03.description: Practical techniques in neuroanatomy and neurophysiology, including brightfield and fluorescence microscopy, neuronal visualization via staining, and invertebrate neurophysiological recording. One lecture, one lab (three hours); one term.
NEUROSCI 3E03.prerequisites: PNB 2XB3 and registration in Level III or above of Honours Neuroscience

NEUROSCI 3J03.name: Visual Neuroscience
NEUROSCI 3J03.description: Using human clinical cases, students will explore how genes and the environment affect the cells and circuits of the visual system. Cases will be investigated through the lenses of basic animal research and optometry. Three lectures; one term.
NEUROSCI 3J03.prerequisites: One of PNB 2XB3 , PSYCH 2E03 , ISCI 2A18 A/B , or LIFESCI 2CC3 ; and registration in Level III or above of an Honours program

NEUROSCI 3MN3.name: Computational Models in Neuroscience
NEUROSCI 3MN3.description: Students will study the role of model-building in neuroscience. They will learn about influential models of the brain and mind and work directly with them in code. Topics will include electrical models of the neuron, connectionist models of learning, and models of vision and information transmission. One lecture (one hour), one laboratory (two hours, weekly); one term.
NEUROSCI 3MN3.prerequisites: One of PNB 2XB3 , LIFESCI 2CC3 , or ISCI 2A18 A/B ; and one of COMPSCI 1MD3 , MATH 1MP3 , or PNB 2A03 ; or permission of the Instructor

NEUROSCI 3SN3.name: Neural Circuits
NEUROSCI 3SN3.description: Principles of circuit and systems neuroscience, emphasizing techniques, synaptic function, and neural circuit development, together with skills for thinking and communicating about science. Three lectures, one tutorial; one term.
NEUROSCI 3SN3.prerequisites: BIOLOGY 3P03 and one of LIFESCI 2CC3, PNB 2XB3, ISCI 2A18 A/B

NEXUS 2A03.name: Impact of Infectious Disease on Individuals and Society
NEXUS 2A03.description: Infectious diseases are a major public health challenge, but their impact expands beyond healthcare. This course will explore the wide-ranging impact of infectious diseases, including economic, societal, and health-related impacts. The course will also explore the social and biological barriers to eradicating disease. Two lectures (one hour); one term.

NEXUS 4A06.name: How to Survive a Pandemic: Capstone Project for Nexus Minor

NURSING 1F03.name: Introduction to Nursing and Health I for Basic Stream
NURSING 1F03.description: This introductory course will familiarize students with ways of knowing in nursing. Students will learn self-directed and person-based learning within a problem-based learning approach to facilitate their learning throughout the B.Sc.N. program. Tutorial (three hours); one term.
NURSING 1F03.prerequisites: Registration in the B.Sc.N. Basic (A) Stream Co-requisite(s): NURSING 1I02

NURSING 1G03.name: Introduction to Nursing and Health II for Basic Stream
NURSING 1G03.description: Students will be introduced to concepts of health and healing and will explore group process theory. They will learn to define clinical questions relevant to nursing and to use evidence-based approach to address these questions. Tutorial (three hours); one term.
NURSING 1G03.prerequisites: Minimum grade of C- in NURSING 1F03 , 1I02 and registration in the B.Sc.N. Basic (A) Stream Co-requisite(s): NURSING 1J02

NURSING 1I02.name: Introduction to Nursing Practice for Basic Stream
NURSING 1I02.prerequisites: Registration in the B.Sc.N. Basic (A) Stream Co-requisite(s): NURSING 1F03 and WHMIS 1A00

NURSING 1J02.name: Professional Nursing Practice I for Basic Stream
NURSING 1J02.prerequisites: WHMIS 1A00 and a minimum grade of C- in NURSING 1F03 , 1I02 and registration in the B.Sc.N. Basic (A) Stream Co-requisite(s): NURSING 1G03

NURSING 1K02.name: Community Engagement and Citizenship for Basic Stream
NURSING 1K02.prerequisites: Registration in the B.Sc.N. Basic (A) Stream This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis.

NURSING 1RP0.name: Reintegration Course
NURSING 1RP0.prerequisites: Registration in the BScN Basic (A) Stream, Accelerated (F) Stream or Post Diploma R.P.N.(E) Stream.

NURSING 2A04.name: Introduction to Professional RN Practice I for Post Diploma RPN Stream
NURSING 2A04.prerequisites: Registration in the B.Sc.N. Post Diploma R.P.N. (E) Stream Co-requisite(s): WHMIS 1A00

NURSING 2AA3.name: Professional RN Practice II for Post Diploma RPN Stream
NURSING 2AA3.description: Theories/concepts from a variety of disciplines are integrated and applied to complex health care scenarios. Nursing concepts related to health and illness across the continuum of individual and family growth and development are examined. Tutorial (four hours); one term.
NURSING 2AA3.prerequisites: Minimum grade of C- in NURSING 2A04 and registration in the B.Sc.N. Post Diploma R.P.N. (E) Stream

NURSING 2I04.name: Introduction to Professional Nursing and Health for Accelerated Stream
NURSING 2I04.prerequisites: Registration in the B.Sc.N. Accelerated (F) Stream Co-requisite(s): NURSING 2PF3 A/B or HTHSCI 2PF3 A/B

NURSING 2J04.name: Professional Nursing Practice II for Accelerated Stream
NURSING 2J04.prerequisites: WHMIS 1A00 , and minimum grade of C- in NURSING 2U04 and registration in the B.Sc.N. Accelerated (F) Stream Co-requisite(s): NURSING 2V04 This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis.

NURSING 2L03.name: Professional Nursing Practice II for Basic Stream
NURSING 2L03.description: This course is an applied professional practice course. Students will begin to apply their knowledge and skills to the care of ill clients and families, under supervision. Students will expand their understanding of internal and external influences on the health of individuals and families at the micro and macro level. Professional practice (eight hours per week) and clinical lab (ten hours); one term.
NURSING 2L03.prerequisites: WHMIS 1A00 and a minimum grade of C- in NURSING 1G03, 1J02, HTHSCI 1H06 A/B, 1LL3 and a Pass in NURSING 1K02 and registration in the B.Sc.N. Basic (A) Stream Co-requisite(s): NURSING 2MM3 This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis.

NURSING 2MM3.name: Nursing Concepts in Health and Illness I for Basic Stream
NURSING 2MM3.description: This course uses a person-based learning within problem-based approach. Students expand their knowledge of core nursing concepts and interprofessional health care content to individuals and families.  Through critical thinking they will enhance their ability to critique and apply that knowledge. Tutorial (three hours); one term.
NURSING 2MM3.prerequisites: Minimum grade of C- in NURSING  1G03, 1J02. HTHSCI 1H06 A/B, 1LL3 and a Pass in NURSING 1K02 and registration in the B.Sc.N. Basic (A) Stream Co-requisite(s): NURSING 2L03

NURSING 2NN3.name: Nursing Concepts in Health and Illness II for Basic Stream
NURSING 2NN3.description: This course uses person-based learning within a problem-based approach. An extension of NURSING 2MM3, students deepen their understanding and application of core nursing concepts and interprofessional health care content. Through critical thinking they will enhance their ability to critique and apply that knowledge. Tutorial (three hours); one term.
NURSING 2NN3.prerequisites: Minimum grade of C- in NURSING 2MM3 and a Pass in NURSING 2L03 and registration in the B.Sc.N. Basic (A) Stream Co-requisite(s): NURSING 2P03, and NURSING 2LA2 A/B or HTHSCI 2LA2 A/B

NURSING 2P03.name: Professional Nursing Practice III for Basic Stream
NURSING 2P03.description: A continuation of NURSING 2L03 with applied professional practice in institutional settings. Professional practice (eight hours per week) and clinical lab (ten hours per term); one term.
NURSING 2P03.prerequisites: Minimum grade of C- in NURSING 2MM3 and a Pass in NURSING 2L03 and registration in the B.Sc.N. Basic (A) Stream Co-requisite(s): NURSING 2NN3 This course is evaluated on a Pass/Fail basis.

NURSING 2U04.name: Introduction to Nursing Practice I for Accelerated Stream
NURSING 2U04.prerequisites: Registration in the B.Sc.N. Accelerated (F) Stream Co-requisite(s): WHMIS 1A00

NURSING 2V04.name: Nursing Concepts in Health & Illness for Accelerated Stream I
NURSING 2V04.prerequisites: Minimum grade of C- in NURSING 2I04 and registration in the B.Sc.N. Accelerated (F) Stream Co-requisite(s): NURSING 2J04

NURSING 3A04.name: Clinical Reasoning in RN Practice for Post Diploma RPN Stream
NURSING 3A04.prerequisites: Minimum grade of C- in NURSING 2AA3 , HTHSCI 2C06 , 2RR3, 3C04 , Pass in NURSING 3QQ3, and registration in the B.Sc.N. Post Diploma R.P.N. (E) Stream

NURSING 3CN3.name: Nursing Practice with the Community: Populations, Partnerships, Politics and Power
NURSING 3CN3.description: Students learn about community health nursing practice with diverse clients including individuals, families, groups, communities, and populations. Exploration of various community settings including primary care, home health and public health nursing will be the focus. Participation in small group theory and professional practice activities will allow students to learn about promoting the health of clients by understanding health equity and social determinants of health. There will be opportunity for students to engage in learning related to emancipatory knowing and advocacy.
NURSING 3CN3.prerequisites: Minimum grade of C- in NURSING 2NN3 , HTHSCI 2H03 , 2HH3 , 1RR3 , and a minimum grade of C- in NURSING 2LA2 A/B or HTHSCI 2LA2 A/B and HTHSCI 2S03 and a Pass in NURSING 2P03 , and registration in the B.Sc.N. Basic (A) Stream; or HTHSCI 2S03 and registration in the B.Sc.N. Post Diploma R.P.N. (E) Stream ; or Minimum grade of C- in NURSING 2V04 , HTHSCI 2H03 , 2HH3 , 1RR3 , 3C04 , and a minimum grade of C- in HTHSCI 2PF3 A/B , and a Pass in NURSING 2J04 , and registration in the B.Sc.N Accelerated (F) Stream
NURSING 3CN3.antirequisites: NURSING 3QQ3 or 3QA3 Co-requisite(s) NURSING 2AA3 or 3SS3 or 3TT3 or 3V03

NURSING 3IH3.name: Introduction to Indigenous Health Policy and Practice
NURSING 3IH3.description: This course is designed to provide an introduction to a number of Indigenous health policy and practice topics. This course introduces the factors and context, both historical and current that determine the health of Indigenous populations in Ontario, Canada, and beyond. The role of the nurse, particularly in providing care for Indigenous Peoples will be integrated. The major components of the course include: (1) overview of Indigenous health policy and practice situations and matters; (2) analysis of the structure and organization of the health care system and the distal determinants of health for Indigenous Peoples (such as colonialism, racism, self-determination, political will and the Indian Act); and finally (3) consideration of interventions, strategies and approaches that impact the health outcomes of Indigenous Peoples from a distal determinants of health perspectives.
NURSING 3IH3.prerequisites: Registered in Level III or above

NURSING 3QA3.name: Professional Community Nursing Practice
NURSING 3QA3.description: A professional practice course in which students learn about community health nursing practice with clients as individuals, families, groups, communities and populations. Student collaborators learn about promoting the health of these clients using various health promotion approaches. Professional practice (six hours); one term.
