SOCSCI 2MR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences

SOCSCI 2BA3.name: Introduction to Business Analysis for Social Sciences
SOCSCI 2BA3.description: The foundation of Business Analysis is planning, stakeholder analysis, structure and cultural awareness of an enterprise. Prepare for Business Analysis projects through needs analysis and business plan development using industry standard strategies such as project charter, interview and focus group techniques. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
SOCSCI 2BA3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences

SOCSCI 2FD3.name: Foundations of Disabilities
SOCSCI 2FD3.description: This course examines the major disabilities within Canadian culture including physical, developmental, organic, acute, chronic, and acquired disabilities. There will be a focus on the symptoms associated with each disability with special attention to the relationship each disability may or may not have to mental illness. Three hours; one term; online.
SOCSCI 2FD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences

SOCSCI 2IS3.name: Intervention Strategies Working with Disabilities
SOCSCI 2IS3.description: Treatments for people with various types of disabilities will be examined. Components of this course will be used to access community resource professionals currently working with people with various types of disabilities; labs will also be used by students to learn practice-based structural interviewing. Three hours; one term; online.
SOCSCI 2IS3.prerequisites: Credit or registration in SOCSCI 2FD3 and registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences

SOCSCI 2PN3.name: Pharmacology for Non-Medical Health Professionals
SOCSCI 2PN3.description: This course will identify medications and their use in treating various forms of disability and mental illness. Students will learn to classify medications and will understand the various families of medications. The content is not intended to train students to deliver medication, but to familiarize them instead with the use of medications in the treatment of various disabilities. Three hours; one term; online.
SOCSCI 2PN3.prerequisites: Credit or registration in SOCSCI 2FD3 and registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences

SOCSCI 2WF3.name: Working with Families with Disabilities
SOCSCI 2WF3.description: In this course students will explore and evaluate modern intervention techniques of community health care in providing services to families who have a member with a disability. Particular attention will be to review community resources for families and best practices related to family intervention. Three hours; one term; online.
SOCSCI 2WF3.prerequisites: Credit or registration in SOCSCI 2FD3 and registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences

SOCSCI 2LI3.name: Legal Implications and Brain Disorders
SOCSCI 2LI3.description: This course will investigate the law as it pertains to brain disorders and outline the significance of acting in compliance with the Statutes of Ontario. Three hours; one term; online.
SOCSCI 2LI3.prerequisites: Credit or registration in SOCSCI 2FD3 and registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences

SOCSCI 2CP3.name: Disability Management Capstone Project
SOCSCI 2CP3.description: Students will examine a topic that contributes to the field of brain disorders management or mental health and disability management. While using qualitative or quantitative research methods to investigate their topic, students will apply problem-based learning. Three hours; one term; online.
SOCSCI 2CP3.prerequisites: Credit or registration in SOCSCI 2FD3 and registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences

SOCSCI 2BR3.name: Board and Staff Responsibilities for the Not-for-Profit Sector
SOCSCI 2BR3.description: This course examines the characteristics of non-profit organizations and the relevance of an organization’s mission within a changing environment. It will also consider the roles and 70 responsibilities of the Chief Executive Officer and the Board of Directors, management styles appropriate to voluntary organizations, and techniques for productive meetings.
SOCSCI 2BR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences.

SOCSCI 2LC3.name: Leadership and Communications for the Not-For-Profit Sector
SOCSCI 2LC3.description: This course examines personal organizational leadership styles. Students will utilize leadership competencies to effectively lead and manage an organization. Students will learn how to develop team building skills, manage productive meetings and form strategic alliances and partnerships. Three hours; one term.
SOCSCI 2LC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences

SOCSCI 2OP3.name: Operational Planning for the Not-For-Profit Sector
SOCSCI 2OP3.description: Students learn to implement and manage an annual operating plan, to set priorities, develop a clear direction for action, assign responsibilities, set out costs and indicate how revenue will be generated to fund annual programs. Students will use the plan as a resource for board, staff and volunteers and to track and evaluate progress. Seminar (three hours); one term.
SOCSCI 2OP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences

SOCSCI 2RD3.name: Resource Development for the Not-For-Profit Sector
SOCSCI 2RD3.description: This course will investigate sources of funding for not-for-profit organizations including grants, foundations, corporate partnerships, government programs and fundraising. Students will learn how to create a resource development plan, and how to identify capacity, vision and ethics in order to assess potential resources available to the organization. Three hours; one term.
SOCSCI 2RD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences

SOCSCI 2SP3.name: Strategic and Long Range Planning for the Not-for-Profit Sector
SOCSCI 2SP3.description: This course will explore the various models of strategic planning. Based on outcome, evaluation and accountability, students will learn how to select the appropriate model and learn how to conduct environmental analysis in order to manage the organization.
SOCSCI 2SP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences

SOCSCI 1HS3.name: Pathways into the Social Sciences
SOCSCI 1HS3.description: This course recognizes a set of specialized, cross-applicable and transferable skills acquired by students in their previous education that facilitate and enhance their transition into a Social Sciences program. Three hours; one term.
SOCSCI 1HS3.prerequisites: Completion of a SHSM program in Health and Wellness; Non-Profit; Justice, Community Safety and Emergency Services; Environment; or Business.

SOCSCI 1RM3.name: How do we Know? Doing Social Sciences Research
SOCSCI 1RM3.description: This course provides students with a glimpse in at the diversity among the types of research methods used within the social sciences. Students will learn how we study the things we do, such as economic inequality, access to health care, changing patterns of crime, the interplay of religious practice and civil rights, by providing students with basic concepts and language related to conducting research. Three hours; one term.
SOCSCI 1RM3.prerequisites: Registration in Social Sciences I, Economics I, or Honours Health and Society I and credit or registration in SOCSCI 1SS3; or registration in Level II or above in a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences; or permission of the department

SOCSCI 1SS3.name: Inquiry in the Social Sciences
SOCSCI 1SS3.description: The systematic investigation of any subject requires a set of widely applicable and transferrable skills. Students learn how to formulate questions, gather and interpret evidence, and reach well-considered conclusions. The content theme will be drawn from Social Sciences issues and will vary depending on the subject expertise of the instructor. Three hours; one term.
SOCSCI 1SS3.prerequisites: Registration in Social Sciences I, Economics I, Honours Health and Society I, or Sociology My Own McMaster pathway program

SOCSCI 1T03.name: Life, the University, and Everything
SOCSCI 1T03.description: In this course, students will build the core academic abilities and habits that are crucial for success in student life and in the transition into and through university. Through a unique blend of online and active in-person learning, students will explore issues and ideas from each of the programs in the social sciences in order to develop their academic interests and plan for success. Three Hours (web modules, weekly tutorials); one term.
SOCSCI 1T03.prerequisites: Registration in Social Sciences I, Economics I or Honours Health and Society I; or registration in Level II Social Sciences General BA with permission of the department.

SOCSCI 2CC3.name: Children and Family in Canada
SOCSCI 2CC3.description: This course is designed to look at the evolution of the family in Canadian society and how our children are contextualized within different family forms. Topics include life cycle development, sexism, hurrying children, self-esteem, prejudice and discrimination and sexual abuse. On-line web modules, tutorials and testing; one term.
SOCSCI 2CC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SOCSCI 2EL0.name: Career Preparation in the Social Sciences
SOCSCI 2EL0.prerequisites: Registration in any Social Sciences program and 18 units completed.

SOCSCI 2J03.name: Introduction to Statistics
SOCSCI 2J03.description: An introduction to basic statistical concepts and their application to the analysis of data from the social sciences. The use of spreadsheets is emphasized. Three hours; one term.
SOCSCI 2J03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above of Honours Bachelor of Kinesiology, Music (Music Cognition), Cognitive Science of Language or a Social Sciences program
SOCSCI 2J03.antirequisites: COMMERCE 2QA3, ECON 2B03, ENVSOCTY 3MB3, LINGUIST 2DD3, STATS 2B03, STATS 2D03.

SOCSCI 2JS1.name: Co-Op Job Search 1
SOCSCI 2JS1.prerequisites: SOCSCI 2EL0 and registration in a Social Sciences Co-op program.

SOCSCI 2N03.name: Conspiracy Theories, Fake News and Critical Investigation
SOCSCI 2N03.description: An interdisciplinary examination through the lens of the Social Sciences of the role of hoaxes, myths, urban legends, and health scares in our contemporary social media landscape. Focuses on the development of the critical thinking and digital literacy skills needed to evaluate journalistic, academic and alternative media sources. Three Hours; one term.
SOCSCI 2N03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above or permission of the department

SOCSCI 2O03.name: Canadian Children
SOCSCI 2O03.description: This course deals with a spectrum of issues related to Canadian children such as family, socialization, identity formation, moral development, abuse and strategies for a better future. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCSCI 2O03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above in any program

SOCSCI 2P03.name: Canadian Adolescents
SOCSCI 2P03.description: This course deals with a spectrum of issues related to Canadian adolescents such as identity formation, sexuality, peer groups and power and the social politics of career formation. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCSCI 2P03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above in any program

SOCSCI 2SS3.name: Inquiry Thinking and Research Skills
SOCSCI 2SS3.description: The systematic investigation of any subject in the Social Sciences requires fundamental research skills. In this course, students develop transferrable research skills including, how to formulate effective research questions, gather and interpret evidence, reach well-reasoned conclusions, and communicate findings. By participating in active learning classroom sessions, students hone their skills while undertaking a student-driven research project based on a shared course theme. The theme will vary depending on the subject expertise of the instructor. Prerequisite: Registration in Level 2 of a program in the Faculty of Social Sciences or Permission of the department. Antirequisite: SOCSCI 1SS3 Three Hours; one term Enrollment Cap: 30 Reserve Capacities: SS2: 100%.

SOCSCI 2WT0.name: Social Sciences Co-Op Work Term
SOCSCI 2WT0.prerequisites: SOCSCI 2JS1 and registration in a Social Sciences Co-op program option.

SOCSCI 3EL3.name: Leadership for Social Innovation
SOCSCI 3EL3.description: This interactive course explores the various models of leadership, diversity, power and change with an opportunity for students to gain practical experience through community based experiences. Three hours; one term.
SOCSCI 3EL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above in any program in the Faculty of Social Sciences or permission of the instructor

SOCSCI 3EP3.name: Social Sciences Experiential Project
SOCSCI 3EP3.description: Students will apply knowledge and skills from one or more Social Sciences disciplines to an experiential project such as a research project, community-engaged project, or work placement. The project will be conducted under the supervision of a Faculty of Social Sciences faculty member. The student will work with the faculty member to define learning objectives and assessment of those objectives. Students must contact the Office of the Associate Dean Academic for details on the application process. One term.
SOCSCI 3EP3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or IV of any Honours program. Permission of the Careers & Experiential Education Manager of the Faculty of Social Sciences is required.

SOCSCI 3JS1.name: Co-Op Job Search II
SOCSCI 3JS1.prerequisites: SOCSCI 2JS1, 2WT0 and registration in a Co-op program in the Faculty of Social Sciences.

SOCSCI 3WT0.name: Social Sciences Co-Op Work Term
SOCSCI 3WT0.prerequisites: SOCSCI 3JS1 and registration in a Co-op program option in the Faculty of Social Sciences.

SOCSCI 4JS1.name: Co-Op Job Search III
SOCSCI 4JS1.prerequisites: SOCSCI 3JS1, 3WT0 and registration in a Co-op program option in the Faculty of Social Sciences.

SOCSCI 4SI3.name: Innovation for Social Impact
SOCSCI 4SI3.description: This course provides students from Humanities, Social Sciences, and Business the opportunity to learn and apply social innovation skills in the non-profit sector. In the classroom, students will gain an understanding of key social innovation concepts including impact assessment, systems mapping, design thinking, collective impact, and theory of change while also learning about the unique characteristics and work environment of the non-profit sector. In the community, students will engage with a non-profit partner to help them conceptualize, develop, and/or implement a social innovation. Three hours (lectures); one term.
SOCSCI 4SI3.prerequisites: Registration in Level IV or above in any Bachelor of Commerce, Social Sciences, or Humanities program. Crosslist(s): COMMERCE 4SI3, HUMAN 4SI3 This course is administered by the DeGroote School of Business

SOCSCI 4WT0.name: Social Sciences Co-Op Work Term
SOCSCI 4WT0.prerequisites: SOCSCI 4JS1 and registration in a Co-op program option in the Faculty of Social Sciences.

SOCWORK 3C03.name: Social Aspects of Health and Illness
SOCWORK 3C03.description: Exploration of issues of health and illness, care delivery, the social determinants of health and contemporary challenges faced by social workers in health care settings. Lectures, discussion and selective use of community resources; one term.
SOCWORK 3C03.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work or Labour Studies program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or 1BB3 and registration in Level III or above of any program

SOCWORK 3I03.name: Social Work and Indigenous Peoples
SOCWORK 3I03.description: Examination of structural and cultural variables underlying the complex relationships between Indigenous communities and mainstream society, with particular attention to how they are played out in social work practice. Lectures, discussion, exercises; one term.
SOCWORK 3I03.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work or Labour Studies program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or 1BB3 ; and registration in Level III or above of any program.

SOCWORK 3O03.name: Social Work and Sexualities
SOCWORK 3O03.description: Examination of issues related to sexuality across the life course e.g. sexual development, sexual and gender identities/expressions, reproduction, relational and political dynamics associated with sexuality. Lectures, discussion, exercises; one term.
SOCWORK 3O03.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work or Labour Studies program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or 1BB3 ; and registration in Level III or above of any program

SOCWORK 3S03.name: Social Work, Disability and Dis/Ableism
SOCWORK 3S03.description: A critical engagement with Social Work and Disability Studies’ understandings of ‘disability’ and ‘dis/ableism’ to explore how they might intersect to inform social work practice. Lectures, discussion, exercises; one term.
SOCWORK 3S03.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work or Labour Studies program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or 1BB3 and registration in Level III or above of any program Not Open to students with credit in SOCWORK 4G03 if the topic was Social Work and Disability: Intersections and Exchanges.

SOCWORK 3T03.name: Poverty and Homelessness
SOCWORK 3T03.description: This course will critically examine social work practices and policies in response to poverty and homelessness including causes, lived experiences, service provision, alternate policy options and activist responses. Lectures, discussion, exercises; one term.
SOCWORK 3T03.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work or Labour Studies program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or 1BB3 ; and registration in Level III or above of any program Cross-list(s): LABRST 3T03 Not Open to students with credit in SOCWORK 4G03 if the topic was Poverty and Homelessness.

SOCWORK 4C03.name: Critical Perspectives on Race, Racialization, Racism and Colonialism in Canadian Society
SOCWORK 4C03.description: This course involves critical analysis of the social relations of race, racism, racialization, and colonialism in Canadian society. Students will have the opportunity to examine various theoretical frameworks including post/anti/neocolonial and decolonizing studies, critical race theory, Indigenous studies, African studies, analyses of whiteness and antiracism/anti-oppression.
SOCWORK 4C03.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work Work or Labour Studies program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or SOCWORK 1BB3 and registration in Level III or above of any program

SOCWORK 4G03.name: Selected Topics
SOCWORK 4G03.description: Critical examination of social work practice in respect to selected social issues. Topics will vary from year to year and the School should be consulted for details for any particular year. Lectures, Discussion, Exercises; one term.
SOCWORK 4G03.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work or Labour Studies program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or 1BB3 ; and registration in Level III or above of any program SOCWORK 4G03 may be repeated, if on a different topic.

SOCWORK 4J03.name: Social Change: Social Movements and Advocacy
SOCWORK 4J03.description: Students engage in experiential learning in the community with mentors to examine current theories and practice in the area of social change. Lectures, discussion, exercises and group work; one term.
SOCWORK 4J03.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work or Labour Studies program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or 1BB3 ; and registration in Level III or above of any program

SOCWORK 4QQ3.name: Indigenizing Social Work Practice Approaches
SOCWORK 4QQ3.description: This course examines the social worker’s role and responsibility in working with diverse Indigenous peoples such as First Nation, Metis and Inuit living on reserve and in urban areas. The concept and process of ethical tensions indigenizing social work practice approaches will be connected to indigenous philosophy and epistemology with the approach of understanding and building relationships and reconciliation between indigenous and non-indigenous peoples, as well practices within the social work profession. Lectures, discussion, exercises; one term.
SOCWORK 4QQ3.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work or Labour Studies program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or 1BB3 ; and registration in Level III or above of any program.

SOCWORK 4R03.name: Feminist Approaches to Social Work and Social Justice
SOCWORK 4R03.description: This course explores feminist frameworks and applies them to social work and social justice practices. Students will consider historical and present day feminist social work practice discourses, feminist critiques of social work practice, and critiques of feminist social work practice. This course will also explore themes of intersectionality, oppression, power, resistance, and activism. Lectures, Discussion, Exercises; one term.
SOCWORK 4R03.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work or Labour Studies program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or SOCWORK 1BB3 and registration in Level III or above of any program

SOCWORK 4U03.name: Immigration, Settlement and Social Work
SOCWORK 4U03.description: Examination of social and political factors impacting the lives of immigrants and refugees as they settle in Canada; critical assessment of social work responses. Lectures, discussion, exercises; one term.
SOCWORK 4U03.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work or Labour Studies program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or 1BB3 ; and registration in Level III or above of any program

SOCWORK 4W03.name: Child Welfare
SOCWORK 4W03.description: This course analyzes the Canadian child welfare system, its policies and programs and teaches skills for working with children, families and substitute caregivers. Lectures, discussions, skills development; one term.
SOCWORK 4W03.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work or Labour Studies program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or 1BB3 ; and registration in Level III or above of any program

SOCWORK 4Y03.name: Critical Issues in Mental Health & Addiction: Mad & Critical Disability Studies Perspectives for SW
SOCWORK 4Y03.description: Critical review of contemporary theoretical frameworks, policies and programs in mental health and addiction and the implications for social work research and practice in Canada. Lectures, discussion, exercises; one term.
SOCWORK 4Y03.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work or Labour Studies program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or 1BB3 ; and registration in Level III or above of any program

SOCWORK 1AA3.name: So You Think You Can Help? Introduction to Social Work I
SOCWORK 1AA3.description: A critical exploration of ideas and values influencing “helping” in social work. Focus on how helping is experienced by people intended to benefit from it. Lectures and discussions; one term Antirequisite(s): SOCWORK 1A06 A/B This course is available to all students.

SOCWORK 1BB3.name: Re-Imagining Help: Introduction to Social Work II
SOCWORK 1BB3.description: A critical exploration of alternative understandings and practices of ‘helping’ in social work rooted in inclusive engagement with service users/communities and respect for their knowledge. Lectures and discussions; one term Antirequisite(s): SOCWORK 1A06 A/B This course is available to all students.

SOCWORK 2BB3.name: Anti-Oppressive Social Work
SOCWORK 2BB3.description: The course provides a grounding in theories and knowledge that underpin anti-oppression, and explores the ways these get taken up in the work that social workers do. Exercises, lectures, discussion; one term.
SOCWORK 2BB3.prerequisites: Enrollment in a Social Work or Labour Studies program

SOCWORK 2CC3.name: Introduction to Community Practice
SOCWORK 2CC3.description: Understanding and analysis of social work practice within a community context that emphasizes the capacity of communities to initiate community action and social change. Lectures, discussion, exercises; one term.
SOCWORK 2CC3.prerequisites: Enrolment in a Labour Studies or Social Work program

SOCWORK 3E03.name: Individual Practice Across the Lifespan
SOCWORK 3E03.description: Examination of theories of social work practice with individuals at various life stages. Exploration of how social location and social context affects individual development and subsequent social work intervention. Lectures, discussion, exercises; one term Antirequisite(s): SOCWORK 3A03, 3N03, 3R03, 4N03.

SOCWORK 3F03.name: Social Work with Groups
SOCWORK 3F03.description: Students will develop effective, ethical group practice skills including assessment from multiple perspectives, facilitation and intervention skills, evaluation, to address the needs of diverse populations. Lectures, discussion, exercises, group work; one term.
SOCWORK 3F03.prerequisites: Enrolment in a Social Work program

SOCWORK 4SA3.name: Critical Child Welfare: From Theory to Practice
SOCWORK 4SA3.description: An advanced course on the development of knowledge, skills, and attitudes needed for child welfare work. Attention to the social/political factors that shape the way practice is imagined and delivered. Seminars, discussions, group work, case simulation, exercises; one term.
SOCWORK 4SA3.prerequisites: SOCWORK 2A06, 2BB3 and 4W03 (all with a minimum grade of C+), and instructor permission

SOCWORK 4TI3.name: Trauma Informed Practice
SOCWORK 4TI3.description: The course considers the historical, psychological/socio/political impact of trauma. Focusing on trauma theory, analysis and skill development, this course will cover various intersections of trauma that will enable social workers to understand and work from a client centered approach. Students are encouraged to critically examine the politics of trauma practices. Lectures, discussion, exercises; one term.
SOCWORK 4TI3.prerequisites: Registration in a Social Work program; or SOCWORK 1AA3 or SOCWORK 1BB3 and registration in Level III or above of any program

SOCWORK 4X03.name: Social Work with Families
SOCWORK 4X03.description: Examination and application of family theory and practice models including a critical look at societal definitions of and expectations for families. Lectures, discussion, exercises; one term.
SOCWORK 4X03.prerequisites: Credit or registration in SOCWORK 3D06 A/B S and 3DD6 A/B S ; or permission of the instructor

SOCWORK 4ZZ3.name: Social Welfare: Practice Implications and Advocacy
SOCWORK 4ZZ3.description: Provides an overview of Canada’s social service system from an historical and contemporary perspective. Explores the purpose and values underlying the development of social welfare programs. Engages in critical analysis of practice implications and policy advocacy for social workers. Lectures and discussion, one term.
SOCWORK 4ZZ3.prerequisites: Credit or registration in SOCWORK 3D06 A/B S and SOCWORK 3DD6 A/B S . The School of Social Work strongly suggests that students complete SOCWORK 3D06 A/B S and 3DD6 A/B S before taking this course.

SCAR 1B03.name: What on Earth is Religion?
SCAR 1B03.description: An introduction to the academic study of religion and religions focusing on key themes and on how scholars approach religiosity both historically and in contemporary global cultures. Topics covered may include truth and truth-claims, ritual and practice, myth and history, authority and power, community and conformity. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 1B06 A/B, RELIGST 1B03.

SCAR 1SC3.name: The Big Questions: Introduction to Society, Culture & Religion
SCAR 1SC3.description: This course focuses on the research of current faculty and senior graduate students in the Religious Studies Department to introduce some of the issues contemporary scholars are grappling with in the academic study of religion. Three hours (lecture and discussion); one term.

SCAR 2AA3.name: Introduction to Modern Standard Arabic
SCAR 2AA3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2AA3 This course introduces students to the basics of the Arabic language. Students will learn the Arabic alphabet, pronunciation, verb forms, and basic grammar. No prior knowledge of Arabic is necessary. Lectures and discussion (four hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2AA3 Cross-list(s): ARABIC 2AA3 NOTE: this course is intended for students with no background in Arabic. Students with any background in Arabic must contact the instructor for an assessment/placement test to determine the appropriate level of Arabic: 2AA3, 2AR3, or 3AA3.

SCAR 2AB3.name: Archaeology and the Bible
SCAR 2AB3.description: Formerly RELIGST 1AB3 Archaeological discoveries have revolutionized the way in which we read the Bible. This course explores archaeology and ancient texts, both canonical and non-canonical, in light of each other with a view to reconstructing key moments in the history of Judaism and Christianity. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 1AB3, 2AB3.

SCAR 2AM3.name: Abraham in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam
SCAR 2AM3.description: Formerly RELIGST 1L03 This course looks at the early depictions of the central figure of Abraham, as well as Sarah and Hagar, Isaac and Ishmael, in what scholars often refer to as the three Abrahamic Faiths. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 1L03.

SCAR 2AP3.name: Apocalypse, Then and Now
SCAR 2AP3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2AP3 How did ancient Jews and Christians portray the end of the world? How do such depictions affect current religious and secular portrayals of the end of the world in modern writing and cinema? Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2AP3.

SCAR 2AR3.name: Introduction to Modern Standard Arabic II
SCAR 2AR3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2AR3 This course builds on the fundamentals covered in SCAR 2AA3. The course expands students’ vocabulary, reading fluency, composition skills, and knowledge of grammatical constructions. Lectures and discussion (four hours); one term.
SCAR 2AR3.prerequisites: One of ARABIC 2AA3 , RELIGST 2AA3, SCAR 2AA3 ; or permission of the instructor

SCAR 2BA3.name: The Bible Then and Now
SCAR 2BA3.description: This course will introduce students to the academic study of the Bible, from its early history as a book to its modern use. Three hours (lecture and discussion); one term.

SCAR 2BB3.name: Images of the Divine Feminine
SCAR 2BB3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2BB3 An examination of some of the ways the divine has been portrayed as feminine in diverse cultures. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2BB3, WOMENST 2BB3 Cross-list(s): GENDRST 2BB3.

SCAR 2BE3.name: The Bible and the Environment
SCAR 2BE3.description: Agrarianism stresses the need for us to structure living in order that humanity might live in healthful relationship with everything around us: humans, animals, plants, and the land. The purpose of this course will be to read biblical passages in light of the recent agrarian thinking of writers such as Wendell Berry, Wes Jackson, and Norman Wirzba. How does the Bible portray humanity’s relationship to the earth and other living creatures? Can modern people find resources within Jewish and Christian scriptures to help live more peaceably and justly with all aspects of our world? Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.

SCAR 2BM3.name: Bible and Magic
SCAR 2BM3.description: This course examines various reference to magic preserved in the Biblical texts and how the Bible itself as a material object has been perceived to possess supernatural powers. Lectures, discussion (three hours); one term.

SCAR 2BN3.name: Sex and the City in Buddhism: The Urban Life of Buddhist Nuns in North India
SCAR 2BN3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2BN3 A survey of sex, celibacy, family, married monks, pregnant nuns, monastic motherhood, entrepreneurial ecclesiastics, and other hopelessly romanticized topics in scholarly portrayals of Buddhism. Two lectures; one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2BN3.

SCAR 2CA3.name: Religion and the Arts
SCAR 2CA3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2CA3, revised An exploration of the encounters between religious traditions and practices and the performing and visual arts. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.

SCAR 2CH3.name: Introduction to Christianity
SCAR 2CH3.description: A survey of the development of some of the essential concepts, practices, and institutions of Christian religion. Three hours (lecture and discussion); one term.

SCAR 2EE3.name: Prophets, Priests, and Sorcerers
SCAR 2EE3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2EE3 This course analyzes various religious experts that appear in the Biblical texts in their ancient cultural contexts. Religious expertise of antiquity and their skills will be compared to contemporary figures that access, interpret, and transmit divine knowledge. Lectures, discussion; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2EE3.

SCAR 2ER3.name: Religion, the Body, and the Machine
SCAR 2ER3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2ER3 This course will focus on the religious ethics of embodiment in various technological contexts of contemporary life (e.g., bioengineering and eugenics, medically assisted suicide, designer babies, cosmetic enhancement, and artificial intelligence). Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2ER3.

SCAR 2F03.name: Storytelling in Asian Religions
SCAR 2F03.description: Formerly RELIGST 2F03 An in-depth study of selected examples of story literature in China, Japan, India, and Tibet with attention to the way religion is represented. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): JAPANST 3H03, RELIGST 2I03, 2F03, 3H03.

SCAR 2FF3.name: Pirates, Pilgrims, and Enslaved in the Mediterranean, 1450-1750
SCAR 2FF3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2FF3 This course examines the Mediterranean region as a zone of intense cultural interaction. Particular emphasis will be given to the interaction between Christian, Jewish and Islamic societies. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
SCAR 2FF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above Cross-list(s): HISTORY 2HH3
SCAR 2FF3.antirequisites: RELIGST 2FF3 This course is administered by the Department of History.

SCAR 2G03.name: Religious Themes in Modern Culture
SCAR 2G03.description: Formerly RELIGST 1I03 An introduction to religious themes, imagery and issues through a study of selected works of modern literature (novels, short stories, poetry, drama), music, art, and film. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 1I03, 1I06.

SCAR 2GB3.name: Great Books in Asian Religions
SCAR 2GB3.description: Formerly RELIGST 1J03 This course introduces foundational books of the major religious traditions of Asia, including Buddhism, Hinduism, Taoism, Confucianism, and Shinto, in their historical and cultural contexts. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 1J03.

SCAR 2GG3.name: Who was Jesus?
SCAR 2GG3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2GG3 A study of the Gospels. Special attention will be given to the possible literary relationships among the Gospels as well as to the distinctive features of their Jesus stories. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2GG3.

SCAR 2GR3.name: Evil
SCAR 2GR3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2GR3 An examination of understandings of reason and evil in ancient Greek, medieval Christian, and modern times, and of how these understandings are related to accounts of the nature of God. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2GR3.

SCAR 2HA3.name: Religion and Health in Antiquity
SCAR 2HA3.description: This course examines health care in ancient Jewish and Christian texts. It focuses on rituals led by priests and prophets as well as various household rituals. Participants explore how concepts of health, magic, and religion are connected in antiquity. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.

SCAR 2HB3.name: Introduction to the Jewish Scriptures/Old Testament
SCAR 2HB3.description: Formerly RELISGT 2HB3 An introduction to the writings of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament in their historical setting, to their role as scripture in Jewish and Christian tradition, and to various methodologies used in their modern academic study. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 1D06 A/B, 2HB3.

SCAR 2HC3.name: Introduction to Biblical Hebrew I
SCAR 2HC3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2HC3 Hebrew Bible. The student will begin to read in the Hebrew Bible. Two lectures (four hours); one term Antirequisite(s): HEBREW 2A06, RELIGST 2HC3 Cross-list(s): HEBREW 2A03.

SCAR 2HD3.name: Introduction to Biblical Hebrew II
SCAR 2HD3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2HD3 An introduction to more grammar, syntax, and vocabulary of the language of the Hebrew Bible. The knowledge acquired should enable the student to read the simple prose and poetry of the Hebrew Bible. Two lectures (four hours); one term.
SCAR 2HD3.prerequisites: HEBREW 2A03 or permission of the instructor

SCAR 2HR3.name: Humour and Religion
SCAR 2HR3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2HR3 Starting with Freud’s theoretical accounts, this course explores the ways in which scholars have analyzed the relationship between religion and humour. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2HR3.

SCAR 2IR3.name: Hollywood/Bollywood and Indian Religions
SCAR 2IR3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2IR3 A survey of depictions of Indian religious traditions in select films from around the world. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2IR3.

SCAR 2J03.name: Introduction to Judaism
SCAR 2J03.description: Formerly RELIGST 2J03 Survey of major facets of Jewish religion and identity from antiquity to the present, including foundational texts, major historical developments and central beliefs and practices. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2J03.

SCAR 2K03.name: Introduction to Buddhism
SCAR 2K03.description: Formerly RELIGST 2K03 A survey of the developments of the essential concepts, practices, and institutions of the Buddhist religion, emphasizing its role in the history and culture of Asian societies. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2K03.

SCAR 2LL3.name: God and Philosophy
SCAR 2LL3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2LL3 A study of conceptions of religious belief, knowledge, and God in the history of modern thought up to the 20th century, with special attention to major challenges to the role of religious faith in human existence. Authors may include: Descartes, Hume, Kant, Schleiermacher, Nietzsche, Dostoevsky, Kierkegaard, Camus, Buber, Levinas. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIG ST 2LL3, 3MM3.

SCAR 2M03.name: Death and Dying: Comparative Views
SCAR 2M03.description: Formerly RELIGST 2M03 A comparative survey of the diversity of social and ritual practices, religious beliefs, and emotional responses surrounding death in a variety of non-Western cultural contexts. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2M03.

SCAR 2MT3.name: Asian Meditation Traditions
SCAR 2MT3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2MT3 A study of the historical traditions and modern transformations of Asian religious practices of meditation and mental cultivation. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2MT3.

SCAR 2MW3.name: Religion, Magic, and Witchcraft
SCAR 2MW3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2MW3 Selected issues in the study of religion, magic and witchcraft, science and the supernatural. Perspectives from history, psychology, and sociology also will be discussed. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
SCAR 2MW3.prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology and registration in Level II or above in any program
SCAR 2MW3.antirequisites: RELIGST 2MW3 Cross-list(s): ANTHROP 2R03 This course is administered by the Department of Anthropology.

SCAR 2N03.name: Death and Dying: The Western Experience
SCAR 2N03.description: Formerly RELIGST 2N03 Drawing on theoretical perspectives and evidence from anthropology and sociology, this course examines death and dying in Western contexts, focusing on biomedical, social, and cultural themes. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2N03.

SCAR 2NH3.name: Gods, Ghosts, and Gandharvas: A Survey of Non-Human Realms in Asian Religions
SCAR 2NH3.description: This course will provide a survey of various non-human realms and their inhabitants in Asian Religions. Lectures, discussion (three hours); one term.

SCAR 2NT3.name: The New Testament
SCAR 2NT3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2NT3 An introduction to the writings of the New Testament in their historical setting, to their role as scripture in the Christian tradition, and to various methodologies used in their modern academic study. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 1D06 A/B, 2NT3.

SCAR 2Q03.name: Introduction to Islam
SCAR 2Q03.description: Formerly RELIGST 2Q03 The origins and early history of Islam with an emphasis on the Koran and the early Muslim community. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2Q03.

SCAR 2QQ3.name: Cults, Conspiracies and Close Encounters
SCAR 2QQ3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2QQ3 Why are people often attracted to ‘alternative’ perspectives and religious movements? This course explores the evolution and social impact of ‘cults,’ conspiracies, and close encounters, including the historical, cultural, political, and religious dynamics that inform all three, using a variety of critical methods. One Lecture (Two hours), one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2QQ3.

SCAR 2RD3.name: Religion and Diversity
SCAR 2RD3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2RD3 This course examines religious practices and traditions in the context of multicultural, diverse societies. Issues to be focused on may include: the intersection of particular religious practices and beliefs and civil rights, medical ethics, and legal issues. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2RD3.

SCAR 2RN3.name: Frenemies: Science and Religion in the News
SCAR 2RN3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2RN3 Is there a conflict between science and religion? This course examines the tension between science and religion, and explores topical issues reported in the news that illustrate the encounter between science and religion in the public square. One Lecture (two hours); one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2RN3.

SCAR 2RS3.name: Religion and the Stars
SCAR 2RS3.description: This course explores religious practices and beliefs concerning the stars and planets. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.

SCAR 2SA3.name: Encountering the Sacred
SCAR 2SA3.description: This course introduces ethnographic approaches to the study of Asian religions. Students will conduct their own ethnographic research on a local religious figure or community. Three hours (lecture and discussion); one term.

SCAR 2SB3.name: Introduction to Sanskrit II
SCAR 2SB3.description: This course will continue the study of Sanskrit grammar. Lectures, discussion (four hours); one term.
SCAR 2SB3.antirequisites: RELIGST 3SA6 A/B, SANSKRIT 3A06 A/B, SCAR 3SA6 A/B Cross-list(s): SANSKRIT 2B03

SCAR 2SG3.name: Spirits, Ghosts, and Demons
SCAR 2SG3.description: This course examines ghosts, demons, and spirits in a range of cultural, contemporary, and historical settings. Special attention is paid to historical and contemporary moral panics, as well as how ghosts, demons, and spirits influence human health and well-being. Two Lectures, one tutorial; one term.

SCAR 2SK3.name: Introduction to Sanskrit I
SCAR 2SK3.description: Introduction to the Sanskrit alphabet and basic grammar. No previous knowledge of Sanskrit is required. Lectures, discussion (four hours); one term.
SCAR 2SK3.antirequisites: RELIGST 3SA6 A/B, SANSKRIT 3A06 A/B, SCAR 3SA6 A/B Cross-list(s): SANSKRIT 2A03

SCAR 2SP3.name: Sport and/as Religion
SCAR 2SP3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2SP3 An examination of relationships between sport and religion, including ritual aspects of sport, connections between social collectivities and sports teams, and sport as meaning-making activity. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2SP3 Cross-list(s): ANTHROP 2EE3.

SCAR 2TA3.name: Islam in North America
SCAR 2TA3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2TA3 This course will explore the history and different expressions of North American Islam. Students will compare and contrast the different manifestations of Islam in North America. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2TA3 Cross-list(s): SOCIOL 2TA3.

SCAR 2TT3.name: Religion and Popular Culture in Contemporary Japan
SCAR 2TT3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2TT3 An introduction to the study of Japanese popular culture in the contemporary period and the religious traditions and world-views that inform it through textual, visual and other multi-media sources, including manga and anime. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): JAPANST 2TT3, RELIGST 2TT3.

SCAR 2UD3.name: Utopias, Dystopias
SCAR 2UD3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2UD3 Utopias and dystopias have become widespread in modern culture. This course discusses the origin and character of utopias and dystopias through an examination of their presentation in various works of modern literature, movies, and TV series. Two lectures, one tutorial, one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2UD3.

SCAR 2VV3.name: The Bible as Literature
SCAR 2VV3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2VV3 An examination of narratives from the Hebrew Bible, Intertestamental literature, and New Testament, from a literary perspective. Attention is paid to narrative features such as character, plot, irony, and symbolism, as well as to the dynamics of the reading experience. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): COMPLIT 2G03, RELIGST 2VV3.

SCAR 2WW3.name: Health, Healing and Religion: Western Perspectives
SCAR 2WW3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2WW3 An overview of the intersection of religious beliefs and practices with concepts of health, wellness, and possibilities for healing in both traditional and contemporary Western contexts. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.

SCAR 2WX3.name: Health, Healing and Religion: Comparative Views
SCAR 2WX3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2WX3 A comparative survey of the intersection of religious beliefs and practices with concepts of health, wellness, and possibilities for healing in a variety of non-Western cultural contexts, both traditional and contemporary. Two lectures, one tutorial, one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2WX3.

SCAR 2YY3.name: The Bible and Film
SCAR 2YY3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2YY3 An examination of the use of the Bible in a variety of films. Genres may include biblical epic, horror, sci-fi, Western, comedy, film noir, animated feature, music video. Topics include the depiction of biblical themes, images, and values in motion pictures as well as their transformation. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2YY3.

SCAR 3AA3.name: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic
SCAR 3AA3.description: An intermediate course enhancing skills in modern standard Arabic through reading materials with the goal of improving comprehension in both written and spoken contexts. Four hours (lectures); one term.
SCAR 3AA3.prerequisites: One of ARABIC 2AR3 , RELIGST 2AR3, or SCAR 2AR3 ; or permission of the Instructor Cross-list(s): ARABIC 3AA3

SCAR 3AR3.name: Culture and Religion
SCAR 3AR3.description: Formerly RELISG 3AR3 This course introduces key theorists and theories, classic and current topics, and issues of methodology and writing in the study of religion and culture. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
SCAR 3AR3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SCAR 3BE3.name: Buddhist Ethics
SCAR 3BE3.description: This course provides an overview of Buddhist ethics with several in-depth studies of Buddhist attitudes towards topics of interest in contemporary ethical debates. Three hours (lecture and discussion); one term.

SCAR 3BW3.name: Gender in Ancient Eastern Mediterranean
SCAR 3BW3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2B03 This course analyzes gender roles in Biblical literature and other texts of Ancient Near East and Mediterranean regions. By examining how gender is depicted in different genres of literature and material artifacts, we will learn about ancient authors’ understanding of gender identities. Lectures, discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2B03, WOMENST 2B03, 3BW3 Cross-list(s): GENDRST 3BW3.

SCAR 3C03.name: Islam in the Modern World
SCAR 3C03.description: Formerly RELIGST 3C03 The spread of Islam, Islam as a minority community, the role of women in Islam and fundamentalism. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
SCAR 3C03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SCAR 3CC3.name: Religion and Politics
SCAR 3CC3.description: Formerly RELIGST 3CC3 The relationship between religion and politics is explored by way of readings by Locke, Rousseau and Schmitt, and case studies concerning the place of religion in public life. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
SCAR 3CC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SCAR 3DD3.name: Jews and Jesus
SCAR 3DD3.description: Formerly RELIGST 3DD3 A study of Judaism in the Greco-Roman world. The course will explore selected questions in political history, the development of sects and parties, the role of the temple, apocalypticism, and the Dead Sea Scrolls. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
SCAR 3DD3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SCAR 3E03.name: Japanese Film and Religion
SCAR 3E03.description: Formerly RELIGST 3E03 An exploration of Japanese religion and culture in a wide variety of visual media, including film, anime, and television. Topics will include Buddhism, Shinto, New Religions, asceticism, ghosts, shamanism, ancestor worship, and Japanese identities. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): JAPAN ST 3E03, RELIGST 3E03.

SCAR 3EE3.name: Sacred Journeys
SCAR 3EE3.description: Formerly RELIGST 3EE3 A study of the significance of travel in various religious traditions, focusing on shrines, pilgrimages, and the inter-relationships between secular and sacred travel. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
SCAR 3EE3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SCAR 3EP3.name: Jewish Ethics and Politics
SCAR 3EP3.description: This course explores connections between Jewish philosophical traditions, political issues, and ethical questions. Three hours (lecture and discussion); one term.

SCAR 3ET3.name: Anthropology of Ethics
SCAR 3ET3.description: This course explores the classical anthropological question of how ethical value is shaped and contested. Grounded in ethnography studies of specific ethical traditions (both religious and secular), course topics may include the problem of suffering, the prospect of human freedom, the cultivation of virtue, and the development of moral obligations. Seminar (three hours); one term Prerequisites: Three units of Level I Anthropology or three units of Level I SCAR or permission of the instructor Cross-list(s): ANTHROP 3ET3.

SCAR 3F03.name: Approaches to the Study of Religion
SCAR 3F03.description: Formerly RELIGST 3F03 An exploration of some of the ways religious phenomena are studied. Attention is also given to the history of the academic study of religion. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SCAR 3F03.prerequisites: Six units of Religious Studies or Society, Culture and Religion courses above Level I

SCAR 3FF3.name: Gender and Religion
SCAR 3FF3.description: Formerly RELIGST 3FF3 An examination of gender in one or more religious traditions. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
SCAR 3FF3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SCAR 3GH3.name: Interdisciplinary Global Health Field Course: Maternal and Infant Health in Morocco
SCAR 3GH3.description: Formerly RELIGST 3GH3 This global health field course provides an integrated linguistic, cultural, historical, and public health experience in Morocco. Introduces students to the determinants of health in the third world and considers social, religious, epidemiological, economic, technological, legal, historical, and family issues that impact birth, pregnancy, women’s health, and health of newborns and children.
SCAR 3GH3.prerequisites: Permission of the instructor Co-requisite(s): ARABIC 3GH3
SCAR 3GH3.antirequisites: HISTORY 3GH3, RELIGST 3GH3 Cross-list(s): ANTHROP 3GH3 Available as a study-abroad experience in the Spring only. This course is intended for students who are entering Level III or above in the following Fall/Winter Session. Students interested in this course must contact Dr. E. Amster by February 15 for application instructions. There is an additional cost associated with this course. This course is administered by the Department of Religious Studies.

SCAR 3HC3.name: Intermediate Hebrew I
SCAR 3HC3.description: Formerly RELIGST 3HC3 A reading course in classical (biblical) Hebrew. Sample texts will be read from some or all of the following: the Hebrew Bible, Mishnah, ancient Hebrew inscriptions and the Dead Sea Scrolls. Two lectures (four hours); one term.
SCAR 3HC3.prerequisites: HEBREW 2B03 or permission of the instructor

SCAR 3HD3.name: Intermediate Hebrew II
SCAR 3HD3.description: Formerly RELIGST 3HD3 Further sample texts will be read from some or all of the following: the Hebrew Bible, the Mishnah, ancient inscriptions and the Dead Sea Scrolls. Two lectures (four hours); one term.
SCAR 3HD3.prerequisites: HEBREW 2B03 or permission of the instructor

SCAR 3JJ3.name: Social Justice
SCAR 3JJ3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2CE3 Some of the central founding influences on conceptions of social justice in the contemporary ‘west’ are religious texts and figures. An exploration of contested examples and their ongoing importance in everyday discourses and practices of the ethics of justice. Lectures, discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2CE3.

SCAR 3LL3.name: Human Being/Being Human
SCAR 3LL3.description: Formerly RELIGST 3LL3 Conceptions of what it means to be human and visions of human flourishing and fulfilment, especially those related to ethics and politics, are often rooted in religious traditions. A study of philosophical, scientific, and religious anthropologies by way of literature, art and film. Lectures, discussion (3 hours); one term.
SCAR 3LL3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SCAR 3PA3.name: The Birth of Christianity
SCAR 3PA3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2HH3 A study of the controversial role played by Paul in the definition and expansion of early Christianity, based on the Acts of the Apostles and Paul’s own extant correspondence. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2HH3.

SCAR 3R03.name: Death and the Afterlife in Early Judaism and Christianity
SCAR 3R03.description: Formerly RELIGST 3R03 An examination of the variety of ways in which physical death and the afterlife were understood in biblical and post-biblical Judaism as well as in the New Testament and early Christianity. Among the topics to be considered are the netherworld, immortality, and resurrection, as well as the relationship of these concepts to issues of faith and morality. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
SCAR 3R03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SCAR 3RB3.name: Ethnicity, Race, and the Bible
SCAR 3RB3.description: Formerly RELIGST 2RB3 This course will examine the variety of ethnic discourses that exist within the Bible. In what ways did biblical writers construct ethnic identity and how has the Bible been used in modern racial ideologies? Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2RB3.

SCAR 3RC3.name: Race, Religion, and Coloniality
SCAR 3RC3.description: We will read accounts of how notions of race and religion emerged in the modern age of colonial expansion, and contemporary theories of antiracism and decolonization. Lectures, discussion (three hours); one term.
SCAR 3RC3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SCAR 3RL3.name: Religion and Law
SCAR 3RL3.description: The notion of law has deep roots in religious thought and writing. This course will survey the historical development of law in the western world in connection with various religious traditions, with a focus on Judaism and Christianity. It will also address some contemporary issues and tensions between religion and law in pluralistic, secular societies. Three hours (lecture and discussion); one term Cross-list(s): ARTSSCI 3RL3.

SCAR 3S03.name: The East Asian Religious Tradition
SCAR 3S03.description: Formerly RELIGST 3S03 Readings in East Asian religious texts in translation will concentrate on themes such as culture vs. nature, virtue vs. power, social responsibility vs. personal cultivation, bookish learning vs. meditation. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
SCAR 3S03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III and above

SCAR 3SA3.name: Advanced Readings in Sanskrit
SCAR 3SA3.description: This course introduces students to selected readings in Sanskrit texts. Lectures, discussion (four hours); one term.
SCAR 3SA3.antirequisites: RELIGST 4B06 A/B, SANSKRIT 4B06 A/B Cross-list(s): SANSKRIT 3A03

SCAR 3SB3.name: Advanced Readings in Sanskrit
SCAR 3SB3.description: Intermediate course with readings in selected Sanskrit texts. Lectures, discussion (four hours); one term.
SCAR 3SB3.antirequisites: RELIGST 4B06 A/B, SANSKRIT 4B06 A/B Cross-list(s): SANSKRIT 3B03

SCAR 3SM3.name: Secular Modernity?
SCAR 3SM3.description: Modernity, including modern politics and modern thought, has long been characterized as secular, and scholars speak of a ‘return of religion’ in our times. But was modernity ever secular? Through history, theory, ideology, and art, we will recover a more complicated relationship between religion and modernity than usually imagined. Lectures, discussion (three hours); one term.
SCAR 3SM3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SCAR 3U03.name: The Buddhist Tradition in India
SCAR 3U03.description: Formerly RELIGST 2BT3 A study of the origins and early development of Indian Buddhism, largely through readings in Buddhist scripture (pre-Mahayana and Mahayana) in translation. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Antirequisite(s): RELIGST 2BT3, 3U03.

SCAR 3US3.name: Uses and Abuses of the Bible
SCAR 3US3.description: This course examines the ways the Bible has been invoked over the centuries to support or challenge cultural, social and political ideals, goals, and policies. Three hours (lecture and discussion); one term.

SCAR 3UU3.name: Zen Buddhism
SCAR 3UU3.description: Formerly RELIGST 3UU3 An examination of myth, history, doctrine, monastic culture, and ritual practices in East Asian Buddhism. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
SCAR 3UU3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above, and three units from the Asian Religions Field of Study

SCAR 3X03.name: Mysticism
SCAR 3X03.description: Formerly RELIGST 3X03 An examination of mysticism in one or more religious traditions. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
SCAR 3X03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SCAR 3Y03.name: Love
SCAR 3Y03.description: Formerly RELIGST 3Y03 A discussion of the variety of accounts of love in Western civilization from the time of the ancient Greeks and the rise of Christianity to modernity. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
SCAR 3Y03.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SCAR 3ZZ3.name: Judaism in the Modern World
SCAR 3ZZ3.description: Formerly RELIGST 3ZZ3 Jews and Judaism in a century of catastrophe and renewal. The progress of Emancipation; Jews in Canada and the U.S.; the Jewish catastrophe in Europe; the Jewish state; Jewish identities in literature and the arts. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term.
SCAR 3ZZ3.prerequisites: Registration in Level II or above

SCAR 4AE3.name: Academic Engagement in Society, Culture & Religion
SCAR 4AE3.description: This course offers students the opportunity to engage with scholars of Religious Studies through public lectures, published writings, etc., and to reflect on their own cultivation of scholarly approaches to the study of religion. The course is run primarily as an independent study with small group discussions and various writing assignments. Independent Study.
SCAR 4AE3.prerequisites: Enrolment in any one of the following: Level IV Combined Honours B. A., Society, Culture & Religion or Religious Studies and Another subject; Level IV Honours Society, Culture & Religion or Religious Studies B.A; Level III Society, Culture & Religion or Religious Studies B.A.

SCAR 4Q03.name: Advanced Readings in Society, Culture and Religion
SCAR 4Q03.description: Formerly RELIGST 4Q03 Independent study of special topics in Society, Culture and Religion One term.
SCAR 4Q03.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above of an Honours Society, Culture and Religion program and permission of the instructor RELIG ST 4Q03 may be repeated, to a total of six units, if on a different topic

SCAR 4SC3.name: Society, Culture & Religion Seminar
SCAR 4SC3.description: Formerly RELIGST 4SC3 Students read the work of, and engage with, a different faculty member from the department each week. One lecture, one term.
SCAR 4SC3.prerequisites: Enrolment in level III or above in Society, Culture, and Religion or by permission of the instructor

SOCIOL 1C03.name: Canadian Society: Social Problems, Social Policy, and the Law
SOCIOL 1C03.description: An examination of Canadian social policy and the law in intimate relationships and families, work, immigration, health, and the criminal justice system. Two lectures, one tutorial, one term.

SOCIOL 1Z03.name: An Introduction to Sociology
SOCIOL 1Z03.description: A survey of the areas of research which interest the sociologist. Interpretation of human action from the standpoint of the group. Two lectures, one tutorial, one term Antirequisite(s): SOCIOL 1A06 A/B.

SOCIOL 2BB3.name: Sociology of Deviance
SOCIOL 2BB3.description: An introduction to the sociological study of deviance covering key concepts, ideas, methods and different forms of deviant behaviour. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2BB3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2CC3.name: Constructing Deviance
SOCIOL 2CC3.description: An exploration of how individuals and behaviours are defined as deviant and the consequences of these definitional processes. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2CC3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2DD3.name: Immigration and the Canadian Mosaic
SOCIOL 2DD3.description: This course overviews contemporary international migration and immigrant integration with emphasis on Canada. Topics include migration theories, immigration policies, socioeconomic integration, and the second generation. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2DD3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2EE3.name: Introduction to Indigenous-Settler Relations in Canada
SOCIOL 2EE3.description: An overview of Indigenous-settler relations in Canada, including the history of colonization and the sociological aspects of contemporary identities, inequalities, conflicts, and social movements. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2EE3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03, or one of INDIGST 1A03 or 1AA3, and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2FF3.name: The Sociology of ‘Race’ and Ethnicity
SOCIOL 2FF3.description: An introduction to the study of “race” and ethnicity. The course examines theoretical, empirical, and policy issues related to racism, discrimination, identity, multiculturalism, and social integration. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2FF3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2GG3.name: Sociology of Education
SOCIOL 2GG3.description: An exploration of formal schooling and the broader education system in Western society with an emphasis on application of sociological theory to educational practices. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2GG3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2HH3.name: Sociology of Gender
SOCIOL 2HH3.description: An introduction to the sociology of gender, including empirical and theoretical dimensions. The course will emphasize social construction, social institutions, and cultural dimensions. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
SOCIOL 2HH3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2JJ3.name: Race, Class, Gender, and Sexuality
SOCIOL 2JJ3.description: The sociology of race, class, gender and sexuality examines structural and cultural inequalities through an intersectional lens. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2JJ3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2KK3.name: Introduction to Classical Sociological Theory
SOCIOL 2KK3.description: An exploration of theories developed up to the early 20th century (including the ideas of Marx, Durkheim, Weber, and the early theorists of gender or “race”). Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2KK3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and registration in any Sociology program

SOCIOL 2LL3.name: Introduction to Contemporary Sociological Theory
SOCIOL 2LL3.description: An exploration of theories developed from the early 20th century to the present (such as the work of neo-Marxists, symbolic interactionists, feminists, and globalization theorists). Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2LL3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and SOCIOL 2KK3 and registration in any Sociology program

SOCIOL 2PP3.name: Sociology of Families
SOCIOL 2PP3.description: An introduction to theoretical, historical, contemporary, and comparative perspectives on intimate relationships, households, and families. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2PP3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2QQ3.name: Dynamics and Transitions in Intimate Relationships and Families
SOCIOL 2QQ3.description: An analysis of diversity in intimate relationships and families, including relationship formation and dissolution, caregiving, paid and unpaid labour, and social policy. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2QQ3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2R03.name: Perspectives on Social Inequality
SOCIOL 2R03.description: This course will introduce the student to major theories of social inequality, such as the Marxian, Weberian and structural-functionalist perspectives. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2R03.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2RR3.name: Case Studies of Social Inequality
SOCIOL 2RR3.description: This course will introduce the student to the empirical literature on social inequality. Depending on the year, the focus will be on class, status, power and elites, income, education, region, age, gender and race/ethnicity. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2RR3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2SS3.name: Sociology of Work and Occupations
SOCIOL 2SS3.description: This course examines the nature and meaning of work in relation to labour market, economic, and demographic changes in Canada over the last century. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2SS3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2T03.name: Sociology of Sport
SOCIOL 2T03.description: This course provides a detailed theoretical and empirical examination of how sport is culturally organized, experienced and mediated. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2T03.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2TA3.name: Islam In North America
SOCIOL 2TA3.description: This course will explore the history and different expressions of North American Islam. Students will compare and contrast different expressions of Islam in North America. Two lectures, one tutorial; one term Cross-list(s): RELIGST 2TA3.

SOCIOL 2UU3.name: Indigenous Ontologies and Ways of Knowing
SOCIOL 2UU3.description: This course will examine the ways in which Indigenous peoples understand themselves as social beings and societies. Indigenous theories and ways of knowing will be drawn from various Indigenous societies throughout North America. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
SOCIOL 2UU3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03, or one of INDIGST 1A03, 1AA3 or RECONCIL 1A03, and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2VV3.name: Law and Society
SOCIOL 2VV3.description: This course considers theoretical perspectives on the role of law in society and sociological research addressing areas such as criminal law, family law, environmental law, immigration law, and media law. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2VV3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2WW3.name: Media and Power
SOCIOL 2WW3.description: This course examines how the production and content of various media are linked to powerful organizations and challenged by subordinated groups through struggles over media policy or resistance through alternative media. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2WW3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 2Z03.name: Introduction to Sociological Research
SOCIOL 2Z03.description: This course is designed to develop those skills necessary to pursue and understand research. Several general methods of sociological research will be examined. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 2Z03.prerequisites: Registration in a Sociology or Social Work program
SOCIOL 2Z03.antirequisites: ANTHROP 2Z03, CMST 2A03, GEO 2HR3, GEOG 2MA3, GERONTOL 2C03, HLTHAGE 2A03 , 2A06, 3Z06, HEALTHST 2B03, SOCPSY 2K03

SOCIOL 3A03.name: Advanced Analysis of Classical Sociological Theory
SOCIOL 3A03.description: An advanced examination of classical sociological theory. Work to be discussed might include Marx, Weber, Durkheim, Mead, Cooley, Du Bois and Freud. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3A03.prerequisites: SOCIOL 2KK3 and 2LL3 and registration in Level III of any Honours Sociology program

SOCIOL 3B03.name: Selected Topics in the Sociology of Education
SOCIOL 3B03.description: An examination of selected topics in the sociology of education. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3B03.prerequisites: SOCIOL 2GG3 SOCIOL 3B03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

SOCIOL 3D03.name: Special Topics in the Sociology of the Family
SOCIOL 3D03.description: An advanced course allowing detailed study of selected topics in the sociology of the family. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3D03.prerequisites: SOCIOL 2PP3 or 2QQ3 SOCIOL 3D03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units. Priority will be given to students registered in a Sociology program.

SOCIOL 3FF3.name: Introduction to Quantitative Research Methods
SOCIOL 3FF3.description: This course introduces the basic principles of statistics used in sociological research. The focus will be on selecting, applying, and interpreting statistics for data analyses. Three hours (lectures and labs); one term.
SOCIOL 3FF3.prerequisites: SOCIOL 2Z03 and registration in Level III of any Honours Sociology program

SOCIOL 3G03.name: Sociology of Health Care
SOCIOL 3G03.description: Selected issues concerning forms of providing health care. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3G03.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above Priority will be given to students registered in a Sociology program.

SOCIOL 3K03.name: Special Topics in Sociological Analysis II
SOCIOL 3K03.description: Same as SOCIOL 3J03. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3K03.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above SOCIOL 3K03 may be repeated, if on a different topic, to a total of six units.

SOCIOL 3KK3.name: Genocide: Sociological and Political Perspectives
SOCIOL 3KK3.description: An examination of genocide and other extreme crimes against humanity. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
SOCIOL 3KK3.prerequisites: Registration in Level III or above
SOCIOL 3KK3.antirequisites: SOCSCI 2C03 Cross-list(s): POLSCI 3KK3 Priority will be given to students registered in a Political Science or Sociology program. This course is administered by the Department of Political Science .

SOCIOL 3MH3.name: Sociology of Stress and Mental Health
SOCIOL 3MH3.description: This course will emphasize the unique perspective sociology offers in the larger interdisciplinary discussion of stress and mental health. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3MH3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or SOCIOL 1Z03 and enrollment in Level III or above.

SOCIOL 3MM3.name: Political Sociology
SOCIOL 3MM3.description: This course examines the field of political sociology, including power, the state, policy, and social change. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3MM3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above Enrolment priority will be given to students registered in a Sociology program.

SOCIOL 3NN3.name: Popular Culture and Inequality
SOCIOL 3NN3.description: How the production, reception, and consumption of art and popular culture are shaped by and reinforce race, class, and gender inequalities. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3NN3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 3O03.name: Qualitative Research Methods
SOCIOL 3O03.description: This course will provide a detailed study of selected qualitative methods in Sociology. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
SOCIOL 3O03.prerequisites: SOCIOL 2Z03 and registration in Level III of any Honours Sociology program

SOCIOL 3P03.name: Advanced Analysis of Contemporary Sociological Theory
SOCIOL 3P03.description: An advanced examination of contemporary sociological theory, with a possible focus on schools of theoretical thought like critical theory, symbolic interactionalism, or feminist theory. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3P03.prerequisites: SOCIOL 2KK3 and 2LL3 and registration in Level III of any Honours Sociology program

SOCIOL 3QQ3.name: Sociology Students and the Work World
SOCIOL 3QQ3.description: This course draws on sociological analysis of work, occupations, and organizations to prepare students for seeking employment and developing careers. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
SOCIOL 3QQ3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level III or above of any Sociology program

SOCIOL 3RI3.name: Racism and Racial Inequality
SOCIOL 3RI3.description: This course introduces students to conceptual and empirical perspectives on racism and racial inequality and draws from Canadian and international experiences. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3RI3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 3RR3.name: Imprisonment
SOCIOL 3RR3.description: An exploration of the history, politics, and consequences of incarceration on individuals and society. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3RR3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level III or above of any Sociology or Honours Social Psychology program, or permission of the Department Cross-list(s): SOCPSY 3RR3

SOCIOL 3SS3.name: Sociology of Judgement
SOCIOL 3SS3.description: An exploration of sociological perspectives on judgement and connections to inequality, power, and authority. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3SS3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level III or above

SOCIOL 3U03.name: Sociology of Sexualities
SOCIOL 3U03.description: An exploration of the social aspects of sexuality and consideration of how sexual experiences are shaped by, and interpreted through, historically specific social contexts. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3U03.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 Priority will be given to students registered in a Sociology program.

SOCIOL 3UU3.name: Power, Conflict, and the Law
SOCIOL 3UU3.description: This course focuses on sociological analysis emphasizing how the legal system reflects the interests of powerful classes or groups and is the basis for social conflict. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3UU3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level II or above

SOCIOL 3VV3.name: The Indian Act: A Social Problem
SOCIOL 3VV3.description: An overview of Indigenous policy in Canada, with a focus on the Indian Act (the earliest race-based legislation in Canada) and its legal and sociopolitical ramifications. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3VV3.prerequisites: Three units of Level II Indigenous Studies; or one of SOCIOL 1C03 or SOCIOL 1Z03 and enrolment in Level III or above; or permission of the Department. Cross-list(s): INDIGST 3VV3 SOCIOL 2EE3 or 2UU3 and/or a background in Indigenous Studies is recommended. This course is administered by the Department of Indigenous Studies.

SOCIOL 3W03.name: Historical Methods in Sociology
SOCIOL 3W03.description: An examination of methods for incorporating historical data and archival sources into sociological argument. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.

SOCIOL 3YY3.name: Sociology of Globalization
SOCIOL 3YY3.description: An exploration of globalization using a sociological perspective focusing on issues such as the global economy, migration, transnational families, and global identity formations. Three hours (lectures and discussion); one term.
SOCIOL 3YY3.prerequisites: One of SOCIOL 1C03 or 1Z03 and enrollment in Level III or above of any Sociology program, or permission of the Department

SOCIOL 4A03.name: Ethnic/Racial Tensions
SOCIOL 4A03.description: The course will investigate the processes by which racial and/or ethnic tensions develop in various societies. Three hours (seminar); one term.
SOCIOL 4A03.prerequisites: SOCIOL 3FF3 and enrolment in Level IV of any Honours Sociology program; or enrolment in Level IV of the Honours Social Psychology program; or permission of the department

SOCIOL 4AA3.name: Selected Topics in the Sociology of the Family
SOCIOL 4AA3.description: An intensive examination of selected problems in the sociology of the family. Lectures and discussion (three hours); one term.
